DOC.HEAD: Bush Says US Sending Forces Adequate for Gulf Offensive
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS grafs 21-23: ``The additional,'' report of Marine comments on logistics; breaks into two takes
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Thursday ordered massive land and sea additions to the U.S. military force in the Persian Gulf to give ``an adequate offensive option'' if needed to drive Iraq from Kuwait. Bush's order will add more than 150,000 military personnel to the 230,000 U.S. troops already in the area. He ordered troops and tanks transferred from Europe, sent in new warships and called up combat-ready National Guard units. Bush, asked directly whether he was going to war against Saddam Hussein, said: ``I would like to see a peaceful solution to this question.'' ``If this movement of force is what convinces him, so much the better,'' Bush said. ``Let's hope he comes to his senses,'' he added. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, giving details of the new buildup, said it would include two armored divisions and smaller armored units from Germany and a division from the United States, the famous ``Big Red One'' First Infantry Division (Mechanized) based at Fort Riley, Kans. Neither he nor Bush would say just how many troops would be joining the 230,000 U.S. forces already in the gulf area. However, full deployment of the units listed by Cheney would add more than 150,000 troops to the U.S. forces there, Pentagon officials said in private conversations. Even without sending all of their support units, the additional combat and essential support forces total about 100,000. Iraq has more than 400,000 troops in the region. Cheney said the Navy would send three additional aircraft carrier battle groups and their escorts, the battleship USS Missouri and a second Marine amphibious group of 5,000 men. And, the defense secretary said, combat-ready National Guard brigades - the 48th in Georgia, the 155th in Mississippi and the 256th in Louisiana - would be called up for the first time, for possible reassignment to the Middle East. They total about 10,000 people. Also, Cheney said, the Air Force ``probably'' would also send reinforcements. Hundreds of additional tanks will be deployed, the secretary said. ``Whether it will be adequate in the event of going to war with Saddam Hussein's army, I'm not going to speculate,'' said Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. Bush's escalation of the U.S. gulf presence was greeted with skepticism from congressional Democrats. ``I am concerned that the administration is moving to establish an offensive capacity in advance of a U.N. resolution authorizing offensive action,'' said Senate Foreign Relations Committee Chairman Claiborne Pell, D-R.I. Pell said the international trade embargo against Iraq has not yet had ``a decent chance to produce results.'' A House Armed Services Committee member, Rep. Ike Skelton, D-Mo., said Bush's use of the word ``offensive'' was ominous. ``The whole attitude seems to be changing from defense to offense,'' he said. ``This is a new chapter.'' Rep. Lee Hamilton, D-Ind., chairman of the Middle East subcommittee of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, said he believed ``the president has been concerned that the focus has been drifting away from the military option'' with European political figures visiting Iraq to negotiate for the release of their citizens held hostage. The president, said Hamilton, ``wants to ... let the Iraqis know that we're deadly serious about this.'' The additional troops were ordered as two Marine Corps generals warned in interviews with The Washington Post that war stockpiles in Saudi Arabia need strengthening. Logistics is ``a concern of all of us because we are ... stretched farther than we've ever been in our nation's history in terms of trying to sustain a large force'' in the field, Lt. Gen. Ernest T. Cook Jr., head of the Combat Development Command, was quoted in Friday editions as saying. A deputy to Cook, Maj. Gen. Matthew P. Caulfield, had similar comments, and the commandant of the Marine Corps., Gen. Alfred M. Gray, spoke in the same vein in a speech at Peeksill, N.Y. last week, the newspaper said. Bush spoke as Secretary of State James A. Baker III was in Moscow consulting senior Soviet officials over Persian Gulf strategy. Soviet officials said they could not rule out the use of force. Bush called this statement ``very helpful,'' and said, ``We're on the same wavelength'' with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on goals in the Middle East.

DOC.HEAD: Police: Relatives Say Kahane Suspect May Have Been Depressed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS two grafs after 3rd graf, `Chief of ...' to UPDATE with newspaper report on Prozac. Pick up 4th graf, `Nosair was ...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Kahane's Legacy, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The man accused of assassinating Rabbi Meir Kahane may have been taking prescription drugs for depression, police said Thursday. El Sayyid Nosair, 34, entered no plea Wednesday night at his arraignment in Bellevue Hospital's intensive care unit. He was shot in the throat by a U.S. Postal police officer after Kahane,an anti-Arab extremist, was shot Monday night at a Manhattan hotel. Chief of Detectives Joseph Borrelli said Thursday that relatives told police they thought Nosair had been under a doctor's care. Nosair was taking Prozac, a drug facing lawsuits that contend it induces violent and persistent homicidal and suicidal behavior, The New York Times said in Friday's editions, quoting a law enforcement official it did not identify. The drug's manufacturer, Eli Lilly & Co. Inc., denies any association between the drug and violence in patients. The Food and Drug Administration has also found no such association. Nosair was on documented sick leave from his job with the city's Department of General Services five days last week, said department spokesman John Beckman. The diagnosis was confidential, Beckman said. Investigators have not linked Nosair to any terrorist groups. Borrelli speculated that Nosair, a native Egyptian who has an engineering degree, may have felt frustrated because he couldn't fulfill his potential in this country. Nosair began working for the city in April 1988 on a crew that tends to heating, air conditioning and ventilation at courthouses. In addition, Nosair injured his hand or arm in an accident at work in which he was nearly electrocuted, Borrelli said. The combined stress ``was acting on him; he wasn't getting ahead,'' Borrelli theorized. One source told New York Newsday that Nosair threw a tantrum in a locker room Monday because he was being transferred to Brooklyn. But Beckman and Borrelli said they had no indication that was true. Beckman confirmed that Nosair was to be transferred, effective Thursday, from Manhattan to Brooklyn. ``It wasn't punitive,'' said Beckman. ``He was a satisfactory worker.'' Beckman said the department has 108 other workers who do the same job as Nosair. ``These guys take these jobs with the understanding they will be transferred. Of the 109, last year there were 61 transfers,'' he said. On Wednesday, the Department of General Services suspended him without pay until further notice, based on his alleged criminal activity and because he allegedly used a false Brooklyn address. Nosair's job has a New York City residency requirement, Nosair lives in Cliffside Park, N.J., Beckman said. Borrelli said police had raised the filed-off serial numbers on the murder weapon, a .357-caliber revolver. The federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms is helping to trace it.

DOC.HEAD: Swedish Police Bring Teddy Bears on Patrol
DOC.TEXT: Police are taking teddy bears along with them on patrol in a western Swedish town, but not for their own comfort. The bears recently began riding in the trunk of patrol cars in the coastal town of Uddevalla, ready to comfort children involved in accidents, Sweden's national news agency said Thursday. ``We have for a long time been missing something to give children who have been hurt in one way or another,'' police assistant Mats Glansberg told a local paper.

DOC.HEAD: EPA Sees No Conflict In Advisors With Tobacco Ties
DOC.TEXT: Six scientists on an Environmental Protection Agency panel on smoking, including its chairman, have ties to a tobacco industry research group, but the EPA says that's no problem. ``We went to our lawyers and said, `Does this constitute a conflict of interest?' and they said no,'' said Donald Barnes, staff director of the EPA's scientific advisory board. ``We were concerned about the appearance of conflict of interest,'' Barnes said. But he said the link between the panel members and the tobacco organization ``does not cause any question to be raised about their technical capabilities.'' The 16-member panel's task is to assure the accuracy and objectivity of two forthcoming EPA studies on the health effects of second-hand cigarette smoke. In addition to the six members with ties to the tobacco research organization, a seventh member of the panel was appointed at the urging of the Philip Morris tobacco company, EPA officials said. ``They've stacked the deck with people who have close ties to the tobacco industry,'' said Dr. Alan Blum, a founder of the anti-smoking group Doctors Ought to Care. ``It's pathetic.'' The panel members are linked to the Center for Indoor Air Research of Linthicum, Md. The center is financed by Philip Morris, R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Co. and Lorillard Corp., three of the nation's largest tobacco companies. Its board of directors is made up of employees of those companies, said Pamela Phillips, an administrator at the center. The chairman of the EPA panel, Morton Lippmann of New York University, is on the science advisory board of the tobacco industry center. Lippmann and another member of the EPA panel, Dr. Jonathan Samet of the University of New Mexico, helped devise the center's research agenda. Samet and three other members of the panel are listed as ``peer reviewers'' for the center. They help determine which research projects the center supports. Yet another panel member, Delbert Eatough of Brigham Young University, receives research funds from the center. A seventh member, Geoffrey Kabat of the American Health Foundation, had been recommended by Philip Morris, EPA officials said. Kabat said, ``I have no direct contact with the tobacco industry at all, and I certainly don't see myself as being an agent of theirs in any respect.'' The makeup of the EPA panel aroused controversy when it was reported last month that the agency had dismissed Dr. David Burns from the panel after the tobacco industry lobbied to get rid of him. Burns, of the University of California, San Diego, was the author of the U.S. Surgeon General's report on passive smoking and is regarded by his colleagues as a leading authority on the issue. He was reinstated to the panel after his dismissal was disclosed. Lippmann said he didn't see any problem working with the EPA and with the tobacco research center. ``It can always raise questions,'' he said. ``I don't view it as any conflict.'' Samet's office said he was on vacation and couldn't be reached. Eatough, who has received research funds from R.J. Reynolds as well as the Center for Indoor Air Research, said the money does not compromise his objectivity. ``I'm sure that it does raise questions in many people's minds,'' he said. But he said he is not constrained by the tobacco research funds. ``What we do is what we do, and we're free to go down what seem the reasonable roads to go.'' The scientists serving as peer reviewers for the Center for Indoor Air Research are Michael Lebowitz of the University of Arizona, Jan A.J. Stolwijk of Yale University and James E. Woods of Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University. Woods didn't return a call to his office. Lebowitz's office said he was out of the office until Nov. 16. Stolwijk said, ``I review grant applications they send me. I don't have anything else to do with them.''

DOC.HEAD: GOP Loses Ground In Traditionally Democratic Sunbelt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Democrats recouped some of their Sunbelt losses from the Reagan era and took firm control of redistricting as Southern voters showed they had no love for taxes and no affection for big spenders. Democrats regained the governorships in Florida, Texas and Oklahoma and won a majority in the Virginia congressional delegation for the first time in 24 years. North Carolina Sen. Jesse Helms and Alabama Gov. Guy Hunt, however, bucked the trend and provided re-election victories for Republicans in key races. Hunt, the first Republican governor in Alabama since 1874, won despite a virtual sweep of top state offices by Democrats. On congressional reapportionment, which will draw the lines of political power for the next decade, Republicans will share control only in Alabama and South Carolina. Democrats will be in command in the rest of the region, including Florida, which will gain four seats in the House of Representatives, and Texas, which will pick up three. ``You have to be careful when you say one party has taken the torch from the other, but the momentum in the South is clearly with the Democrats,'' said Del Ali, an analyst with Mason-Dixon Opinion Research. ``The Democrats have done something they've been unable to do in 12 years and that is steal an issue from under the Republicans.'' Taxes were an issue Republicans had made inroads with in the South over the past decade, but some Democrat candidates turned the tables Tuesday. Tax increases signed by Republican Florida Gov. Bob Martinez were blamed for his defeat by former Sen. Lawton Chiles, who grabbed 56 percent of the vote. Big-spending was another issue: Chiles imposed a $100 limit on contributions to his campaign and raised $5.2 million to oust Martinez. Martinez, only the second Republican governor Florida has had since Reconstruction, raised $10.6 million. Taxes and big spending proved to be key issues in the Texas race, too. Democrat Ann Richards, the state treasurer best known for her biting keynote speech at the 1988 Democratic National Convention, came from behind to defeat millionaire rancher and oilman Clayton Williams. Williams, who spent $8 million of his own money on a $20 million campaign to keep the governor's office in GOP hands, disclosed in the final week of the campaign that his tax bill in 1986 was $0. It was just one of a string of setbacks for the loose-talking Republican. A CBS-TV exit poll said 25 percent of Tuesday's Texas voters made their choice in those last seven days. ``I just would shoot myself in the foot and then I'd load up and try it again,'' Williams said after his defeat. In Oklahoma, David Walters recaptured the governor's office for the Democrats by easily defeating Republican Bill Price. Walters has accused Price of oil-price gouging. Price denied that allegation and filed a libel suit against Walters. Georgia Democrat Zell Miller defeated Republican Johnny Isakson in the governor's race, retaining the office for the Democrats. Georgia Democrats also threw a scare into Rep. Newt Gingrich, the fiery second-in-command House GOP leader. Gingrich hung on to defeat Democrat David Worley in a suburban Atlanta district. Arkansas Gov. Bill Clinton and Tennessee Gov. Ned McWherter, both Democrats, and South Carolina Republican Gov. Carroll Campbell all were re-elected. In Senate races, Democratic incumbents Howell Heflin of Alabama, David Boren of Oklahoma, Al Gore of Tennessee and Jay Rockefeller of West Virginia won re-election handily, as did Republicans Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, Strom Thurmond of South Carolina and Phil Gramm of Texas. Senators David Pryor, D-Ark., Sam Nunn, D-Ga., J. Bennett Johnston, D-La., Thad Cochran, R-Miss., and John Warner, R-Va., were re-elected either in uncontested races or with only third-party or write-in opposition. Helms, the torchbearer of the right wing who had been trailing in some polls shortly before the election, launched a last-minute blitz of attack ads against civil rights legislation. His opponent, former Charlotte Mayor Harvey Gantt, is black. Gantt, according to Thad Beyle, a University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill political scientist, ``ran right into the jaws of a racial campaign.'' Helms won 54 percent of the vote. Democratic state Sen. William Jefferson, a Harvard-educated lawyer, was elected Louisiana's first black congressman since Reconstruction. Jefferson succeeds retiring U.S. Rep. Lindy Boggs. Voters in the nation's capital sent Mayor Marion Barry back to private life by decisively rejecting his bid for a city council seat and electing newcomer Sharon Pratt Dixon to succeed him as mayor. Jackson also won his first elected office Tuesday, a nonvoting, unpaid ``shadow'' Senate seat from which he will attempt to persuade Congress to make the District of Columbia a state. --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Scott McCartney is the AP's Southwest Regional Reporter, based in Dallas.

DOC.HEAD: Slumping Economy Knocks Out Some Candidates in Recession-Struck Northeast
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The money problems of the recession-struck Northeast inflicted casualties on both Democrats and Republicans - not only in Tuesday's elections, but throughout the long political season. Some candidates were knocked out; others were bloodied, even if they did win. Four incumbent governors lost their seats and five others were re-elected. ``We had a lot of restlessness in the Northeast,'' said Lee Miringoff, director of the Marist College Institute for Public Opinion in Poughkeepsie, N.Y. ``We've had a lot of moving vans come up and change the occupants of the statehouses. There was major concern about the economy and state budgets directed at the occupants.'' Just the same, voters stopped short of carrying out tax revolts in Massachusetts and Maryland that would have resulted in the biggest state rollbacks in history. Analysts said they apparently were swayed by slick, million-dollar campaigns that warned of desperate consequences if the referendums passed - jobs lost and cuts in education, police protection and services to the elderly. Instead, voters opted for political newcomers to carry out a less drastic mandate to hold the line on spending and taxes. Democratic Gov. Mario Cuomo of New York was among Tuesday's survivors. He won a third term, and remains a 1992 presidential prospect. But Cuomo captured 53 percent of the vote against three weak opponents, well short of the record-setting 65 percent he received four years ago. He won despite a record $1.8 billion tax increase and a state credit rating that is the third worst in the nation. ``He had a solid victory,'' said Miringoff. ``But to some degree the same kinds of trends were affecting New York, concern over the economy and state budgets and a general sense on the part of the voters that things were going in the wrong direction.'' Voters in New Jersey, angry over Democratic Gov. Jim Florio's $2.8 billion tax package, took out their wrath on Sen. Bill Bradley. Florio was not up for re-election, and at 6-foot-5, the former New York Knick presented a big target. Bradley received 50 percent of the vote compared to 48 percent for Christine Todd Whitman, a little-known Republican. He reportedly spent $10.5 million on his campaign, nearly 20 times what Mrs. Whitman spent. ``I think Bradley was caught in the restlessness and the frustration that existed in New Jersey,'' said Miringoff. ``He was the visible target, sort of the surrogate governor.'' New governors were elected in Massachusetts, Connecticut, Vermont and Rhode Island, where budgets and taxes rose by the billions and workers lost their jobs by the thousands. Correctly gauging the mood of the voters, three Democratic governors - Michael Dukakis of Massachusetts, William A. O'Neill of Connecticut and Madeleine Kunin of Vermont - bowed out of the primaries. In Massachusetts, William Weld, a former assistant U.S. attorney general, became the first Republican elected to the governorship in 20 years. He narrowly defeated tart-tongued Democrat John Silber, on leave as president of Boston University. Both campaigned as outsiders who would return the state's economy to good health. Each defeated his party's endorsed candidate in the primary. Weld supported Question 3, a referendum that would have rolled back taxes and some fees to their 1988 levels, cutting $3.9 billion from state revenue over the next 18 months. Silber opposed the measure; the voters backed Weld, but rejected Question 3. Paul Watanabe, a political analyst at the University of Massachusetts at Boston, said the tax-busting referendum was too drastic. It was defeated because voters guaranteed there would be substantial change by electing political newcomers in the September primary, he said. Voters rejected caps on property taxes in Anne Arundel and Baltimore counties in Maryland. Lowell P. Weicker Jr., former three-term Republican U.S. senator, won the Connecticut governorship as an independent. He will be the state's first third-party governor since the Civil War and its first non-Democratic governor in two decades. In Vermont, Republican Richard Snelling, Gov. Kunin's predecessor, was returned to the office he held 14 years ago, defeating Democrat Peter Welch, a former state senator. Bruce G. Sundlun, a millionaire Democratic businessman, soundly defeated the incumbent Republican governor in Rhode Island, Edward D. DiPrete, 74 percent to 26 percent. Sundlun had lost twice before to DiPrete, who had reversed himself on a pledge of no new taxes. ``I think the voters were focusing on the economy in the Northeast,'' DiPrete said. ``I think they had made up their minds and that was it.'' In Maine, the incumbent Republican governor, John R. McKernan, narrowly won over his predecessor, U.S. Rep. Joseph E. Brennan, a Democrat. Brennan had campaigned on charges that McKernan failed to move quickly enough to counter the faltering economy. Brennan served two four-year terms as governor before changing offices with McKernan in 1987. Govs. Robert Casey of Pennsylvania and William D. Schaefer of Maryland, both Democrats, won re-election easily. Both held the line on taxes and both states declared budgt surpluses for the fiscal year ended June 30. Another incumbent winner was Republican Gov. Judd Gregg of New Hampshire, who pledged to keep the state free of income and general sales taxes. --- EDITOR'S NOTE - George Esper is the AP's Northeast Regional Reporter, based in Boston.

DOC.HEAD: Incumbents Big Losers in Midwest: Four Governors, One Senator Out
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Voters delivered a knockout punch to incumbents in the nation's midsection, ousting four governors and one U.S. senator - the only senator in the nation to lose a re-election bid. Two veteran Democrats and two freshman Republicans were defeated Tuesday in heated gubernatorial contests. And in a stunning upset in the Senate, Minnesota GOP incumbent Rudy Boschwitz lost his bid for a third term. In the most tumultuous race, Minnesota Gov. Rudy Perpich was narrowly defeated by Republican Arne Carlson, who was a 11th-hour replacement after the GOP candidate withdrew amid charges of sexual improprieties. In Michigan, two-term Gov. James Blanchard lost by a razor-thin margin to Republican state Senate Majority Leader John Engler. The governor is the first Michigan chief executive to be booted from office in nearly 30 years. In two other contests, Republicans blamed for higher taxes lost bids for second terms. In Kansas, State Treasurer Joan Finney defeated Gov. Mike Hayden. And in Nebraska, businessman Ben Nelson eked out a win over Kay Orr, the state's first woman governor. Some poliical analysts speculate the gubernatorial losses are tied to the office itself. ``The governors were a lot more vulnerable than legislators,'' said Burdett Loomis, a University of Kansas political science professor. ``Governors have to deal with the fiscal problems on the ground. That certainly may mean raising taxes, cutting budgets, things likely to be unpopular. ``Someone like Blanchard over eight years has done a lot of unpopular things,'' he said. ``Hayden created a number of enemies. Perpich was seen as flaky and ticked off a variety of people. The potential to lose is much greater with the governors. You're much more accountable for your actions.'' In two of three gubernatorial races in which taxes dominated, GOP incumbents lost. In Kansas, Mrs. Finney, who will became the state's first female governor, blamed Hayden for high property taxes resulting from statewide reappraisal and implementation of a classification system completed in 1989. ``It was pretty clearly a vote on Hayden, mostly on the property tax issue,'' Loomis said. ``One thing Finney did really hit on was this kind of prairie populism that's always here in the Plain states. Rural Kansans, rural Nebraskans, are normally Republican. They're not that far from the edge of the economy. When they have economic fears, the tendency is to move toward populist (ideas).'' In Nebraska, Mrs. Orr was on the defensive for endorsing a 1987 income tax increase that hit many lower- and middle-income residents. But in Illinois, GOP Secretary of State Jim Edgar won a close race over Democrat Neil Hartigan even though the Republican supported an extension of a temporary income tax increase. ``I think people like to have a public official who will level with them before the election and not surprise them after the election,'' said Edgar, longtime heir-apparent to Gov. James Thompson, who retired after 14 years. Hartigan also was hurt by a low turnout in Chicago, disaffection among blacks with the Democrats and doubts about his campaign pledges. ``I think Hartigan scored some points on the tax issue ... but he lost points in other settings among people who simply found his message lacking in credibility,'' said Jim Nowlan, professor of public policy at Knox College in Galesburg, Ill. ``They just couldn't believe Hartigan was going to cut taxes and do all he said he was going to do.'' In Ohio, the GOP captured one of its biggest prizes as former Cleveland Mayor George Voinovich won the gubernatorial race over state Attorney General Anthony Celebrezze Jr. Democratic Gov. Richard Celeste was barred by law from seeking a third consecutive term. And in Minnesota, the Republicans added another gubernatorial seat to their column with Carleson's victory over Perpich, who sought a fourth term. The GOP state auditor became the Republican candidate only last week after Jon Grunseth withdrew from the race amid sexual misconduct charges. The Republican turmoil spilled over into the Minnesota Senate race, in which Boschwitz lost to college professor Paul Wellstone, a liberal activist who was outspent by a 7-1 margin but captured voters' attention with clever campaign commercials. In two other Senate races, Capitol Hill veterans originally among the GOP's brightest prospects failed to unseat liberal Democrats. In Illinois, Paul Simon trounced U.S. Rep. Lynn Martin, who never gained momentum in her campaign. And in Iowa, Tom Harkin scored a solid win over U.S. Rep Tom Tauke, becoming the first Democratic senator in the state to win re-election. In other contests: -Iowa Gov. Terry Branstad swept to a third term over Democrat Don Avenson, state House speaker. -Wisconsin Republican Gov. Tommy Thompson scored a double-digit win over Assembly Speaker Tom Loftus. -South Dakota GOP Gov. Republican George Mickelson handily won re-election over former state Sen. Bob Samuelson. And in the Senate: -South Dakota Republican Sen. Larry Pressler won a third term over businessman Ted Muenster. -Indiana's Dan Coats, who inherited Vice President Dan Quayle's seat, defeated Democratic state Rep. Baron Hill. -Michigan Democrat Carl Levin won in a landslide over U.S. Rep. Bill Schuette. -Nebraska Democrat James Exon scored an easy win over former U.S. Rep. Hal Daub. -Kansas Republican Nancy Kassebaum crushed Democratic challenger Dick Williams. --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Sharon Cohen is the AP's Midwest Regional Reporter, based in Chicago.

DOC.HEAD: Incumbents Survive Anti-Government Sentiment; Environment Measures Defeated
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Western voters voiced anti-government sentiments without kicking out those in government, approving limits on politicians' terms but removing few incumbents from office. Economic worries, meanwhile, appeared to dull enthusiasm for sweeping environmental reforms proposed in several states. Voters rejected most of the measures, including California's closely watched ``Big Green'' initiative. And Republican Pete Wilson's victory over Democrat Dianne Feinstein in the California governor's race was a bright spot for the GOP. It will give the party leverage when it comes time to reapportion the nation's largest congressional delegation. Tuesday's election provided plenty of evidence of Western voters' disillusionment with government. Voters in Colorado and California approved limits on how long politicians can hold office. Arizona voters defeated a proposed pay raise for legislators by a margin of 2 to 1. And in Alaska, Walter Hickel capitalized on an anti-government mood, winning the governor's race as an independent. The long-time Republican, elected as Alaska's second governor in 1966, said his campaign appealed to those fed up with traditional Democrat-Republican politics. ``I think Alaskans just want a change - they want to have more of a say in government,'' Hickel said. ``It's sort of an anti-government feeling out there.'' But when it came time to judge incumbents holding office, Western voters were kinder, in keeping with a nationwide trend that returned more than 95 percent of incumbents to Congress. Voters supported the five Western governors seeking re-election, all Democrats. They were Govs. Roy Romer of Colorado, John Waihee of Hawaii, Cecil Andrus of Idaho, Mike Sullivan of Wyoming, and acting Nevada Gov. Bob Miller. Four U.S. senators seeking re-election coasted to victory: Ted Stevens, R-Alaska; Pete Domenici, R-N.M.; Alan Simpson, R-Wyoming; and Sen. Max Baucus, D-Mont. Even two incumbent senators that appeared vulnerable managed victories. Sen. Daniel Akaka, D-Hawaii, defeated GOP challenger Rep. Pat Saiki. And in Oregon, Republican Sen. Mark Hatfield survived the biggest scare of his Senate career, winning a fifth term over Democrat Harry Lonsdale. In Washington, first-term Rep. Jolene Unsoeld, a Democrat, was targeted for defeat by the GOP, but weathered a strong challenge by Republican Bob Williams. Why the loyalty to incumbents in a year when people are supposedly disgusted with Congress? ``You can't beat somebody with nothing,'' said Kent Briggs of the Center for the New West, a Denver-based research group. ``It may have been in a lot of these races there wasn't a credible alternative. The anti-incumbency sentiment didn't really get going until the end of this year, and by that time everyone had filed.'' Exceptions to the staying power of incumbents were five-term Rep. Denny Smith, R-Ore., who lost to Democrat Mike Kopetski, and Rep. Charles Pashayan Jr., R-Calif., defeated by Democrat Calvin Dooley. Observers say links to the savings-and-loan scandals contributed to both losses. Wilson's win in California was not the only GOP success. The party retained two Western seats where its senators were retiring: Rep. Hank Brown beat Democrat Josie Heath in Colorado, and Rep. Larry Craig of Idaho won over Democrat Ron Twilegar. But Democrats made inroads, too. In Idaho, Democrat Larry Larocco filled the seat vacated by Craig. And in Utah, the House seat held by retiring GOP Rep. Howard Nielson went to Democrat Bill Orton, making it the first time since 1974 that Utah has had more than one Democrat among its three congressmen. Some blamed Republican slides on anti-tax sentiment. But few voters opted to cut taxes themselves. Oregon voters were the exception, passing a measure to phase in a 1.5 percent property tax ceiling over five years. But Montanans refused to scrap their state income, property and sales taxes in favor of a ``transaction charge'' of 1 percent on all financial dealings. Colorado voters rejected a measure requiring voter approval for any state or local tax increase. And Utah voters refused to abolish a state sales tax on food. The strongest message among ballot propositions was the defeat of sweeping environmental reforms. California voters rejected, 2 to 1, the closely watched ``Big Green'' initiative that would have stiffened regulation of air pollution, pesticides, offshore oil-drilling and logging. They also rejected ``Forests Forever,'' a proposed limit on clear-cutting of forests. Washington voters defeated a strong growth-control measure, and Oregon voters rejected strict recycling rules and a proposal to close the state's only nuclear power plant. ``I think concerns on the economy were a factor,'' Briggs said. ``There's a perception out there that the economy is sliding into a recession. When people are confronted with charges that if we do something it will cause `X' loss of jobs, it gives them pause.'' Other highlights in Western races: -In Arizona, Republican Fife Symington held a small lead over Democrat Terry Goddard in a gubernatorial race headed for a runoff. Symington led Goddard by about 3,600 votes with 99 percent of 1.04 million votes counted, and about 7,000 votes went to write-in candidates. A state constitutional amendment requires runoffs in races in which no candidate receives a majority of the votes, but no laws are in place to implement a runoff. It could be next spring before a runoff is completed. -Alaskans voted to change the nation's most liberal marijuana law, making private use of pot a crime again. -Oregonians defeated a measure to give tax breaks to parents who send their children to private schools or teach them at home. They also rejected, 2 to 1, a restrictive anti-abortion law. -Nevada voters approved a measure to protect abortion rights. It prohibits any change in the state's abortion law except by vote of the people. --- EDITOR'S NOTE - David Foster is the AP's Northwest regional reporter, based in Seattle.

DOC.HEAD: Shocked Gingrich Pledges to Renew Ties With District
With PM-Congress Rdp
DOC.TEXT: Rep. Newt Gingrich says he's gotten the message from Georgia's 6th District voters, who came within a hair of retiring him from elected office. ``It's to pay more attention, to listen more, to reach out to people more to make sure you're their incumbent,'' the Jonesboro Republican said Wednesday after complete but unofficial returns showed him defeating Democrat David Worley by less than 1,000 votes. Worley, who won only 41 percent of the vote against Gingrich two years ago, clearly shocked the House GOP whip, who was so confident of victory he didn't bother to come home and campaign during the entire month of October. ``There's no question that if I had to do it over again, I would have flown home more often,'' Gingrich said. ``...But we thought we were in pretty good shape.'' Worley didn't even have the formal support of House Democratic leaders who backed him in 1988, but decided not to this year after Worley made an issue of Gingrich's support for a $35,000 congressional pay raise. ``That was clearly a very negative factor,'' Gingrich said of the pay raise issue. ``There is no question in my mind that without that, the race would have been dramatically easier.'' Gingrich cited three other contributing factors for his close shave: an anti-incumbency mood among voters, a Democratic tide that overwhelmed most Republicans in Georgia on Tuesday, and the long, bitter strike against Eastern Air Lines, the largest employer in his district. Worley, 31, a Jonesboro lawyer, said he intends to demand the recount that in Georgia is automatic when the difference between candidates is less than 1 percent. ``We had hundreds of grassroots supporters,'' Worley said. ``We got the right message to the voters that it's time for a change.'' Roger Ailes, the Republican consultant who managed President Bush's media campaign in 1988, said voters were angry at Gingrich for leading the House GOP revolt against President Bush and the president's deficit reduction agreement. But Gingrich said his opposition to the budget agreement and its tax increases probably saved him from defeat. Other GOP political experts agreed. ``I don't think Republicans abandoned Newt Gingrich because of what he did on the budget,'' said Ed Rollins, co-chairman of the National Republican Congressional Committee. Rollins said Gingrich ran into trouble because voters who always had viewed him as a outsider challenging Georgia's Democratic establishment began to see him as a congressional insider once he won election as GOP whip. Worley's surprising showing did seem to rejuvenate House Democrats. ``Newt Gingrich now becomes target No. 1 for 1992 if he wins the recount,'' said Rep. Beryl Anthony, D-Ark., chairman of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee.

DOC.HEAD: Conservatives Seek to Boost Support for Bush's Gulf Policy
DOC.TEXT: A group of well-known conservatives is taking out advertisements in major newspapers and on television to drum up support for President Bush's Persian Gulf policy. Sam Zakhem, a former U.S. ambassador to Bahrain, said Tuesday that he and others formed the Coalition for America at Risk to back Bush's policies. The idea for the coalition came two months ago when some conservatives seemed to waver in their support of Bush's decision to send 225,000 troops to defend Saudi Arabia from Iraq, Zakhem said in a telephone interview from his Denver home. ``Many people run out of patience and this is a very important thing for the national interest of the United States,'' he said. ``Support President Bush and the brave men and women of Operation Desert Shield working to free Kuwait,'' reads part of a full-page ad. It has appeared in The New York Times, The Wall Street Journal, the Los Angeles Times, The Washington Times, The Washington Post and USA Today. A full-page ad in The Washington Post's front section costs $19,000. Zakhem said he informed Bush of the coalition's plan in early September. White House spokesmen did not immediately return a telephone call seeking reaction. A recent public opinion poll by ABC News found about 65 percent of Americans approve of Bush's handling of the gulf crisis. Zakhem said the ads are being paid for by the coalition's well-heeled backers. But Otalie English, a spokeswoman for Keene Shirley & Associates, the public relations firm representing the coalition, said the campaign is supposed to be self-supporting once it gets off the ground. The newspaper ad invites readers to call a toll-free telephone number for a ``free emergency action kit.'' English said the kit includes a bumper sticker and several 900 telephone numbers. Callers can - for a fee - receive updates on the situation in Kuwait and learn to set up a grassroots organizing campaign, she said. The toll-free number has been flooded with requests, Zakhem said. Zakhem said the coalition hopes for a peaceful solution to the gulf crisis, but he added that question is up to Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. The group includes retired Maj. Gen. John K. Singlaub, who was involved in sending weapons to the Nicaraguan Contra rebels in the Reagan administration; David Keene of the American Conservative Union; Grover Norquist of Americans for Tax Reform; Lewis Tambs, a former ambassador to Costa Rica; and Doug Wead, who resigned earlier this year as Bush's liaison to conservative and religious groups.

DOC.HEAD: GOP Redistricting Survivors: `They'd Have Killed Us'
DOC.TEXT: Republicans may not have won many redistricting skirmishes, but they feel lucky to merely have survived Democratic efforts to shut them out of the process in several key states. ``They'd have killed us into the end of the next century,'' said Bill Stevens, a spokesman for the New York state Senate Republicans. The GOP repelled Democrats' attempts to take the chamber in Tuesday's elections. ``It's not a game in which gentlemen draw district lines ... There's no Marquess of Queensberry rules,'' Stevens said. ``That's not the way it's done.'' The game was to gain control of the state governments that will reassign U.S. House seats based on population shifts - a process that can reshape congressional delegations and legislatures for the coming decade. Democrats racked up big redistricting victories, taking the governorships in Florida and Texas, which together will gain seven U.S. House seats, and adding Rhode Island, New Mexico and Oklahoma to the list of states where they hold a lock on recharting political lines. The GOP won a round by taking the California governor's race, but that only ensures Republicans negotiating power there because the state's Legislature is controlled by Democrats. Because New York has a Democratic governor and Democratic state Assembly, the GOP had to have the state Senate to maintain any bargaining power. Population shifts will cost the state three U.S. House seats. A similar breakdown was at stake in Pennsylvania, which will lose two House seats, and where the GOP hung onto control of the state Senate. ``If we hadn't held on ... we would have been subject to a reapportionment steamroller pencil that would have drawn the lines in a highly partisan manner,'' said Senate President Robert Jubelirer, who led the Republicans' successful defensive. ``At least now we are a player at the table.'' In Florida, Democrats hold all the power because they retrained slim majorities in the state Senate and House and snatched the governor's seat as well. Florida will gain four U.S. House seats. Allen Stonecipher, executive director of the Florida Democratic Party, said the party's monopoly will help Democrats regain the ground they lost in the 1980s. ``After a decade of unadorned Republican economics ... it's important that Democrats have an opportunity to advance a different approach to economic and domestic problems,'' he said. The states that will gain or lose House seats are most often thought of as key redistricting states. But all political lines, such as state legislative district lines, are remapped. State control can be equally important. Creative juggling of district lines - stacking a district with precincts that generally vote either Republican or Democratic - can oftentimes guarantee whether a Republican or Democrat will win in that district. The process can come in handy when party leaders are looking to help out a budding young political star. They can redraw a district that will better position a politician for a run for higher office down the road. The same is true if the party that controls the redistricting process sees a future threat from a young politician on the other side. ``You can either blunt the other person's talent pool or you can use redistricting to enhance your own talent pool,'' Stevens said.

DOC.HEAD: NASA to Cut Costs of Space Station Program
DOC.TEXT: NASA is literally going back to the drawing board to live within its budget and still find a way to build a space station to put Americans into space permanently. ``We have $6 billion more program planned than we have money for,'' William B. Lenoir, the head of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's space flight program, said Wednesday. Congress gave the agency three months to revamp a space station design that was six years in the making. ``It is our intention to come back in 90 days with the answers to what can we do, what makes sense ... and still have a useful, affordable program,'' Lenoir told reporters. ``If we cannot come up with what we consider a reasonable program then we would have to readdress whether we should even go forward with the space station.'' The Bush administration had asked Congress to spend $2.51 billion in 1991 to propel the $37 billion space station into the hardware-building stage. The lawmakers allotted $1.9 billion instead and told NASA to build the station in smaller steps, each independent of the other. They also squashed NASA plans to increase yearly spending for the station to $4 billion in 1996, telling the agency it could count on no more than $2.5 billion to $2.6 billion in any one year. NASA had long planned to hold a comprehensive design review during the last two months of this year, and Lenoir said that process will go forward, even though the final design will have to be reduced in scope. ``We are not going to start over,'' he said. ``We are going to use as much of the existing system as possible.'' Some of the modules may be built half-size to save money, but the whole station will be designed to accommodate additions later. Congress told NASA it should be able to build a ``man-tended'' station with three or four shuttle flights, instead of six. Man-tended is the term used for periodic visits to the station by astronauts who fly there on the space shuttle for stays of 16 days. Lenoir said plans remain to start construction in the spring of 1995, meaning the station would be ready for work early in 1996. The revised plan, however, won't permit NASA to have crews aboard permanently by the end of the decade as had been envisioned. A frequent criticism of NASA is that it is building a Cadillac of a space station with all possible options, when it should be building a Chevrolet instead. Asked about this, Lenoir recalled that Johnny Cash once had a song called ``One Piece at a Time,'' and said, ``Maybe we are going to build a Cadillac one piece at a time.'' Meanwhile Wednesday, NASA announced that it will launch the shuttle Atlantis on Nov. 15 on a military mission, reportedly carrying a spy satellite that will gather intelligence information on the Persian Gulf. The mission had been delayed by hydrogen leaks on the shuttle. The agency also reported that a special investigative team found no pattern in a series of accidents on the ground involving shuttle equipment.

DOC.HEAD: And Now a Word from the 110 Million Non-Voters
DOC.TEXT: Enough on the election. Now for a word or two from the silent majority - the 110 million Americans who didn't vote. ``I never took the time,'' said Melissa Withers, 20, of Mabelville, Ark., on her way to a babysitting job. ``I'm always, well, usually, mad when it turns out the way it does. But I've just never taken the time to go down and register.'' ``It's just sleazeball A or sleazeball B,'' said civil engineer Jim Allerton of Seattle, explaining why he didn't vote. ``I don't believe in Santa Claus,'' said college student Jennifer Toledo in Rhode Island. ``I don't believe in the tooth fairy. I don't believe in politicians.'' They worry the experts, these non-voters. Proportionately, there are more of them in America than any other democracy in the world. There are more in this century than in the last century. There are more in the 1990s than there were in the 1950s. About 64 percent of voting-age Americans didn't vote Tuesday, according to Curtis Gans, who gathers turnout statistics. ABC News surveyed 1,028 likely non-voters. It found their political views were pretty much like those of everyone else. They are concerned about the crisis in the Persian Gulf. They worry about the economy, drugs, the deficit, taxes. Sixty-four percent say they trust the government to do what is right ``only some of the time.'' Sixty percent say local elected officials care more about serving special interests than helping people. Gans has been studying them for 15 years as director of the nonpartisan Committee for the Study of the American Electorate. He said people voted in heavier numbers on Tuesday in places ``where there was something important to decide.'' But in places where the public only saw messages framed by political consultants and sensed that nothing real was at stake, turnout was down, he said. Gans' conclusion: when serious candidates discuss important issues, people respond. Bruce Buchanan, a University of Texas political scientist, said only some of the non-voters are the disenchanted - turned off, feeling impotent, convinced their vote wouldn't make a difference. Others are kept away by procedural barriers - difficulty in registering or in getting to the polls. Others, especially the young, simply feel government has no relevance. ``Most people in America come close to regarding politics as very distant from their lives,'' he said. ``It's just not an urgent matter.'' The Washington Post commissioned a study of people who haven't registered and put them into three groups: too busy (young, educated, somewhat more affluent than the others); too cynical (middle age and middle class); or physically impaired or illiterate (older). Associated Press reporters across the country talked to non-voters Tuesday and Wednesday. They fell into all the categories. Turned off was Skyp Krantz, 43, of Dayton, Ohio, a $9,000-a-year clerk in a record store. ``Why bother?'' he asked. ``No matter who is voted in, once they are elected they do what they want or worse, what somebody with a lot of money wants.'' Unregistered was Jim Madzinski, 28, manager of a Tulsa, Okla. food service company. ``Honestly, I'm not registered in Oklahoma,'' he said. ``The last thing I want to do is get pulled in for jury duty.'' Untouched by it all was college student Kevin Moore, 25, in Madison, Wis. ``I'm just not interested,'' he said while waiting to cross a street on his bicycle. ``I don't think anyone running for office can do anything for me.'' Kim Cruea, 26, a nanny who cares for four children in Indianapolis, wasn't registered. But even if she were, she said, ``with all these horrible campaign commercials, I wouldn't know who to vote for. They make everyone sound so horrible.'' Hostile was Bert Heacock, 39, a building services manager and part-time night watchman in Boston. ``They're all back-stabbers,'' he said. ``They need to clean up politics. It's all mudslinging and cutting each other down.'' Heacock intends to vote with his feet. He said he's saving his money for a move to Nova Scotia, Canada.

DOC.HEAD: Halloween Rampage: Most Attacks on Homeless Go Unnoticed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The Halloween night rampage in which a homeless man was slain and nine others were wounded in a frenzy of bats and cleavers caught the city's attention. But activists say other assaults on the homeless go virtually unnoticed. ``Unfortunately, nobody seems to care,'' said Keith Summa, a advocate for the homeless. As he sees it, every day is a scary Halloween for the homeless, and the horrors are mostly masked by a society that cares little about those who have nothing. On Halloween, a gang of 18 youths dressed as vampires, the Grim Reaper and the horror film character ``Jason'' poured across the footbridge linking Manhattan to Wards Island, in the East River, where more than 100 men live at a city men's shelter. Wielding a meat cleaver, bats and lengths of pipe, they attacked 10 men, using the cleaver to slash the throat of 35-year-old Carlos Melendez, who died on a deserted path on the wooded island. One victim was hospitalized for a head injury and eight others were released after treatment for deep cuts. Six people, ages 13 to 23 and from the upper Manhattan housing projects facing Wards Island, have been arrested and charged with murder. Some residents of the area are afraid of the homeless, claiming they mug people to get drug money. Others know that the homeless sometimes are defenseless. ``The youths pick on the homeless,'' said project resident Ronell Bailey. ``They'll kick them, they'll bother them. It's rough here.'' Recent studies of the homeless at Wards Island show they also have other problems. The first study of AIDS among homeless in New York City in 1989 found that 105 of 169 men tested at the Wards Island shelter were infected. That is a rate of 62 percent. Earlier this year, a study found that 42.8 percent of the men at the shelter tested positive for tuberculosis, compared with 5 percent to 15 percent of the general population. Six percent of the homeless men actually had the disease. On Monday, four of the nine men who were injured in the Halloween attack came to the Coalition for the Homeless, where Summa works as the advocacy director. ``They were looking for some assistance,'' he said. ``There was a feeling among all four of them that they want justice. They wanted to make sure the folks were prosecuted and convicted and that this doesn't happen to somebody else.'' But increasingly, he said, it does: -On Sept. 23, a bat-wielding gang of Brooklyn teen-agers was blamed for the torching of an abandoned van in which three homeless people were asleep. Nora Reilly, 25, was burnd over 100 percent of her body and died. Two men were critically injured. -On Sept. 26, a homeless man in his 50s known as Ruben was set on fire and burned over 85 percent of his body in Queens. -In May, a homeless woman died after she was beaten on a Brooklyn street after someone accused her of stealing a radio. -On Nov. 4, 1989, Samuel Jenkins was burned over 30 percent of his body when a woman set fire to his makeshift shelter in a Manhattan park. He later died. -On Sept. 18, 1988, a homeless man known as Johnny was killed when a gang of teen-agers chase him onto a busy highway, where he was struck by a car. Summa said about 200 homeless people in New York die on the streets each year, many victims of the winter cold. Some are electrocuted when they try to seek refuge in subway stations. ``From the information we see, homeless people are much more the victims of crime than the perpetrators, although I don't think that's the perception of the general public,'' he said. ``Homeless people at this point are not prone to report this sort of crime because they don't think they'll get justice.'' Mary Brosnahan, director of the Coalition for the Homeless, said part of the problem is that the city, through its indifference to the homeless issue, sends out a message that ``homeless people are disposable.'' ``It takes as grisly a crime as this to get people's attention,'' she said. ``This stuff is on the rise and a lot more mean spirited. It's alarming.''

DOC.HEAD: House Republicans Face Tough Decision in Wake of Elections
DOC.TEXT: Growing Republican frustration over lopsided Democratic majorities in the House and Senate hangs over a crucial GOP meeting that could lead to a shakeup of its congressional campaign apparatus. Republicans yielded at least nine more House seats and a Senate seat to the Democrats in Tuesday's polling. Top GOP figures said the party fared better than expected, given the historic mid-term losses suffered by the party in power in the White House. Rep. Guy Vander Jagt of Michigan joined other top Republicans putting the best face on the GOP's mid-term election performance. But on the side, Vander Jagt is campaigning quietly for re-election as chairman of the Republican National Campaign Committee. He has held the top RNCC job for 15 years, but the GOP has not made substantial gains in the House during that time. Some Republican sources had suggested he might be considering stepping down, but he said Wednesday he was lining up votes for re-election. Party sources have said that Rep. Don Sundquist of Tennessee is challenging Vander Jagt. The climate surrounding that early December organizational meeting is clouded by another lingering problem - White House displeasure with Ed Rollins, the RNCC co-chairman and one-time political director for Ronald Reagan. Rollins, who was brought into the campaign committee two years ago by Vander Jagt, got into hot water for advising Republicans with tough anti-tax records and pledges to distance themselves from Bush. His advice came after the president abandoned his no-new-taxes pledge in the quest for a deficit reduction deal with majority Democrats. Bush's top spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, gave no indication Wednesday that the Rollins rift with the White House had healed. Asked during his daily news briefing if the president wanted Rollins to stay on at the campaign committee, Fitzwater said, ``Ed Rollins' situation is up to the committee, and that's for them to consider.'' For his part, Rollins said he wasn't about to leave voluntarily. ``I made a four-year commitment to Guy Vander Jagt because I felt it would take four years to change the way we run congressional campaigns around this country,'' he said. He acknowledged that his advice to Republicans about shying away from Bush was a source of ``irritation'' with the White House but said he continues to support the president. ``I think we probably saved a couple campaigns,'' he said. ``I didn't in any way, shape or form want to go to war with the White House, and I certainly don't want to go to war with the White House in the future.''

DOC.HEAD: Arne Carlson: A Tumultuous Career in Minnesota Politics
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Minnesota's new governor, Arne Carlson, has a long record of public service and an equally lengthy slate of political controversy. Even the way Carlson won was fraught with upheaval: He lost the Sept. 11 GOP primary to Jon Grunseth and threatened a few days later to mount a write-in campaign for the general election but changed his mind. He actually did start a write-in bid when Grunseth became embroiled in sexual impropriety allegations, and finally was awarded the ballot spot after Grunseth withdrew nine days before the election. With 98 percent of precincts reporting, Carlson had 808,182 votes, or 50 percent, to 772,543 votes, or 48 percent, for Gov. Rudy Perpich. At his best, Carlson supporters see him as a deep thinker who cares passionately about public policy. ``Arne is a consummate politician,'' said Barbara Carlson, his first wife. ``It's his vocation, his avocation. He is really extraordinarily good at what he does. ... The best thing about him is he is really committed and caring about people and he is committed to solving problems.'' But she added, ``He's got a terrible temper. I think his worst fault is his terrible temper.'' His critics see Carlson, 56, as a political brawler who shoots from the hip with reckless abandon. His political career began in controversy in 1965, when he unseated Minneapolis alderman Richard Franson. Franson brought an unfair campaign practices suit on the ground that Carlson mailed out 12,000 documents resembling a county tax statement containing an accusation that Franson wanted to raise homeowners' taxes. The election was overturned, but the state Supreme Court overruled the lower court on a technicality. In 1967, Carlson ran a hard-hitting campaign against three-term Mayor Arthur Naftalin, a former aide to the late Hubert H. Humphrey. Naftalin narrowly won. ``He conducted a campaign that was really quite unfair,'' said Naftalin, 73. ``Coming out of that 1967 thing, I've never had a very positive impression of Carlson.'' Carlson served four terms in the Minnesota House before running for state auditor in 1978, unseating a maverick Democrat whom he later called a ``lazy buffoon.'' He was re-elected in 1982 and 1986. His moderate stances on many issues and his pro-choice position on abortion have aroused the ire of conservatives in his own party. The second son of Swedish immigrants, Carlson grew up poor in the Bronx borough of New York City. He won a scholarship to Choate, a prestigious prep school in Connecticut, graduated from Williams College in Massachusetts and attended graduate school at the University of Minnesota.

DOC.HEAD: Nebraska Governor: From Rural Town to Statehouse
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: From his rural roots in southern Nebraska, Earl Benjamin ``Ben'' Nelson branched out on a career that led him to the Statehouse. Nelson grew up in the small town of McCook, the son of a lineman for a power company. He became an attorney specializing in insurance issues and worked both for a private insurance company and in state government before deciding to campaign for the governor's office. At 49, he made it. He narrowly defeated Republican Gov. Kay Orr, but his margin of victory was so slim that the absentee ballots could force a recount. Nelson had thought about the governor's race in 1982 but said he changed his mind after one of his children's teachers said it might not be a good time to put his family in the spotlight. At the time, Nelson and his second wife, Diane, had been married two years. Both were widowed and each had two young children. ``It just wasn't my time,'' he said. Nelson has learned to be patient. He had to wait 42 days after the May 15 Democratic gubernatorial primary before being named the party's nominee in one of the closest races in Nebraska history. After a recount, the state Board of Canvassers declared Nelson the nominee by a 42-vote margin over Bill Hoppner of Lincoln. Nelson has said he doesn't believe it's a hindrance that he has never held an elected office. ``It may be an advantage to come in from a business approach,'' he has said. But his business ties to First Executive Corp. of California, an insurance holding company criticized for its involvement in high-risk securities known as junk bonds, became an issue in the campaign. Nelson, who served on First Executive's board of directors, said he was not responsible for the company's management and its investment policy. Nelson graduated from the University of Nebraska in 1963, then received a master's degree in philosophy in 1966. He worked for seven years for the Consumer Division of the Nebraska Insurance Division, eventually becoming supervisor of compliance and enforcement. After he earned a law degree in 1970, he worked for the Central National Insurance Group of Omaha until 1980, except for two years when he was state insurance director in then-Gov. Jim Exon's cabinet. He re-entered private law practice in 1981 and in 1982 became executive vice president of the National Association of Insurance Commissioners, an organization of state insurance commissioners. He joined an Omaha law firm in 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Money Helps, But it Doesn't Necessarily Buy a Seat in Congress
DOC.TEXT: The elections proved once again that money can be an unbeatable political asset - but it doesn't guarantee victory. A handful of upsets and surprising turnabouts showed money sometimes isn't everything when it comes to winning votes. While the vast majority of incumbents, with their superior fund-raising ability, won their races, there were notable exceptions. They were seen in: -Minnesota, where Democrat Paul Wellstone beat Republican Sen. Rudy Boschwitz after Boschwitz spent nearly $5 million to less than $800,000 by Wellstone entering the home stretch of the campaign. Wellstone said he won on ``shoe leather power.'' -Florida, where former Sen. Lawton Chiles ousted Republican Gov. Bob Martinez after Chiles set a $100-per-donation limit on his own campaign contributions. Martinez thus had a 2-1 money edge over Chiles. -Kansas, where Democratic challenger Joan Finney beat Gov. Mike Hayden despite Hayden's spending about $2 million to Finney's $318,000. The figures reflect their primary and general election spending as of last week. -Oregon, where Democratic Gov.-elect Barbara Roberts raised $1.8 million and beat Republican Attorney General David Frohnmayer, who raised $3.2 million as of Nov. 1. -Nebraska, where Republican Gov. Kay Orr had raised $2.2 million as of last week but was ousted by Democratic challenger Ben Nelson, who had raised $1.5 million. -Texas, where Democratic gubernatorial contender Ann Richards eked out a victory over Republican oilman Clayton Williams, despite Williams' $20.4 million war chest that included $8 million of his own money. Richards raised just over $11 million. Several of the 13 House members who were defeated heavily outspent their victorious opponents, according to their spending reports on file with the Federal Election Commission. Among them: Reps. Bill Grant, R-Fla.; Roy Dyson, D-Md.; John Buechner, R-Mo.; Doug Walgren, D-Pa.; and Robert Kastenmeier, D-Wis. Despite those exceptions, the general pattern of cash-rich incumbents hanging on to their seats held true. The vast majority of House members were returned to office, with just 13 of the 406 who sought re-election being defeated. Two California races remained undecided. ``The overwhelming campaign finance advantage held by congressional incumbents dominated and controlled the races,'' said Fred Wertheimer, president of the citizens lobby Common Cause. In North Carolina, Sen. Jesse Helms used more than $11 million to turn back a strong challenge by Democrat Harvey Gantt, who had raised $6 million as of mid-October. Money helped some challengers as well. In Rhode Island, Republican Gov. Ed DiPrete was outspent 2-1 and went down in defeat to Democrat Bruce Sundlun. But Sen. John Kerry, D-Mass., fended off a challenge from James Rappaport, whose campaign war chest included more than $3 million in personal loans. Kerry, who reported raising more than $5 million as of mid-October to Rappaport's $3.7 million, said: ``We have proven that money can't buy you a U.S. Senate seat.'' The Senate race in New Jersey was noteworthy for Christine Whitman's strong showing against incumbent Democratic Sen. Bill Bradley, despite Bradley's huge spending edge. Bradley spent $12.6 million to her $1 million, according to their campaigns, but beat her by just two percentage points. Similarly, Republican Rep. Newt Gingrich of Georgia barely hung on to his seat, although he had raised $1.3 million by mid-October to $274,000 for Democratic challenger David Worley. Such races prove that ``money is not always the price of admission. Special circumstances mean that voters do what they want to do,'' said Larry Sabato, professor of government at the University of Virginia. ``Worley had problems with money. He might have been able to beat Gingrich easily'' with a bigger war chest, said Sabato. In California, where the governor's race was the top priority for both political parties, total spending reached $40 million, but money was not considered a deciding factor. Republican Sen. Pete Wilson raised about $21 million to Democrat Dianne Feinstein's $18 million.

DOC.HEAD: Election Fallout: Possible Primary Challenge, Credibility Loss
DOC.TEXT: The next time President Bush hits the campaign trail, it will be for himself. And many analysts suggest he can take little comfort from Tuesday's mid-term election results. Bush could even face a primary challenge from within his own party, with Republicans still splintered after this year's bruising battle over taxes and the budget. But then, it all depends on who's doing the talking. ``Let me tell you something. President Bush wasn't on the ballot yesterday. If he was, he would have won big,'' asserted Charlie Black, spokesman for the Republican National Committee. If either New York Mayor Mario Cuomo or New Jersey Democratic Sen. Bill Bradley had run against Bush on Tuesday ``they would have had their clocks cleaned,'' Black said. But another Republican, hard-line conservative Richard Viguerie, saw it differently. ``If he (Bush) had been on the ballot yesterday against a credible Democrat, he would have suffered a massive defeat.'' Bush's only recourse if he wants to be re-elected in 1992, Viguerie suggested, is to ``clean house, get rid of most of his Wall Street country club advisers and bring in some conservatives who are in touch with grassroots America.'' Even so, most mainstream politicians and analysts seem to agree that the mid-term elections should not be seen as a referendum on Bush's presidency. But many say there are lessons in it that will have a bearing on the 1992 race. White House and other GOP strategists clearly are sifting through the results of the elections as they focus their sights on 1992. The most serious problem Bush could face is a primary challenge from within his own party. With conservatives still angry about Bush's abandonment of his no-new-taxes pledge, this looms as a real possibility, many analysts suggest. ``I think there is likely to be a primary challenge from the right,'' said Norman Ornstein, a political analyst at the American Enterprise Institute. ``The question is whether it'll be a minor annoyance like that John Ashbrook provided Nixon in 1972 or more like what Ronald Reagan provided for (President) Ford in 1976 - taking him to within an inch of his political life.'' Republican consultant John Sears, who engineered Reagan's nearly successful 1976 challenge to Ford, said Bush's main problem now ``is that he's lost some of his credibility in the last month.'' ``He has got to be sure in the next couple years that, when he takes a position, he sticks with it,'' Sears said. ``Otherwise, he'll end 1992 in a bad position. People already don't trust Congress and they don't want to not trust their president.'' Lyn Nofziger, another former Reagan aide, blames Bush's switch on taxes for the losses the party did incur in Congress. ``It means he's got some fence-mending to do. He can't afford to alienate people any further. He's got to get hold of things again.'' The base that elected Bush in 1988 ``is really kind of shattered,'' Nofziger said. Ed Rollins, whom Bush has tried to get fired as co-chairman of the National Republican Congressional Committee, said Bush ``obviously has had a little setback in the polls but he's still the most popular president going into mid-term elections in modern times.'' ``I think there's tremendous opportunity to get ready for '92 with strong leadership the next two years,'' said Rollins, whose memo suggesting House Republicans distance themselves from Bush on taxes drew presidential ire. For the record, the White House was being blase about the outcome of Tuesday's mid-term elections. ``You win some and you lose some. We campaigned hard in Texas and lost; campaigned hard in California and won. It goes back and forth,'' said presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. Fitzwater said the one-seat Republican loss in the Senate and the nine-seat loss in the House means little actual change in Congress. And, he declined to see any message in the election results as a result of Bush's turnabout on tax increases. Still, Fitzwater noted, ``Nobody likes taxes. Generally, it's better politically to be against taxes ... You don't win points by raising taxes. That's been clear.'' There's little doubt that the elections leave Bush in a weakened position with respect to Congress. But Fitzwater said the veto will remain a primary legislative tool for the president. ``Bush is going to be marginally weaker in Congress,'' said David Mason, an analyst with the conservative Heritage Foundation. And, Mason said, ``If he can't get a more defined message in '92 than he did in this year, he's going to have a problem.'' ``If we have a recession between now and '92, the economy will be the overriding issue,'' Mason added - a view echoed by nearly all analysts. Meanwhile, the White House is playing coy on the subject of Bush's re-election efforts. ``Hasn't declared yet,'' Fitzwater said. ``Hasn't said.''

DOC.HEAD: Prime Minister Took A Long Fall From Grace
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: The tempestuous tenure of Vishwanath Pratap Singh as head of India's first coalition government started with enormous goodwill, lurched through a series of crises, and ended in public invective. In 11 months as prime minister, Singh found little time to tackle India's endemic problems: poverty, separatist revolts by embittered minorities and the people's growing feeling of isolation from the government. Instead, he got bogged down in feuds within his Janata Dal party and the constant need to appease partners in his unwieldy coalition. Singh's defeat in a confidence vote in Parliament on Wednesday night came amid allegations he had used the age-old divisions in India, caste and religion, to try to further his own political interests. When Singh and his hurriedly assembled National Front coalition prevented former Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's Congress Party from winning November 1989 elections, he was hailed as a crusading angel out to end patronage and corruption. The coalition formed an unlikely government with support from a right-wing Hindu party and a left-wing group who barely concealed their antipathy for each other. Singh also had to contend with feuding within his own party, which was riven by factions and had at least two other men who fancied the top job. Nevertheless, he received a good amount of public support in his early days in office. ``We join the people in extending our good wishes to Mr. V.P. Singh,'' said a February editorial in the Economic Times. ``He not only deserves but requires the nation's good wishes in tackling the tremendous tasks that lie ahead.'' Just days after Singh took the oath of office on Dec. 2, trouble brewed in the Moslem-majority state of Jammu and Kashmir. Moslem separatists, escalating their struggle to secede from mostly Hindu India, kidnapped the daughter of Singh's home minister and launched a cycle of violent protests and assassinations. The government's crackdown on the Kashmiri movement represent one of the darker spots of Singh's tenure. Kashmir, once India's showplace for tourists, is now fully in the grip of the separatist campaign. In Punjab state, scene of a lingering rebellion by Sikh militants, Singh started out promisingly. He made a trip to Amritsar, the Sikh holy city, within a week of taking office and waded through crowds of Sikhs in an open jeep, disregarding the pleas of worried security men. Three months later, his party piloted a bill through Parliament postponing elections in Punjab for six months because of the violence. Another six-month postponement was sought in October. ``There is no difference between this government and Gandhi,'' a Sikh member of Parliament said at the time. This year, the number of killings by Sikh militants in Punjab has surpassed 2,650, higher than any single year in Gandhi's five-year tenure. Secessionist sentiment has also flared in the northeastern state of Assam, where belligerent tribes want independence. Meanwhile, the national economy is in a woeful condition. Gasoline prices have been raised twice this year, inflation is rampant, and the economic crunch caused by the Persian Gulf crisis has hit India harder than most other nations. Through all of this, Singh waged a running feud with Deputy Prime Minister Devi Lal, who was accused of exemplifying the cronyism Singh had vowed to eliminate. Singh forced the issue out into the open in July by threatening to resign. His party backed him, and he ousted Devi Lal. But within weeks, Singh pushed through what many saw as a divisive plan to strengthen his power base. He made into law an affirmative action program that reserved almost half of all government jobs for lower-caste Hindus. At least 150 people committed suicide or died in protests against the law. Critics said Singh was using it to gain favor among lower castes, who form a majority of voters among India's 880 million people. The Supreme Court temporarily eased the situation by blocking the job quota plan while it studied its legality. But then fundamentalist Hindus, who had been threatening for two years to build a temple on the site of a mosque in the remote northern town of Ayodhya, began whipping up Hindu sentiment over the campaign. The issue aggravated tensions between Hindus, who make up 82 percent of India's population, and Moslems, who comprise 12 percent. At least 22 Hindus were killed by police in two attempts to storm the shrine, and Hindu-Moslem riots have claimed the lives of more than 340 other people in the past two weeks. Singh said he would uphold India's tradition of secularism and prevent Hindus from taking over the mosque. It was a laudable stand, but critics saw it as an attempt to woo Moslem votes. In the end, the 59-year-old Singh was brought down by the combination of a split in his own party and the withdrawal of support by the right-wing, Hindu fundamentalist Bharatiya Janata Party. Singh has one thing in common with Gandhi, whom he served as defense and finance minister before their falling-out. Both were called ``Mr. Clean'' at the start of their terms; both resigned amid allegations of dirty politicking. Of Singh, the Sunday Observer newspaper said last month: ``History will remember him as one who willfully sought India's social dismemberment in the crass pursuit of votes. Nearly a year after he came to power on the vote of just one-fourth of the electorate, V.P. Singh has left the economy in tatters and society in ruins. Is it possible to recall even one laudable step the government has taken?''
