DOC.HEAD: China Signals Return to Normal for Program With United States
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. government program that sends Chinese on American tours is back in official Chinese favor, a U.S. Embassy spokesman said today, underscoring the much-improved relations of recent months. Though tensions persist, both sides appear determined to stress pragmatic cooperation and put aside ideological and human rights issues. The Chinese government never formally blocked the U.S. International Visitor Program, which has given more than 600 selected Chinese a brief taste of U.S. society since 1979. But since June 4, 1989, when the Chinese army killed hundreds of unarmed civilians in crushing a pro-democracy movement, about half the Chinese invited by the program have begged off, apparently under official Chinese pressure. The West had reacted to the army assault with outrage, imposing sanctions on China. U.S. Embassy spokesman Sheridan W. Bell said today that Chinese sources recently informed the embassy that ``the Chinese government is now encouraging people selected for International Visitor Program grants to take part in the program.'' There was no official Chinese notification of the change, he said. Bell said it was too soon to see any improvement in the Chinese acceptance rate, but added, ``We hope this will lead to a full resumption of the program. ``We view this development as a positive step and believe it reflects a renewed Chinese government realization that such exchanges are highly beneficial both to the Chinese participants and to our two nations,'' he said. Contacts between the two governments have reached a post-June 1989 high in the past few months as the United States has sought Chinese cooperation in the Persian Gulf crisis. As a permanent member of the U.N. Security Council, China's vote has been needed on resolutions demanding Iraq withdraw from Kuwait. Although China had good relations with Iraq, it has supported all resolutions so far, earning it reacceptance by Western nations. President Bush has helped, opposing moves in Congress to punish China for its crackdown by withdrawing its most-favored-nation trade status. China has in turn freed more than 800 jailed political activists over the past year and allowed its most famous dissident, Fang Lizhi, to leave the country after he spent a year in hiding in the U.S. Embassy. After a one-year halt, China also resumed participation in the Fulbright program this year. Sixteen American professors were sent to China to teach and do research, and 16 Chinese professors went to the United States. The International Visitor Program, run by the U.S. Information Agency at a cost of about $10 million a year, brings about 2,800 people from around the world to the United States annually. Program officials began inviting Chinese participants after U.S.-Chinese relations were established in 1979. Before the June 1989 crackdown, 70 to 80 Chinese were taking part each year. The visitors participate in programs related to their fields of work, touring U.S. schools, businesses, hospitals or government institutions.

DOC.HEAD: Tuesday's Voter Turnout Near Lowest in Nearly 50 Years
With PM-Turnout List
DOC.TEXT: A voting analyst says turnout in elections this week appears to be near the 1986 level - the lowest in nearly half a century. Analyst Curtis Gans said Tuesday's turnout was up in 26 states and the District of Columbia and down in the rest. In the 1986 midterm election, 36.4 percent of those eligible to vote actually went to the polls, the lowest percentage since 1942. After inspecting returns from all 50 states and the District, Gans estimated the turnout again was 36.4 percent on Tuesday. This year, Maine has the higest turnout at 55.18 percent, Gans reported, based on nearly complete returns. Other states with strong showings for an off-year were Montana at 54.61 percent, North Dakota, 53.24 percent, and Minnesota at 52.51 percent. The biggest gainer was Massachusetts, where a hotly contested race for governor boosted turnout 11.91 percentage points to 49.32 percent. On the other end of the scale, Mississippi managed only 16.9 percent turnout. There, the only statewide contest found Sen. Thad Cochran unopposed. Gans said the 16.9 percent figure was likely to be revised upward when all ballots are counted, but he could not guess by how much. Tennessee managed only a 22.48 percent turnout, with 22.48 percent in Virginia; 28 percent in South Carolina and 29.03 percent for West Virginia. Biggest declines in turnout from four years ago were in Idaho, down 14.3 percentage points; Tennessee down 13.7 points and Mississippi down 11.8 points. By party, Democratic turnout declined by 0.45 percentage points and Republican turnout increased by the same share, according to Gans, director of the nonpartisan Committee for the Study of the American Electorate. The number of voters choosing independent or others jumped 1.77 percentage points, however. The vote for independents was boosted by the election of independent governors in Alaska and Connecticut and an independent House member in Vermont.

DOC.HEAD: Infotechnology Seeking Buyers For its Operations
DOC.TEXT: The new heads of Infotechnology Inc., the troubled parent of Financial News Network and United Press International, say they will recommend selling the companies' principal operations. Alan J. Hirschfield and Allan R. Tessler, appointed co-chief executives in a management shakeup on Oct. 24, said Wednesday they have retained the investment banking firm Wertheim Schroder and Co. for the purchase negotiations, hoping to conclude sales contracts by the end of the year. ``We believe the prices that FNN and Infotech businesses are anticipated to command could satisfy the companies' financial obligations,'' they said in a statement. They said they were asking banks and creditors for a 90-day moratorium on payments. FNN has outstanding about $49.5 million in bank loan principal and approximately $88 million in equipment lease obligations. Infotech has outstanding about $20.7 million in bank loan principal. United Press International had already said it was seeking a buyer, but on Monday the news agency said it would have to liquidate if members of the Wire Service Guild reject its proposal to cut wages by 35 percent for 90 days. A similar pay cut for management staff was announced last week. ``As a result of recent contract cancellations and other ongoing factors, UPI currently has a substantial negative monthly cash flow,'' Hirschfield and Tessler said Wednesday. ``It has been necessary to make some painful decisions regarding layoffs and reduced compensation to continuing employees in order for UPI to remain in business until suitable purchasers are identified.'' The news agency has declined to specify how many people are losing their jobs in the continuing layoffs. Financial News Network provides business, sports and market data to cable systems in the United States and Canada. FNN and Infotechnology collectively own 51 percent of the Learning Channel, and Infotechnology also has investments in other media, communications and biotechnology companies. Hirschfield and Tessler, who replaced Earl Brian as the head of FNN and Infotechnology, said they were ``distressed by many of the unfounded rumors surrounding current events at the company.'' ``First and foremost, any and all allegations concerning fraud or misappropriation of funds at the companies have been, and are being, taken extremely seriously by the boards of directors and have been, or are being, thoroughly investigated by the companies' outside auditors,'' they said. ``In addition, the companies are cooperating with the Securities and Exchange Commission's inquiries that we have previously disclosed.'' They said only one case had been found in which company funds were improperly paid out. ``That incident, previously disclosed by FNN, involved the receipt by FNN's former chief financial officer of compensation payments, which were not properly authorized, in the approximate amount of $795,000.'' The financial officer, C. Steven Bolen, was fired last month.

DOC.HEAD: Franks Says He Won't Pursue Exclusively Minority Or GOP Agenda
DOC.TEXT: Gary Franks is the first black Republican elected to the House in 58 years and his political agenda probably won't appeal to many minorities. The 37-year-old real estate developer opposes racial quotas and he is a fiscal conservative. ``From the conservative-liberal perspective, there's a major difference between me and my future colleagues in the House of Representatives who are black,'' Franks said following his victory in Tuesday's election. He is an opponent of the 1990 civil rights reform act which was vetoed by President Bush. The son of a mill worker, Franks won a scholarship to Yale and worked for two Fortune 500 companies before starting his own real estate firm. Republicans were delighted. ``It's a great win,'' said Gary Koops, a spokesman for the National Republican Congressional Committee. ``Not only have we held a Republican open seat and elected a strong new congressman who's a Republican, it also broadens the Republican Party.'' It was a bright spot amid gloomy news in congressional races. The GOP lost at least nine House seats. Franks defeated liberal Democrat Toby Moffett, a former four-term congressman seeking to make a political comeback. Despite a sometimes chilly reception from local black leaders and organizations during the campaign, Franks carried the black precincts of his home city, Waterbury. And he insisted that while opposed to racial quotas, he is pro-civil rights, ``to the hilt.'' ``I've had crosses burnt in front of my house when I was nine years old,'' said Franks, who was born and raised in Waterbury. ``I had a dead opossum put in my mailbox, which I had the misfortune to open, with a note saying `You're next.''' Still, Franks hardly rivals Jesse Jackson for liberal credentials that remain popular in the black community. ``For some time you have only heard from black Democrats from a national perspective. Now, for the first time, you will hear from a black Republican in the House,'' said Franks, an alderman in Waterbury. The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People criticized Franks on the civil rights issue and withheld its endorsement. And during the campaign, two prominent Waterbury black leaders - and members of the Republican Party - endorsed Moffett over Franks. About 4 percent of the population is black in Franks' congressional district. Moffett, 46, congratulated Franks. ``Let's understand that he has made history,'' Moffett said. Franks becomes the first black from Connecticut ever to sit in Congress. The last black Republican in the U.S. House was Oscar de Priest, who represented Illinois from 1929 to 1935. He last won re-election in 1932. The win was a highly sought-after prize that drew more than $50,000 in national GOP aid, a visit by President Bush to the district and a reception for the candidate at the White House. When word came through of Franks' victory, Bush telephoned the winner with his congratulations. With Franks' conservative agenda, national Democrats aren't concerned that his election will mark the beginning of a drain on one of their most dependable voting blocs. ``I don't expect you'll see minorities flocking to the Republican Party because of Gary Franks, unless he changes his philosophy, which I don't expect he'll do,'' said Howard Schloss, a spokesman for the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee. Still, Franks doesn't plan to champion a GOP agenda. ``My No.1 priority is to serve my constituents,'' Franks said. Franks won the seat vacated by Republican Rep. John Rowland, who lost a gubernatorial bid to independent Lowell Weicker.

DOC.HEAD: Farm Population Dwindles Despite Rural Influx
DOC.TEXT: Urban sprawl and long-distance commuting have helped boost population growth in rural America, but new government figures show the number of farm people continues to dwindle. The farm population dropped by 150,000 to an estimated 4,801,000 in 1989, a decrease described as ``not a statistically significant difference'' from 1988. Last year's farm population was reported at 1.9 percent of the U.S. total of more than 248.2 million people, the smallest share on record. In 1980, the 6.05 million living on farms represented 2.7 percent of the 221.7 million people in the United States. At the turn of the century, the 1900 census showed 29.9 million living on farms, 39.3 percent of the population of 76 million. The annual report was released Wednesday by the Census Bureau of the Commerce Department and the Economic Research Service of the Agriculture Department. Overall, the rural population was estimated at more than 66.2 million, up from just under 64.8 million people in the 1988 survey. The rural population includes those in living in the open countryside and small towns. Large cities and their suburbs, plus towns of 2,500 or more, are considered urban. As used in the report, the farm population consists of those living on farms in rural areas, but does not include the relatively few who live on farms in urban areas. A farm is defined as a place that sold agricultural products worth $1,000 or more in the previous year. The farm population definition is based on residence only. Many people reside on farms but do no agricultural work, and many farmers and farm employees do not reside on farms. Felicia LeClere of the Economic Research Service, one of the report's authors, said there were no real surprises in this year's figures. ``The things that have come out have been long-term trends, and none of them has been surprising,'' she said in a telephone interview. LeClere cautioned that all the figures are subject to revision when the official 1990 census results are available next year. She is confident that the annual figures are on track, however. Officials have noted the increase in rural population - rising by 12 million people since 1950 - and point out that urban sprawl and a willingness of city workers to commute greater distances have been important factors. One possible effect of the 1990 census is a reclassification of some of these distant areas from rural to urban. That could show up later as a slowdown in rural growth. The report said the largest share of the rural population, about 44 percent, continues to be in the South. That has been the case since the first U.S. census was taken in 1790. ``Although the regional distribution of the rural population changed only slightly in the last 40 years, the regional distribution of the farm population shifted markedly,'' the report said. In 1950, one-third of all farm people lived in the Midwest and slightly more than half in the South. ``A rapid decline in the Southern farm population, rather than growth in the Midwest's farm population, reversed the regional rankings,'' the report said. ``Half of the total farm population now lives in the Midwest, and less than a third lives in the South.'' Other observations in the report included: -Farm people continue to be older than the non-farm population in general, with a median of 38 years in 1989, compared with 32.5 years for non-farm residents. A median age means half of the people are older, half younger. Non-farm refers to urban plus rural non-farm people. -Last year 97.4 percent of farm residents were white, and 1.8 percent were black, compared with 84 percent white and 12.5 percent black in the non-farm population. The remainder were described as of other races. -Only 2.9 percent of the farm residents were of Hispanic origin. -Nearly 69 percent of the farm residents 15 years and older were married and living with spouses in 1989, compared with 55.4 percent of the non-farm people.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th item to DELETE extraneous matter from 2nd graf, `A judge...'
DOC.TEXT: Pro wrestler Andre the Giant was fined $100 for doing to a TV cameraman what he does to opponents in the ring. A judge found Andre Roussimoff guilty of criminal mischief for scuffling with Ben Hildebrandt last year after losing a match. The 7-foot-4, 540-pound wrestler on Tuesday was also ordered to pay $233 to KCRG-TV to fix the camera. The scuffle broke out when Roussimoff, who acted in the movie ``The Princess Bride,'' contended Hildebrandt videotaped the match without his permission. Hildebrandt said he was just shooting crowd scenes when the wrestler put him in a head lock. The judge found Roussimoff innocent of assault, saying the wrestler didn't mean to harm Hildebrandt.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutors: Sect Actually Based on Terror
LaserPhoto NU1
DOC.TEXT: A black sect that won civic honors for renovating inner-city buildings, fighting drugs and operating businesses under its charismatic leader built its empire on extortion, firebombings and murder, prosecutors charged. A federal grand jury accused the group's leader, Yahweh ben Yahweh, and 16 followers of involvement in the slayings of 14 people, including so-called ``white devils'' who were killed to gain entrance to the sect's inner circle. Some victims were decapitated. Others' ears were cut off, U.S. Attorney Dexter Lehtinen said. Yahweh and several members of the sect were arrested in early morning raids Wednesday. ``Any dissenter was subject to extreme violence, including murder, to maintain control of the organization,'' Lehtinen said. The sect also used ``random violence as a ritual membership initiation rite,'' he said. The indictment accuses those named of racketeering, conspiracy and extortion from 1981 to 1987. Yahweh, 55, born Hulon Mitchell Jr., regulated all aspects of his followers' lives, including when and how they had sex, sometimes ordering women members to his own bed, Lehtinen said. The Yahwehs consider themselves the true chosen people, and Yahweh ben Yahweh - who claims to be the son of God and whose name is Hebrew for ``God, son of God'' - had in the past referred to all whites as devils. Recently the Yahwehs, who have claimed about 10,000 members, diminished their anti-white rhetoric and became known as hard workers who built a modest empire of 27 small businesses and properties. Their combined tax value has been assessed at $3 million, but their market value is believed to be more. Yahweh was arrested by the FBI in a New Orleans hotel. Three others were arrested in Lafayette, La. His top aide, Judith Israel, or Linda Gaines, was taken into custody in Atlanta, and another arrest was made in Durham, N.C. Seven members were arrested at the sect's Temple of Love in Miami. The group's enterprising spirit, strict religious practices, promotion of family values and strong opposition to drugs drew praise from local officials. Mayor Xavier Suarez recently attended a ribbon-cutting at a Yahweh store with the sect's leader, who has also received civic honors for rebuilding the inner city. A proclamation declared Oct. 7 Yahweh ben Yahweh Day in Miami. But the indictment said the businesses were built in part by the threat of violence and by extortion of contributions from reluctant black neighborhoods. The charges include firebombing homes after people opposed fund-raising efforts. The sect first became widely known in 1986 when it took over a drug-infested Opa-locka apartment complex, evicting residents and promising to make it a crack-free haven. Two residents who resisted were shot to death, and sect member Robert Rozier, a former pro football player, was convicted in the slayings. Rozier - who could have faced the electric chair - agreed to provide much of the evidence against Yahweh in exchange for a 22-year sentence, sect lawyer Ellis Rubin said. Most of the slaying victims listed in the indictment were Yawheh members who left the group or opposed their leader. Some were shot, others decapitated and some beaten to death. Seven white men were killed by those applying to join the Brotherhood, a secret group within the sect. Yahweh ordered the ears cut off some victims as proof they were killed, Lehtinen said. Rubin, who has accused authorities of persecuting the group, said he was surprised by Wednesday's raids. He said he told authorities that sect members would surrender after the long-expected indictment was handed up. In Washington, FBI Director William Sessions denied there was any harassment or racism involved in the prosecution. Rubin said he would appear with Yahweh at a New Orleans hearing scheduled for Friday. Four of the 17 defendants were still being sought.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Down In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 22,96.81, down 530.44 points or 2.26 percent, on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: State Justice's Name Blamed for Weak Voter Support
DOC.TEXT: State Supreme Court Justice Armand Arabian ran as much as 10 percentage points behind his colleagues on Election Day, and the only reason he can think of is his name. Arabian, an Armenian-American like the man who appointed him, Gov. George Deukmejian, figured his name must have reminded people of oil, sheiks and the Middle East conflict, court spokeswoman Lynn Holton said Wednesday. Arabian is little known and his conservative record is similar to those of four other Deukmejian-appointed justices who also won new terms Tuesday. Their majorities ranged from 66 to 69 percent. Arabian's was 56 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Third-Party Governors Reflect Voter Dissatisfaction
DOC.TEXT: Voters elected independent governors in Connecticut and Alaska in a historic warning to Republicans and Democrats that they aren't the only choices in American politics. But experts are saying the winners are not true independents in that if they hope to get anything done, they won't stay independent for long. In Connecticut, former U.S. Sen. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. completed a political comeback Tuesday with a narrow victory in a three-way field. In Alaska, former Gov. Walter Hickel was the winner in another close, three-way race. Their victories mean two independent governors will be in office simultaneously for the first time in U.S. history. Both men are former Republicans who left the party after falling out of favor - Weicker because he was considered too liberal, Hickel because he was viewed as too conservative. They'll lead states whose legislatures are still party-controlled. Hickel said an anti-government feeling among voters carried him back into office. ``I think Alaskans just want a change - they want to have more of a say in government,'' he said. Weicker said bypassing party politics will make his state more efficient. ``We didn't ask or bequeath upon any particular party to run our business for us,'' he said. ``We can run it better than anybody else can.'' Weicker's independent attitude surfaced in 1973-74 while serving on the Senate Watergate Committee. He was one of President Nixon's most outspoken critics. Later, he also was arrested outside the South African Embassy in Washington during an anti-apartheid protest. Nixon appointed Hickel interior secretary in 1968 and fired him in 1970 because of what Hickel says were industry pressures. Hickel also had written Nixon a letter chiding him for failing to listen to America's youth protesting the Vietnam War. Weicker ran under the banner of A Connecticut Party. Excluding his running mate, only one legislative candidate joined in - and he lost. Hickel adopted the banner of the Alaska Independence Party, an established third party that wants to make Alaska an independent country. It was a move of convenience, since Hickel ignores the party's independence plank. The former GOP mavericks are making history by shunning major-party affiliation and winning, but it is widely felt they could not have won without their high name-recognition and their former major-party ties. ``The message is very guarded,'' said William Schneider, a political scientist at the American Enterprise Institute. ``It helps if you're a known quantity. For a third party to succeed, a major party has to split.'' Experts tended to agree that the independent victories send a warning to Republicans and Democrats. ``These are more than blips,'' said James Reichley, an expert on party politics with the Brookings Institution. ``They're indicators that neither of the major parties are attracting voters.'' In another sign of anger at the two established parties, socialist candidate Bernard Sanders won Vermont's congressional seat, defeating Republican and Democratic candidates. ``Our small state might go down in history as the leading state in a political revolution which takes power away from the multinational corporations and the wealthy and gives it back to the people,'' Sanders said. The independent governors-elect face the prospect of lonely times in office. Weicker, for example, will be unable to file a bill without legislative sponsorship. Reichley predicted that both would move back into a close, if not official, relationship with the GOP. And as so often happens in politics, a feature that can help a candidate get elected can often make governing more difficult. ``They have no party they can call on, allies who will support them if they get in trouble,'' Schneider said. ``That's a big problem. Without a political party, you're on your own. It's sink or swim.''

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING a0459 to make slug conform to PM-News Digest.
Third-Party Governors Reflect Voter Dissatisfaction
DOC.TEXT: Voters elected independent governors in Connecticut and Alaska in a historic warning to Republicans and Democrats that they aren't the only choices in American politics. But experts are saying the winners are not true independents and that if they hope to get anything done, they won't stay independent for long. In Connecticut, former U.S. Sen. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. completed a political comeback Tuesday with a narrow victory in a three-way field. In Alaska, former Gov. Walter Hickel was the winner in another close, three-way race. Their victories mean two independent governors will be in office simultaneously for the first time in U.S. history. Both men are former Republicans who left the party after falling out of favor - Weicker because he was considered too liberal, Hickel because he was viewed as too conservative. They'll lead states whose legislatures are still party-controlled. Hickel said an anti-government feeling among voters carried him back into office. ``I think Alaskans just want a change - they want to have more of a say in government,'' he said. Weicker said bypassing party politics will make his state more efficient. ``We didn't ask or bequeath upon any particular party to run our business for us,'' he said. ``We can run it better than anybody else can.'' Weicker's independent attitude surfaced in 1973-74 while serving on the Senate Watergate Committee. He was one of President Nixon's most outspoken critics. Later, he also was arrested outside the South African Embassy in Washington during an anti-apartheid protest. Nixon appointed Hickel interior secretary in 1968 and fired him in 1970 because of what Hickel says were industry pressures. Hickel also had written Nixon a letter chiding him for failing to listen to America's youth protesting the Vietnam War. Weicker ran under the banner of A Connecticut Party. Excluding his running mate, only one legislative candidate joined in - and he lost. Hickel adopted the banner of the Alaska Independence Party, an established third party that wants to make Alaska an independent country. It was a move of convenience, since Hickel ignores the party's independence plank. The former GOP mavericks are making history by shunning major-party affiliation and winning, but it is widely felt they could not have won without their high name-recognition and their former major-party ties. ``The message is very guarded,'' said William Schneider, a political scientist at the American Enterprise Institute. ``It helps if you're a known quantity. Without a political party, you're on your own. It's sink or swim.''

DOC.HEAD: Magellan Finds Signs Venus Was Deluged by Gargantuan Lava Flows
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf pvs, `Head said ...' to CORRECT attribution to Saunders.
DOC.TEXT: The Magellan spacecraft has found evidence that ocean-sized floods of molten rock once inundated more than half the surface of Venus. NASA scientists said they don't yet know if there was one great outpouring of lava from cracks in Venus or a series of smaller flows, each hundreds of thousands of square miles, that engulfed parts of Venus at different times. The scientists at the space agency's Jet Propulsion Laboratory reported the findings Wednesday. Magellan uses radar to make pictures of cloud-covered Venus. The spacecraft was launched from space shuttle Atlantis in May 1989, went into orbit around Venus on Aug. 10 and formally began making maps and pictures of the planet on Sept. 15. Geologist Steve Saunders, Magellan's chief scientist, said he favors the view that the lava gushed out of cracks called vents in a global set of eruptions that happened all at once, maybe 400 million years ago. Brown University geologist and Magellan scientist Jim Head said, however, the evidence is incomplete. ``There's no question that the vast majority of the surface of Venus has been formed by lava flows and volcanic activity,'' he said. ``But the question is, did it all happen catastrophically?'' The lava covers roughly 60 percent of the planet, according to Saunders. Saunders said he began to suspect Venus was subject to such catastrophic volcanic activity because Magellan's pictures of Venus show the planet has fewer large meteorite impact craters than Earth's moon, and because ``the ones we find are all relatively fresh.'' That suggests ``there's a process of very widespread volcanism that occurs from time to time that destroys all the craters - and everything else,'' he said. Saunders said Venus' widespread lava flooding was similar to, but much larger than, vast lava deposits such as India's Deccan Traps and the Pacific Northwest's Columbia River basalts. The Deccan lava floods happened when Earth's crust split open as India drifted away from Africa about 66 million years ago, allowing huge volumes of molten rock to pour onto the landscape. The Columbia River basalts, which formed in massive eruptions roughly 12 million to 20 million years ago, cover much of the Pacific Northwest east of the Cascade Range. Magellan's $744 million map-making mission was suspended Oct. 26 because the sun is lined up almost directly between Venus and the Earth, impairing communications between controllers and the spacecraft. The suspension also was meant to allow engineers time to fix Magellan's wobbling solar power panels. NASA hopes to resume mapping Saturday.

DOC.HEAD: Government Throws Out 223 Over-the-Counter Drug Ingredients
DOC.NOTE: Eds: In 5th graf ``hyoscyamine'' is CQ
DOC.TEXT:
The Food and Drug Administration has banned 223 ingredients in over-the-counter drugs on grounds manufacturers have offered no proof they were effective for problems they were supposed to treat. The ingredients range from pine tar in dandruff fighters to dehydrated garlic in digestive aids to aspirin in medications for external use. The FDA action Wednesday does not ban the ingredients entirely, just in certain uses. For example, aspirin may still be used in products for pain relief taken internally, because it has been shown to be effective pain reliever. The over-the-counter drug industry said most of the ingredients already had been withdrawn, but some familiar drugstore and supermarket products will be affected. For example, Tegrin Lotion, sold for use against psoriasis, may no longer contain allantoin. Also Packers shampoo and soap may not contain pine tar, and Donnagel, used to treat diarrhea, may no longer include atropine sulfate, hyoscyamine sulfate and scopolamine hydrobromide. The ban becomes effective in six months. The agency said none of the ingredients posed a safety problem in any of the banned uses. The ruling is part of an 18-year-long review of about 300,000 nonprescription products that were on the market when a new took effect in 1972. As part of its effort to complete that review, the agency last week proposed to ban 111 drug ingredients in over-the-counter diet products. Most companies have stopped using those ingredients, industry officials said. Manufacturers have been on notice since May that the agency wanted to ban the list of 223 ingredients, and most have reformulated their products, said Jack Walden, a spokesman of the Nonprescription Drug Manufacturers Association. ``Overwhelmingly, this is a housekeeping action,'' he said. ``The industry long ago came into compliance ... It affects products now on the market very, very little.''
---
DOC.HEAD: President Calls Candidates
DOC.TEXT:
President Bush telephoned nearly 50 candidates around the country to offer either congratulations or condolences, officials said. White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said Bush was calling both winners and losers on Wednesday, ``wishing them every success in the years ahead.'' Bush made no public appearances. Fitzwater said Bush would continue making calls.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. to Withdraw All Jet Fighters From Philippines Base
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon says all U.S. jet fighters based in the Philippines will be withdrawn by next September. The announcement Wednesday came on the eve of a new round of negotiations on the future of American bases there. The 48 aircraft will be removed from Clark Air Base along with more than 1,800 Air Force personnel, leaving a U.S. military airlift command unit, training units and special operations forces at Clark, the Pentagon said. Between 7,500 and 8,000 U.S. Air Force personnel currently are based at Clark. In Manila, Philippine Foreign Secretary Raul S. Manglapus described the planned pullout as a ``partial victory.'' ``It's their privilege to withdraw,'' Manglapus said. ``It's certainly a step forward.'' He did not elaborate. Negotiations under way involve the future of Clark and five other American military facilities in the Philippines. A leasing agreement on U.S. use of the installations expires next September; Manila wants the U.S. military phased out by then, but the Bush administration has proposed a withdrawal period of 10 or 12 years.

DOC.HEAD: Documents: Late Emperor Said He Went To War Rather Than Face Coup
DOC.TEXT: The late Emperor Hirohito said shortly after World War II that he had not opposed attacking the United States because he feared civil war might otherwise break out in Japan, newly released documents indicate. In an eight-hour conversation with aides about his role before and during the war, Hirohito also rejected the Japanese tradition that reveres the emperor as a living god, Japanese media reported on Wednesday, citing the transcript. The conversation was held in spring 1946, when Allied occupation forces were considering whether to charge the emperor with war crimes. The discussions appear to have been part of preparations by aides for a possible trial. The Japan Broadcasting Corp. said the transcripts were recorded by Hirenari Terasaki, a former diplomat. Terasaki also translated for the emperor in some of his meetings with Douglas MacArthur, supreme commander of the Allies during the postwar occupation of Japan. The broadcasting corporation said that when Terasaki died, the transcripts of the conversation were given to his daughter, Mariko Terasaki Miller, who lives in the United States and recently rediscovered the documents. ``If I had tried to veto the beginning of the Pacific War, a coup d'etat would have occurred, and my trusted aides would have been killed. My life also could not have been guaranteed,'' Hirohito said. He was referring to fears of an uprising in Japan's powerful military. ``Even if that were acceptable, a violent civil war would have occurred, resulting in a tragedy several times worse than (World War II), and leading to circumstances that the war would not have ended. I believe that Japan would have been destroyed,'' Kyodo News Service quoted the transcripts as saying. He appeared to be referring to the possibility of a civil conflict between those Japanese who favored going to war and those who did not. Japanese officials met and decided to attack the United States shortly before the bombing of Pearl Harbor on Dec. 7, 1941. The radio network quoted Hirohito as saying he did not halt the war later because he feared the public might believe the government had given in to the United States, despite Japan's strong army and navy. Before he died in January 1989, Hirohito made few public statements about his role during the war. However, he had consistently said he did not intervene in the war plans because he could not, as a constitutional monarch, interfere in decisions made by the government. ``To my knowledge, I have not heard him say that (refer to a possible coup) before,'' said Otis Cary, a professor at Kyoto's Doshisha University and an acquaintance of the emperor. In contrast, Cary said, Hirohito took a strong role in 1936 in putting down a coup attempt within the army. ``But by December 1941, the situation was so tight. The military had complete hold on the government,'' Cary said in a telephone interview. ``The emperor just held his peace.'' The transcript quoted Hirohito as telling the five aides that it was ``troubling'' for him to be referred to as a living god. ``Biologically, I have the same body as ordinary people, so I am not a god,'' Kyodo quoted the transcripts as saying. Although Hirohito is considered to have renounced his divinity in a New Year's message in 1946, Japanese rightists have maintained he did not explicitly deny his prewar status as a Shinto God in the Japanese translation of those remarks. The comments were originally written in English and probably intended primarily for Western consumption. Critics charge that next week's enthronement ceremonies for Emperor Akihito, Hirohito's successor, will violate Japan's postwar constitution by once again linking the emperor with the Shinto religion. Akihito's formal coronation has been delayed more than a year by an official period of mourning.

DOC.HEAD: Filmmakers Scrambled For Screenplays During Studio Fire; Guard Arrested
DOC.TEXT: The fire that destroyed beloved movie sets at Universal Studios sent Steven Spielberg and other filmmakers at one of Hollywood's plushest mogul complexes scurrying to save precious scripts. Police on Wednesday arrested a security guard on suspicion of torching the studio and tourist attraction. Destroyed sets included those for ``Dick Tracy,'' the ``Back to the Future'' films and an unfinished Sylvester Stallone movie, ``Oscar.'' The blaze on the backlot Tuesday night came within several hundred yards of the Amblin Entertainment complex, a sprawling and luxurious Sante Fe-style adobe showpiece where Spielberg, Robert Zemeckis and other directors work. ``If the wind had shifted, we would have been in big trouble here,'' Amblin spokesman Marvin Levy said. Gusts up to 50 mph helped spread the fire. When homeowners flee flames they grab pets, photo albums and irreplaceable documents. When filmmakers do it, they take screenplays, artwork and other creations. Spielberg and his staff, along with other filmmmakers, made a dash through offices before getting out, Levy said. Spielberg focused his efforts on pre-production work for ``Hook,'' a tale based on the ``Peter Pan'' character Capt. Hook. Dustin Hoffman is slated for the title role, with Robin Williams scheduled to co-star. ``Oscar,'' a 1930s-era gangster comedy featuring Stallone as a mobster hounded by his father to go straight, had finished filming for the day before the fire broke out. ``We lost the entire set and are going to shut down for a week to 10 days. We have to build New York Street somewhere,'' said publicist Spooky Stevens. ``We also lost 21 vintage cars, the camera equipment, props, every bit of wardrobe.'' The guard, Michael J. Huston, 40, of Tujunga was booked for investigation of arson and jailed on $1 million bail. ``He was on duty when the fire started and after questioning he was arrested early today at the studio,'' said sheriff's Deputy Rich Erickson. ``We won't disclose a possible motive.'' How the fire was set also was not disclosed. Huston had been on the job one month, said Dan Slusser, general manager of Universal City Studios. Bob Gale, writer and producer of the ``Back to the Future'' films, told his assistant at Amblin to collect some artwork and a computer disk containing script revisions for ``Princess of Mars.'' Gale lamented the loss of the ``Back to the Future'' sets, where Michael J. Fox rode a futuristic skateboard. It was one of many popular stops on the Universal Studios tour. ``There's nothing there,'' Gale said. ``I couldn't believe it. You're just looking at this big expanse of nothing. It was a shock.'' Zemeckis, who directed all three ``Back to the Future'' films and ``Who Framed Roger Rabbit,'' heard of the fire as he sat down for a dinner party. ``I called my office and the phone machine was working so I knew there had to be a pretty good chance the building was OK,'' he said. The studio tour operated despite the damage Wednesday, and visitors got to see scorched sets from films like ``To Kill a Mockingbird,'' ``The Sting'' and TV's ``Kojak.'' ``The show must go on,'' a tour driver said. Some visitors said the fire gave the studio, the third most popular theme park in the nation, added appeal. ``We saw all the smoke last night,'' said Chris Bridge, traveling with his family of four from Australia. ``It was a great show.'' Favorite tour attractions survived, including the earthquake ride, the shark-snapping ``Jaws'' ride and the Bates Motel from ``Psycho.'' The King Kong exhibit and a burning house were not operating Wednesday. Officials expected to reopen them this week. Damage to the 75-year-old studio was expected to be in the millions, but no official estimate was given. Flames were doused before they could reach vaults that house the Universal film library.

DOC.HEAD: American Half of Chess Showdown Ends in Tie
DOC.TEXT: The 12th and final U.S. game in the championship chess match between Garry Kasparov and Anatoly Karpov ended in a draw, leaving the pair tied 6-6 in points as the duel moves to France for up to 12 more games. Each player won one game in New York. The 10 other games, including Wednesday night's, ended in draws. Only once in the previous 33 world championship matches have there been so many draws in the first 12 games: in 1978, when Karpov beat Viktor Korchnoi. The championship resumes Nov. 24 in Lyons, France. The first player to gain 12{ points wins the championship and $1.7 million of a $3 million purse. A win is worth a point, a draw a half-point. Grandmaster Patrick Wolff, who did commentary during the match, said the biggest surprise in the New York portion of the match was the inconsistency. The first five games could be considered the best opening quintet in world championship history, Wolff said. Games six through nine were ``terrible,'' and the final three were a slight improvement, he said. Wolff also said chess experts had expected Kasparov, the defending champion, to take a substantial lead. But Karpov surprised them. ``It's very unclear who's better now. It's getting hot,'' said international chess master Norman Weinstein. Danny Martin, a member of a New York City chess club, said the draws were expected. ``It's what happens when the best play the best,'' he said. Chess lovers paid $25 to $100 for tickets to watch the games in the Hudson Theater or on video monitors in the adjoining Hotel Macklowe, where grandmasters explained the moves in several analysis rooms. About 500 journalists covered some or all the matches. Wednesday's game ended after Kasparov's 37th move.

DOC.HEAD: Villagers Join Contras In Blockading Southeastern Nicaragua
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Former Contra rebels and their supporters have cut off the isolated southeast with roadblocks in a widening protest, demanding the government deliver the land and other aid it promised the ex-guerrillas. Last week, ex-Contras began erecting blockades on the only road that connects the southeast with other parts of the country. By Wednesday, they had gained the support of villagers along the route. The blockades have barred trucks carrying produce, grains, milk and beef to markets in Juigalpa and Managua, causing mounting losses to farmers in this rich agricultural and cattle-growing region. At least 20 former guerrillas staged a peaceful occupation Wednesday of Interior Ministry offices in Juigalpa, the midpoint on the strategic Rama Road between Managua and the Atlantic coast city of Bluefields, which is 150 miles east of the capital. Riot police ousted the occupiers later in the day. But in Bluefields, the city hall, a Roman Catholic church and a relay station for National Television - occupied non-violently on Tuesday - remained in control of ex-Contras protesting against President Violeta Chamorro's administration. To publicize their complaints, a group of demobilized rebels have also occupied Managua's cathedral since Monday. The former rebels have erected 14 roadblocks on the Rama Road in the past week, gaining increasing support from villagers as displeasure with the six-month-old administration speads throughout the region. The roadblocks reach as far as La Palma, some 75 miles east of Managua. ``We are not Contras, but we support the boys,'' said Efrain Rodriguez, 45, a farmer from La Palma. ``Violeta has got to deliver on what she promised. And these piricuacos have got to go.'' Piricuacos is an Indian word meaning ``curs,'' an insult opponents throw at the Sandinistas, whom Mrs. Chamorro defeated in Feb. 25 elections. The Sandinistas, who ruled for 10 years, remain the country's most powerful political force. Former members of the U.S.-backed Contra rebel force that fought the Sandinistas for nine years are demanding that they be given the aid promised in exchange for their having disbanded and returned to civilian life. They also want the Sandinista People's Army and the Sandinista police dissolved. In a process that ended in June, About 20,000 rebels accepted amnesty and turned in their weapons. They were promised land, food, medicines and materials to build simple homes in the countryside. Like the ex-rebels, anti-Sandinista civilians complain of harassment by police and soldiers, most of whom are Sandinista sympathizers. ``We want to see what the president promised. We want to see the army changed,'' said Wenceslao Centeno, 19, also of La Palma. ``They (army) threaten us all the time. This is not democracy.'' Interior Minister Carlos Hurtado on Wednesday invited the mayors of the blockaded region to meet with him in Managua today to resolve the crisis. Mayors of eight towns in the region are backing the former Conta fighters. The fact they belong to the 14-party coalition that helped bring Mrs. Chamorro to power indicates the extent of discontent with her government. Villagers allow only reporters and emergency medical cases to cross the roadblocks. ``We're ready for them to attack,'' said a woman at a roadblock near La Palma. ``We have no weapons, but we are ready to die. We're not going to let the government continue ignoring us.'' An attempt earlier this week to advance the blockade 10 miles west of La Palma was frustrated when police took over the entrance to Juigalpa, the most important town in the region. Juigalpa riot police showered tear gas on about 200 people Monday and beat them with nightsticks to disperse the protesters, who had started pushing large rocks across the highway. Four people were reported hospitalized with injuries. Since then, police and rmy units have set up roadblocks of their own, at Juigalpa and points west of the city, checking vehicles for weapons and asking drivers for identification and their destinations. The bishop of Juigalpa, the Rev. Pablo Antonio Vega, led a candlelight protest march of about 250 people through Juigalpa on Tuesday night. ``I recognize that everything that has been promised has not been delivered,'' Mrs. Chamorro said in a videotaped message broadcast on television Tuesday night. ``But I believe they (Contras) also have to recognize the causes that have prevented'' the fulfillment of the promises.'' The government is beset by a host of economic and political problems that threaten the country's stability. Mrs. Chamorro announced the formation of a third government commission aimed at setting up talks with the former rebels.

DOC.HEAD: Official: Imelda Offers Most Of Her Money In Hong Kong Banks
DOC.TEXT: Imelda Marcos has agreed to give the Philippines 60 percent of the money she has in five Hong Kong banks if the government drops a lawsuit against the former first lady in California, an official said today. David Castro, chairman of the Presidential Commission on Good Government, said President Corazon Aquino's administration will drop the $5 billion suit if its share of the Hong Kong money exceeds $200 million. Mrs. Marcos would admit no guilt to charges of embezzlement. If the agreement is carried out, it would be the first known settlement between the government and the Marcoses. Castro's agency has had little success recovering the billions the government claims Mrs. Marcos and her late husband, former President Ferdinand Marcos, stole during his 20-year administration. Castro told reporters he would leave later in the day for Los Angeles, where he is to appear in federal court Friday to explain the planned settlement. Mrs. Marcos's lawyer, James P. Linn, spoke of the arrangement in Los Angeles on Monday. Linn and the government's attorneys said they did not know how much money is in the Hong Kong accounts. Writer Reynaldo Fajardo, a confidant of Mrs. Marcos, told reporters at his own news conference that he witnessed signing of the agreement in Los Angeles last month. Fajardo said the accounts were in Standard Chartered Trustee Ltd., Hong Kong and Shanghai Bank, Wing Lung Bank, Wing Hang Bank and the Banque de l'Indochine et Suez. Castro said the government was prepared only to drop the California suit and not other legal moves against the Marcoses. The Los Angeles suit, filed in 1989, alleges Marcos and his wife stole $5 billion from the government during their 20 years in power. Castro said settlement would not provide for Mrs. Marcos to return to the Philippines. The Marcoses left the country during the 1986 civilian-military uprising that toppled the Marcos administration and propelled Mrs. Aquino to power. Marcos died September 1989 in Hawaii. Mrs. Aquino refused to allow him to be buried in the Philippines and banned his family from coming home.

DOC.HEAD: Ship Catches Fire, Report That 100 Missing Erroneous
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES thruout with initial report of 100 missing erroneous. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A two-year-old girl was killed and two people were missing after a ferry caught fire in the southern Philippines on Wednesday, the Coast Guard said. The Coast Guard earlier said 100 people were missing after the Tandag sank off the coast of Cortes town, about 510 miles southeast of Manila. Coast Guard spokesman Lt. Danilo Corpuz later said the report was erroneous and blamed the error on poor communications. He said another vessel, the Surigao Del Sur, was actually involved. He said the 491-ton vessel's engine room caught fire at about 7 p.m., causing panic among passengers who jumped off the ship. He said the accident occured about 1.5 miles off the coast of Cortes. He said fishing boats and Coast Guard vessels were able to rescue 145 passengers and 48 crew members before dawn Thursday. He said the ferry left the port of Tandag on its way to the central city of Cebu, about 180 miles northwest. Corpuz said the initial radio report to Manila by a remote Coast Guard station early Thursday indicated 100 out of 130 passengers were missing. He said the confusion was caused by poor communications between Manila and the Coast Guard station.

DOC.HEAD: World Chess Championship: The Scene Leaves New York
With PM-Chess Showdown
DOC.TEXT: If American crowds have trouble keeping quiet at tennis matches, it's hard to see chess catching on here as a spectator sport. Chess fans have to sit on their hands. There are no hot dog or beer vendors. You can't shout ``exd4!'' or ``Bf6!'' And most matches end in a tie. The U.S. Open here two months ago was raucous compared to the inside of the Hudson Theatre on Wednesday, as titleholder Garry Kasparov and Anatoly Karpov played to a draw in the last game of the U.S. half of their world championship chess match. Chess folk take their quietness seriously. As they followed Game 12 - watching the players in person and on video screens and listening to running commentary via headsets - spectators would occasionally murmur at an audacious move. Immediately, their neighbors shushed them and the words ``Silence Please'' flashed on the largest screen. For stage presence, Kasparov and Karpov are no John McEnroe and Jimmy Connors. Both players sat at the board, leaning forward, heads in hands. Kasparov occasionally jiggled his right foot. There was no dialogue and there were certainly no tantrums. Nobody threw any chess pieces. In a whimsical touch, the stage was flanked by giant cutout chess pieces that looked like illustrations from Lewis Carroll's ``Through the Looking Glass.'' Although known for their dislike of one another, the champion and challenger were polite during the 12 matches in New York. Most of the time, the two took turns sitting down. As one pondered his move, the other would wait offstage. Chess does have its share of excitement, though. On Wednesday, after move number 31, the pace picked up considerably. Because of the time rules, Karpov was left with only nine minutes to make his next nine moves, while Kasparov had 20 minutes left for the same number of moves. For this, both sat at the table. For those fans who can't take the silence, the analysis rooms in the adjoining Hotel Macklowe offer a diversion. There, the chess buffs follow the game on monitors while grandmasters provide color commentary. In Lecture Room 5.08, grandmaster Roman Dzindzichashvili was holding forth energetically. ``I think absolutely terrible move by Karpov!'' he said. ``Absolutely terrible!'' Another kibitzer shouted, ``Do you think he didn't see bishop E6?'' ``No, he saw bishop E6,'' Dzindzichashvili said. ``He just underestimated.'' Lack of TV coverage of this year's championship is a sore point for true chess fans. Syndicated columnist Shelby Lyman was host for the move-by-move coverage of the 1972 championship between Boris Spassky and Bobby Fischer on PBS. ``I have three, four, five people come up to me every day asking, `Why aren't you on TV?''' Lyman said. ``Some of them are almost crying.'' If the United States is not agog with the championship - which began Oct. 8 and resumes Nov. 24 - the Hotel Macklowe, at least, was buzzing with nothing else. In lounges and on elevators, people talked chess in a dozen languages. ``It's exciting to be in a chess milieu,'' said Steve Shapiro of New York. ``When you're playing, you're with a buddy or in a club. Rarely are you part of a chess scene. There are lots of scenes in this town, and chess ain't one of them.'' For their patience and good behavior, the spectators - who paid from $25 to $100 per ticket to attend Game 12 - were rewarded with a draw. Ever polite, the audience waited a few seconds before applauding. The players shook hands with each other and with match officials and withdrew, silently. The best-of-24-game match now moves to Lyons, France, tied 6-6 in points.

DOC.HEAD: Abortion: Philosopher Advocates Law Defining Brain-Birth
DOC.TEXT: A philosopher grappling with the morality of abortion says the beginning of protected human life should be defined in terms similar to those used in declaring a person brain-dead. The concept is not entirely new, but making it law would be, Hans-Martin Sass of the Kennedy Institute of Ethics in Washington told colleagues at a conference here this week. His so-called Uniform Determination of Life Protection Act would permit abortion until the 70th day after conception, when some normal brain functions begin, Sass said. After the 70th day the fetus would be a protected human life. Brain-death is the legally recognized termination of human life, defined by cessation of brain activity. Establishing the 10-week timetable for fetuses would mark the earliest onset of fetal brain development, or brain-life, Sass said. ``The absence of brain-specific cells in early embryonal development could be understood as the absence of brain-life,'' Sass said. Under those conditions, ``abortion of inanimate life must be legally protected.'' Sass is a senior research fellow at the Kennedy Institute and professor of philosophy at Georgetown University. He also is co-director of the Center for Medical Ethics in Bocum, Germany. He proposed the act at a University of Iowa symposium that ended Wednesday. About 60 medical, ethics and legal experts from 15 countries attended the four-day symposium examining the question of when life actually begins. ``In strong contrast to the consensus regarding the end of life, we do not have a uniform understanding regarding the beginning of human life, which has to be morally recognized and legally protected,'' Sass said. ``For strong moral, as well as cultural, legal and political reasons, I argue for a Uniform Determination of Life Protection Act.'' People would be free to use contraception or have an abortion within the 70-day timeframe. Abortions are now legal in the United States through the sixth month of pregnancy, or later if the woman's health is threatened.

DOC.HEAD: Moody: Quiet Man with a History of Trouble in the Courts
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Mail Bombings, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Walter Leroy Moody Jr., indicted in the mail-bomb assassinations of a federal judge and a Savannah alderman, is a self-employed editor who was convicted in 1972 of possessing a pipe bomb. Moody emerged as a suspect in February, when it was disclosed that FBI agents searched his home in Rex, a small town rapidly becoming part of Atlanta's southern suburbs. According to his mother, Moody is a ``bookworm.'' An attorney of his, Michael Ford, says he's a quiet man ``who very much desires to be left alone.'' But the quiet man at least twice before has tried to kill people, prosecutors say. And he has stayed in the news this year in connection with the bombings, other legal problems and even a plan to cash in on his misfortune. In Florida, Moody was charged in 1983 with three counts of attempted murder. Prosecutors said he bought insurance policies on three divers he then tried to kill during a photo project in the Gulf of Mexico. The case ended in a deadlocked jury. Before the indictment on Wednesday, Moody, 56, already was imprisoned without bond on federal bribery, perjury and obstruction-of-justice charges stemming from his 1972 case. He is scheduled to go on trial Nov. 26. His 28-year-old wife, Susan, also charged in the bribery-obstruction indictment, has petitioned for divorce. Moody said in court papers filed in March that another man - an Atlanta paramedic and former private investigator, not publicly identified - is the person ``probably responsible'' for last December's mail bombings. By July, Moody was outlining plans to cash in on his notoriety by selling T-shirts and soliciting screenplays. He said proceeds from T-shirts with logos including ``Moody Motion Pictures'' - a company that didn't exist - would be used to finance a movie about his travails. Moody also created an Associated Writers Guild, a company put out of business by the U.S. Postal Service in June for fraudulent claims. A psychiatric evaluation requested by federal prosecutors in connection with the bribery-perjury case found ``there may be reasonable cause to believe'' Moody is mentally ill. A psychiatrist who treated Moody in the late 1960s described him as ``the type of individual who could sell you the Brooklyn Bridge.'' Moody, a native of Fort Valley in middle Georgia, served two years in the U.S. Penitentiary in Atlanta after his 1972 conviction. Prosecutors contended he planned to send a bomb and an extortion note demanding $65,000 to a dealer who had repossessed his car. But the bomb exploded when his then-wife, Hazel, opened the package, injuring her. Moody appealed to vacate his conviction in 1988, contending that new evidence showed he was innocent. But the appeal was denied the following June by a three-judge panel of the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals. Six months later, a judge on that court, Robert S. Vance, was killed when a package bomb exploded in his suburban Birmingham, Ala., home. Vance was not one of the three judges who ruled on Moody's appeal. But he had served on two court panels that did consider cases involving Moody: one that rejected his appeal over the dismissal of a Florida lawsuit and one that heard arguments in August 1989 on a second appeal. Two days after Vance's Dec. 16 assassination, Savannah alderman and civil rights lawyer Robert Robinson was killed by a bomb at his law office. Along with his history of trouble in the courts, Moody has something of a legal background. He attended John Marshall Law School in Chicago for two years in the late 1960s and represented himself in at least one appeal.

DOC.HEAD: 1990 Election in Brief
Retired Pro Wrestler Defeats 18-Year Incumbent in Mayor's Race
DOC.TEXT: Jesse ``The Body'' Ventura, a retired pro wrestler, pinned 18-year Mayor Jim Krautkremer at the ballot box. Unofficial results of Tuesday's election showed Ventura elected mayor with 12,728 votes to 7,390 votes for Krautkremer. Ventura, 39, who retired from the ring in 1986, wore a goatee, earrings and feather boas during his wrestling days. Now cleanshaven and a more sedate dresser, he got into politics when this Minneapolis suburb of 50,000 proposed development in a marsh near his home. Campaigning for slow-growth development, expanded recycling and a two-term limit for city officials, Ventura waged his race for the four-year office mostly through yard signs. He and Krautkremer never debated. Krautkremer, who advocated more aggressive development, said before the election that Ventura's only involvement in the community had been the marsh fight. ---
DOC.HEAD: Former NFL Quarterback Loses Bid For House Seat
DOC.TEXT: Former National Football League quarterback Oliver Luck was sacked in his bid for a seat in Congress. Democratic Rep. Harley Staggers got 56 percent of the vote to keep his 2nd District seat. Luck, a Republican, got 46 percent. ``Unfortunately, in elections, like hand grenades and horseshoes, close doesn't count,'' Luck said. The Staggers family has held the seat for 40 of the past 42 years. Staggers' father, Harley O. Staggers Sr., held the seat from 1948 to 1980. Luck, 30, a Morgantown lawyer, played for the NFL's Houston Oilers. ---
DOC.HEAD: Tony La Russa Just Can't Win This Year
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also moved on sports wires.
DOC.TEXT: Tony La Russa just can't seem to win this year. No, not THAT Tony La Russa. After all, Oakland Athletics manager La Russa can at least claim an American League championship, even if his team was swept in the World Series by the Cincinnati Reds. But a man named Tony LaRussa lost his bid Tuesday for a seat in the state House. The independent candidate lost 77 percent to 23 percent to Terry Van Horne, a Democrat who has represented the Pittsburgh-area district since 1981. ---
DOC.HEAD: Man Defeats Wife i State's Attorney Race
DOC.TEXT: Bruce Selinger beat a familiar candidate in his bid for another term as Slope County state's attorney - his wife. Selinger won by a nearly 3-to-1 margin. Brenda Selinger withdrew from the race in October, but her name appeared on the ballot Tuesday. She got 119 votes, her husband 337. Mrs. Selinger filed to get on the ballot because she and her husband were unsure who wanted the job more. She said she wanted the job because the hours are part-time and she has a 2-year-old child. But she has since found part-time work.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Higher, Tokyo Stocks Fall
DOC.TEXT: The dollar surged against the Japanese yen today, while Tokyo share prices plunged for the third consecutive day. The dollar closed at 129.50 yen, up 1.95 yen from Wednesday's close of 127.55 yen. It opened at 129.20 yen and ranged between 128.95 yen and 129.70 yen. Trading totaled $13.92 billion, up from Wednesday's $12.646 billion. The dollar's early strength stemmed from British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's remarks Wednesday that Iraqi troops would be removed forcefully if they did not withdraw from Kuwait, dealers said. At midmorning, however, market players became uncertain about the dollar's trend, Bank of Tokyo dealer Naohiko Yasuda said. ``Trading became totally directionless today, but the dollar was no longer in a continuing down-trend,'' Yasuda added. He said the dollar was weaker than other major currencies, but the yen was even weaker, mainly because of political uncertainties resulting from the government's lack of leadership in deciding Japan's role in the Middle East. Other dealers said growing concern about Mideast tensions, especially before the three-day weekend in Tokyo, helped spur buying of the dollar, seen as a safe haven in times of international crisis. Japan's financial markets will be closed Monday for Emperor Akihito's enthronement. Dealers said there also was demand for dollars to pay for oil purchases. Japan imports virtually almost all of its oil, of which 70 percent comes from the Middle East. On the stock exchange, the 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average lost 530.44 points, or 2.26 percent, closing at 22,969.81 after narrowing its losses by about 100 points in the afternoon. The index now has fallen 1,415.52 points, or 5.8 percent, in three days. Volume on the first section amounted to some 360 million shares, up slightly from Wednesday's 330 million. Traders said investors held off buying today because of fears of war in the Persian Gulf, in addition to discouraging economic factors including a weaker yen, falling bond prices and the overnight plunge in the Dow Jones Industrial Average in New York. ``Nobody wanted to buy amid the poor performances in the yen and the bond prices, especially just ahead of a three-day weekend,'' said Yoshiro Inoue, an analyst with Nomura Securities Co. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds fell to 84.26 points at 5 p.m. (3 a.m. EST) from Wednesday's 84.59-point finish. Their yield rose to 7.875 percent from 7.800 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Sexual Activity Jumps Among Teen-age Women in the Eighties
DOC.TEXT: The proportion of American teen-age girls and women having sex climbed in the 1980s, but the pregnancy rate changed little because of increased use of condoms, a study found. ``All the publicity about using condoms has had some impact,'' said Susheela Singh, co-author of the Alan Guttmacher Institute study released Wednesday. The study of sexual behavior from 1982 to 1988 also found one of every five teen-agers having sex in 1988 used no birth control. Among poor teen-agers, one in four failed to use contraceptives during intercourse and one-third of all young women are still unprotected from pregnancy the first time they have sex, the study found. The proportion of girls ages 15 to 19 who had sexual intercourse rose from 47 percent in 1982 to 53 percent in 1988, the study found. The increase was greatest among whites and in higher-income families. In 1982, the proportion of whites who were sexually active was 45 percent, compared to 52 percent in 1988. The increase among teen-agers in families with income of more than 200 percent of the poverty line was from 40 percent to 50 percent. ``The levels of sexual activity were already high among non-white and poor girls,'' Singh said. ``The white and non-poor are catching up as attitudes change and become more liberal.'' The study found that 58 percent of the overall sexually active group reported having intercourse with two or more partners. According to the study, 48 percent used a contraceptive method at first intercourse in 1982, mainly a condom, compared to 65 percent in 1988. Regular condom use jumped 25 percentage points to 47 percent, it said. ``Thus male involvement in contraceptive use at first intercourse increased substantially,'' the study found. The study also found that 57 percent of all pregnancies conceived in 1987 were unintended. While that is about the same as in 1982, the proportion of unintended pregnancies terminated by abortion fell, from 54 percent in 1982 to 50 percent in 1987. Among teen-agers, there were 127 pregnancies per 1,000 women in both 1982 and 1988, according to the study. The institute's study is based on data released in the spring by the National Center for Health Statistics. The National Survey of Family Growth compiled the 1988 data from interviews with 8,450 women; a total of 7,969 women were interviewed in 1982.

DOC.HEAD: Scientists: Comet Dust May Have Seeded Life on Earth
DOC.TEXT: The chemical building blocks for life on Earth may have arrived aboard comet dust, two scientists say. The NASA scientists examined a discovery made in Denmark last year to develop the hypothesis reported in today's issue of the British journal Nature. Kevin Zahnle and David Grinspoon of NASA's Ames Research Center at Moffett Field in California tried to explain the discovery of ancient soil that contained concentrations of amino acids believed to have come from outer space. Amino acids are vital to life, combining to form proteins and other organic structures. The buried amino acids in Denmark appeared in strata above and below a layer of the element iridium, which some scientist say marks the impact of a huge meteorite that killed off the dinosaurs 65 million years ago. The scientists who found the amino acids suggested that they had arrived on the meteorite, an idea that met with some skepticism. Zahnle and Grinspoon suggested instead that the meteorite was only a chunk of a large comet that created a dust cloud rich in organic molecules. Dust from this cloud deposited the amino acids in the soil before and after the meteorite struck, they propose. A similar rain of organic molecules far earlier in the planet's history could have provided the raw materials for life, Grinspoon theorized in an interview.

DOC.HEAD: Special Election Considered Boost for De Klerk
DOC.TEXT: President F.W. de Klerk's National Party easily won a special parliamentary election considered a referendum on his efforts to end apartheid, results showed today. Residents of the affluent suburb of Randburg, north of Johannesburg, gave National Party candidate Marthinus Van Schalkwyk 10,882 votes to 1,969 for Leonie Steele of the pro-apartheid Conservative Party. Van Schalkwyk had been expected to win in traditionally liberal Randburg. He replaces the resigning Wynand Malan of the anti-apartheid Democratic Party. The Democrats did not contest the seat. The larger question was whether South African whites backed de Klerk's dramatic reforms, such as releasing black leader Nelson Mandela, legalizing opposition groups and eliminating parts of the apartheid system of segregation and white dominance. The Conservative Party favors strict racial segregation and considers de Klerk a traitor for attempting to negotiate power-sharing with the black majority. De Klerk said Wednesday's balloting ratified his reforms. ``I think the exorbitant claims of support by the Conservative Party have been disproved,'' the president said Thursday. Before the election, the Conservatives predicted they would receive a substantial shift in support from National Party voters. Only a small shift occurred. In the 1989 general election, 755 Randburg residents supported the Conservative candidate, compared with some 6,000 for the National Party candidate and 8,000 for Malan. The Conservative vote more than doubled Wednesday, but fell short of the 12 to 17 percent swing predicted by party leaders. Despite the drubbing, Conservative leader Andries Treurnicht proclaimed victory. He noted the combined National Party-Democratic Party vote in 1989 exceeded 14,000, while Van Schalkwyk received less than 11,000 Wednesday. Similar results nationwide would give the Conservatives victory in a whites-only election, he said. The Conservative Party has most of its support in rural and blue-collar areas. Amber Solomon, 19, said she wanted to avoid the Conservative Party ``at all costs.'' ``I can't understand how they can still want to racially discriminate,'' Solomon said after voting. ``The country's going through a transitional stage, no doubt about it. The Conservative Party seems to be terrified of that.'' The National Party now holds 95 elected seats in the dominant white chamber of Parliament. The Conservative Party has 39 and the Democrats have 32. There also are chambers for Asians and people of mixed race, but not for the black majority.

DOC.HEAD: Irish Folk Singer Tom Clancy Dead at 67
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with two grafs to CORRECT name in second graf. Picks up 3rd, `After serving ...'
DOC.TEXT: Tom Clancy, an actor and member of folk music's influential Clancy Brothers, has died of cancer at age 67. Clancy died on Wednesday at Mercy Hospital in Cork, his family said. After serving as a radio officer with the Royal Air Force during World War II, Clancy became an actor. He worked with a touring British Shakespearean repertory theater before moving to New York for Broadway and off-Broadway roles. Clancy was praised for his work in the plays of Eugene O'Neill. It was in New York in 1959 at the beginning of the folk music boom that the Tom, Paddy, Liam and their friend Tommy Makem formed their group. Bobby Clancy also occasionally sang with the group, which was considered a major influence on the current folk music revival in Ireland. Clancy continued to act through the height of the Clancys' singing fame. He appeared in the film ``Airport'' and television series ``Starsky and Hutch,'' ``Little House on the Prairie'' and the ``Incredible Hulk.'' Clancy returned to Ireland five years ago and settled into semi-retirement in Ring, County Waterford, where Friday's funeral will be held. Clancy was the second in a family of 11 children. His elder brother, Paddy, was with him when he died. Liam and Bobby Clancy were expected to cut short a U.S. concert tour to return to Ireland for the funeral. Clancy is survived by his wife Joan and their four daughters.

Lawrence Durrell, a British author and poet whose chief work was the four-part ``Alexandria Quartet,'' died at his home in southern France at age 78. The cause of his death was not disclosed. Durrell held a number of official and diplomatic posts from 1941 to 1958, a life he spoofed in two novels: ``Esprit de Corps'' (1958) and ``Stiff Upper Lip'' (1959). His 1938 novel ``The Black Book'' was about decadence. ``Alexandria Quartet'' consisted of ``Justine,'' ``Balthazar,'' ``Mountolive`` and ``Clea,'' published from 1957 to 1960. He also wrote several volumes of poetry. Durrell died in Sommieres, where he had lived since 1966.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Up, Gold Lower
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rose against all major foreign currencies today in early European trading. Gold prices were lower. Dealers said speculation that Western forces will launch strikes against Iraqi troops in occupied Kuwait boosted the dollar, which is considered a safe haven investment in times of trouble. British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's statement of willingness to use force against Iraq and the decision to increase U.S. troop strength in the Persian Gulf left traders ``uncomfortable'' without dollars in their trading portfolios, a trader in Frankfurt said. In Tokyo, the dollar rose 1.95 yen to a closing 129.50 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a higher rate of 130.00 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Wednesday: -1.4960 German marks, up from 1.4820 -1.2575 Swiss francs, up from 1.2435 -5.0170 French francs, up from 4.9715 -1.6823 Dutch guilders, up from 1.6712 -1,124.50 Italian lire, up from 1,113.75 -1.1675 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1627 In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.9580, compared with $1.9760 late Wednesday. London's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended gold price of $386.30 per ounce at midmorning, from $387.25 bid per ounce late Wednesday. In Zurich, the bid price was $386.20, down from $386.75 late Wednesday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose $2.67 to close at a bid $386.31. Silver traded in London at a bid price of $4.26 a troy ounce, from Wednesday's $4.28.

DOC.HEAD: Rain and Snow in Northeast
DOC.TEXT: Rain and snow fell in parts of the East early today, and temperatures dipped into the 20s across the northern Plains and Midwest. Rain also fell in Boise, Idaho, and central Texas. Snow mixed with freezing rain was forecast for New Mexico and Texas. Showers were expected along the Washington coast, and flurries were likey along the Idaho-Wyoming border. Snow fell in Buffalo, N.Y., and Portland, Maine, early today, and rain fell in New York state and Boston. The nation's high on Wednesday was 90 degrees at Fort Myers, Fla. DOC.HEAD: Interior Minister Warns of Retaliation
DOC.TEXT: Iraq's interior minister said today that the multinational forces in Saudi Arabia will all be targeted by Iraq's forces if U.S. troops initiate an attack from Saudi soil, the official Iraqi News Agency said. The minister, Latif Nassayif Jassim, was reacting to the new Saudi-U.S. agreement on the command structure for joint military action. The agency quoted him as saying: ``We will retaliate on any American aggression against Iraq, and all the allies of the American forces in Saudi Arabia will be our target.'' More than 300,000 troops have massed in the kingdom to stand up to Iraq after its Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. They include some 230,000 Americans. Secretary of State James A. Baker III reached agreement with Saudi leaders earlier this week that in the event of military action against Iraq, U.S. officers would command their own troops. A joint U.S.-Saudi command would be retained in the event of an Iraqi incursion into the kingdom. ``This agreement confirms the plot which we warned of before, the real agressive and imperialist aims of the American and Western presence in Saudi Arabia, and exposes Saudi Arabian-American claims and lies that Iraq is threatening Saudi Arabia,'' Jassim was quoted as saying. ``We repeated many times that there are no Iraqi threats to Saudi Arabia.'' Jassim said that if an attack is launched on Iraqi forces from Saudi Arabia ``We will make all Saudi lands where these foreign forces are now stationed a battlefield,'' INA reported.

DOC.HEAD: Lemuel Boulware, Developer of `Boulwarism' Bargaining Technique, Dead at 95
DOC.TEXT: Lemuel Ricketts Boulware, who devised management's one-offer formula for labor negotiations that became widely known as ``Boulwarism,'' has died at age 95. Boulware died Wednesday at his home in Delray Beach, Fla., the General Electric Co. reported. Boulware took charge of employee relations for G.E. in 1947, a year after the company had gone through a devastating strike. He quickly developed what became known as Boulwarism, a practice he said was designed to improve labor-management relations by showing employees that the company wanted to do what was right voluntarily.
