Under Boulwarism, G.E. would listen to union demands, compare wages and benefits at other companies and make an offer from which it would not budge during further negotiations. The policy flowered in the 1950s and '60s, but fell out of favor after G.E. was hit with a nationwide strike in 1969 and several court rulings that went against Boulwarism. Boulware, who retired from G.E. in 1961, graduated from the University of Wisconsin in 1916, and later served as an infantry captain in World War I. He also taught accounting and commercial law at the University of Wisconsin, Florida Atlantic University and the Plymouth Institute night school in New York. He also wrote the books ``The Truth About Boulwarism'' and ``What You Can Do About Inflation, Unemployment, Productivity, Profit and Collective Bargaining.'' His wife, Norma, died in 1987, and there are no immediate survivors.

DOC.HEAD: Brothers Elected Sheriff in Neighboring Maryland Counties
DOC.TEXT: Norman and Robert Pepersack are brothers - and now the're also brothers in law. The two men were elected sheriffs in Maryland counties Tuesday - Norman in Baltimore County and Robert in neighboring Anne Arundel County. Their victories continued a family tradition of law enforcement. Robert, 49, is a 25-year veteran of the state police and commander of the firearms licensing section. That's the same job Norman, 56, had before he retired about six years ago. Their grandfather, Mathias Pepersack, was the first Maryland state trooper - assigned badge No. 1 in 1920. Their uncle, Vernon L. Pepersack was warden of the state penitentiary and corrections commissioner. Robert Pepersack said he and his brother, both running as Republicans, found a way to save money on their campaigns. ``We used the same sign,'' he said. ``It said Pepersack for Sheriff.''

DOC.HEAD: Entomologists Find Butterfly Thought Extinct
DOC.TEXT: Entomologists say they want endangered species protection for a recently rediscovered butterfly that experts believed had been extinct for more than 50 years. Paul Hammond, an Oregon State University entomologist and butterfly expert, said he rediscovered the butterflies by accident. ``In the spring of 1989 I hiked out onto a south-facing slope of a hill that had native prairie on it, and here was this very unusual kind of lupine plant with all these little blue butterflies swimming around on it. ``I knew immediately what it was,'' he said. It was Fender's blue butterfly, a relic of the ice ages found only in Oregon's Willamette Valley. The butterfly was last seen near the small town of Wren, west of Corvallis, in 1937. Since that find last year, several pockets of the species have been found in western Oregon. A petition is being prepared to ask the U.S. Fish and Wildlife to declare the butterfly a threatened species under the federal Endangered Species Act. Hammond said the butterfly has a wingspan of only about 1 inch. The male is a ``brilliant, iridescent blue,'' he said. ``They really stand out. The female is a drab brown.'' The butterfly dates back more than 10,000 years, Hammond said. Surrounded by glaciers to the north and mountains to the south, east and west, the butterfly's habitat was limited to a small area of the Willamette Valley.

DOC.HEAD: Family of Suspect Shocked at Kahane Assassination
DOC.TEXT: The Egyptian-born American who allegedly killed militant Rabbi Meir Kahane was described by his father in interviews published today as a caring son who shied away from politics. ``I can't imagine he did that,'' said Abdel-Aziz Nosair, whose son el-Sayyid A. Nosair was charged with murder following Tuesday's assassination in a New York hotel. Cairo's three major government-owned newspapers today published interviews with the elder Nosair in his home at Port Fouad, across the northern tip of the Suez Canal from Port Said. The son, identified by authorities in the United States as a native of Port Said who immigrated from Egypt in 1981, took U.S. citizenship last year. He was seriously wounded after the Kahane shooting when he exchanged gunfire with a U.S. Post Office policeman, who also was wounded. On Wednesday, as police from Egypt's Interior Ministry stood guard at the Nosair house in Port Fouad, the ministry in Cairo denied that the Kahane assassin was Egyptian. Ministry officers said a check of records in Port Said turned up no one with his name. Abdel-Aziz Nosair told the newspaper Al-Akhbar that a day after Kahane's slaying, government intelligence had summoned him to ask about his son. He said he was asked ``whether I had heard from him recently and whether any family members were even remotely connected to any political activites.'' The questioners never indicated why they were interrogating him, Nosair said. He said he later read in newspapers that his son was a suspect in the assassination. The newspaper said Nosair chain-smoked cigarettes nervously as he and another son, Ahmed, talked with Al-Akhbar. Attempts today to contact the family in Port Fouad were unsuccessful. Journalists said government security agents had ordered family members not to talk after they met with local reporters. In the Al-Akhbar interview, the reporter asked Nosair his feelings about Kahane, a U.S.-born Israeli who rejected his American citizenship to serve in the Knesset, Israel's parliament. Kahane was a founder of the Jewish Defense League and advocated deporting Arabs from Israel and the occupied territories. ``From what I read, he was strongly fanatical against all Arabs,'' the elder Nosair said. ``No doubt what happened to him is God's vengeance. I can't really describe my feelings now.'' Nosair said he was certain his son had no links with Palestinian groups and that he was never politically active. But he said: ``I believe his Egyptian and Arab friends (in the United States), with their feelings that America is biased toward Israel, may have led him to commit this act against a leading Jewish extremist.'' The suspect in the Kahane killing had worked for the last two years for the New York City Department of General Serivces as an airconditioning and heating maintenance man. He lived in Cliffside Park, N.J., where his neighbors described him as quiet and devoutly Moslem man. He married an American woman who converted. From all accounts, he was not politically active. Al-Ahram, the only Egyptian daily with greater circulation than Al-Akhbar, played down Nosair's Egyptian background. It carried only a brief statement from his father on the suspect's education and what is described as his apolitical life.

DOC.HEAD: Camp Pendleton Fire Partially Contained
DOC.TEXT: Firefighters partially contained a wind-whipped brushfire that has blackened at least 7,000 acres on a Marine Corps base after temporarily halting train service and closing Interstate 5. Cpl. Lamont Peabody, a Camp Pendleton spokesman, said early today that the 2-day-old fire was 50 percent to 70 percent contained. No injuries have been reported, and the only damage found was slight singeing of structures at the Border Patrol checkpoint on I-5. ``The fire is burning in direction they want it to, toward the southeast and toward the fire breaks,'' Peabody said. Fire officials on the lines haven't indicated when they expect to have the fire under control, Peabody said. It broke out Tuesday night in the northern part of the sprawling base; the cause has not been determined. About 500 firefighters from San Diego and Orange counties and Camp Pendleton were fighting the blaze, aided by aircraft dropping fire retardants and water, said base spokeswoman Capt. Rose Ann Sgrignoli. About 20 miles of I-5 between Oceanside and the Orange County line was closed for much of Wednesday when high Santa Ana winds caused flames to jump the freeway and set the median on fire. The Pacific Railway line that parallels I-5 also was ordered shut down for about nine hours Wednesday. The fire initially forced the temporary evacuation of about 300 trailer park residents and a dozen workers at the San Onofre Nuclear Power Plant. Southern California Edison Co. spokesman David Barron said the fire had threatened nuclear power plant buildings on the east side of I-5 as well as the facility's three generators west of the freeway, but none was damaged.

DOC.HEAD: U.S.-Phillipines Talks on Future of Air Bases Show Progress
DOC.TEXT: American and Philippine officials reported progress today in talks on the future of U.S. military bases after Washington agreed to remove all combat planes from the Philippines. In a joint statement, the two sides said they discussed security issues related to the bases but gave no details. ``Progress was so great that the panels will be working into the evening hours,'' the statement said. On Wednesday, U.S. special negotiator Richard Armitage told Foreign Secretary Raul Manglapus that Washington would remove its 48 combat aircraft along with more than 1,800 Air Force personnel from Clark Air Base, one of six installations in the Phillipines. Manglapus has said the Philippines wants to take control of Clark when the current bases agreement expires in September 1991. The status of the Subic Bay naval base and the other installations are subject to negotiation. The bases are technically Philippine property but are effectively under American control. They are among the oldest and largest U.S. installations on foreign soil. The Manila Times reported today that the Philippines had drawn up a 154-page draft agreement allowing the Americans continued use of key facilities at the bases for a limited period after September 1991. In return, the Philippines wants preferential trade agreements, duty free access to U.S. markets for selected goods, guaranteed purchases of Philippine sugar, unspecified loans from the U.S. Export-Import Bank, debt relief, increased investments and other economic concessions, the newspapers said. As the talks resumed, a dispute emerged within the Philippine government over its negotiating tactics. On Wednesday, Health Secretary Alfredo Bengzon, the panel's co-chairman, contended the United States was using loans and aid to pressure the Philippines into an agreement. He said several Philippine officials were siding with the Americans, including the military chief of staff, Gen. Renato de Villa. Diplomatic sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the controversy reflected concern within the government that the panel's tough stand was endangering relations with the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Defendant's Friend Testifies for Prosecution In Jogger Case
DOC.TEXT: A defense lawyer in the Central Park jogger trial suggested prosecutors bought the testimony of a woman who told the court a teen-age defendant told her he didn't rape the woman but did fondle and hold her legs. Melody Jackson, 29, gave the most damaging evidence against Kharey Wise so far when she testified Wednesday about a telephone conversation they had in July 1989. Jackson, a Wise family friend who has known him since he was 8, said she spoke to Wise for about 15 minutes when he called the home of her sister, apparently from the jail where he has been held on $50,000 bail. ``I said, `Kharey, I don't believe what I've been hearing. I don't believe you had sex with that woman,''' Jackson said during her tearful testimony. ``He said, `Mel, I didn't have sex with her. The only thing I did was touch her legs,''' Jackson told the court. On cross-examination by Wise's lawyer, Colin Moore, Jackson said Wise told her he ``held and fondled'' the woman's legs. Moore attacked Jackson as a liar. He suggested she was testifying for money, a plea deal with the prosecution or perhaps for publicity as the trial's star witness. The lawyer asked Jackson why she had waited so long to come forward. She answered that she had not ``come forward,'' but had been approached by prosecutors and later subpoenaed, giving her no choice but to cooperate. Moore and Howard Diller, lawyer for co-defendant Kevin Richardson, said Lederer told them about Jackson just minutes before she was to appear. Also Wednesday, prosecutors introduced a statement in which Richardson said a scratch on his face was made by the jogger. In the statement, Richardson denies raping the woman. Wise, 18, and Richardson, 16, are the second group of defendants to be tried on charges of rape, attempted murder, sodomy, assault, robbery and riot in the attack on the woman jogger and two men on April 19, 1989. Three other teen-agers were convicted in August of rape, assault and other charges in the attacks on the joggers, but acquitted of attempted murder. All were sentenced to five to 10 years in prison. The sixth defendant, Steven Lopez, 16, will be tried separately on the same charges early next year. The 30-year-old victim, who testified at the trial last week, was found near death in Central Park. She has returned to work as an investment banker, although hampered by vision and balance problems.

DOC.HEAD: Gandhi Backs Government Bid by Dissident Politician
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with Gandhi's party backing Chandra Shekhar to form a new government.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-India-Singh, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Former Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's Congress Party announced today it will support a bid for power by a leftist politician who helped lead a historic no-confidence vote that brought down the government. Gandhi's decision to back Chandra Shekhar and not seek the prime minister post himself cleared the way for President Ramaswamy Venkataraman to ask Chandra Shekhar to form a government, a Congress Party spokesman said today. Earlier today, Venkataraman had asked Gandhi if his Congress Party was able to form a government. The declaration by Ghandi capped a day of meetings following Prime Minister V.P. Singh's defeat Wednesday in a 346-142 Parliament no-confidence vote. It was the first time an Indian government was ousted by Parliament since the country won its independence from Britain in 1947. Singh's 11-month-old government collapsed under a wave of religious and caste violence and political bickering. Chandra Shekhar, a veteran, left-leaning politician, led the faction that broke away from Singh's centrist Janata Dal party and opposed him in the vote. ``The party has decided to suppport Mr. Chandra Shekhar from outside,'' Congress Party spokesman V.N. Gadgil told a news conference today. ``That has been conveyed to the president.'' Gandhi, when asked why he was not willing to form a government himself, said: ``I don't think we will be able to put together a stable government on our own.'' No single party in Parliament's policy-making lower house has a majority. By agreeing to support Chandra Shekhar from outside the government, Gandhi and his Congress Party can make or break the new government but would not hold any Cabinet posts. Gandhi could use the opportunity to prepare his own party for new elections. Chandra Shekhar's dissident faction of the Janata Dal party had only 56 votes in the 522-member Parliament when the vote agianst Singh was taken. The Congress Party has 195 seats, and its allies have another 15. Singh remains caretaker prime minister until a new government is formed. Venkataraman could call new elections, but most major parties are reluctant to face a campaign at a time when the country is in political, sectarian and ethnic turmoil. Singh's coalition government was shaken by continued separatist struggles in Kashmir and Punjab states, rising prices and by Singh's program to raise the government job quota for low-caste Hindus. The job-quota policy led to violent demonstrations and a wave of suicides among upper-caste Hindus. The government was ultimately crippled last month when a right-wing Hindu party withdrew from the broad Singh-led coalition in protest over a shrine claimed by both Hindus and Moslems. About 370 people have been killed since in sectarian riots or clashes with police. About 82 percent of India's 880 million people are Hindus, while 12 percent are Moslem and 2 percent are Sikh.

DOC.HEAD: WALTER MEARS: What's Hot in 1992? Could be the Drive to Limit Politicians' Terms
An AP News Analysis
DOC.NOTE: EDs: CORRECTS 18th graf, bgng, But there ... to make year 1980, sted 1960; Moved Nov. 7 as b0118, PM-Walter Mears, for use today
DOC.TEXT: It started as a sleeper among issues, but the drive to limit politicians' terms is awake and kicking now, and the people pushing the idea say they'll seek to put it on at least 15 state ballots in 1992. Claiming headway in both the victories and frustrations of Tuesday's off-year elections, term-limit campaigners will meet in Washington early next month to talk about their next steps. While the immediate target is the state legislatures, their ultimate aim is to limit tenure in Congress. Term limits were approved Tuesday in Colorado and California, the two states that had the issue on the ballot and, for good measure, in Kansas City, Mo., which put a ceiling on city council tenure. Oklahoma voted for term limits earlier in the fall. And then 95 percent of the House incumbents who ran again won again, an outcome one strategist said would help the push for limits. ``Even in an anti-incumbent year, you can't beat 'em,'' said Eddie Mahe, a Republican campaign consultant and advisor to Americans to Limit Congressional Terms. It is largely a Republican movement, although some Democratic candidates signed on during the campaign. Measures that force turnover would work to GOP advantage; they are outnumbered in the legislatures as in Congress, and Democrats have just extended their House control to 38 years. Proposed constitutional amendments to limit congressional tenure to 12 years have, predictably, gone nowhere in Congress. The measure approved in Colorado on Tuesday would apply to members of Congress as well as state officeholders, and therefore it is certain to be challenged in court. So the political pressure point is in states, especially those that hold direct elections on such questions. Elsewhere, Mahe said, the term limit drive will be pressed in the legislatures, where lawmakers may be loath to limit their own tenure but likely to approve a call for limits in Congress. That might just offer some openings for ambitious state lawmakers who'd like to get to Washington. In the three states that have approved term limits, the voters overrode opponents who insisted that limits are no cure for the ills of government, state or federal, and could make them worse. Strong, seasoned legislators would be dismissed along with weak ones, the opponents say, while bureaucrats and lobbyists would gain even more clout. ``I think term limits is really a reaction against the fact that so many of our congressional elections, and our other elections, are not really competitive,'' said Gov. Richard F. Celeste of Ohio, chairman of the Democratic Governors' Association. Mahe said that when, and if, more states impose limits, or at least call for them nationally, Congress will start to feel the political heat. ``Once those are in place at the state level, the pressure at the national level is going to be geometrically increased,'' he said. ``This is going to be an issue,'' says Vice President Dan Quayle. ``You had the tax revolt in the 1970s and early 1980s, and in the 1990s, I think, you're going to see the voter revolt.'' Campaigning for Republican candidates this year, both Quayle and President Bush pushed term limits. The 1988 Republican platform endorsed limits on House and Senate tenure, without saying what the ceiling should be. Quayle says he favors 12 years. ``All around this country there is a growing momentum for limiting terms of legislators,'' Bush said before the elections. ``...Term limitation is an idea whose time has come, and I think its time has come to Capitol Hill, frankly.'' Quayle built part of his set campaign speech around the issue. ``The chairman, listen to this, the chairman of the House Appropriations Committee has been in the Congress longer than my mother and father have been married. He had seven years of seniority when I was born,'' he would say, drawing ripples of laughter. ``I tell you, there is an idea that is sweeping this country, and that is the idea that it is time to limit the terms...'' The chairman, Rep. Jamie L. Whitten, D-Miss., just won his 26th term. But there is turnover, for all the power of incumbency, and more than 60 percent of House members have been elected since 1980. Mahe said the organizations pushing term limits will seek commitments from House candidates in 1992 that they won't seek to serve more than a dozen years in Congress. ``When they're running for the first time, 12 years looks like a long time,'' he said. To a veteran, though, it doesn't look that long. Former Sen. Eugene J. McCarthy, who also served in the House, once recalled that he'd arrived as a foe of the seniority system. But the longer he stayed, McCarthy said, the more he saw the wisdom of it. --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Walter R. Mears, vice president and columnist for The Associated Press, has reported on Washington and national politics for more than 25 years.

DOC.HEAD: Gov. Jim Florio Takes Blames For Democratic Election Losses
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Jim Florio took responsibility for the Democratic Party's election losses and close calls in New Jersey, and said parts of his bitterly disputed $2.8 billion tax package may be rewritten as a result. ``I got the message that the results were really directed at me,'' Florio said at a news conference Wednesday. ``It was a strong message, a humbling message.'' The backlash by New Jersey taxpayers nearly cost U.S. Sen. Bill Bradley his bid for re-election to a third term Tuesday. Bradley, considered nearly invulnerable, barely fended off a challenge from little-known Republican Christine Todd Whitman, who lost by fewer than 55,000 votes. Florio, who wasn't on the ballot because he was elected governor just last year, said that in the wake of Bradley's close call, elements of his tax legislation were open to possible changes, particularly the school funding formula. In his first six months in office, Florio raised the state income tax for wealthy New Jersey residents and increased the state sales tax from 6 percent to 7 percent. The higher income tax, which goes into effect Jan. 1, will pay for a complex program of property tax relief and higher funds for the state's disadvantaged schools. Republican leaders touted the election results as a repudiation of the Democratic Party under Florio. Top GOP legislators repeated their call for a repeal of the tax package. ``He just spawned an electoral disaster for his own party,'' GOP State Chairman Bob Franks said. Florio conceded that he might have pushed his agenda too fast and without regard for opinions outside his administration. At his news conference, Florio stopped well short of saying he would consider repealing any of his tax legislation. But the governor repeatedly said the school aid formula might be modified and that he would discuss his administration's policies with Democratic legislative leaders. ``Everything is on the table for people who are responsible and constructive,'' Florio said in response to a question about the school funding formula. State Senate Minority Leader John Dorsey said Republican leaders have acknowledged the need for higher taxes to increase revenue for poor school districts to comply with a state Supreme Court ruling. But Dorsey disputed the size of the tax increase needed to comply with the ruling. In its ruling, issued in June, the court said that New Jersey's system of using property taxes to fund schools was unfair to poor districts and unconstitutional. The state has until July 1991, to devise a plan to improve the funding for disadvantaged schools.

DOC.HEAD: Controller's Error Blamed in Near-Collision
DOC.TEXT: A passenger jet nearly collided with a small plane over downtown Chicago last week because of an air traffic controller's error, the Federal Aviation Administration says. The crew of a United Boeing 737, en route to Seattle from Chicago on Nov. 1 with 96 passengers, reported a ``near mid-air collision'' with a Cessna 172, FAA spokesman Mort Edelstein said Wednesday. The jet came within about 1,300 feet of the small plane horizontally and 200 feet vertically, the FAA said. Federal guidelines require a minimum separation of 1.5 miles horizontally and 500 feet vertically. The second plane was a law enforcement plane, said Donald Zochert, another FAA spokesman. But he declined to identify the agency that operated it. A preliminary investigation indicated the controller had planned to turn the jet but apparently failed to issue the order fast enough, Edelstein said. The controller was removed from his position and has undergone retraining, the FAA said.

DOC.HEAD: Virginia Chain Gang Fugitive Fights Extradition
LaserPhoto NY11
DOC.TEXT: Charles A. Kelliher's 40 years a fugitive from a Virginia chain gang have come to an end, but he says he has paid society all it has coming and at least 100 of his friends agree. Kelliher's past caught up with him last week when federal marshals knocked on the door of his Brooklyn apartment. Diane Kelliher, his wife of 20 years, said she ``had no idea. I was shocked about the whole thing.'' Kelliher was taken to a New York City jail, where he has been held without bond since Oct. 31. The 59-year-old former moonshine runner and self-described hell-raiser, said he fled a prison road crew in 1950 when he was a 19-year-old rowdy from Manassas. ``We were out on a highway cleaning ditches,'' Kelliher said Wednesday. ``Something happened on the other side of the road and the guards turned and I took off.'' Kelliher had served only a few months of a 22-year sentence when he fled to New York. He had been convicted of getting drunk, breaking into the county courthouse and stealing his own car, which police had confiscated when they caught him hauling illegal whiskey. ``I thought he had lost his mind - 22 years!'' he said of the judge. Virginia authorities - who have a program to locate long-missing fugitives - enlisted the help of federal law enforcers who, after hours of stakeouts and computer record searches, traced Kelliher to his Bay Ridge apartment. Donald Zimmerman, of the Virginia Department of Corrections in Richmond, said the state still wants Kelliher to serve the 21 years, eight months he owes. Kelliher, with the help of attorney Philip A. DiPippo, who learned of his case through news reports, is resisting extradition. ``I don't owe anybody anything. I've damn sure paid my dues,'' Kelliher said. ``This to me is truly all unnecessary,'' he said. At a hearing Wednesday, Criminal Court Judge Seymour Gerschwer said he had no jurisdiction in the matter and sent the case to the state Supreme Court. Some two dozen of Kelliher's friends - many he met through Alcoholics Anonymous - attended the hearing to show support for Kelliher. For 10 years, Kelliher has been sober and has helped and inspired recovering alcoholics, his friends said. Friend Bettyann Seccia said Kelliher and his wife ``have helped me tremendously.'' A petition submitted to the court with more than 100 signatures described Kelliher as ``a man of conscience and heart. Through the years that we have known him, he has been an exemplary role model for all of us.''

DOC.HEAD: Alleged Associate of Mobster Gotti Killed
DOC.TEXT: A man believed to be a close associate of reputed organized crime boss John Gotti was found shot to death in a Mercedes-Benz on the side of a road, police said. Edward Lino was found slumped inside the car Tuesday night, said Sgt. Nick Vreeland, a police spokesman. He had been shot at least nine times in the chest and face. Lino, 48, had been tried three times on charges of drug racketeering, accused of dealing heroin and cocaine. He was acquitted once and the other two trials ended in mistrials. Detectives say they believe Lino, who lived on Long Island, was driving home through the borough of Brooklyn when he stopped his car to talk to his killer. He apparently stepped on the gas and tried to get away when the killer opened fire, police said. The car crashed into a fence. Police said they did not have a motive for the killing. But New York Newsday and the New York Post reported law enforcement sources as saying that Lino was probably killed because of involvement with drug dealing, which was once taboo in organzied crime circles. The Post quoted sources as saying that Lino became a ``made'' member of the Gambino crime family when Gotti allegedly took control after the death of Paul Castellano in 1985. In February, Lino was acquitted on charges that he and two co-defendants conspired to distribute heroin for a drug ring managed by Gotti's brother, Gene. Gene Gotti was convicted and sentenced to 50 years in prison. Lino was also a defendant in two other federal drug racketeering cases that ended in mistrials because of alleged jury tampering.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Officer, Arab Guerrilla Killed in Clash on Border
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with Israeli commander saying Jordanians were linked to security establishment, more quotes from Israeli officials. CORRECTS to seven number of previous infiltration attempts from Jordan. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: An Israeli army officer and a Jordanian guerrilla were killed today in a firefight on the banks of the Jordan River, the army said. Four other Jordanians were captured and two were wounded. The guerrillas - who were armed with pistols, knives and copies of the oran - were planning to stage an attack on Jerusalem, the regional Israeli commander, Maj. Gen. Yitzhak Mordechai, told Israel radio. He also said the men had ``links to the Jordanian security establishment.'' Another officer said at least four were policemen, but it was not immediately clear if the guerrilla killed was an officer. All five of the Jordanians wore civilian clothes. The predawn clash occurred north of Jericho in the occupied West Bank, military officials said. The infiltrators were detected after they broke through a security fence. Mordechai said the Oct. 8 Temple Mount shooting in Jerusalem which killed 20 Palestinians ``may have been an incentive'' for the infiltration. He also suggested the Persian Gulf crisis could have had an influence. Many Palestinians in Jordan have been strong supporters of Saddam Hussein. Defense Minister Moshe Arens said the Persian Gulf crisis has burdened Jordan's King Hussein and suggested ``perhaps this influences his control over certain things.'' ``I want to believe the Jordanians are doing all they can to prevent infiltrations,'' Arens said. ``But this isn't the first time they haven't succeeded.'' Capt. Yehuda Lifshitz was killed in the clash, the army said. He was to be buried in his hometown north of Tel Aviv later today. There have been at least seven other infiltrations or attempted infiltrations blamed on Jordanian soldiers or police in the past two years. In August, a Jordanian soldier was killed and another was captured after they crossed into Israel. A Jordanian soldier was captured in Israel in April trying to cross the border. Israel captured the West Bank from Jordan in the 1967 Middle East war. The area is home to about 1 million Palestinians and about 70,000 Jewish settlers.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Said To Draw Up Resolution For Use of U.N. Force in Iraq
With PM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: U.S. officials have prepared a resolution authorizing U.N. military force against Iraq but are not introducing the measure until they are sure they have enough votes for passage, diplomats have said. Secretary of State James A. Baker III is abroad lining up key support for the Security Council resoution, the diplomats said Wednesday on condition of anonymity. He was visiting Moscow today after a quick tour of several Middle Eastern nations. ``We know they've got it on paper, but it would be absurd for them to pass it around until they've got all the crucial support lined up,'' one official said. In Washington, U.S. officials close to the situation confirmed the account. They also spoke on condition of anonymity. If approved, the U.S. draft resolution would mark the first time the Security Council approved U.N. military force under a joint military command. Iraq has defied 10 Security Council resolutions. They include an embargo on trade with Iraq, and demands that Baghdad free all foreign hostages, withdraw unconditionally from Kuwait and allow the restoration of Kuwait's government. Baker said in Turkey that Iraq's invasion of Kuwait ``is, after all, the first real crisis of the post-Cold War era, and it is very important that when the United Nations takes action and passes resolutions, those resolutions and the act be implemented.'' Baker flew to Moscow on Wednesday to continue his diplomatic initiative on the Persian Gulf crisis, which includes rallying support for the use of U.N.-sanctioned military force. He then travels to Paris and London. Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze, in a Sept. 25 speech to the General Assembly, hinted at a U.N. military operation, saying: ``The United Nations has the power to suppress `acts of aggression.''' On Tuesday, Chinese Foreign Minister Qian Qichen indicated to Baker that his country would not oppose a resolution authorizing a military strike to force Iraq out of Kuwait, U.S. officials said. Qian, who met for two hours with Baker in Cairo, did not explicitly approve sending troops into action. ``We'll have to wait and see,'' Qian told reporters. China is one of the five U.N. Security Council members with veto power over resolutions; the others are the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union. Iraq seized oil-rich Kuwait on Aug. 2 and then annexed the emirate. In response, the Pentagon has sent 230,000 U.S. troops to the region, among a multinational force of more than 300,000. They face about 430,000 Iraq troops deployed in Kuwait and southern Iraq. The new U.S. draft resolution marks the first time the Security Council would approve of U.N. military force under Article 42 of the U.N. Charter. Article 42 permits the council to ``take such action by air, sea, or land forces as may be necessary to maintain or restore international peace and security.'' ``Such actions may include demonstrations, blockade, and other operations by air, sea, or land forces of Members of the United Nations,'' it says. The Security Council has never had a unified military command; the closest approach was during the Korean War, when it authorized the United States to command the U.N. forces repelling North Korea's invasion. That was only possible because the Soviets were boycotting the Security Council to protest Taiwan's being seated as the delegation from China.

DOC.HEAD: Man Acquitted Of Sparking 1988 Hells Canyon Blaze
DOC.TEXT: A camper has been acquitted of criminal negligence for accidentally igniting a 9,000-acre forest fire in Hells Canyon by burning his used toilet paper. U.S. Magistrate Mikel Williams found Philip J. Arnold innocent Wednesday in connection with the Aug. 20, 1988, blaze in the Payette National Forest, which took more than two weeks to control. Williams noted that campfires were not banned at the time, and ruled that Arnold, of Santa Barbara, Calif., was not aware of the substantial risk of fire during that drought-plagued summer. In addition, he said, the Forest Service's evidence did not prove Arnold committed a criminally reckless or negligent act. Part of Arnold's defense was based on the fact that camping books and even some Forest Service maps instruct campers to burn their toilet paper after use. However, Payette National Forest Supervisor Sonny LaSalle said, ``The only safe way to deal with human waste is to bury it.'' He said toilet paper will decompose if it is put in a 6-inch-deep hole and covered with dirt.

DOC.HEAD: Red Square Shooting Suspect Charged With Terrorist Offense
DOC.TEXT: Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze today said the shooting incident near Soviet leaders in Red Square should not be taken very seriously, but officials charged the suspect with a terrorist offense. The incident occurred Wednesday just 80 yards from President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and other officials during Revolution Day celebrations to mark the 73rd anniversary of the Bolshevik Revolution. No one was injured. The gunman, identified as Alexander A. Shmonov, 38, was being held in custody today on charges of ``committing a terrorist act,'' said Aleskei Kandaurov, deputy director of the KGB's public relations office. The suspect is an unemployed metal craftsman who was last employed at the Izhorsky metal working factory in Leningrad, Kandaurov said. Kandaurov could not confirm a report by one newspaper that the gunman was carrying a light explosive in addition to a hunting rifle. He confirmed the man was carrying at least one device, but said laboratory tests have not confirmed whether it is an explosive. The suspect, charged by the Moscow's chief prosecutor, will undergo psychiatric tests, Kandaurov said. He gave no other details. A plainclothes officer knocked the gun away from the man after Shmonov fired once into the air and into the ground, newspapers said. ``I don't think this incident should be taken very seriously,'' Shevardnadze said before meeting with U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III. ``This is a huge country where something is always happening somewhere.'' Newspapers today were filled with glowing reports about the celebrations across the country, but gave only brief reports of several large protest rallies around the nation. Pravda criticized the rallies as ``extravagant escapades verging on simple hooliganism.'' The newspapers also offered few new details about the shooting near the Lenin Mausoleum, where Gorbachev stood with other officials to watch the festivities. The conservative labor newspaper Trud said the suspect was carrying a small explosive usually used for military rehearsals and that could cause no serious damage. ``It is hard to tell now whom he was aiming at. But one thing is clear: if it were not for the immediate reaction of a policeman, who succeeded in knocking the gun into the air, a disaster might have happened,'' the paper said in a short page-one report. During the celebrations, Gorbachev stood near officials including Russian President Boris N. Yeltsin and Moscow Mayor Gavriil Popov.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Army Names Head Of Elite Troops As New Chief of Staff
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 4 grafs to RAISE HIGHER speculation about dissension in the Iraqi military. Pickup 3rd, `The sacking...'
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi President Saddam Hussein has dismissed his military chief of staff, prompting Western officials to speculate there is dissension among Iraqi military leaders about the invasion of Kuwait. Saddam replaced Lt. Gen. Nizar al-Khazraji with the commander of the elite Republican Guards, the Iraqi army newspaper and U.S. officials said today. Western analysts with considerable knowledge of Iraq's military said the move could indicate opposition to holding onto conquered Kuwait in the face of the growing U.S.-led multinational force and U.N.-imposed sanctions. The officials in Washington said it might even indicate opposition to Saddam's decision to invade the oil-rich emirate on Aug. 2. The sacking of Khazraji, a hero of the 1980-88 Iran-Iraq war, came amid mounting U.S. and British warnings that force might be used to dislodge the Iraqis from Kuwait if necessary. ``It's very ominous,'' said Hans-Heino Kopietz, a former analyst with London's International Institute for Strategic Studies, now with Control Risks, an international security firm in London. ``It's not wise to change horses in midstream at this point in time. Khazraji's dismissal now is indicative of some opposition to Saddam within the military, who after all may have to take on the multinational force,'' said Kopietz. He has just returned from a lengthy Middle East tour. The Iraqi army newspaper, Al-Qadissiya, named the new chief of staff as Gen. Hussein Rashid, but did not say when he was named to replace Khazraji. It mentioned Rashid's new title in a report of a graduation ceremony he attended at Baghdad's military academy on Wednesday. In Washington, officials confirmed Khazraji had been replaced by Rashid. They said Khazraji was replaced because he objected to the invasion. Khazraji has been made a special military adviser to Saddam, believed a demotion for the military commander, the officials said. ``Khazraji was promoted to a non-job,'' said one official. The U.S. officials spoke on condition of anonymity. Khazraji had been chief of staff since 1985 and was one of the top officers in Saddam's inner circle of military advisers. ``It's very odd,'' said analyst Shahram Chubin of the Geneva-based Graduate Institute of International Affairs and author of books on the Persian Gulf war. ``It's very easy to speculate. It's not yet clear why Saddam's done this, but he's taking a big gamble,'' he said. Rashid was Khazraji's deputy and commanded the 120,000-strong Republican Guards, Saddam's best troops who are considered loyal to him and form a virtual separate army within the million-strong army. The Republican Guards spearheaded the invasion of Kuwait. During the gulf war, Rashid commanded an armored division with some success. He is believed to be from Takrit, Saddam's birthplace north of Baghdad. Saddam has packed the hierarchy of the ruling Baath Arab Socialist Party with relatives, by blood or marriage, who come mainly from Takriti clans. Rashid's appointment is the second known top-level change in Baghdad in the past two weeks. Oil Minister Issam Chalabi was fired on Oct. 28 and replaced on an interim basis by Brig. Gen. Hussein Kamel, Saddam's cousin and son-in-law who is also minister of Industry and Military Industrialization. Kamel, who is also from Takrit, has been responsible for developing Iraq's arms industry and producing new surface-to-surface missiles. Chalabi was purportedly replaced after he imposed gasoline rationing because of shortages prompted by the U.N. trade embargo. That order was later rescinded and officials denied there was any shortage. But Kopietz noted: ``There was more to Chalabi's dismissal than meets the eye. He's a moderate, close to the West and the oil industry where he was widely respected. He was understood to be trying to persuade Saddam from pursuing his strategy of confrontation.'' ``It may well be that there's growing opposition to Saddam within the Iraqi hierarchy,'' Kopietz added. Iraqi dissident groups have reported several purges of senior officers since the invasion, possibly because the officers disapproved and because Saddam apparently miscalculated how the West would react. There has been no independent confirmation of reports that officers have been executed or imprisoned. But Saddam has regularly purged senior officers whom he suspected could threaten him since he took power in 1979. Analysts believe this opposition heightened after Saddam, seeking to secure Iraq's border with Iran as his international isolation increased, made concessions to Iran on Aug.15. He agreed to Iranian demands to withdraw his forces from territory seized in the closing stages of the Iran-Iraq war and to share sovereignty of the Shatt-al-Arab waterway on the southern boundary between the two countries. Kopietz said at the time: ``It must have been a bitter pill for the army to swallow. They must have wondered what the hell they'd fought the Iranians for eight years for.'' Chubin said today: ``I'm sure there's considerable disquiet in the military, who're not necessarily all convinced Takriti Baathists.''

DOC.HEAD: Georgia Man Indicted in Fatal Letter Bombings That Spurred Wave of Terror
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs the last 2 grafs with 6 to update with report O'Ferrell's wife identified Moody's wife in lineup. Arraignment, orignally set for 1:30, now scheduled for 3:30 p.m. EST.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: Civil rights leaders breathed easier with the indictment of a Georgia man in a series of mail bombings that killed a federal judge and an NAACP lawyer and put the South on edge just before Christmas last year. The indictment, unsealed Wednesday, also accuses Walter Leroy Moody Jr., a 56-year-old self-employed editor, of sending racist, threatening letters. He was to be arraigned in federal court today. The bombings and threats spread a wave of pre-Christmas terror that had lawyers, judges and civil rights officials contacting authorities when they received unexpected packages. ``We are relieved that federal authorities believe that a suspected perpetrator has been identified, and cautious that no other persons are or may be implicated,'' said Earl Shinhoster, Southeast director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. He said the bombings ``created a climate of uneasy apprehension for many of us in the civil rights community that will not be easily abated even with the indictments.'' Moody, for months a leading suspect in the case, was charged in the slayings of appeals Judge Robert Vance of Mountainbrook, Ala., on Dec. 16, 1989, and civil rights lawyer Robert Robinson of Savannah two days later. The nail-packed bombs bore marked similarities to one that Moody was convicted of possssing in 1972, federal authorities said. They said all three bombs were constructed by a method not used in any of more than 10,000 bombs they had examined over the years. The indictment also accuses Moody of sending bombs to the 11th U.S. Circuit courthouse in Atlanta - Vance was a member of the 11th Circuit - and to the NAACP in Jacksonville, Fla. Those two bombs were safely defused. In addition, Moody was charged with sending dozens of threatening letters to NAACP officials, lawyers, judges and TV stations, and with sending a tear-gas bomb that went off at the NAACP's Atlanta office. U.S. Attorney General Richard Thornburgh and FBI Director William Sessions, who announced the indictment in Washington, said authorities believe Moody acted alone. Officials declined to say what his motive might have been, but it has been speculated that racism or revenge against the judicial system prompted the attacks. Moody is white, as was Vance. Robinson, a Savannah city alderman who did legal work for the NAACP, was black. The letters, some signed ``Americans for a Competent Federal Judicial System,'' said the killings were in retaliation for court decisions on school desegregation and black-on-white crime. They threatened more violence against lawyers, judges and the NAACP. Six of the charges, including murder of a federal judge, carry up to life in prison. Moody's attorney, Bruce Harvey, charged that the indictment lacked evidence linking his client to the crimes. ``We need to see some facts,'' he said. ``We need to see some hard evidence.'' Moody, described by his lawyer as a quiet man ``who very much desires to be left alone,'' has been known to be a prime suspect in the case since FBI agents searched his home in Rex in February. Robert Wayne O'Ferrell, an Enterprise, Ala., junk dealer who wrote numerous letters to the 11th Circuit, had also been a suspect. Authorities declined to say if he has been cleared, but his lawyer, Paul Harden, said O'Ferrell had been told Wednesday he is no longer a suspect. Thornburgh declined to say what, if any, relationship Moody had with O'Ferrell. Police at one time believed that O'Ferrell had been in possession of the typewriter used to write the letters that followed the bombings. O'Ferrell's wife, Mary Ann O'Ferrell, picked Moody's wife, Susan, out of an FBI lineup in Alabama Oct. 18, identifying Mrs. Moody as the woman to whom she sold a typewriter in the spring of 1989, Jefferson County, Ala., Sheriff Mel Bailey told The Birmingham News. Bailey was out of his office this morning and Anthony Bishop, a lawyer for O'Ferrell, declined to comment on the lineup report. Mrs. Moody's lawyer, Sandra Popson, would not confirm that her client participated in the Bessemer, Ala., lineup. On Oct. 19, Mrs. Moody filed for divorce. Moody and his wife have been in custody since July, when they were indicted on perjury and witness tampering charges involving his 1972 bomb conviction. That bomb was intended for an auto dealer who had repossessed Moody's car, but Moody's first wife mistakenly opened the package and was seriously injured, authorities said.

DOC.HEAD: Palestinian Kills Israeli Arab Prison Guard, Kahane Supporters Detained
DOC.TEXT: A Palestinian stabbed to death an Israeli Arab prison guard today, and police detained seven followers of slain Rabbi Meir Kahane on suspicion of incitement after they vowed to avenge his death. One of those detained, Yekutiel Ben Yaakov, said in his eulogy that Kahane's men would ``let our friend the submachine gun, our friend the knife, talk for us.'' Kahane was assassinated by an Arab in New York on Monday. The Kahane supporters were arrested at the Jewish Idea seminary run by the late extremist rabbi's Kach movement, a spokesman said. Police said the seven were being held on suspicion of incitement. Meanwhile, police guarded Israeli Arab leaders, Jewish leftists and journalists after they received death threats from supporters of the anti-Arab Kach movement. Police said four shots were fired outside the home of the mayor of the Israeli Arab town of Shfaram on Wednesday. Today's fatal stabbing occurred in Jenin prison in the occupied West Bank, a military source said. The victim, a Druze guard, was attacked by a Palestinian visiting an inmate. The incident was the latest in a rash of knifing attacks by Palestinians following the Temple Mount killings last month in which 20 Arabs were killed by police during riots. In the occupied Gaza Strip, soldiers shot and wounded an Arab after he tried to stab a soldier at a roadblock. The soldier escaped unharmed because he was wearing a flak jacket, Israel radio said. The army said that in the wake of the knifings, it has begun issuing the padded jackets to some soldiers, including those manning roadblocks and standing guard in the occupied territories. The Haaretz newspaper, meanwhile, quoted a Kach leader as saying the group had drawn up a hit list. Security officials told the daily that Kahane's heavily armed followers may go underground to organize attacks. Mayor Ibrahim Nimer Hussein of Shfaram said police have warned him he might be in danger. He said a police van passes by his house at regular intervals, and police frequently call him to make sure he is all right. Israeli Arab legislator Wahab Abdel Daroushe said he received a call from someone who identified himself only as a ``good Israeli.'' ``He said that `Kahane's people have put you on their list and decided to kill you,''' Daroushe said, adding that police posted guards outside his home. Another Israeli lawmaker, Yossi Sarid of the left-wing Citizens Rights Movement, reported receiving death threats, and said police were guarding him. ``I'm a target and I know it,'' Sarid said. ``The mood now is very tense. If you look at the reports about Kahane's funeral, one name was mentioned specifically by the crowd - my name.'' During the funeral, attended by 15,000 people, hundreds of Kahane supporters went on a rampage attacking Arabs, stoning police and smashing shop windows. At one point, scores of rioters stoned and beat members of an Israel television crew. ``Suddenly you find yourself a target for the mobs,'' television reporter Benny Liss told army radio. ``Worse than the blows is the humiliation. They pulled off my skullcap.'' Another journalist, Sima Kadmon, wrote conservative Maariv daily today that she was shocked by the hatred at the funeral. ``I covered (Arab) demonstrations full of hatred and violence, and I swear by our God and their God that I was never as afraid as yesterday in the streets of Jerusalem,'' she wrote. Few Palestinian workers came to Jerusalem, apparently out of fear or as part of a two-day general strike beginning today to mark the one-month anniversay of the Temple Mount riots.

DOC.HEAD: Students Demonstrate Against Ershad, 20 Injured
Laserphoto DHA-1
DOC.TEXT: Anti-government demonstrators demanding the resignation of President Hussain Muhammad Ershad fought with police today, exploding homemade bombs in the center of the capital. Riot police fired rifles in the air and used tear gas and steel-tipped batons to disperse the protesters, who were mostly students, according to journalists at the scene. They said at least 20 people were slightly injured by police. The trouble began after police blocked a march by about 3,000 people toward Ershad's office, erecting barbed wire barricades over a one-mile perimeter from the building. The students threw stones, and police responded with truncheons. Witnesses said the students retreated in groups and began rampaging through the streets. At least 30 cars, jeeps and buses were damaged, reporters said. Police fired in the air and lobbed tear gas shells near Dhaka College, and students responded with homemade explosives. Opposition political parties, with wide student support, are campaigning for Ershad to quit before elections are held next year. The opposition contends the three elections held since Ershad seized power in a bloodless coup in 1982 were rigged. Ershad, a former general, has refused to step down before the election, which he intends to contest. Eight anti-government protesters were killed in demonstrations last month.

DOC.HEAD: Albanian Leader Calls for Amendments on Party's Role, Religion
DOC.TEXT: Albanian President Ramiz Alia said his hard-line Communist country should rethink enshrining the Communist Party's leading role and policy of atheism in the constitution, the state news agency said. Alia, who is trying to introduce cautious reforms and bring his Balkan country slowly out of self-imposed isolation, also decried bureaucracy and a lack of discipline while calling for stronger rule of law. The comments by Alia, head of the Communist Albanian Labor Party, to the party's Central Committee appeared to be another cautious step toward reform. The speech also seemed timed to influence a Paris summit that will decide later this month whether to admit Albania to an all-European system of cooperation and human rights. In the speech reported by the ATA news agency on Wednesday, Alia did not say the Communists should give up power or legalize a political opposition, nor did he suggest a specific constituional ammendment. The constitution refers to the party as the ``only leading political force in the state,'' but Alia said Communists won that status ``through struggle, work, self-denial, and adherence to the interests of the people and the homeland.'' That echoed Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's rationale earlier this year for calling on the Soviet Communist Party to give up its guaranteed monopoly on power. Alia called for strengthening the rule of law, saying it would only solidify the party since the law is based on party policy. ``The law stands above all,'' he said. ``No instruction, decision, order or authority exists above the law.'' Failure to recognize the supremacy of law leads to ``injustice and chaos, and causes great social damage.'' Albania is the only hard-line Communist country left in Eastern Europe, where revolution last year toppled Communist governments. But earlier this year, cracks began showing in Albania's Communist edifice as well. About 5,000 Albanians slipped past guards to make their way to embassies in the capital, Tirana, and were allowed to emigrate. Alia also said the 1976 constitution, which declares an official policy of atheism, violates the right of religious belief. ``Just as it is anyone's right to be an atheist, so he must not be prohibited from believing,'' Alia said. But he did not make a clear statement calling for that policy to be eliminated.

DOC.HEAD: `Subfertile,' A Play by Tom Mardirosian, Opens Off-Broadway
DOC.NOTE: Eds: No PMs planned.
DOC.TEXT: The hero of Tom Mardirosian's new play, a character not unlike Mardirosian himself, faces 40 fearfully, talks to dinosaurs in the Museum of Natural History, favors loud bowling shirts and suffers from a low sperm count. This autobiographical trivia doesn't sound like the stuff of good comedy but it is, particularly because the protagonist is played by Mardirosian himself, a balding raconteur with a wry, humorous outlook on life. His play is called ``Subfertile,'' and it opened Wednesday in the tiny studio theater at off-Broadway's Playwrights Horizons. Mardirosian's last comedy, ``Saved from Obscurity,'' was done there two years ago and dramatized his struggle to become an actor. With ``Subfertile'' he struggles to become a father. The journey to parenthood isn't easy, according to Mardirosian. You think Connie Chung and Maury Povich have problems? The roadblocks for our hero aren't just physical. There are expensive and uncaring doctors, humiliating medical examinations, the endless questions of well-meaning friends and the inevitable tensions between husband and wife. But Mardirosian manages to make the difficulties comic, often outrageous fun. The playwright takes a personal, conversational tone with the audience. He talks directly to them. The actor starts with his first sexual experiences, back as a teen-ager in Buffalo, N.Y., and works his way up to the present. He covers his college and post-college dalliances as well as the problems he and his wife Jackie have when they try to conceive. One highlight is an operation Mardirosian endures to improve his sperm count. The anesthetic produces a hilarious fantasy sequence right out of ``Star Trek'' - call it ``Sperm Trek'' - in which Mardirosian becomes a Spock with soul and sensitivity. The playwright-actor gets expert help from four other actors, some in a variety of roles. They include Frederica Meister, who plays his beleaguered wife; Richard Council as two different doctors and his obnoxious blue-collar childhood friend; Susan Knight as a giggly beauty-parlor operator he beds, and Kitty Crooks as a third doctor who tries to get him out of his predicament. Director John Ferraro doesn't let the evening spin too long. At 90 minutes, it's exactly right. ``Subfertile'' further cements Mardirosian's reputation as a playwright of promise whose best subject is himself.

DOC.HEAD: British Novelist Lawrence Durrell Dead at 78
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with more quotes from Durrell interviews, Faber and Faber to publish his last book soon. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto PAR2
DOC.TEXT: Lawrence Durrell, the British novelist whose works evoked the exotic imagery of the Mediterranean, has died at his home in southern France, his family said today. He was 78. The cause of his death on Wednesday was not disclosed. Durrell had been fatigued for about two weeks, a family member said. Durrell told The Washington Post in 1986 that he was suffering from emphysema. Durrell, who was a close friend of American novelist Henry Miller, died in Sommieres, a small town in the Provence region near the Mediterranean coast where he had lived for 24 years. His best-known work was the Alexandria Quartet series, the elements of which came from the time he spent in Alexandria, Egypt, during World War II. The novels, written from 1957 to 1960, are ``Justine,'' ``Balthazar,'' ``Mountolive'' and ``Clea.'' Durrell's verse - romantic, taut and often humorous - began appearing in 1938. It includes, ``Collected Poems,'' ``Red Limbo Lingo,'' and ``Vega and Other Poems.'' Durrell was born in 1912 in India and spent his boyhood in the northern city of Darjeeling near the Tibetan border. His father, a civil engineeer, had gone to India to help build the country's first railroads. Lawrence was one of four children. His younger brother, Gerald, a ``zoomaniac,'' as Lawrence called him, is a well-known naturalist and author. The elder Durrell said in a 1982 interview: ``When I was looking back the other day to what the hell my career had been, I found I was really trying to find my way back to India. I think I really must have been marked by that enormous silence up in the mountains.'' At the age of 18, he left India for London, where he dabbled in jazz and poetry without much success. In 1935, he first encountered Greece, the inspiration for some of his works. Durrell and Gerald moved to Corfu, an Ionian Island off the West Coast of Greece. It was from there he began a near 50-year correspondence with Miller. Letters between the two were published in two volumes in 1963 and 1988. Durrell described the letters once as, ``full of of insight, full of fun.'' He moved to Rhodes three years after World War II. He later lived in Argentina, England, Yugoslavia, then moved to Cyprus in 1952. Cyprus was the inspiration for his work ``Bitter Lemons,'' written in 1957, while living in southeastern France. The book is a vivid, many-faceted account of Cyprus during the British-Turkish-Greek struggles there. It was also while living in France that Durrell wrote the Alexandria Quartet. The series - written in a lush, baroque prose style - took as its theme love as a means of self-discovery. It is a portrait of an English writer's life amid the inhabitants of Alexandria, Egypt. The author called his quartet, ``a continuum of words,'' ``a relativity poem.'' Durrell once said, ``I regard writing as a fascinating bore and wish it were better paid. I intended to die young and have the following words on my tomb: `Lawrence Durrell wishes you great passions and short lives.' If I die old it will only need altering one word.'' Four years ago he emerged briefly from his self-imposed privacy to accept an award of Commander of Arts and Letters. In 1988, several love letters written by Miller to Hollywood actress Brenda Venus, part of Durrell's personal papers, were sold at a London auction. In London, the Press Association news agency said Durrell's last book, ``Caesar's Vast Ghost: A Portrait of Provence,'' will be published next week by Faber and Faber. Matthew Evans, managing director of Faber and Faber, said: ``What he wanted to do was write a book which paid tribute to the part of France he lived in for so very many years. ``He knew it was his last book ... and only recently saw the first copy.'' In the 1986 Washington Post interview, Durrell said he had suffered bad health problems in recent years. ``Suddenly, in my old age I've toppled into emphysema and no longer can travel or stand on my head or do anything enjoyable except drink,'' he said. Durrell was married three times and had two daughters, one each by his first and second wives. His youngest daughter, Sappho-Jane, died in 1985, Durrell's oldest daughter, Penelope Berengaria survives him. Information on his wives and funeral plans were not immediately known.

DOC.HEAD: Regardless of the Outcome, Try to Make it Look Good
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 graf to UPDATE with Bush comments on the election. Picks up 3rd graf pvs `The conflicting ...' SUBS 8th graf pvs `-Democrats gained ...' to DELETE now-redundant first references to Wellston and Boschwitz
DOC.TEXT: President Bush conceded today that ``I'm not talking victory'' about the 1990 elections in the wake of Democratic gains in Congress. But the president quickly added that GOP losses were less than the historic average. ``I didn't do as well as I'd like,'' the president said at a news conference. Democrats strengthened their hold on Congress by gaining one Senate seat and nine in the House. Republicans were quick to contend that those losses were below the historic average for a first-term president in his first congressional elections. Democrats counter that the average loss of two dozen House seats normally occurs after the president carries many House candidates into office with him. That didn't occur in 1988, when Democrats gained three House seats despite Bush's victory. ``I'm not talking victory because I am very disappointed about how some of the races turned out,'' Bus said in his first public discussion of the elections results. He cited the defeat of Republican Sen. Rudy Boschwitz of Minnesota by Democrat Paul Wellstone as particularly disappointing. Invited to announce his plans for 1992, Bush brushed off the question by saying, ``No decision has been made.'' The president did not accept any responsibility for GOP losses, although many analysts said before the voting that Republicans were hurt when Bush dropped his tough line against any tax increases. ``I don't think there is any confusion about how I feel about taxes,'' he said. ``I'm going to hold the line on taxes.'' The president was less bullish about the election results than some of his party leaders, who were energetically arguing that the losses were a victory because they were not much worse. Democratic Party chairman Ronald H. Brown and Republican Party spokesman Charles Black raced from one joint appearance to another Wednesday. Brown declared the 1990 outcome ``a no-confidence vote'' on Bush, while Black found in the results ``a good day for the Republican Party.'' The conflicting views mean little to citizens of Arizona who are headed for a runoff vote perhaps months away to determine the identity of their next governor. Republican Fife Symington held a lead of fewer than 5,000 votes over Democrat Terry Goddard in the race to succeed Rose Mofford as governor of Arizona. About 10,000 votes went to other candidates and the state constitution requires that if no candidate gets 50 percent of the votes, the top two meet again in a runoff. Until the race is settled, Mofford will remain governor. Also undecided are two House races in California, two of them involving Democratic incumbents, Doug Bosco and Jim Bates. With all other races decided the 1990 outcome was this: -Democrats gained one Senate seat to increase their majority to 56-44. All Democratic incumbents won; only one Republican lost - Wellstone unseated Boschwitz. -The Democrats also picked up nine House seats to pad their majority to 268-167, assuming the two unsettled California races go to the Republican candidates who now are leading. -Governors provided the most excitement. The Republicans retained California, but the Democrats captured statehouses in Florida and Texas from the GOP. When the dust had settled the Democrats held 28 governorships and the Republicans 19. Two were won by independents - Lowell Weicker in Connecticut and Walter Hickel in Alaska. Those are the numbers. Defining them was the job of the Browns and Blacks. ``Americans read George Bush's lips yesterday, and they made it clear they didn't like his message,'' said Rep. Beryl Anthony, D-Ark., chairman of the House Democratic campaign committee. The outcome ``wasn't due to any kind of national trend, I don't think, or issue, so much as it was something about (each) individual member,'' said House Minority Leader Robert Michel, R-Ill. Control of congressional and legislative reapportionment was a special goal of both the 1990 campaign. In this area the Democrats looked like clear winners. Overall, Democrats emerged from Tuesday's vote with redistricting monopolies in 17 states. Republicans control the process outright in just three states, New Hampshire, Utah and Vermont, none of them redistricting battlegrounds. The victories of Lawton Chiles over Republican Gov. Bob Martinez in Florida and Ann Richards over GOP businessman Clayton William in the Texas governor's race gave the Democrats the monopoly of the redistricting process in those two key states that will gain seven House seats between them. Black insisted that ``our party is very well-positioned not only for 1992 but for the rest of this decade.'' That assessment was based on the GOP's having a voice in redistricting for 231 of the 435 congressional districts, roughly 65 more than 10 years ago. One of the biggest surprises in the results was the defeat of Democratic Gov. Jim Blanchard of Michigan by Republican John Engler. ``This is simply an overpowering moment,'' said Engler, who a week ago looked to be far behind in the polls. Other incumbent governors who lost were Republicans Kay Orr of Nebraska, Mike Hayden of Kansas and Edward DiPrete of Rhode Island. Why were governors hit harder than members of Congress? Larry Sabato, a political analyst at the University of Virginia, traced their vulnerability to the policies of the Reagan administration. ``Reagan transferred the authority and the responsibility and the fiscal burdens to the states, and the governors were forced to raise taxes,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Roman Catholic Man Killed in Northern Ireland
DOC.TEXT: A Roman Catholic man died after being shot by two gunmen in his Belfast home, police said today. No one immediately claimed responsibility for the Wednesday night attack, but police said they suspected killers linked to extremist Protestant factions. The Royal Ulster Constabulary said the victim, Gary Campbell, 22, had no known connection with the security forces or paramilitary groups. Campbell was watching television when two gunmen walked through the unlocked front door of his house and fired four shots, police said. He died on the operating table at nearby Mater Hospital. Neighbors said the gunmen casually drove away after the attack. Police said the car was stolen and was set ablaze in a Protestant neighborhood about a mile away from the shooting scene.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Loses Eye, At Least 10 Others Affected By Tainted Drops
DOC.TEXT: One woman lost an eye after using eye drops that were contaminated by bacteria and at least 10 other people are under treatment after using the same drops made by a local pharmacy, doctors said. At least four city hospitals are treating patients whose eyes have been injured by the contaminated drops, The Pittsburgh Press reported in today's editions. So far, one woman who used the drug has had a badly infected eye surgically removed, at least two others could lose eyes, and two more have lost sight in an eye, the newspaper said. The patients, mostly women 55 to 78 years old, underwent cataract surgery in the past month. Joseph Kilkeary, who identified himself as the manager of Hieber's Drug Store, said Wednesday night that he was unsure how many people received the medicine the pharmacy produced, but it's ``somewhere between 20 and 200.'' Eye surgeons at Allegheny General Hospital's ophthalmology department determined the drops were contaminated by bacteria as they cared for a woman suffering from a severe internal eye infection, the newspaper said. ``Her doctor thought the stitches from her cataract surgery three weeks ago had broken and become infected, but it turned out to be far more severe,'' said Dr. John Kennerdell, the department's chairman. The woman's right eye was removed last week when large doses of antibiotics failed to save her vision. Laboratory tests linked the infection to the Indocin drops, a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory medication made at the pharmacy by mixing powdered Indocin with other solutions. Kennerdell on Monday got the names of the four physicians who were prescribing the medication. Later that day, three more patients with identical symptoms were referred to Allegheny General. At the same time, patients were being treated for infection at other hospitals - three at Central Medical Center, one at St. Francis Hospital and three at Eye and Ear Hospital. Indocin, produced by Merck, Sharp & Dohme, is taken orally for pain caused by diseases such as rheumatoid arthritis. Many eye specialists prescribe it in the form of drops. Kilkeary said Hieber's has made the drops for years ``without any problems whatsoever.''

DOC.HEAD: Border Treaty Signing Predicted This Month; Germany Forgives Loan
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with plans to sign border treaty later this month
DOC.TEXT: The leaders of Poland and Germany said today a treaty confirming their present border would be signed soon, settling decades of debate over the frontier and ethnic Germans in Poland. Chancellor Helmut Kohl made the announcement at his summit with Polish Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki, their first meeting together since German unification on Oct. 3. Kohl said the treaty would be signed this month in Warsaw, but did not give a specific date. ``We are deeply convinced that real peace will be possible only if Germans and Poles march together along this road into a peaceful future,'' Kohl told reporters. ``We want this border to bring us closer and not to divide Europe between the developed rich and the poor,'' said Mazowiecki. The border along the Oder and Neisse rivers, established by the victorious World War II Allies in 1945, gave Poland 40,000 square miles of German territory as compensation for an even larger portion of Poland taken by the Soviet Union. Many Germans continued to question the border, hoping for a return of the Silesian, Pomeranian and East Prussian lands that comprise about a third of present-day Poland. The treaty - whose text was completed last week - commits Germany to relinquishing the claims. A second treaty, not yet completed, seeks to lay the groundwork for future cooperation, including close economic ties, German aid for Poland's shift to a market economy and provisions for the German ethnic minority in Poland. No date has been set for the signing of the friendship treaty. Kohl greeted Mazowiecki at the picturesque, centuries-old city hall in Frankfurt an der Oder. Mazowiecki arrived in a motorcade that crossed a bridge over the Oder River. Before the meeting began, Germany forgave nearly $500 million in loan payments owed by Poland.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Helicopter Wreckage Found; Crew Still Missing
DOC.TEXT: Rescue teams have recovered wreckage from a U.S. Army helicopter that disappeared off the Greek coast on Wednesday. The U.S. Embassy said today the three crew members remain missing, but a police official in Isthmia, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said human remains were spotted near the crash site 35 miles southwest of Athens. The UH-1H Huey helicopter crashed in the Saronic Gulf while en route to Hellenikon U.S. Air Force Base, adjacent to Athens International Airport. The helicopter was on a training mission from the U.S. Army 6th Aviation Detachment based in Vicenza, Italy, said an embassy official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The official declined to identify the crew. Greek military aircraft and vessels continued today to comb the area for the missing crew. The semi-official Athens News Agency, quoting unidentified Greek military sources, said the helicopter landed at a small Greek island near Corfu in northwestern Greece because of mechanical problems. After repairs, the helicopter continued its flight.

DOC.HEAD: Papers Says Top Executives Back Local Management
DOC.TEXT: The parent company of the Daily News denies union claims that it is calling the shots in the newspaper's handling of its 2-week-old strike. ``This is a New York situation and it will be solved by the Daily News management in New York,'' said Charles Brumback, president and chief executive officer of the Tribune Co. of Chicago. Labor leaders have charged that the Tribune Co. provoked the strike to try to break the unions and, failing that, close the paper. Brumback called those charges ``baloney.'' He conceded that some advertisers had pulled out and that distributing the paper was a major problem. The News said Wednesday that Brumback and Tribune chairman Stanton Cook visited the paper Tuesday to reaffirm support for the paper's management and its determination to keep publishing. The unions, representing 2,100 workers, had been working without contracts since March 30. The News, whose pre-strike daily circulation of 1.09 million made it the nation's third largest metropolitan daily, had insisted during negotiations that it could not survive without ending what it called union featherbedding. The paper began recruiting permanent replacements in the spring in anticipation of a strike. A group of clergymen, expressing concern over the economic and social damage of the strike, went to the News Building on Wednesday to urge the News to return to negotiations with its striking unions. The clergymen also criticized union violence but aimed most of their barbs at the company. Speaking for a clerical ``Coalition of Conscience,'' the Rev. James A. Forbes Jr., senior minister of Riverside Church, said the tactic of hiring permanent replacements for striking employees ``seriously undercuts management's claim to be bargaining in good faith.'' ``This company is not anti-union,'' said Lisa Robinson, a spokeswoman for the News. ``We have negotiated for the better part of this year and continue to be open to the bargaining process. That is the place to resolve differences with the parties directly involved.'' The News has been publishing daily during the strike, and says 150 of the 350 Newspaper Guild editorial workers have returned to work.

DOC.HEAD: Government to Pardon 2.5 Million People for Coronation
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Ministry plans an amnesty for about 2.5 million people to mark the coronation of Emperor Akihito next week, a ministry official said Thursday. The official said the scale of the planned amnesty was announced after a meeting between Vice Minister of Justice Yasuchika Negoro and Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu. Other details of the pardons, expected to be mainly for traffic violations, have not been made public, he said, speaking on condition of anonymity. More than 10 million people received amnesty to mark the funeral of Akihito's father, Emperor Hirohito, in February last year. Akihito, who became emperor immediately after Hirohito's death in January 1989, is to be formally enthroned in ceremonies beginning Monday. The Japanese government declares such amnesties to mark events it deems to be of major historical importance. An amnesty also was declared in 1972, when Okinawa was returned from U.S. to Japanese jurisdiction.

DOC.HEAD: Archaeologists Find Prehistoric Skeleton Near Sea Of Galilee
DOC.TEXT: Archaeologists discovered a 19,000-year-old skeleton on the shores of the Sea of Galilee during the excavation of a pre-historic settlement, a spokeswoman for the Department of Antiquities said. It's only the second skeleton from this period found in the area, and will provide clues to scientists on how hunters, gatherers and fishermen lived, spokeswoman Efrat Brown said Wednesday. The skeleton is that of a man who was buried in a hole, lying on his back with his knees pulled up. Fishbones were found next to the body. The grave is located in an ancient settlement on the southwestern tip of the Sea of Galilee, the lake where the Bible says Jesus performed many of his miracles.

DOC.HEAD: Jazzman's Irreplaceable Contrabass Stolen
DOC.TEXT: A 150-year-old German-made contrabass was stolen from Danish jazzman Niels Henning Oersted Pedersen in Germany, a newspaper reported Thursday. ``I've been playing on it since 1963. It's like losing an arm,'' Oersted Pedersen, also known as ``NHOP'' among jazz fans, told the Copenhagen daily, Politiken. Oersted Pedersen said he might have to cancel concerts across Europe unless the instrument is recovered. ``I sound like that contrabass. And that sound can hardly be recreated on another instrument,'' he said. The contrabass, the largest instrument in the violin family, has a range an octave below a normal bass. The contrabass disappeared last Friday at the Frankfurt-am-Main international airport in Germany where Oersted Pedersen was attending a jazz festival with Belgian guitar player Philippe Catherine.
