DOC.HEAD: Chess Fans: The Quietest Sport Fanatics
DOC.TEXT: Among the varied breeds of sports fanatics, chess enthusiasts are the quietest. They have to sit on their hands. They can't stand up to order a hot dog or step out to buy a beer. And they definitely can't shout armchair suggestions like ``exd4'' or ``Bf6'' during a match. The U.S. Open at Flushing Meadows was downright raucous compared to the inside of the Hudson Theatre where Garry Kasparov and Anatoly Karpov played to a draw in their last stateside game Wednesday of the current championship. The dueling chess mavens leave New York to begin the second half of theirchampionship match in Lyons, France, tied 6-6. Each player won one game in New York; the 10 others ended in draws. The second half of the championship resumes Nov. 24. The first player to gain 12{ points wins. If tied after 24 games, Kasparov keeps his title. As for stage presence, Kasparov and Karpov are no McEnroe and Connors. There was no Hulk Hogan-Iron Sheik-like dialogue between these two sworn enemies, and certainly no tantrums. Most of the time they didn't even stay on stage together. As one pondered his move, the other waited off stage. Nobody slam-dunked any chess pieces to the ground or sent an errant queen spiraling across the stage. But that's not to say the sport lacks excitement. On Wednesday, after move number 31, politeness and solitude took a back seat to hurriedness. Because of time constraint rules, Karpov was left with only nine minutes to make his next nine moves while Kasparov had 20 minutes left for the same number of moves. For this, both sat at the table. And while there were no lavish tailgate parties or interruptions as mutinous fans were escorted out, there was a certain fairytale-like ambiance. When not straining to see the taut expressions on the player's faces, fans - who paid between $25 and $100 per ticket - could focus on the giant cutout chess pieces that looked like they came straight out of Lewis Carroll's ``Through the Looking Glass.'' One thing there's plenty of is quiet. These fans would likely be out of place in the blue seats at Madison Square Garden or at any New York Jet football game, where rudeness is the prevailing rule. Chess folk take their quiet seriously. As they followed Game 12, spectators would break into an occasional murmur. They were immediately shushed by neighbors and the words ``Silence Please'' flashed on a giant screen. For those fans who can't take the silence, the analysis rooms in the adjoining Hotel Macklowe offered a diversion. There, chess buffs followed the game on monitors while grandmasters provided color commentary. ``I think absolutely terrible move by Karpov!'' grandmaster Roman Dzindzichashvili exploded at one point. ``Absolutely terrible!'' ``Do you think he didn't see bishop E6,'' someone shouted. ``No, he saw bishop E6,'' Dzindzichashvili said. ``He just underestimated.'' If the United States as a whole was not agog with the chess championship, the Hotel Macklowe, at least, was buzzing with nothing else. In lounges and on elevators, people talked chess in a dozen languages. ``It's exciting to be in a chess milieu,'' said Steve Shapiro of Manhattan, who watched the final American match with his brother. ``When you're playing, you're with a buddy or in a club. Rarely are you part of a chess scene. There are lots of scenes in this town, and chess ain't one of them.''

DOC.HEAD: Laotian Family Opts for `American' Baby Name - Ronald Smith
DOC.TEXT: A Laotian couple with a 15-letter last name wanted a shorter, simpler, more American name for their newborn son. So Phouthone and Chanhsy Sichanthongthip (pronounced sik-en-ton'-tip) chose the name Ronald Smith. ``It's too hard here to have a last name that's a long name,'' the baby's father said. Sichanthongthip, 23, said his mother, brother and sister all approved of the name when they visited the hospital in Mason City on Wednesday. The child was born hours earlier. ``They say it's OK. It's good. They like it,'' he said. In 1986, Sichanthongthip and his father moved to Forest City, 30 miles northwest of Mason City, after they escaped to Thailand from Laos. In 1988, they were joined by other family members, who left Laos with help from a Lutheran church. Chanhsy Sichanthongthip said her husband was looking through a book of baby names when he came up with the idea of an American name. Ronald's last name will be Smith rather than Sichanthongthip. ``He wanted the baby different because he was born in the United States,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Analysts: Saddam Sacked Military Chief Over Kuwait Opposition
DOC.TEXT: Saddam Hussein has dismissed his military chief of staff for opposing the occupation of Kuwait and analysts said Thursday the move indicated growing dissension in his armed forces hierarchy. The Iraqi army's al-Qadissiya daily reported Thursday that Lt. Gen. Nazir al-Khazraji, chief of staff since 1985, was replaced by Gen. Hussein Rashid, commander of the elite 120,000-strong Republican Guards force. The newspaper did not say what happened to Khazraji or when he was dismissed. But several Western military and intelligence sources said Khazraji opposed the Kuwait occupation. They also believe Saddam might be seeking to surround himself with relatives and loyalists as the standoff with the multinational gulf force enters its fourth month. A Western intelligence source, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Rashid is a hard-liner in Iraq's Baath Socialist Party who would be expected to support Saddam's policies. Rashid had been Khazraji's deputy chief of staff for operations. U.S. officials in Washington said Rashid is considered a ``very competent'' commander and led an armored brigade in the 1980-88 war against Iran. ``It's very ominous,'' said Hans-Heino Kopietz, a former analyst with London's International Institute for Strategic Studies who is now with Control Risks, an international security firm in London. ``Khazraji's dismissal now is indicative of some opposition to Saddam within the military,'' Kopietz said in a telephone interview. U.S. officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Khazraji was named a special military adviser to Saddam in what was seen as a demotion. Al-Qadissiya mentioned Rashid's new title in a report of a graduation ceremony he attended at Baghdad's military academy Wednesday. The shakeup comes amid increasingly tough U.S. and British warnings they might use force to dislodge the Iraqis from Kuwait. ``Saddam's taking a big gamble,'' said analyst Shahram Chubin of the Geneva-based Graduate Institute of International Affairs and author of several books on the Gulf War. Some analysts said Rashid's appointment was in part designed to keep the Republican Guards on Saddam's side. The guards, considered to be Iraq's best troops, led the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. ``The rest of the army may be neutralized. But the Republican guards could turn against him if he takes the country down the road to national suicide,'' said Bernard Trainor, a former U.S. Marine general who has visited Iraq several times. ``As he tightens up, he's gathering around him all the hard-liners and sycophants who are afraid to challenge him,'' said Trainor, who heads the national security program at Harvard University's Kennedy School of Government. Rashid is believed to hail from Takrit, Saddam's birthplace north of Baghdad. Saddam has packed the hierarchy of his ruling Baath Arab Socialist Party with relatives, by blood or marriage, who come mainly from Takriti clans. Rashid's appointment is the second known top-level change in Baghdad in the past two weeks. Oil Minister Issam Chalabi was fired Oct. 28 and replaced by Brig. Gen. Hussein Kamel, Saddam's cousin and son-in-law. Kamel is also Minister of Industry and Military Industrialization and is believed to head Saddam's internal security apparatus. Kamel, a Takriti, has been responsible for developing Iraq's arms industry and producing new surface-to-surface missiles. Chalabi was purportedly replaced after he imposed gasoline rationing because of shortages due to the U.N. trade embargo. That order was later rescinded and officials denied there was any shortage. But Kopietz noted: ``There was more to Chalabi's dismissal than meets the eye. He's a moderate, close to the West and the oil industry where he was widely respected. He was understood to be trying to persuade Saddam from pursuing his strategy of confrontation.'' ``It may well be that there's growing opposition to Saddam within the Iraqi hierarchy,'' Kopietz added. Chubin noted: ``I'm sure there's considerable disquiet in the miliary, who're not necessarily all convinced Takriti Baathists.'' Iraqi dissident groups have reported several purges of senior officers since the invasion of Kuwait, possibly because they disagreed with it and Saddam's apparent miscalculation about how the West would react. There has been no independent confirmation of reports that some officers have been executed or imprisoned. But since Saddam took power in 1979, he has regularly purged senior officers who he suspected could pose threats. Some have disappeared or died under mysterious circumstances, including a defense minister, Gen. Adnan Khairallah, Saddam's cousin and brother-in-law, killed in a 1989 helicopter crash. Analysts believe opposition heightened after Saddam, seeking to secure Iraq's border with Iran as his international isolation increased, made concessions to Iraq's former foe in Aug. 15. The accord freed most of 30 divisions guarding Iraq's eastern frontier to bolster forces facing the multinational force in the gulf region.

DOC.HEAD: Griffiths Says I Told You So
DOC.TEXT: Lt. Gov. Martha Griffiths says Gov. James Blanchard lost his job in part because he removed her as a running mate. ``I don't know if I feel vindicated, but I think it clearly shows that I won it for him the first two times,'' Griffiths said Wednesday after Republican John Engler defeated Blanchard by 50.4 percent to 49.6 percent. In announcing last summer he was dropping her from the ticket, Blanchard said he was concerned about the 78-year-old Griffiths' ability to run the state in the event something happened to him. ``I feel bad for him, but he took some very bad advice,'' she said. ``I would have gotten out the Detroit vote,'' she said, referring to the low turnout in Detroit, which analysts said hurt Blanchard. Griffiths said voters also told her repeatedly they had planned to vote against Blanchard because he took her off the ticket. Griffiths said Blanchard officials never took her up on an offer to campaign for the two-term governor.

DOC.HEAD: Lawrence Durrell, Author of `The Alexandria Quartet,' Dead at 78
DOC.TEXT: Lawrence Durrell, the British novelist who conveyed his love for Mediterranean life in ``The Alexandria Quartet'' and other lyrical works, died at his home in southern France, his family said Thursday. He was 78. The cause of death Wednesday was not disclosed. Durrell had been fatigued for about two weeks, a family member said, and the author said in a 1986 interview that he suffered from emphysema. ``He was a very odd mixture of things,'' said Philip Howard, literary editor of The Times of London, in an interview with the British Broadcasting Corp. ``The thing he will be remembered for is the great tetralogy of novels, `The Alexandria Quartet,' which were all the rage in the early '60s, and were in many ways the most accessible thing in the modernist movement,'' Howard said. ``He was a real mixture of modernist structure and extreme romanticism.'' ``The Alexandria Quartet'' consists of four novels set in the Egyptian coastal city where Durrell served as press attache at the British Embassy in World War II. The works, written from 1957 to 1960, are ``Justine,'' ``Balthazar,'' ``Mountolive'' and ``Clea.'' They brought him the commercial success that had not accompanied his earlier literary acclaim. The series - written in a lush, baroque prose style - took as its theme love as a means of self-discovery. It is a portrait of an English writer's life amid the inhabitants of Alexandria. ``Classicism means becoming a spokesman for the cosmology of your time, and what the hell was the cosmology of our age if it wasn't Einstein and Freud,'' Durrell said in a 1982 interview with The Associated Press. ``So I used the theory of relativity, the four dimensions, as a kind of point of departure to make a classical frame in four volumes.'' Durrell was born in 1912 in central India and spent his boyhood in Darjeeling, near India's border with Tibet. But it was the Mediterranean that caught his passion and where he spent his public and private life. At the age of 18, he left India for London, where he dabbled in jazz and poetry without much success. In 1935, he first encountered Greece, the inspiration for some of his works. Durrell moved to Corfu, an Ionian Island off the west coast of Greece. It was from there that he began a nearly 50-year correspondence with American author Henry Miller. Letters between them were published in two volumes in 1963 and 1988. Durrell described the letters as ``full of of insight, full of fun.'' Two years ago, several love letters written by Miller to Hollywood actress Brenda Venus, part of Durrell's personal papers, were sold at a London auction. Durrell served in Britain's diplomatic corps in Egypt, Greece and Yugoslavia, and as director of public relations for the British government in Cyprus. Another acclaimed work, ``Bitter Lemons'' published in 1957, was an account of his years in Cyprus during the island's independence struggle. ``I spent 25 years subsidizing myself by doing jobs I didn't particularly like, but it was useful in the long run,'' Durrell said in 1982. ``I made notes. I learned from Stendahl, and by the time I really wanted to write books I had quite a well-furnished documentary library in my brain.'' He wrote ``The Alexandria Quartet'' in Nimes, southeastern France, and lived for the last 24 years in Sommieres, a nearby small town in the Provence region near the Mediterranean coast. Four years ago he emerged briefly from his self-imposed privacy to accept an award of Commander of Arts and Letters bestowed by the local mayor. Press Association, Britain's domestic news agency, said Faber and Faber will publish a new Durrell book next week, ``Caesar's Vast Ghost: A Portrait of Provence.'' Matthew Evans, managing director of Faber and Faber, said: ``What he wanted to do was write a book which paid tribute to the part of France he lived in for so very many years. ``He knew it was his last book ... and only recently saw the first copy.'' Durrell was married three times and hadtwo daughters, according to Press Association. One wife and one daughter have died, it said. No funeral plans were immediately announced. His brother, Gerald Malcolm Durrell, who survives, is a zoologist and popular writer of nature books.

DOC.HEAD: An Account of the Opposing Forces in the Gulf
DOC.TEXT:
Here is a breakdown of the opposing forces gathered in the Persian Gulf. ---
UNITED STATES - Officials say about 230,000 troops, including those aboard ships, are in the gulf region, and at least 100,000 more could be sent. Ground forces in Saudi Arabia include the 82nd ``All American'' Airborne Division; the 101st ``Screaming Eagles'' Airborne Division; the 24th Mechanized Infantry Division, with about 200 M-1 Abrams tanks and 300 Bradley Fighting Vehicles; the 11th Air Defense Artillery Brigade; 197th Mechanized Infantry Brigade; the 1st Cavalry Division and the 3rd Armored Cavalry Regiment. Amphibious capability is provided by 45,000 men of the 1st, 4th and 6th Marine Expeditionary Brigades. There is a Special Forces contingent from the 1st Special Operations Command.
The U.S. fleet in the gulf, the Arabian Sea and the eastern Mediterranean totals about 55 ships. They include the aircraft carriers Independence, Saratoga and John F. Kennedy; the battleship Wisconsin with 32 Tomahawk cruise missiles, five missile cruisers, four destroyers, several frigates, plus supply ships and six to eight nuclear submarines. The aircraft carriers have a combined strike force of 180 A-6 Intruder fighters, F/A-18 Hornet fighters and F-14 Tomcats. The Marines have about 60 AV-8B Harrier jump-jets. The Pentagon has also sent 22 F117A Stealth fighter-bombers to unspecified bases; 14 long-range F-111F bombers to Incirlik airbase in southwest Turkey, and another squadron to Spain. There are an estimated 150 F-16s and F-15s; more than 70 A-10 tank-killing Thunderbolts, and unspecified numbers of F-4 Wild Weasel air-defense suppression jets and other combat aircraft deployed at 30 airbases in the region. A squadron of 6-8 B-52G strategic bombers is on the Indian Ocean island of Diego Garcia. --- BRITAIN - A three-ship flotilla permanently stationed in the gulf has been beefed up to 12 ships, including a missile destroyer, two missile frigates and three minesweepers. They have support ships. Four squadrons of Tornado and Jaguar interceptors and ground attack jets are in Saudi Arabia, Bahrain and Oman. Three Nimrod maritime reconnaissance aircraft are in Oman. The 7th Armored Brigade, successors to the famous ``Desert Rats'' of World War II, have started arriving with 120 Challenger tanks and 9,500 troops in Britain's biggest military operation since the 1982 Falklands War against Argentina. British troop strength is expected to reach 15,000. --- FRANCE - It has about 14 ships and 13,000 troops in the gulf region. The warships include a guided-missile cruiser, two missile destroyers, two frigates and one corvette with support vessels. France is sending three squadrons of interceptors and fighter-bombers. The 4,000-troop Rapid Action Force is deployed with Arab forces in Saudi Arabia's northeastern desert. It includes the 5th Combat Helicopter Regiment with 42 gunships; the Foreign Legion's 3nd Infantry Regiment with anti-tank missiles; the 1st Spahis Cavalry Regiment with armored vehicles, and an anti-aircraft missile unit. A company of 190 paratroopers equipped for chemical warfare is in the United Arab Emirates. The French deployment is the nation's biggest overseas operation since the Algerian war in the early 1960s. --- ITALY - The frigates Libeccio, Orsa and Zeffiro and a support ship, the Stromboli, are in the gulf. The corvettes Minerva and Stinge are in the eastern Mediterranean replacing U.S. units assigned to the gulf. A squadron of eight Tornado fighters is based near Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates, to provide air cover for Italian warships. No ground force deployment is planned. --- CANADA - The destroyers Athabaskan and Terra Nova and the supply ship Protecteur are heading for the gulf. A squadron of 18 CF-18 fighter jets and 450 military personnel based in West Germany are in Saudi Arabia. --- NETHERLANDS - The frigates Witte de With and Pieter Florisz are in the Gulf of Oman. The combat supply ship Zuiderkruis is expected there in November. --- SPAIN - The frigate Santa Maria is in the Gulf of Oman. The corvettes Cazadora and Descubierta are in the Bab el Mandeb Strait in the southern Red Sea. ---
AUSTRALIA - The guided-missile frigates Adelaide and Darwin and the supply ship Success are in the gulf region. --- BELGIUM - The minehunters Iris and Myosotis with the supply ship Zinnia are in the Gulf of Oman. The Belgians have also commited four C-130 military transport planes. --- ARGENTINA - The destroyer Almirante Brown and the frigate Spiro are expected to arrive in the gulf region soon. Both West German-built warships are armed with anti-ship Exocet missiles. A 100-man army unit will also be sent. --- SOVIET UNION - The Udaloy-class destroyer Admiral Tributs and an anti-submarine ship are in the Gulf of Oman. Moscow has indicated it would send ground forces, but only under U.N. command. The Slava-class missile cruiser Chervona Ukraina and the Sovremenny-class destroyer Bystry passed through the Suez Canal Oct.4, ostensibly en route to join the Soviet Pacific Fleet. But they could be deployed in the gulf region. --- GREECE - Greece has sent its most advanced frigate, the Limnos, to the eastern Mediterranean. Greece is supplying merchant ships for the U.S. sealift. --- WEST GERMANY - It is providing merchant ships to transport U.S. troops to Saudi Arabia and has provided $2 billion toward the multinational force. Germany's Constitution prohibits it from sending military forces outside its borders. ---
DENMARK - It has sent a corvette, the Olfert Fischer. Danish merchant ships are helping in the U.S. sealift. ---
NORWAY - It has sent the Coast Guard cutter Andenes to support the Danish corvette. Norway has offered anti-chemical warfare equipment. --- PORTUGAL - It has commited a naval support ship to the gulf. --- POLAND - It will send a military field hospital and a hospital ship to the gulf. --- CZECHOSLOVAKIA - It has sent a 200-man army unit with anti-chemical warfare equipment. --- GULF COOPERATION COUNCIL (Saudi Arabia, Bahrain, Oman, United Arab Emirates, Qatar and, until Aug. 2, Kuwait) - A rapid deployment force of up to 10,000 troops is based at Hafr al-Batin, Saudi Arabia, 40 miles south of the Kuwait border. They and allied Arab-Islamic forces form the first line of defense. The GCC force has been beefed up with about 7,000 soldiers of Kuwait's 20,000-man army who escaped their country when Iraq invaded. Most of their heavy weapons were captured by Iraq, but some combat jets and tanks were saved. The GCC and other Gulf Arab forces total around 144,500 men, 330 combat aircraft, 800 tanks and 36 major naval units. They are supported by: EGYPT - It has pledged up to 20,000 troops with tanks and heavy artillery. About 14,000 troops - including paratroopers, commandos, chemical warfare specialists and infantry - are in Saudi Arabia. Several thousand more soldiers from the 3rd Armored Division and the 3rd Mechanized Infantry Division, are expected soon. Five hundred troops are in the United Arab Emirates. --- SYRIA - About 6,500 troops, mostly elite Special Forces units who have fought the Israelis and others in Lebanon, are in Saudi Arabia. A 15,000-man armored division, with about 420 tanks and heavy artillery, is also arriving. Some troops are based in the United Arab Emirates. --- PAKISTAN - It has pledged to send 5,000 troops, with 2,000 already in Saudi Arabia and 2,000 in the United Arab Emirates, along with 1,000 advisers. About 5,000 advisers are already attached to the Saudi armed forces. --- MOROCCO - It has 1,200 troops in Saudi Arabia and 500 in the United Arab Emirates. --- BANGLADESH - It has 2,000 troops, including engineering and infantry units, in Saudi Arabia. --- IRAQ - The army has seven corps totaling 55 divisions. There are 555,000 regular troops and 480,000 reserves. Regular forces include seven divisions of elite Republican Guards. Iraq claims a militia called the Popular Army has 5 million men. Saddam Hussein has 5,500 tanks, including about 500 high-quality T-72s and 1,000 medium-quality T-62s; 3,500 artillery guns; 200 multiple rocket launchers; an estimated 500 surface-to-surface missiles; more than 330 surface-to-air missile launchers, including captured Kuwaiti systems; 500-plus combat aircraft, including Soviet-supplied long-range Su-24 fighter-bombers and advanced MiG-29 interceptors. The equipment is spread around an estimated 25 airbases. Its main naval units are a training frigate with anti-submarine torpedoes, an estimated eight Soviet-built missile-attack craft and six torpedo boats. In Kuwait, Iraq has an estimated 10 divisions, four of them armored, totaling 170,000 troops; 3,500 T-55 and T-62 tanks, and 1,700 artillery pieces in what appear to be defensive positions. About 250,000 men, including the seven Republican Guard divisions with up to 1,300 tanks and 750 guns, are in southern Iraq as a tactical reserve. Silkworm anti-ship missiles are believed to have been deployed to counter any U.S. amphibious landing in Kuwait. FROG-7 battlefield missiles have also been deployed, including batteries captured in Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON: view, frankly.
DOC.TEXT: Q: If I may, are you saying it's one time only? A: I'm just saying I'm going to hold the line on taxes and fight back all these plans that are coming at me that I think will - maybe I'm getting paranoid about it when I hear them talk about, let's go out and raise taxes again, but I thought that was kind of the message coming out of the end of the budget debate. And if that's the case, we're in for a whale of a fight, and the proffered hand may miss the shake because we're not going to compromise on that. Q: Sir, can we go back out beyond the Beltway again for a minute? A: Let's do it, Michelle. Q: A couple of years ago the Texas Republican party passed an English-only amendment as part of its party platform, and you spoke out against this. You said that this was an alienating message to send to people you want to participate. This year, the North Carolina Republican party sent postcards to minority voters, Democrats, suggesting that they had given false information to elections officials, giving them false information. Is this an appropriate campaign tactic, and why have you been silent about this? A: I have - because I haven't tried to get into the campaign tactics in 50 states. And on the postcard -I mean the English-only, I don't think it's a good thing to have. I mean, I want every kid to speak English. I've been for bilingual education all my life, continue to support it. But I think the goal of it should be that every kid in this country speak English. But I just don't think the English-only approach is the way to do it. I think it could result in certain discrimination. But I'm sorry, I can't help you on the details of a race for the United States Senate or a governor's race or a congressional race. I just have not gone into that. Q: Sir, are you saying that you don't know anything about this. ... A: I read a lot of charges and countercharges, and I've heard some people say it's bad and I've heard others say it's not. And I do recall that some time, any time somebody puts in what they call a voter security program, some people raise hell about it, and that's not right either. So, it ought to be - it depends how it's done. And I just don't know enough about what you're trying to get me into to get into that. Yeah? Q: Yes, Mr. President, I wonder if you've had any reaction to the margins of victory of Mario Cuomo and Bill Bradley, two Democrats thought to be looking at challenging you in two years? A: I'm not thinking about '92. Q: Let's talk about races. Q: What do you think happened? A: Look, I just told Michelle, I haven't gone into the details of all these races. I don't know, I don't know. A: Why haven't you? Q: I want to ask you about Director Bennett. We've heard stories of threats against himself, against his family, and maybe that's why he's leaving. What do you know about that? A: Well, I'd let him respond to that question. But I - maybe Bill, why don't you. Bennett: I got one question. Come on, let me take it. So far I've read tat I am bored, restive, restless, tired, unhappy, moping about lack of media attention, sulking about not being in the Cabinet, in a snit with John Sununu - all sorts of things that I've read about - and being stampeded out of town, none of which are true. I mean, I - there have been people who haven't liked me since I have been in public service. The Yale English Department, they may be threatening - I don't - the National Education Association and, you know, and this latest crowd. But, I mean, I'm not the stampeded-out-of-town type. There's nothing there. Q: How about threats? Bennett: Oh, I mean there are threats, there are always threats in this kind of. ... They've been there since the beginning of this job. I mean, that's always the case. I think what people are picking up on is when I went up to Alaska to talk about the recriminalization of marijuana - which by the way occurred, that took place, that initiative passed - there were some anonymous threats from some potheads that they were going to blow me up. But they - but the notice that went out from the - one of the pothead societies said, ``Come confront Bennett,'' but the date they put on it was two days after the day I was there. So if they did leave anything dangerous, it's probably going off up there on the icecaps somewhere without any. ... Q: Why are you leaving? Bennett (to Bush): I don't want to tie you up; should we go into this? Bush: No, no, I'm going to just take two more and then I'm leaving. Bennett: When the president and I talked 20 months ago, we talked about things that needed to be done. I'd had two jobs in government, humanities chairman and secretary of education. And we decided that what we needed to do was to get a good strategy, which we've got; to get bipartisan support for it, which we've got, broadly - there are still some things Democrats need to do, like the crime bill; third, that we needed to get the right amount of resources for it, which we've achieved, and fourth, to begin to see some progress, some results. And we said at that time, I remember the president saying to me, ``If you can get this thing started, going in the right direction, moving, I'll be very grateful.'' And I think we got that. And so I'm, you know, I took the job freely and now I leave freely. MORE

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON: leave freely.
DOC.TEXT:
Q: Why don't you want to see it through? Bennett: Well, I, seeing it through is going to, I mean, I think if this nation stays on course, I think it's probably, we will probably beat the goals that we stated in the National Drug Control Strategy of 10 years. I think we'll be there in five years if the states do the things that they're supposed to do, and if others do what they're supposed to do. The federal commitment, I think, is clear; unprecedented commitment, unprecedented amount of money, resources, and so on. That's five years. That's, you know, I've had nine years in government. I think that's enough for now. I mean I do want to tell my critics I am not leaving public life, and worse than that, I may not even be leaving public service forever. I may not, you know, I may be back. One needs to be careful about this. But I don't leave with any sense of remorse or apology. I'm proud of what we've done, and I think what we've done is a good thing. And we really are making progress. Bush: With your permission, let me just take two; Jessica and Ellen. ... Yes, Ellen? Q: Mr. President, you say that your reading of the election shows that people didn't and don't want their taxes raised. Upon reflection, do you wish you had kept your campaign promise and not supported higher taxes? A: Do I wish I'd been able to? Yes, very much so. In fact, we tried. We sent a budget up there and it kind of died for lack of a second. And it had no taxes in it. And that's - I very - I wish I had a Congress that would do it just my way, because I am still convinced we can get by without having raised anybody's taxes of any kind. And so, yes, I have serious regrets about that. Q: Well, can you make the promise now, sir, that you will not support new taxes in the future? A: Can I make the promise I won't support them? Absolutely. But I'm - you know, sometimes you run into some realities. But I'm girding up my loins to go into battle to beat back the tax attempts that I think are coming. Because I think the American people are fed up with it. And I think that was very clear. I think in my case they probably know that there had to be some compromise, at least from the way you look at does the American people support the deficit agreement or not. But I want to be on theside of no tax increases, and we're going to go right to bat again in the Congress at that. We fight that battle all the time. Yes, Jessica? Q: Mr. President, there seemed to be not very much debate about the Persian Gulf during the election, even though we have our young people there and their lives are on the line. I'm wondering, do you take this - the fact that you weren't seriously challenged by the opposition party on this matter - do you take this as support for any decision that you might make, with respect to having to go to war there, without respect, say, to the House's adjournment resolution that said they should come back if you go to war. A: Jessica, look, I said I didn't want to take any Persian Gulf questions. ... I will reply to this, and then ask - and it is the last one anyway - but I - look, we have had extensive consultations with Congress. We will continue to have extensive consultations with Congress. I think the people in the campaign for the most part recognized that I was trying very hard to separate support for the Persian Gulf policy from the pure head-on-head confrontation of domestic politics. And again, I tried continually on the road to salute the Democratic leadership and Democratic members, along with Republican leadership and Republican members, for what I think has been extraordinarily solid support. And I think that support has led to good support from the American people. But we have a major foreign policy objective there. I am determined to see the objective fulfilled. I am determined to hold this coalition together. But that must be done without partisan politics intervening. And so that then leads me to say I will continue to consult. I know the responsibilities I have to do that. I know the importance of the support of the Congress, and I will continue to reach out to them and keep them informed and consult. And they know my views. So I don't think there's any - I don't think that the campaign has driven any wedge between me and the leaders on Capitol Hill or the American people on this very important problem. Q: So that does mean that you feel that there is widespread national support for whatever it is that you have to do, that you decide to do? A: No question about it. Q: Well, I like to feel the American people would support their president on whatever decision is made. And I think one way to guarantee that is to be sure that you consult, to be sure that you spell out your objectives as clearly as possible, to be sure you keep this historic coalition together. And the importance of the Baker trip, for example, I think is obvious. And so, so far, I think that the ingredients are there for full support. And I view my responsibilities as such that I must be sure that's right. I'll go the extra mile, here at home and abroad, to see that we, that our, the common objectives as stated by the United Nations are met. I'll turn it over to Bill. And let me just say, I've read some silly speculation about Bill Bennett's leaving. And he has my total confidence. There's no internal politics that's caused him to make this decision. If he feels like it, he can tell you when he - I don't want to violate confidences - when he and I had our first and then subsequent talks about this. He knows the affection that Barbara and I have for him and his family. I know that the kind of sacrifice that anyone serving this country goes through, not just in the controversy of the job but in terms of financial aspirations for their families that need to be educated. And so please discount some of this understandable speculation. He has my confidence. I think I have his, and I know that he has the love and affection or his family from Barbara and me. And I think he's done an outstanding job for his country. And even his severest critics, I think, will tell you that, those that started off the most critical. We've made progress in an area that is vital to every single family in this country. And I will never get over being grateful to Bill Bennett for what he's done. Bennett: Thank you very much. Bush: Good luck.
END TEXT

DOC.HEAD: Pan Knocked Into Observatory Aboard Columbia
DOC.TEXT: A protective blanket over part of an astronomical observatory aboard the space shuttle Columbia was torn when a worker accidentally knocked a metal pan into it, NASA said Thursday. The mishap was not expected to affect Columbia's astronomy mission, targeted for early December, said NASA spokeswoman Pat Phillips. The accident occurred Wednesday as the worker was moving a platform that provides access to Columbia's cargo bay, she said. The aluminum pan, located beneath the platform to catch debris, nicked the blanket and left a hole about one-fourth of an inch long and one-eighth of an inch wide, Phillips said. The blanket covers the Astro observatory's star tracker, used by the three ultraviolet telescopes that constitute the observatory to locate and lock onto stars. ``We don't think anything happened'' to the star tracker, Phillips said. The worker responsible for the accident is employed by Lockheed Space Operations Co., NASA's prime contractor for shuttle processing. Lockheed spokesman J.B. Kump said the company was investigating. NASA officials reported Wednesday that a special team assigned to look into similar accidents over the past year could find no connecting link. The most embarrassing mishap - a beam that was left rattling loose inside Atlantis' engine compartment last month while the vehicle was being moved - also was caused by Lockheed employees.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Sergeant At Arms To Retire
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For Release at 5 p.m. EST
DOC.TEXT: Henry K. Giugni, the Senate sergeant at arms, said Thursday he will retire at year end after 27 years of government service. As sergeant at arms for the past four years, Giugni has been the Senate's chief law-enforcement officer and principal manager of most of its support services. His office, with a $120 million annual budget, provides services to Senate offices for every state. Giugni, 65, said he will become a vice president of Cassidy and Associates, a Washington lobbying group, in January. A former Honolulu motorcycle policeman, Giugni worked for 23 years as administrative assistant to Sen. Daniel K. Inouye, D-Hawaii.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Helicopter Wreckage Found, Crewmen Still Missing
DOC.TEXT: Rescue workers on Thursday found wreckage from a missing U.S. Army helicopter that crashed in the Saronic Gulf, but continued searching for the remains of the three crewmen, the U.S. Embassy said. The rescue team said the state of the wreckage and human remains discovered at the site suggested it was unlikely that any of the crewmen had survived. The UH-1H Huey helicopter was on a routine flight from the Army's Southern European Task Force base in Vicenza, Italy, when it crashed Wednesday evening near the islet of Evreos, 12 miles southeast of Corinth, an embassy official said. The helicopter's destination was the Air Force's Hellenikon base, adjacent to Athens International Airport. The crewmen were identified as Chief Warrant Officer James Harbeson, 37, of South Carolina; Chief Warrant Officer Manuel Gomez, 29, of Camden, N.J.; and Sgt. Michael Chandler, 23, of San Antonio, Texas. He had no hometown for Harbeson. All three men were part of the Sixth Aviation Detachment. Greek military aircraft and ships continued to search the crash site late Thursday. The semi-official Athens News Agency said prior to the crash the helicopter had landed at a small Greek islet near Corfu in northwestern Greece because of mechanical problems. It continued its flight after repairs were made, the agency said.

DOC.HEAD: No New Income Taxes, Bush Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs after 12th graf pvs `We're in ...' to UPDATE with comment from Bush's economic adviser. Picks up 13th graf pvs `Even before ...'
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, reviving the no-new-tax pledge he abandoned in a budget deal, said Thursday the only way Democrats will be able to raise income tax rates will be ``over my dead veto.'' ``It ain't going to happen, I'll guarantee you,'' Bush told reporters at a news conference after saying he expects congressional Democrats to come up with new tax proposals. But he hedged his pledge somewhat when asked flatly if he would reject new taxes. ``Can I make the promise I won't support them? Absolutely,'' Bush said. ``But ... sometimes you run into some realities. But I'm girding up my loins to go into battle to beat back the tax attempts that I think are coming.'' He said Democrats had an ``insatiable desire'' to raise taxes and accused them of trying to ``stick me with being anti-civil rights'' for vetoing a landmark bill banning job discrimination. Bush struck a sharply combative stance toward the Democrats, who increased their power in both the House and Senate with Election Day victories. ``I didn't do as well as I'd like,'' the president said, reflecting on Tuesday's GOP losses. Bush said the clear message from Election Day was that ``people feel they're taxed too much.'' Six incumbent governors, of both parties, went down to defeat. The losses generally reflected tax or economic woes. Bush, in one of his gloomiest assessments, said he was very concerned that the economy was faltering. He said he would consult with economists in and out of the government on ways to soften the blow and stimulate growth. ``We're in some tough times right now,'' the president said. Michael Boskin, Bush's chief economic adviser, told a business group Thursday that he wouldn't rule out a possible negative quarter of economic growth either in the final three months of this year or early next year. He didn't specifically forecast a recession, but said there was no doubt economic growth was weak. ``The economy at best is in a lull, but we do expect that lull to be relatively brief and relatively minor,'' Boskin said. Even before the election, Republicans were heavily outnumbered in Congress, and their losses Tuesday will make it harder for Bush to win veto battles and push a legislative agenda. But Bush said the results won't ``tie my hands at all'' in dealing with lawmakers, signaling that he would be less conciliatory in the next two years. ``When you extend the hand (of cooperation), somebody else has to reach out and shake it,'' Bush said. He said he would appeal for Democratic support for his policies, but warned: ``I'm going to use the veto so as to stop a lot of bad things from happening to this country. ... I am more determined than ever to use it.'' Bush abandoned his politically popular no-new-tax pledge during negotiations with Congress to reduce the massive budget deficits. To the dismay of many Republicans, the deal Bush approved for fiscal 1991 includes $140 billion in new taxes. House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., said Wednesday there's support among Democrats for a surtax on millionaires, one of the provisions omitted from the budget deal. Bush said that if Democrats want higher taxes, ``we're in for a whale of a fight and the proffered hand (of conciliation) may miss the shake because we're not going to compromise on that.'' ``What I think we're going to see comng down the pike at me ... is a whole wide array of tax proposals out of the Democrats. ... And they're going to do it over my dead veto - or live veto, or something like that, because it ain't going to happen, I'll guarantee you.'' With his latest pledge of no-new-taxes and his bashing of Democrats, Bush appeared to be testing themes for his own re-election race in 1992 - although he insisted he hasn't decided whether to run. ``I'm not thinking about '92,'' he said. Bush mugged an exaggerated grin when asked about the weaker-than-expected election showings Tuesday of two potential Democratic rivals - New York Gov. Mario Cuomo and New Jersey Sen. Bill Bradley. He said he was heartened that GOP losses in gubernatorial and congressional races were well below historical trends for a party that controls the White House. ``I'm not talking about victory because I am very disappointed that way some of the races turned out,'' Bush said.

DOC.HEAD: President Vows Greater Economic Independence For Pakistan
DOC.TEXT: In a strident address before parliament Thursday, President Ghulam Ishaq Khan promised to end his country's hat-in-hand relationship with the United States. Ishaq Khan also warned the 12-year-old war in neighboring Afghanistan would not end until the Soviet Union halted its support for that country's Communist government. The president made his remarks in a speech to a joint session of Parliament. As expected, Pakistan's new Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif easily won a vote of confidence in the 217-member National Assembly, the policy-making lower house that two days earlier elected him prime minister. He received 153 votes. It was unclear why the vote was called so soon because Sharif has yet to form a government. Under Pakistani law, a vote of confidence must be held within three months. ``We will no longer have our hands out for help. We can no longer rely on others for our bread and butter. Otherwise, we will never enter the 21st century with our heads held high,'' Ishaq Khan said. Washington suspended $573 million in aid to Pakistan last month after President Bush refused to guarantee that Islamabad did not possess the capability for making nuclear weapons. There were claims, however, the aid cut was an attempt to bolster Ms. Bhutto's election campaign. It is believed that both Pakistan and its often hostile neighbor to the east, India, have nuclear capability, although both deny the charges. Former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto, whose 20-month-old government was dismissed by Ishaq Khan Aug. 6 on charges of corruption and mismanagement, did not attend the joint session. ``It wasn't a boycott. She just missed her plane,'' a spokesman for Ms. Bhutto said on condition of anonymity. But none of Ms. Bhutto's Pakistan People's Party members in parliament attended the session. Ms. Bhutto has accused the president of staging a constitutional coup against her government and engineering massive vote fraud in last month's national elections. The right-wing Islamic Democratic Alliance swept to power in those elections. The coalition of 18 diverse parties capitalized on the simmering anti-American sentiment in Pakistan. While Ms. Bhutto tried to portray herself as the symbol of democracy that generated much needed foreign aid for Pakistan, her opponents painted her as an American puppet. ``To those who wish to extend their hand of friendship as equal partners we will take it. ... But we shall not compromise on our basic rights,'' Ishaq Khan said. ``We hope that America will realize the importance of our friendship rather than reacting to allegations.'' Before the election, U.S. congressmen warned the president against disqualifying Ms. Bhutto. The former prime minister faces seven charges of misconduct before special one-judge tribunals. Conviction on any one of the charges could bar her from politics for seven years. In his 30-minute Urdu-language speech, Ishaq Khan also warned Moscow there would be no end to the civil war in neighboring Afghanistan unless it abandons its support for the Kabul government. ``It must be clear to the Soviet Union that what they allowed to happen in Eastern Europe must also be applied to Afghanistan. Otherwise, we will never have peace in the region,'' he said. U.S.-backed Afghan insurgents have fought successive Communist governments in Kabul from their bases in Pakistan. When Soviet soldiers left Afghanistan in February 1989 after nine years and the Moslem resistance failed in major battles, attention shifted toward a political settlement, something the fundamentalist guerrillas reject.

DOC.HEAD: Alleged Bomber, on Hunger Strike, Appeals Extradition
DOC.TEXT: A suspect in an IRA bombing who has been on a hunger strike for 30 days appealed to the Supreme Court on Thursday to block his extradition to Britain. The case is the first to come before the courts under the 1987 extradition act, which Irish Prime Minister Charles Haughey has said will facilitate the extradition of terrorist suspects. Dessie Ellis, 38, is wanted in Britain in connection with five bomb attacks in the early 1980s. He says he cannot get a fair trial there and should not be extradited. On Wednesday, he was hospitalized, and he was not in court for the appeal. ``I will die rather than be extradited to Britain,'' Ellis said in an interview published recently in Republican News, a weekly newspaper that reflects the views of the outlawed Irish Republican Army and its legal political wing, Sinn Fein. Britain's attorney general has issued warrants accusing Ellis of conspiracy and possessing explosives. Ellis' attorney, Patrick McEntee, made three arguments against extradition: that there are no corresponding offenses in Irish law, that the six-year delay would make extradition ``unfair, improper and constitutionally wrong,'' and that Ellis cannot receive a fair trial in Britain. Chief Justice Thomas Finlay, one of five judges who heard the appeal, reserved judgment. There was no indication when the court would rule, but Irish Justice Minister Ray Burke had warned Ellis on Tuesday that he might be dead by the time the court rules if he persists in his hunger strike. Burke has refused appeals from Ellis' family that he intervene to block extradition. His family said Ellis has lost 30 pounds and suffers from fatigue, dizziness and sore eyes. The charges involve five incidents in 1981 in which three people were killed and a military officer lost part of a leg. In previous hearings, a detective from Scotland Yard said 13 fingerprints found in a cache of explosives link Ellis to the crimes. Extradition has been a contentious issue between Britain and Ireland, especially because of past cases in which suspects have successfully pleaded that their alleged offenses were ``political.'' Owen Carron and James Pius Clarke, who successfully appealed extradition earlier this year, attended Thursday's hearing. So did Patrick Ryan, a Roman Catholic priest sought in Britain on terrorist charges who convinced the Irish courts last year that he could not get a fair trial. Opponents of extradition point to recent cases in Britain in which appeals courts reversed convictions of alleged IRA members, but only after some had been in prison 15 years. Ten prisoners belonging to the IRA or the Irish National Liberation Army died on hunger strikes in the Maze Prison in Northern Ireland in 1981. The best known was Bobby Sands, who was elected to Parliament during his 65-day fast. No one has died on a hunger strike in Ireland since 1946.

DOC.HEAD: Homosexual Wins First Round In Legal Battle With Boy Scouts
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Retransmitting a0665 to correct cycle designator.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto LA11
DOC.TEXT: A judge's ruling has cleared the way for a homosexual man to proceed with a discrimination lawsuit against the Boy Scouts of America and its national policy banning homosexuals as poor role models. Timothy Curran, 29, was asked to leave the Scouts in 1980 when he took a young man to his senior prom. He filed his lawsuit in 1981 when his bid to return as an adult leader was rejected. Superior Court Judge Sally Disco ruled late Tuesday that the Mount Diablo Council in the San Francisco Bay area is subject to California's Unruh Civil Rights Act. The act forbids businesses from discriminating on the basis of sexual orientation, race, religion or disability. Disco said the council is a business because it has considerable property holdings and makes money by selling products to the public. The Boy Scouts had argued that it is a non-profit organization free to promote its own moral philosophy. Curran, a free-lance television editor and former Eagle Scout, said he wants to serve as a scout leader and is not seeking monetary damages. ``I'm really pleased to see that after 10 years in the courts this case is developing some momentum and moving toward a conclusion,'' Curran said Wednesday. The two sides will meet Nov. 16 to discuss a date for the start of a jury trial. George Davidson, an attorney for the Boy Scouts, said he believes the lawsuit will be decided in the organization's favor.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Candidate Appears in Strong Position for Presidency
DOC.TEXT: A lawyer who favors liberalizing strict laws on birth control and abortion appeared in a strong position Thursday to become Ireland's first woman president, according to partial and unofficial returns. Mary Robinson trailed former deputy prime minister Brian Lenihan in the preliminary count, but pre-election polls indicated the second round on Friday would put her over the top. ``It looks like President Robinson now,'' said Justice Minister Ray Burke, who had supported Lenihan, a member of the dominant Fianna Fail party. ``It's looking good, but it's not by any manner or means decided yet,'' said Mrs. Robinson, whose supporters staged early celebrations. She was nominated by the Labor and Workers party, although she has no party affiliation. As president, she would be expected to refrain from any political controversies. The president's main powers are the right to dissolve Parliament when a government has lost support, and to refer legislation to the Supreme Court. On Thursday afternoon, unofficial returns showed Lenihan with 44.5 percent of the vote; Mrs. Robinson with 38.8 percent and Austin Currie of Fine Gael with 16.7 percent, according to Press Association, a British news agency. Turnout was estimated at 63 percent of the 2.47 million eligible voters, compared with 68 percent in parliamentary elections last year. Under the Irish system, voters mark a second preference on their ballots. In the second round, Currie stands to be eliminated and his votes distributed among the two top finishers. A poll published Tuesday in The Irish Times indicated that urrie's supporters preferred Mrs. Robinson by 3-to-1 over Lenihan. Currie had urged his supporters to make her their second choice. Former Prime Minister Garret FitzGerald of Fine Gael said on Irish Radio that he expected Mrs. Robinson to finish with 52 percent of the vote. Mrs. Robinson, 46, would be the first leftist candidate to be president of Ireland, and the first since 1945 who didn't come from Fianna Fail. She is a lecturer in European Community law at Trinity College in Dublin, and has supported more liberal contraception laws, legalized divorce and the right of women to obtain information about abortion, which is outlawed in Ireland but available in Britain. Lenihan, 59, was first elected to Parliament in the 1960s, and has held several Cabinet posts. Prime Minister Charles Haughey was forced to dismiss Lenihan as deputy prime mininster and defense minister last week to save his coalition government from collapse. Lenihan was accused of lying about a his role in a 1982 attempts to keep President Patrick Hillery from calling a national election. Lenihan quickly dropped from front-runner to second place in opinion polls. Currie, 51, was a leader in the Catholic civil rights campaign in Northern Ireland in the 1960s and a founder of the Social Democratic and Labor Party, the main Catholic party there. He moved to the Irish Republic and was elected last year to the Dail, the lower house of Parliament. All three candidates are Catholics. It is Ireland's first contested presidential election in 17 years.

DOC.HEAD: Transportation Secretary Calls For End to Rail-Truck Feud
DOC.TEXT: Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner called for a truce Thursday in the escalating battle between the nation's railroads and the trucking industry. The struggle, with each side threatening to take steps to hurt the competitive position of the other, was prompted by the desire of truckers to increase productivity by introducing heavier and longer trucks to the nation's highways. That led to fears in the railroad industry that profits could be slashed as cargo shifted from freight trains to the larger trucks. The fight is expected to move to Congress next year as the House and Senate consider federal policies on surface transportation, a debate that could lead to authorization of larger trucks. ``Competition between the railroad and trucking industries is healthy and something that we expect and need,'' Skinner told the annual meeting of the Railway Progress Institute. ``However, all of us recognize that a war of words can escalate into the kind of conflict in which both sides are damaged,'' the transportation secretary said. ``I am therefore beginning a very concerted effort to urge both industries to remember that while they may argue about the political and economic issues at one level, reality requires that they cooperate at other levels,'' he said. ``Too much is at stake from a global competition standpoint for the railroad and trucking industry to fight with each other,'' Skinner said. He said he will deliver an identical message to the trucking industry. ``The message applies equally,'' he said. ``I favor no mode over the other.'' Skinner said his job was to ``assure that everyone gets heard, that no one gets bowled over, that the end result is in the best interest of the public and America's position in the global economy,''

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with further quotes, combines pvs in top 10 grafs
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said today he has ordered a new wave of U.S. troops to the Persian Gulf area to give the multinational military force there an ``adequate offensive military option should that be necessary.'' The president's announcement at a White House news conference did not specify how many more American forces would be added to Operation Desert Shield, but Pentagon sources said it could be more than 100,000. The sources said the extra troops would include armored divisions from U.S. bases in Germany and possibly from the United States. Bush said he did not need to get United Nations approval to launch a military action against Iraq but indicated the administration would first seek out that support. ``Yes, we have the authority but we've been great believers in going to the United Nations,'' Bush said in a question and answer session after his announcement. Bush said he still held out hope the confrontation over Iraq's invasion and occupation of Kuwait could be settled short of war. But he also said he wanted to give the American ground commander in Saudi Arabia, Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, a credible offensive option. ``I would love to see a peaceful resolution to this question and that's what I want,'' the president said as Defense Secretary Dick Cheney stood nearby. But Bush added, ``I have not ruled out use of force at all, and that's what's evident by what we've done here today.'' Bush said 230,000 U.S. forces are in the gulf area now to ensure that Iraqi President Saddam Hussein does not gain a ``chokehold on the world's economic lifeline.'' High Pentagon officials have indicated for some time that additional forces were being considered for the Operation Desert Shield force now totaling 230,000 from the United States and 70,000 for allied countries. Iraq has deployed more than 400,000 troops in the region. In late October, Cheney said up to another 100,000 men and women could be sent to the gulf area. He said at the time the Pentagon had set no upper limit on deployments and that he wanted enough force ``to deal with any contingency.'' The source who disclosed the decision to send extra troops declined to say how many would go. An armored division has nearly 20,000 troops but can require so many support units that it may account for as many as 40,000 personnel. Meanwhile, a Marine official said Wednesday many hundreds more combat troops from the Marine Corps Reserve are likely to be ordered to active duty. The Marines on Tuesday said 824 reservists, including 633 combat specialists, were being activated to become part of a 5th Marine Expeditionary Brigade undergoing desert warfare training in California. Those were the first combat reserve forces to be put on active duty in the Persian Gulf crisis. Col. Russell Appleton, head of manpower policy and planning at Marine Corps headquarters, said reserves will be used to help form expeditionary brigades to replace units scheduled to rotate out of the gulf area. ``You're seeing the tip of that spear'' of reserve deployments, he said, adding that he could not comment on any reserve call-ups beyond those announced this week. Also on Wednesday, the Bush administration denounced the procession of foreign dignitaries to Baghdad to plead for the release of hostages. It is ``a matter of great concern to us,'' presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said. He referred specifically to recent missions by former West German chancellor Willy Brandt, former British prime minister Edward Heath and former Japanese prime minster Yasuhiro Nakasone. ``Clearly, these people are being used. And we want to point that out in the strongest terms,'' Fitzwater said.

DOC.HEAD: State Experiencing Negative Impact From King Holiday Defeat
With AM-King Boulevard
DOC.TEXT: Arizona voters' rejection of two ballot measures that would have established a Martin Luther King Day already is taking a toll on the state's pocketbook, economic development and business leaders said. David Radcliffe, president of Phoenix & Valley of the Sun Convention and Visitors Bureau, said he knows of at least four groups that have canceled reservations for conventions or stays at hotels since the propositions failed in Tuesday's election. He could not identify the groups Thursday or say how many visitors they would have brought to Arizona. ``I'm not anxious to call people to see if they want to cancel,'' Radcliffe said. ``I've never been as high as the day we booked the Super Bowl, and I've never been so low as I feel now.'' NFL commissioner Paul Tagliabue said Wednesday he will recommend the 1993 Super Bowl be moved from the Phoenix area because of the defeat of the King holiday. Gov. Rose Mofford estimated that losing the Super Bowl would cost Arizona $200 million in lost revenue. Robert Hayward, a tourism analyst for the Pannell Kerr Forester accounting firm, said losing the Super Bowl would not just mean losing money, but also losing face. ``The Super Bowl leaving could be even worse for our image (than the King Day rejection). It could put us squarely in the national limelight,'' Hayward said. Since then-Gov. Evan Mecham in 1987 rescinded a holiday declared by his predecessor, about 40 convention groups have canceled their Arizona plans and the state has lost about $30 million, Radcliffe said. Those figures are based only on what is documented, he said, adding that other groups may have ruled out the state and state officials would never even know of the loss. Robert Rudder, sales director for The Sheraton hotel in downtown Phoenix, said two groups canceled reservations there since the election, resulting in a $250,000 loss of revenue. He would not identify the groups. The Sheraton will honor the holiday and is mounting a drive to raise the $500,000 it is estimated it would cost the state to give state employees a paid holiday, Rudder said. The hotel is offering $50,000, he said. Rudder said the holiday was defeated Tuesday because the two propositions on the ballot were ``conflicting and confusing.'' One measure called for eliminating the state's existing Columbus Day holiday and creating a King Day. The other called for having both as paid holidays. The two propositions grew out of grassroots petition drives following legislative action. The holiday issue may not be the deciding factor for businesses and visitors to come to the state, but it may be used as an excuse, said Chuck Shipley, vice president for government affairs for the state Chamber of Commerce. The King Day issue also could tip the balance if it is a close choice between Arizona and another state for a new industrial plant, said Lois Yates, deputy director of the Arizona Department of Commerce. Bob Mariano, president and chief executive of Chase Bank of Arizona, said executives from the parent Chase Manhattan Corp. of New York expressed concern over the holiday defeat. The executives would not say if the vote would affect their decision on where to relocate a proposed credit-card operation, Mariano said. Suburban Tempe is one of two finalists for the 2,000-employee operation. The other is Salt Lake City.

DOC.HEAD: Germany, Poland Agree to Sign Border Treaty
DOC.TEXT: Chancellor Helmut Kohl announced Thursday that Poland and the newly united Germany will sign a historic border treaty this month, ending decades of concern over the common frontier. Kohl also said he wanted a wide-ranging friendship and cooperation treaty to be submitted to the German and Polish legislatures for ratification by the end of February. ``We are deeply convinced that real peace will be possible only if Germans and Poles march together along this road into a peaceful future,'' Kohl said of the treaties. He made the comments following a day of talks with Polish Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki, the first foreign leader to visit united Germany. Mazowiecki said he was satisfied with the ``important results'' of the talks in this German border town on the Oder River across from Poland. Mazowiecki also said the German-Polish border must not be a divider between East and West. ``We want this border to bring us closer and not to divide Europe between the developed rich and the poor,'' he said. The meeting came exactly one year after Kohl became the first Western leader to visit newly democratic Poland, a trip interrupted when the dramatic news reached Warsaw that the Berlin Wall had fallen. Kohl pleased his Polish guests on Thursday by saying he hoped visa requirements for Poles to visit Germany would be lifted by Christmas. ``I think we made great progress for the future,'' Polish government spokeswoman Malgorzata Niezabitowska told reporters, adding the visit was ``a big success.'' People from former East Germany do not need visas to visit Poland, and many travel there to shop in the flourishing, inexpensive Polish markets. While Polish traders welcome the business, other Poles have expressed resentment over their need for visas. After their talks, Kohl and Mazowiecki crossed the wide bridge over the Oder into the Polish town of Slubice, where they were greeted by about 1,000 cheering residents. The border treaty would confirm the present border formed by the Oder and Neisse rivers and commit Germany to relinquishing claims on former German territory forever. The Oder-Neisse border, drawn by the victorious wartime Allies in 1945, gave Poland 45,000 square miles of formerly German land. An even larger part of Poland was taken by the Soviet Union after the war. The post-war explusion of millions of German refugees is still an emotional issue in Germany. During the news conference, a man identifying himself as Hermann Schulz held up a German flag together with that of his homeland in East Prussia, now part of Poland. ``We should be allowed to be represented at these talks. We want to return to our homeland,'' he said. Many Germans have questioned the border through the years, dreaming of a possible return to the Silesian, Pomeranian and East Prussian land that make up about one-third of present-day Poland. Travel between the two countries should become easier soon. Kohl said the two-lane, 372-mile stretch of highway that links Warsaw and the German capital Berlin should be improved. The friendship and cooperation treaty, like a treaty to be signed between Germany and the Soviet Union on Friday, will lay the foundation for future economic, political and cultural cooperation. Kohl stressed Germany's commitment to helping Poland make the transformation from a socialist to a capitalist economy, adding that he would help Poland obtain associate member status in the European Community. Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher is to travel to Warsaw later this month to sign the border treaty with his Polish counterpart Krzystof Skubiszewski. A precise date was not given.

DOC.HEAD: Harrisburg Voters Choose to Change King Boulevard Back to Former Name
With AM-King-Arizona
DOC.TEXT: Racism prompted city voters to reverse a 4-year-old decision that named a street in honor of slain civil rights leader Martin Luther King Jr., critics said. Harrisburg voters approved a referendum Tuesday to change to name of Rev. Dr. M.L. King Boulevard back to Market Street. The Rev. Jefferson Wright, who opposed the referendum, said racism drove voters. ``The street was there for four years until a bunch of racists came along to take it down as a reassurance in their minds of their power,'' he said. The City Council voted in 1986 to name 24 blocks of the major thoroughfare after King. Residents opposed to the change won a non-binding referendum in the spring of 1987 to return the street's name to Market Street, but the City Council ignored it. Enraged, the residents hit the streets to gather enough signatures to put a binding referendum on Tuesday's ballot. James H. High, a supporter of the referendum, denied the charges of racism. He said people were angry that the council had ignored the wishes of a majority of voters. ``I think this raised such a fervor because it's always been Market Street and we've always had a Market Street. Most cities have a Market Street,'' he said. Some residents of King Boulevard also complained about the inconvenience of changing their addresses. A spokesman for Mayor Stephen Reed said the new street signs should be in place within the next 30 days. ``The idea of them taking the signs down hurts so bad,'' said referendum opponent Dana Olsen. ``I have an image of them taking the signs down and throwing them in the back of some open-panel truck and dumping them somewhere. That hurts.''

DOC.HEAD: French High School Protesters Seek More Spending on Education
DOC.TEXT: More than 50,000 high school students continued protests Thursday seeking more spending on education, and hundreds blocked railway tracks to demand free train rides to a mass rally in Paris. At several stations where youths occupied the tracks, officials of the national railroad offered 60 percent discounts to those wishing to attend Monday's rally. It was not immediately clear if the students accepted the offer. Thursday's protests were largely without violence, as has been the case throughout most of the three-week campaign. Youths in Lyon broke windows and threw stones, injuring one student, but protest organizers described the troublemakers as ``outside elements.'' In Paris, where a few thousand students marched, some youths smashed windows and looted a shoe store. Police reported seven arrests. Marches and rallies have taken place daily across France this week, and an even bigger show of force is expected Monday when, for the first time, students have been urged to converge on Paris from throughout the country. On Thursday, major associations of parents and teachers endorsed the students' goals. The biggest turnout was in Toulouse, where an estimated 15,000 students marched. Several hundred blocked tracks at the train station, demanding a free trip to Paris on Monday, and railroad officials offered a round-trip fare of $40 - a 60 percent discount. Tracks at several other stations also were blocked by youths demanding free rides to Paris on Monday. About 3,000 students protested in Lyon, 5,000 in Besancon, 4,000 in Reims, 6,000 in Rennes, 10,000 in Brest, 6,000 in Quimper and 2,000 in Toulon, according to police and student and media estimates. The protests began in the northern suburbs of Paris following the gang rape of a girl in a school lavatory and assaults on several teachers. The students have been demanding more government spending to improve security on campus, replace substandard facilities, upgrade curriculum and hire more teachers to ease classroom overcrowding.

DOC.HEAD: Not Many `Rascals' Out, But THRO Vows to Try Again
DOC.TEXT: A national grassroots drive to oust incumbent politicians may have failed this election year, but its founder said Thursday he is already looking ahead to the 1992 elections. ``We're going to take a look at what we did wrong and how we can make it better. Then it's back to business,'' Jack Gargan said. ``Now we have the funding, credibility - and two years.'' Gargan said his group, ``Throw the Hypocritical Rascals Out'' or THRO, intends to buy a full-page advertisement in USA Today to thank supporters nationwide, then begin looking toward 1992 and races for president and Congress. ``We're going to say `thank you, America' and let folks know we're going for bear in '92,'' he said. Gargan said a national taxpayer association representative told him Thursday that Tuesday's races involving incumbents were roughly 12 percent closer than had been predicted. ``When you can go from a dead stop in 132 days and make a 12 percent impact with no staff, no funding and no experience, it's heartwarming,'' he said. Gargan, 59, who is a financial planner, formed the non-profit THRO in June and targeted members of Congress as irresponsible spenders to be voted out. He used $9,000 in retirement money to buy a full-page local newspaper advertisement headlined: ``I'm mad as hell and I'm not going to take it anymore!'' Since then, he said he's received about $600,000 in contributions and letters from more than 70,000 people. As the money came in, he bought ads in newspapers small and large, urging people to vote against all incumbents in all races. While he doesn't have final figures yet, Gargan said the campaign war chest should have $100,000 to $200,000 left. ``We became sort of a threat and we forced them (incumbents) to spend much more of that PAC (political action committee) money to boost themselves,'' he said. ``We also made people across this nation step back and look at who's running this country.'' Gary Koops, spokesman for the Republican Congressional Campaign Committee in Washington, said THRO reflected the discontent of voters nationwide who were weary of ``business as usual'' in Congress. ``Many incumbents who'll be going back to Washington were scared for their political lives,'' Koops said. Others - such as Hollis Friedman, a spokeswoman for the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee in Washington - said the anti-incumbent sentiment was overblown. ``The few incumbents that did lose lost because they weren't addressing the people's needs and interests properly and not because people just wanted to get rid of an incumbent,'' Friedman said. Robin Krivanek, Hillsborough County supervisor of elections, said the anti-incumbent mood came through loud and clear locally. ``What amazed us is that there were people out there taking a blanket approach to this campaign,'' Krivanek said. ``We had people who had no idea of who these people were but wanted their names so they could vote them out.''

DOC.HEAD: FCC Takes Tentative Step Against Toy-Based TV Programs
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Communications Commission moved Thursday toward a possible crackdown on children's TV programs based on toys, but an official said the agency was ``twisting and turning'' to steer clear of shows such as ``Sesame Street.'' Critics contend that programs such as ``He-Man'' and ``G.I. Joe'' are thinly disguised sales pitches and have urged the FCC to declare such shows to be 30-minute commercials. The commission, however, wasn't willing to go that far. ``The mere fact that a story line ... is built around a toy being sold on the market would not make it a program-length commercial,'' said Regina Harrison, a lawyer in the FCC's mass media bureau. The commission, she said, was ``twisting and turning trying to reach a definition that won't cut out shows'' such as ``Sesame Street.'' The commission, under orders from Congress to complete a 3-year-old investigation into so-called program-length commercials, proposed defining such programs as any children's show ``associated with a product in which commercials for that product are aired.'' Previously, the commission defined program-length commercials as material ``so interwoven with, and in essence auxiliary to, the sponsor's advertising'' that the entire program is in effect a commercial. Peggy Charren, president of the Action for Children's Television, said manufacturers don't advertise their toys on shows based on their products for fear children won't notice the ads. She said the FCC's proposed definition would not solve the problem of shows being used to promote toys. The commission invited public comment on what penalties, if any, should be imposed on program-length commercials. Harrison said violators could receive fines or have their licenses threatened at renewal, or both. The commission also said it would consider during license renewal whether a station had provided programs specifically designed to meet the educational and informational needs of children. The commission, in the same 5-0 vote Thursday, proposed implementing ad time limits that Congress ordered as part of the Children's Television Act of 1990. Those limits are 10.5 minutes per hour on weekends and 12 minutes per hour on weekdays on children's shows, including cable TV. The rules are to take effect in April, and violations could lead to fines from $25,000 to $250,000. The commission lifted similar restrictions in 1984, but congressional testimony showed that advertising on some programs increased to 14 minutes per hour. A federal appeals court in 1987 ordered the FCC to reconsider its decision.

DOC.HEAD: Alleged Bomber, on Hunger Strike, Appeals Extradition
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead to CORRECT to suspect in IRA bombings sted singular. Picks up 2nd pvs, `The case...' CHANGES story slug from AM-Ireland-IRA to AM-IRA Appeal to conform to news advisory.
DOC.TEXT: A suspect in IRA bombings who has been on a hunger strike for 30 days appealed Thursday to the Supreme Court to block his extradition to Britain. The case is the first to come before the courts under the 1987 extradition act, which Irish Prime Minister Charles Haughey has said will facilitate the extradition of terrorist suspects. Dessie Ellis, 38, is wanted in Britain in connection with five bomb attacks in the early 1980s. He says he cannot get a fair trial there and should not be extradited. On Wednesday, he was hospitalized, and he was not in court for the appeal. ``I will die rather than be extradited to Britain,'' Ellis said in an interview published recently in Republican News, a weekly newspaper that reflects the views of the outlawed Irish Republican Army and its legal political wing, Sinn Fein. Britain's attorney general has issued warrants accusing Ellis of conspiracy and possessing explosives. Ellis' attorney, Patrick McEntee, made three arguments against extradition: that there are no corresponding offenses in Irish law, that the six-year delay would make extradition ``unfair, improper and constitutionally wrong,'' and that Ellis cannot receive a fair trial in Britain. Chief Justice Thomas Finlay, one of five judges who heard the appeal, reserved judgment. There was no indication when the court would rule, but Irish Justice Minister Ray Burke had warned Ellis on Tuesday that he might be dead by the time the court rules if he persists in his hunger strike. Burke has refused appeals from Ellis' family that he intervene to block extradition. His family said Ellis has lost 30 pounds and suffers from fatigue, dizziness and sore eyes. The charges involve five incidents in 1981 in which three people were killed and a military officer lost part of a leg. In previous hearings, a detective from Scotland Yard said 13 fingerprints found in a cache of explosives link Ellis to the crimes. Extradition has been a contentious issue between Britain and Ireland, especially because of past cases in which suspects have successfully pleaded that their alleged offenses were ``political.''
