Owen Carron and James Pius Clarke, who successfully appealed extradition earlier this year, attended Thursday's hearing. So did Patrick Ryan, a Roman Catholic priest sought in Britain on terrorist charges who convinced the Irish courts last year that he could not get a fair trial. Opponents of extradition point to recent cases in Britain in which appeals courts reversed convictions of alleged IRA members, but only after some had been in prison 15 years. Ten prisoners belonging to the IRA or the Irish National Liberation Army died on hunger strikes in the Maze Prison in Northern Ireland in 1981. The best known was Bobby Sands, who was elected to Parliament during his 65-day fast. No one has died on a hunger strike in Ireland since 1946.
Here is a transcript of remarks by President Bush and Defense Secretary Dick Cheney announcing the dispatch of additional U.S. troops to the Persian Gulf.

PRESIDENT BUSH: I have a brief statement and then I'd be glad to take a couple of questions and then turn to Secretary Cheney who will take some questions. And then he will go over to the Pentagon for an in-depth - more of an in-depth briefing. On August 6th, in response to the unprovoked Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, I ordered the deployment of U.S. military forces to Saudi Arabia and the Persian Gulf to deter further Iraqi aggression and to protect our interests in the region. What we've done is right, and I'm happy to say that most members of Congress and the majority of Americans agree. Before the invasion in August, we had succeeded in the struggle for freedom in Eastern Europe, and we'd hopefully begun a new era that offered the promise of peace. Following the invasion, I stated that if history had taught it any lesson it was that we must resist aggression or it would destroy our freedom. Just ask the people of Kuwait and the foreign nationals in hiding there and the staffs of the remaining embassies who have experienced the horrors of Iraq's illegal occupation, its systematic dismantling of Kuwait and its abuse of Kuwaitis and other citizens. The world community also must prevent an individual clearly bent on regional domination from establishing a choke hold on the world's economic lifeline. We are seeing global economic stability and growth already at risk as each day countries around the world pay dearly for Saddam Hussein's aggression. From the very beginning, we and our coalition partners have shared common political goals: the immediate, complete and unconditional withdrawal of Iraqi forces from Kuwait; restoration of Kuwait's legitimate government; protection of the lives of citizens held hostage by Iraq, both in Kuwait and Iraq; and restoration of security and stability in the Persian Gulf region. To achieve these goals, we and our allies have forged a strong diplomatic, economic and military strategy to force Iraq to comply with these objectives. The framework of this strategy is laid out in 10 United Nations resolutions overwhelmingly supported by the United Nations Security Council. In three months, the U.S. troop contribution to the multinational force in Saudi Arabia has gone from 10,000 to 230,000 as part of Operation Desert Shield. Gen. Schwarzkopf reports that our forces in conjunction with other coalition forces now have the capability to defend successfully against any further Iraqi aggression. After consultation with King Fahd and our other allies, I have today directed the Secretary of Defense to increase the size of U.S. forces committed to Desert Shield to ensure that the coalition has an adequate offensive military option should that be necessary to achieve our common goals. Toward this end, we will continue to discuss the possibility of both additional allied force contributions and appropriate United Nation actions. Iraq's brutality, aggression and violations of international law cannot be allowed to succeed.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Former Judge Helps Network Present Noriega Tapes
With AM-Noriega Tapes, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: When CNN continued its coverage of recorded telephone conversations of Manuel Noriega while appealing a federal judge's order in the case Thursday, a former judge read the story. Catherine Crier, a former Texas District Court judge, was one of several anchors telling viewers that CNN continued to broadcast its first report on the jailed Panamanian dictator because U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler's ruling would amount to unconstitutional prior restraint. Hoeveler issued a temporary injunction in Miami barring CNN from broadcasting parts of recordings of Noriega's conversations with his lawyers that could infringe on attorney-client privilege. CNN used excerpts from the jailhouse tapes Thursday morning, repeated that during the day and said it planned to televise another installment Thursday evening. The Atlanta-based cable news operation said it would appeal Hoeveler's ruling. Ms. Crier, the youngest woman elected to Texas District Court, was among the anchors explaining that CNN continued to repeat the morning segment ``because it believes it has the right to do so under the First Amendment.'' CNN said Ms. Crier had nothing to do with the decision to broadcast the story, and was reading the same commentary as other anchors. CNN declined to allow her to be interviewed about the story's judicial ramifications. Ms. Crier created a stir when she was hired at the 24-hour news network in 1989 with no journalistic experience. She has said she left the judgeship because courtroom competition ``may have surpassed the notion of serving clients, of seeking justice.''

DOC.HEAD: Food Coupons to be Issued in Moscow on Dec. 1
DOC.TEXT: Coupons will be distributed to Muscovites beginning Dec. 1 to ensure that staples such as meat, butter and flour are not stripped from the capital's shelves by non-resident shoppers, a newspaper reported Thursday. The coupons, to be sold for about $56 for a month's supply, will enable residents to purchase 3.3 pounds of meat, nearly a half-pound of butter and 1.1 pounds of flour, according to the Moskovsky Komsomolets newspaper. The newspaper article indicated the coupons might buy other items but it did not list them. It also did not provide any more details on the program, except to say the measure was announced by Moscow Mayor Gavriil Popov. The move appeared to represent the latest attempt by city officials to keep out-of-towners from raiding the usually better-stocked store shelves in Moscow. In recent weeks, there have been fears that Moscow will be facing a hungry winter because of the nation's worsening economy, problems with supplies of food and a poor harvest of traditionally plentiful staples such as potatoes. Residents would not necessarily be limited to these stated amounts of meat, flour and butter, but could buy them at higher-priced private markets. Coupons already are issued for sugar and cigarettes, limiting citizens to 4.4 pounds of sugar and seven packs of cigarettes per month per person. Other cities in the country have different limitations on these goods and others, including vodka. The coupons do not ensure that the products can be found, however. Even with coupons, some residents have a hard time finding sugar for sale at state stores. In May, state stores began requiring that shoppers in Moscow show their internal passports to prove they live in the region. The move stemmed from a wave of panic-buying that followed the announcement of plans to increase prices of certain goods - plans that later were canceled. The residence requirement angered shoppers who had to remember to carry their passports with them and slowed down long queues while sales clerks looked for the stamp that indicated Moscow residency. Many clerks simply stopped checking for the residency stamp, defeating the purpose of the regulations. The Moskovsky Komsomolets newspaper sarcastically headlined the brief article on the introduction of the food coupons, ``Let's have a feast.''

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Union Gives Qualified Support For Use Of Force In Gulf
DOC.TEXT: Reluctantly and for the first time, the Soviet Union gave its qualified consent Thursday to the use of military force to get Iraqi invaders out of Kuwait if peaceful pressure tactics fail. But even as U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III accomplished this goal, it became apparent that an arms control treaty due for signing in Paris in less than two weeks was still not finished. Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze said there were problems concluding the accord to reduce NATO and Warsaw Pact tanks, antiaircraft artillery and other non-nuclear weapons in Europe. U.S. officials, who demanded anonymity, said the problems were more than technical in nature and that Baker would leave behind arms control experts to keep working on them when he flies to London and Paris on Friday to continue his consultations on the Persian Gulf situation. Baker came to Moscow on Wednesday seeking at least Soviet acquiescence to the Bush administration's intention of having the U.N. Security Council authorize the use of force as a last resort to liberate Kuwait. His visit came as President Bush announced in Washington that he has ordered a new wave of U.S. troops to the Persian Gulf area to give the multinational military force there an ``adequate offensive military option should that be necessary.'' Baker has talked about the military option during his travels to Bahrain, Saudi Arabia, Egypt, Turkey and the Soviet Union. On Tuesday in Cairo Chinese Foreign Minister Qian Qichen told Baker that China, along with the Soviet Union, the United States, France and Britain a permanent member of the U.N. Security Council, would not block a U.N. resolution on the use of force. Shevardnadze made no mention of military action in a joint news conference with Baker until he was pressed by reporters. Finally, he said: ``whether or not the use of force could be ruled out -- probably this could not be ruled out -- and a situation may emerge which effectively would require such a move.'' Baker, who stood tensely at Shevardnadze's side, smiled at the assertion. It was the first time the Soviets had indicated publicly they would at least acquiesce if the United States, which holds the presidency of the Security Council this month, attempted to win passage of a resolution authorizing force against Iraq. Shevardnadze stressed that any decision to use force against the Iraqis should be taken by the United Nations. ``We should not doubt the ability of the Security Council to take wise and mature decisions,'' he said. ``I would advise against looking for some difference in the positions between the Soviet Union and the United States,'' Shevardnadze said. Shevardnadze was more evasive in a later session with Soviet reporters. Asked if Moscow would support the use of force under the U.N. Charter, the Soviet foreign minister responded with a laugh: ``I won't say.'' Baker said the two governments had agreed on the principle that a peaceful settlement is preferable but the use of force could not be ruled out. Earlier, Shevardnadze had said the use of force would be ``undesirable'' and that ``the No. 1 task of the international community is to see that the U.N. resolutions are implemented.'' Baker met with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev for nearly two hours at his official country residence outside the city and held sessions with Shevardnadze before and after that meeting. The talks covered 13 hours, after which Baker called Bush with a report. Meanwhile, differences still stood in the way of the Conventional Forces in Europe treaty, the projected centerpiece for a 34-nation summit meeting in Paris Nov. 19-21. ``My guess is that we would be able to find a solution to all the problems,'' Shevardnadze said during a break in his talks with Baker. They then returned to the subject and Margaret Tutwiler, the State Department spokeswoman, said they ``settled a number of technical issues.'' Bush has said he would not attend the summit unless the treaty was ready. It is the most comprehensive arms control accord in history, encompassing Europe from the Atlantic Ocean to the Ural Mountains in the Soviet Union. Hanging in the balance also is another accord to cut U.S. and Soviet long-range nuclear missiles, bombers and submarines by 30 percent. Shevardnadze said there were ``some difficult problems'' with that pact, which Bush had hoped to sign at another summit meeting this winter in Moscow. The outlook is clouded by disagreement over several issues, including how much leeway the Soviets would have to keep testing their SS-18 intercontinental ballistic missiles.

DOC.HEAD: Contaminated Eye Drops Threaten Sight
DOC.TEXT: One woman lost an eye and at least 12 other people are being treated for serious eye infections after using bacteria-contaminated drops made by a pharmacy here, doctors said Thursday. Surgeons at Allegheny General Hospital this week discovered the drops were tainted after the woman who lost her eye was referred to them, said Dr. John Kennerdell, chairman of the hospital's ophthalmology department. ``Once this type of bacteria gains access to the inside of the eye it causes a very devastating infection,'' Kennerdell said. ``That's why it's so dangerous.'' The majority of the 13 patients, mostly women 55 to 78 years old, took the drops after undergoing cataract surgery during the past month, Kennerdell said. It isn't known how many people bought or used the contaminated drops. However, pharmacist Joseph Kilkeary, who made the eye drops, said 20 to 25 customers bought the drops in October. They have been told to quit using the drug and return it to their doctor or the pharmacy. Thirteen people were hospitalized for treatment, nine at Allegheny General, three at Central Medical Center and one at Eye & Ear Institute, all in Pittsburgh, doctors said. One man who used the drops is being monitored by Kennerdell but shows no sign of infection. Doctors removed the woman's right eye last week after antibiotics failed. The 12 other patients are receiving large doses of antibiotics. Two of the patients have impaired vision and could lose an eye, Kennerdell said. Doctors declined to disclose the patients' names. The drops were sold by Hieber's Drug Store, which has been in business for more than a century and is owned by Kilkeary. The pharmacist said he makes about 10 bottles at a time for five Pittsburgh physicians who prescribe the medication. The drops contain a liquid solution and Indocin, a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug taken in pill-form for arthritis. Although the Food and Drug Administration has approved use of Indocin for arthritis, some doctors prescribe it to reduce swelling of the retina following eye surgery, Kennerdell said. Kilkeary dissolves the pills in a liquid solution, sterilizes the mixture and bottles it. Pharmacists commonly mix solutions not offered by drug companies when doctors prescribe them, said Harvey Miller, an FDA spokesman in Philadelphia. He said the practice is legal as long as doctors prescribe the drugs. The FDA will investigate to determine whether any federal laws were violated, he said. Gary Bruell - a spokesman for Merck Sharp & Dohme, the maker of Indocin - said the drug is intended to be taken orally for arthritic conditions. ``We really can't comment on what physicians or pharmacists may be doing with the product outside its current labeling,'' he said. The doctors who prescribed the drops also have been notified, Kennerdell said. Kilkeary said he didn't know how many bottles were contaminated. Lab tests on bottles in the store found no contamination, he said. ``I have no idea how many bottles were not sterile,'' he said. Kilkeary, a pharmacist for more than 40 years, said he has sold the drops for years without any problems and can't imagine what might have gone wrong. Kennerdell said he suspects the pharmacy's sterilizer, used to purify the drops after the solution is mixed, was faulty. Kilkeary said he had no reason to suspect the equipment, which is new.

DOC.HEAD: Hepburn Turns 81
DOC.TEXT: Katharine Hepburn, who turned 81 Thursday, was philosophical about her advancing age, saying ``I look forward to oblivion.'' ``I'm what is known as gradually disintegrating,'' Hepburn said in an interview in her home last month. ``I don't fear the next world, or anything. I don't fear hell, and I don't look forward to heaven.'' But Hepburn was far from all gloom and doom in the interview with The Associated Press. She said she still enjoys life to the fullest and is still being offered acting roles. ``Yes, I get offered roles,'' she said. ``But I'm fascinated by writing now. I find all life thrilling. So that I like to write, I like to paint, I like to play tennis, I like to swim.'' ``I don't like depressing stories about the inevitability of someone going down the drain. Getting old? I think it's unhealthy. Why should anyone want to see that. They're all going to get old, they're all going to fade away.'' Hepburn credits her survival in Hollywood - and life - to her innate sturdiness. ``I'm tough by nature. Tough, direct,'' she said. ``My father was that way. My mother was that way. We were encouraged to be that way. If you do something that is unpopular, but you believe in it, I think that's what matters. And if someone tries to dissuade you from that, I would be very tough about it.''

DOC.HEAD: Analysts See Further Sign of Consumer Spending Slowdown
DOC.TEXT: Americans took out a seasonally adjusted $3 billion more in consumer credit than they paid off in September, the government said Thursday in a report some analysts saw as a further sign of a consumer spending slowdown. Sandra Shaber, an economist with the Futures Group, a Washington management consulting company, said consumer credit this year will increase only 3.5 percent, compared with growth of about 9 percent in both 1988 and 1989. It's another sign of slower spending by consumers who account for two-thirds of the nation's economic activity, she said. The Federal Reserve said consumer credit in September rose 4.9 percent at an annual rate after an increase of 5 percent, or $3.1 billion, in August. While the August borrowing pace was stronger than the 3.4 percent rate first reported last month, it was slower than the 7.8 percent increase posted in July. Ms. Shaber also said the amount of debt compared to disposable personal income has been dropping - a sign, she said, of a lack of consumer confidence. ``And it's not likely to get any better,'' she said. Various surveys have shown that consumer confidence has been fading recently, particularly after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait in August. Declines in confidence often mean a drop in spending - and thus a slower economy - even if consumers have the money. Nevertheless, automobile loans rose in September for the first month since March. They posted a 0.7 percent increase at an annual rate to a seasonally adjusted $163 million after a 6.3 percent, or $1.5 billion decline in August. But Ms. Shaber said that while consumer auto purchases picked up slightly in September, ``we'll see much smaller increases if not some liquidation'' in auto loans in the current quarter. Revolving, or credit card, debt rose 10.7 percent, or $1.9 billion, down from a 13.3 percent growth rate in August. Ms. Shaber said much revolving credit is for convenience buying and is repaid in 30 days. ``It's not really debt,'' she said. Bank and credit union loans not secured by real estate rose 6.6 percent, or $1.2 billion, after jumping 11.7 percent a month earlier. Borrowing for mobile homes fell 11.4 percent, or $219 million, after a 9.5 percent, or $180 million, increase in August. The various changes left total consumer debt at the end of September at $735.4 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Guatemala Voters Indifferent as Presidential Balloting Approaches
DOC.TEXT: Guatemalan voters squeezed by five years of rising inflation and crime are approaching this week's presidential elections with chilly indifference. Guatemala's 3 million registered voters were urged to stay away from the polls in newspaper ads run Thursday by the Guatemalan National Revolutionary Unit, an umbrella group representing the country's guerrilla organizations. Although the ads did not threaten violence in Sunday's election, the group resorted to blowing up bridges and downing trees across highways to keep the electorate away during the country's last election in 1985. President Vinicio Cerezo of the Christian Democrat Party, prevented by law from seeking a second term, became the country's first civilian president following a series of military or military-backed regimes. During his term, unemployment, inflation and crime have risen dramatically. As many as 29 percent of voters questioned by one pollster said they planned to cast a blank ballot on Sunday, a traditional form of protest in this Central American country. Twelve candidates are vying for president. The poll, released Wednesday by Guatemala's private sector, identified the frontrunner as newspaper publisher Jorge Rafael Carpio Nicolle of the National Center Union party, with 21 percent of the vote. Carpio Nicolle, who was narrowly defeated by Cerezo in a runoff election in 1985, has been the frontrunner in polls since he announced his candidacy last year. He was followed, with 17 percent of the vote, by Alvaro Enrique Arzu Irigoyen, the former mayor of Guatemala City who resigned this year to run on the Advanced National Party ticket. Margin of error for the poll was not available. If no candidate gets a majority of the vote on Sunday, the two frontrunners will compete in a runoff vote on Jan. 6, with the winner taking office on Jan. 14. A runoff is considered a virtual certainty. Voters also will choose 116 members of congress and 300 mayors. Cerezo's predecessor, retired Gen. Jose Efrain Rios Montt, was waging a vigorous campaign for Sunday's election until he was ruled constitutionally ineligible to hold office because he came to power during a 1982 military coup. Rios Montt, whose regime of law and order and swift justice is remembered fondly by many Guatemalans but criticized by rights activists, urged voters this week to cast blank presidential ballots but to vote in the other races. A Rios Montt backer has filed a motion to block the elections because he was barred from running, but legal specialists say it is unlikely to be granted. About 300 foreign observers will attend the elections, including Joao Baena Soares, heads of the Organization of American States. Preliminary results from the nation's 5,630 polling places are expected Sunday night.

DOC.HEAD: WASHN: to succeed.
DOC.TEXT: Secretary Baker has been consulting with our key partners in the coalition. He's met with the Emirs of Bahrain and Kuwait, King Fahd, President Mubarak, as well as the Chinese foreign minister, President Ozal, Foreign Minister Shevardnadze, President Gorbachev. He also will be meeting with Prime Minister Thatcher and President Mitterrand. I have been heartened by Jim's appraisal of the strong international solidarity and determination to ensure that Iraq's aggression does not stand and is not rewarded. But right now Kuwait is struggling for survival. And along with many other nations, we've been called upon to help. The consequences of our not doing so would be incalculable, because Iraq's aggression is not just a challenge to the security of Kuwait and other Gulf nations, but to the better world that we all have hoped to build in the wake of the Cold War. And therefore, we and our allies cannot and will not shirk our responsibilities. The state of Kuwait must be restored, or no nation will be safe, and the promising future we anticipate will indeed be jeopardized. Let me conclude with a word to the young American GIs deployed in the Gulf. We are proud of each and every one of you. I know you miss your loved ones and want to know when you'll be coming home. We won't leave you there any longer than necessary. I want every single soldier out of there as soon as possible. And we are all grateful for your continued sacrifice and your commitment. Now, with no further ado, I'd be glad to take a couple of questions and then refer to, when I leave - Dick, take some questions, and then go over to the Pentagon. Helen? Q: Mr. President, it sounds like you're going to war. You have moved from a defensive position to an offensive position and you have not said how many more troops you are sending or really why. PRESIDENT BUSH: Well, I said why right now, and I hope that it's been very clear to the American people. Q: Well is there - are there new reasons that have moved this posture? PRESIDENT BUSH: No, I'm just continuing to do what we feel is necessary to complete our objectives, to fulfill our objectives that have been clearly stated. Q: Well, are you going to war? PRESIDENT BUSH: I'm not - we - I would love to see a peaceful resolution to this question. And that's what I want. Q: What made you change from defense to offense? PRESIDENT BUSH: I would like to see a peaceful solution to this question. I think Saddam Hussein should fully, without condition, comply to the U.N. resolutions. And if this movement of force is what convinces him, so much the better. Yeah - Q: Mr. President, you said that - you said last week that the sanctions haven't had the impact that you wanted. Some - some members of the coalition are urging a go-slow approach. The President of Egypt says you've got to wait two or three months before you judge whether the sanctions have worked. Are you willing to wait that long? PRESIDENT BUSH: Wait for what? Q: To see if the sanctions have worked?
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Bush Says US Sending Forces Adequate for Gulf Offensive
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with Cheney comments, edits throughout
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Thursday he was immediately sending ``significant numbers'' of additional military forces to the Persian Gulf to build ``an adequate offensive option'' if needed to drive Iraq from Kuwait. Asked directly whether he was going to war, Bush said, ``I would like to see a peaceful solution to this question. I think Saddam Hussein should fully'' withdraw his troops from Kuwait. ``If this movement of force is what convinces him, so much the better,'' Bush said. He added later, ``When he surveys the force that's there ... he will recognize that he is up against just a foe that he can't possible manage militarily.'' The president would not say how big the buildup would be. There are 230,000 Americans in the Gulf region, and Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney told reporters, ``We will not put an upper limit on this deployment.'' Congressional and administration sources had said overnight that two armored divisions from Europe would be moved to the gulf. An armored division has nearly 20,000 troops but can require so many support units that it may account for as many as 40,000 personnel. Cheney said additional Army, Navy and Marine forces would be involved, along with hundreds of battle tanks. Army National Guard combat units will be activated for the first time, though a decision won't be made until later on whether they will be shipped overseas or merely filled in behind regular Army troops sent earlier, the defense secretary said. Bush spoke as Secretary of State James A. Baker III was in Moscow consulting senior Soviet officials over Persian Gulf strategy. Soviet officials said they could not rule out the use of force. Bush called this statement ``very helpful,'' and said, ``We're on the same wavelength'' with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on goals in the Middle East. Bush said he hopes international economic sanctions force Saddam to withdraw, but his declaration concerning offensive forces dramatically altered his three-month policy in the Persian Gulf, which has been to be able to withstand further aggression by Iraq. It was Bush's second news conference of the day. Earlier, he discussed political and economic matters, but brushed off questions about the gulf. It was possible that this gave Baker time for fresh meetings in Moscow. The president said he also had consulted with Saudi King Fahd, whose nation has provided the main staging area for the U.S. and multinational deployment. The deployment began at 10,000 troops shortly after the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, and has grown to 230,000. The new buildup involves ``a considerable additional increment to U.S. forces,'' said Cheney. He said naval, air and heavy ground forces from the United States and Europe would be deployed. Bush said current forces were adequate as a defense against ``any further provocation'' by Iraq. To the troops half a world away, he pledged: ``We won't leave you there any longer than necessary.'' Cheney stood by the president's side as he announced: ``I have directed (him) to increase the size of U.S. forces committed to Desert Shield to ensure that the coalition has adequate offensive military option should that be necessary.'' Bush committed American troops three months ago, and since then has spearheaded the development of an international diplomatic response that has included massive forces and several United Nations resolutions calling on Iraq to withdraw its troops from Kuwait. Asked what had changed that led him to decide to beef up the forces, he replied that it was a ``guarantee of the safety of all and I think it sends a very strong signal'' to Saddam. Said Bush, ``Iraq's brutality, aggression and violation of international law cannot be permitted to succeed.'' ``I find it hard to believe that today, Nov. 8, that he does not understand that he's up against a determined, unprecedented alliance,'' he said. The president said he believed Saddam ``felt he was going to have ust an easy time of it'' when he moved into Kuwait. ``There's where the miscalculation was,'' he said. Bush said the United States and other countries decided to confront Saddam to guard against ``some horrible world conflagration'' at a later date. Bush said there were no ``mixed signals'' from Moscow. Earlier in the day, Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze had said, ``Whether or not the use of force could be ruled out - probably this could not be ruled out - and a situation may emerge which effectively would require such a move.'' It was the first time the Soviets had indicated publicly they would at least acquiesce if the United States, which holds the presidency of the U.N. Security Council this month, attempted to win passage of a resolution authorizing force against Iraq. In the past, Shevardnadze had said the use of force would be ``undesirable.'' Besides shoring up U.S. forces in Saudi Arabia, the new buildup would make use of tanks and other equipment covered by upcoming limits on conventional forces that are part of a new arms agreement to be signed later this month in Paris. In addition, Cheney said the Navy will be sending an estimated three additional aircraft carrier groups, one additional battleship and an amphibious group. He also said several Marine Corps units would be dispatched, and additional Army mechanized forces, including hundreds of battle tanks. Iraq has more than 400,000 troops in the region. Bush said at his morning news conference, ``I've been very clear that we want to see the sanctions be so successful that we don't have to have anybody shooting over there. And I've also said we're not ruling any options out.'' Referring to the U.S.-led coalition that now confronts Iraq, Bush said, ``I am determined to hold this coalition together.'' He promised to ``go the extra mile,'' both in conferring with Congress at home and with U.S. gulf allies abroad, to make sure that U.N. resolutions calling for complete and unconditional Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait are bring results. ``The importance of the Baker trip is obvious,'' he added. ``And I think that the ingredients are there for full support.'' Baker has consulted with other allies, including the Chinese, in the course of his current trip. Bush said he had ``good support from the American people,'' and ``I'd like to feel the American people would support their president on whatever decision is made.''

DOC.HEAD: Plan Near, But Officials Edgy About Pension Role
With AM-NYC Fiscal
DOC.TEXT: A long-awaited plan to save Philadelphia from bankruptcy will be unveiled Friday, but some officials already are edgy about the role city pension funds might play. Bond-rating agencies already have lowered the city's debt to junk-bond status, the lowest among major U.S. cities. State House Speaker Robert W. O'Donnell said Thursday he expects to announce the plan along with Mayor W. Wilson Goode and other political leaders. The plan is expected to address a short-term cash shortage that threatens to halt payments to city vendors and employees next month. It also is expected to address long-term problems contributing to a projected $206.4 million deficit this year in the city's $2.19 billion general fund budget. The plan's rough outline, leaked in recent days, reportedly includes a 1 percent local sales tax, spending cuts, sale of city-owned assets and a financial oversight mechanism outside city government. Pennsylvania has a 6 percent sales tax but the city does not have one of its own. To avert the cash shortage, the plan reportedly includes a short-term borrowing of up to $350 million from the city's $1.5 billion pension fund, the state treasury and local banks. Several of the steps would require approval by City Council and the state Legislature. Officials also have sought higher state support for court costs and for programs that serve abused and neglected children. O'Donnell refused to discuss details and said many of them could change once they reach lawmakers. ``What we've done is go down into details far enough to get a sense that it can be done, without specifying as part of the agreement that this is the way it will be done.'' he said. The sales tax, for example, could end up being another type of tax, as long as it accomplishes the same goal, he said. The city was snubbed by Wall Street in September when it tried to float $375 million in temporary loan notes. The money was needed to tide the city over until spring, when payments from two of its three major taxes are due. Bond-rating agencies have urged city and state leaders to cooperate to find permanent solutions. ``Failure to address Philadelphia's financial crisis with concerted action is likely to result in non-payment of debt service and the elimination of basic services necessary for the protection of people and property,'' Standard & Poor's Corp. warned in September. Current state law prohibits the city Board of Pensions and Retirement from investing in junk bonds, as the city's debt is now rated. City Councilman David Cohen and 11 fellow Democrats proposed an ordinance Thursday that would allow the board to invest in Philadelphia notes, regardless of quality. ``In my book, the obligations of the city of Philadelphia are extremely high quality. We have never defaulted,'' Cohen said. A public hearing on the bill is scheduled for next Wednesday and it could become law as early as Nov. 21, Cohen said. At the urging of labor organizations, the pension board's investment committee voted Thursday to hire an outside attorney to determine if board members legally could approve an investment in unrated Philadelphia notes. Joseph Herkness, who represents the city's unionized white collar workers on the pension board, said he could only back such an investment if no other alternative existed to avoid payless paydays for city workers and vendors. City Controller Jonathan Saidel would back the pension board's purchase of Philadelphia notes as long as a permanent solution was in place to end city deficits, Deputy City Controller David Volpe said. City Councilwoman Joan Krajewski said she doubts the investment would be a good risk for pension funds. ``No way should we touch anyone's pension, no way,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: California Issues Plan to Warn Public of Imminent Quakes
DOC.TEXT: California emergency officials Thursday issued the nation's first detailed plan for warning the public of imminent earthquakes and valid quake predictions. Scientists still can't predict exactly when and where a quake will occur. But the new plan reflects scientists' growing ability to use historic patterns of seismic activity to identify times and places where odds of a damaging earthquake are greater than usual. The 140-page Short-Term Earthquake Prediction Response Plan spells out how scientists and officials will warn the public of such situations, as well as policies and procedures for responding to predictions, the state Office of Emergency Services said. The plan was released during a meeting of 180 Southern California government officials. The conference was designed to help them learn how to protect public safety when the state endorses an earthquake prediction or issues a formal warning, called an advisory, that a dangerous quake may be imminent. ``There is no other state - or even the federal government - that has such a formal plan to respond to earthquake predictions and forecasts,'' said Richard Andrews, the emergency agency's chief deputy director. Andrews said the plan sharply contrasts with the depiction of state emergency officials in NBC's mini-series, ``The Big One: The Great Los Angeles Earthquake,'' that will be broadcast nationwide Sunday and Monday nights. In the movie, a state official tries to suppress a quake prediction to protect real estate interests. ``The very clear policy of the state of California is that scientific conclusions and validated earthquake predictions will be issued to the government and public in a systematic way,'' Andrews said. Research by the U.S. Geological Survey shows that after any quake in California, there is a 6 percent chance of a larger quake within a few days. After several quakes in recent years, state officials used that knowledge to issue advisories that there was an increased chance of a larger quake within three to five days. The new plan contains specific procedures state emergency officials will use to consult with scientists and issue future quake advisories, hopefully within two hours of a quake that may be a foreshock to a seismic disaster. Andrews said such warnings will allow county and city officials to activate emergency operations centers, charge up emergency generators, evacuate high-risk buildings, close schools, and urge people to stay home. The plan also specifies how the Office of Emergency Services and the California Earthquake Prediction Evaluation Council will evaluate and respond to quake predictions. The response could range from declaring the prediction invalid to endorsing a prediction by issuing a formal warning or even urging the governor to declare a state of emergency to prepare for possible imminent disaster. Studies of public reaction to warnings of hurricanes and other disasters show residents will not panic in response to a quake warning, but will take appropriate steps to prepare, said Denis Mileti, a Colorado State University sociologist. He is chairman of the National Academy of Sciences' natural disasters committee. California officials issued two earthquake advisories in 1988 and 1989 after quakes over magnitude 5 on the Richter scale ruptured the San Andreas Fault in Northern California's Santa Cruz Mountains. Those advisories expired without a larger quake. But the same section of the fault finally gave way in the magnitude 7.1 Loma Prieta quake that killed more than five dozen people and caused at least $7 billion in damage in the San Francisco Bay area in October 1989. Andrews and others credited the warnings for raising the level of preparedness in the region, averting even greater destruction when the larger quake hit.

DOC.HEAD: WASHN: have worked?
DOC.TEXT: PRESIDENT BUSH: Well, we're - well, I think from talking to Jim Baker and recently to President Mubarak that we are in total sync with him. But I hope that the sanctions will work within a two-month period. But I don't think we've got a difference with Egypt on this at all, Terry. Q: The question is, how long are you willing to give - PRESIDENT BUSH: Well, I can't tell you how long. I'm not going to - if I - if I knew, I certainly wouldn't want to signal that to - to Saddam Hussein. Yeah, John? Q: Prime Minister Thatcher said yesterday that if indeed Saddam doesn't withdraw from Kuwait, that you and the allies will use force. I haven't heard you say that before. You've talked about wanting to retain the option of force, but would you use force? PRESIDENT BUSH: Well, I - I don't want to go - to say what I will or will not do. But certainly I noted what Prime Minister Thatcher said - one of the strongest members of this coalition. And she's an eloquent spokesman for her views and speaks in a way that shows that we're all together. So I have not ruled out the use of force at all and I think that's evident by what we're doing here today. Q: Sir, can I just follow that up by - by going back to a speech you gave at the Pentagon back in August, when you talked about oil, affecting the Middle East oil reserves. You talked about American jobs, in fact the American way of life being endangered. Yet when you went out on the campaign trail, you seemed to shy away from oil. You said demonstrators don't seem to understand that we're not going to go to war for oil. But that was one of the things you talked about and, in fact, isn't oil part of the American national interest? Isn't that a main reason we're there? PRESIDENT BUSH: It is a part of it, but it is not the main reason, or I'd say a main reason. A main reason we're there is to set back aggression, to see that aggression is unrewarded. My argument with some of the protests is that they seem to focus, to suggest that oil is the sole reason that we are involved in this enormous commitment, and that is simply not correct. There's a lot of other interests, and the restoration of the security and stability in the Persian Gulf region clearly relates to the world's economic interests. I'm not denying that and I'm not backing away from the fact that all the Western world has, you know, a real interest in that. But that - my argument with those people is that they are missing the point. The point is, it is the aggression against Kuwait that has caused this coalition to come together as it has. Yeah, Ann. Q: Do you feel that you are free to take offensive action without any kind of U.N. resolution authorizing it? PRESIDENT BUSH: Yes. We have the authority, but we've - we've been great believers in going to the United Nations. And I think one of the major successes has been the ability to have world opinion totally on our side because of U.N. action. The peacekeeping function of the United Nations has indeed been rejuvenated by the actions of the Security Council. Way in the back, because I've been accused by a distinguished senior reporter of not getting into the back of the room, so I'd like to rectify that.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Brando Says Prosecutors Too Tough on His Daughter
DOC.TEXT: Marlon Brando accused prosecutors in Los Angeles of putting too much pressure on his daughter, Cheyenne, saying she is too troubled to give credible testimony about her lover's murder. Los Angeles District Attorney Ira Reiner and his deputy, Steven Barshop, ``exceeded their ethical obligations ... for political and professional gains,'' Brando charged in a statement. ``I hold them directly responsible for the physical and mental state in which she now is in.'' The statement was released Wednesday by a family spokesman in Tahiti, where Miss Brando, 20, is hospitalized while recovering from a drug overdose. Brando has said he would like to fly here to visit her, but his statement didn't say when that might happen. Miss Brando has given six contradictory versions of what happened the night of May 16, when her 26-year-old lover, Dag Drollet, was shot to death at the Brando home in Southern California, Brando said in the statement. Miss Brando's brother, Christian Brando, 32, is charged with murder, and she is considered the key witness in the case. Brando said his daughter had been under ``extraordinary pressure'' to return to the United States to testify although she could not be a credible witness. A month after Drollet was shot, Miss Brando left the United States for Tahiti, where she gave birth to a child. French authorities, who accuse her of being an accessory to the murder, had refused to allow her to be returned to California. Miss Brando was hospitalized after ingesting a large dose of tranquilizers and anti-depressents on Nov. 1. Christian Brando had been scheduled to go on trial this week, but the proceedings were delayed while the court reviews Miss Brando's status.

DOC.HEAD: Corn Harvest Estimated at a Four-Year High
DOC.TEXT: Farmers are closing in on a 1990 corn harvest estimated at a four-year high of 7.93 billion bushels, up 5 percent from last year but down slightly from prospects last month, the Agriculture Department said Thursday. The latest outlook, based on Nov. 1 indications, was down 1 percent from the department's October forecast. The harvest was about 64 percent completed by Oct. 28, only slightly behind normal. ``Many growers continue to report yields lower than previously anticipated,'' the department's Agricultural Statistics Board said. ``Ears in late-planted fields in Indiana did not fill out. Corn borers also did considerable damage in Illinois.'' Farmers harvested 7.53 billion bushels in 1989, and the department in its initial 1990 forecast Aug. 9 put this fall's harvest at 7.85 billion bushels. The forecast was raised on Sept. 12 to 8.12 billion bushels and then lowered to 8.02 billion on Oct. 11. At 7.93 billion bushels, this year's harvest still would be the largest since farmers produced 8.23 billion bushels in 1986, according to USDA records. Based on the latest surveys, the average corn yield nationally was estimated at 119 bushels per acre harvested, compared with 116.2 last year and 120.3 indicated last month. The record was 119.4 bushels in 1987. As livestock feed, corn is the largest and most important U.S. farm crop and is essential for the production of meat, poultry and dairy products. Consumer food prices, which rose an average of 5.8 percent in 1989, the sharpest year-to-year increase since 1981, are expected to climb 5 percent to 7 percent in 1990. Soybean production, a source of high-protein meal and vegetable oil, was estimated at 1.9 billion bushels, down 1 percent from last year's harvest of 1.93 billion bushels but 4 percent more than the October forecast of 1.82 billion bushels. Cotton production was indicated at 14.9 million bales, up 22 percent from last year's output of 12.2 million bales and 2 percent more than the October forecast. No new estimates of 1990 production of wheat and other crops harvested earlier were included in the report. The fall crop of potatoes was estimated for the first time this season at 342 million hundredweight, up 5 percent from last year due to an increase in acreage. Average yields were forecast at 298 hundredweight per acre, down one hundredweight from 1989. ``Drought in North Dakota and Minnesota cut into production potential for the third straight year,'' the report said. ``Maine farmers were hit by heavy October rains followed by hard freezes late in the month that virtually shut down harvest operations.'' The potato outlook also was said to be hurt by ``extremely variable temperatures'' in Idaho, Oregon and Washington during the growing season. In a related supply-and-demand report, analysts said total corn use in the 1990-91 marketing year, which began Sept. 1, is expected to be about 8.045 billion bushels. With use exceeding estimated production, the U.S. corn stockpile may decline to a projected 1.236 billion bushels by Sept. 1, 1991, compared with 1.344 billion this Sept. 1. The report said corn prices at the farm may average $2.20 to $2.60 per bushel in the 1990-91 marketing year, down from $2.36 in 1989-90 and unchanged from the October projection. Soybean prices were indicated to average $5.35 to $6.35 per bushel, down from the October range of $5.70 to $7 per bushel. This fall's larger crop is putting pressure on prices and will mean a rise in soybean stockpiles in 1990-91. By next Sept. 1, the report said, soybean inventories could be around 255 million bushels, compared with 239 million bushels this Sept. 1 and last month's projection of 175 million bushels next year. The report also showed the Soviet Union's grain harvest at 235 million metric tons this year, unchanged from the October forecast. However, analysts said Soviet grain imports in 1990-91 now are expected to be 28 million tons, down from 30 million anticipated last month. An all-crops production index was reported at 112 percent of the 1977 average used for comparison, up one percentage point from October and the highest reading since the index averaged 116 percent in 1985. Other 1990 crop estimates based on Nov. 1 indications, compared with 1989 output, included: -Sorghum, 559.8 million bushels and an average yield of 60.5 bushels per acre, compared with 617.9 million and 55.4 in 1989. -Rice, 154.4 million hundredweight and a yield of 5,499 pounds per acre, compared with 154.5 million and 5,749. -Peanuts, 3.45 billion pounds and a yield of 1,949 pounds per acre, compared with 3.99 billion and 2,426. -Tobacco, 1.6 billion pounds and a yield of 2,198 pounds per acre, compared with 1.37 billion and 2,016. -Sugar beets, 27 million tons and a yield of 19.7 tons per acre, compared with 25.1 million and 19.4. -Sugar cane, 25.3 million tons and a yield of 35.3 tons per acre, compared with 29.4 million and 34.5.

DOC.HEAD: Napal Protesters Demonstrate on Queen's Birthday
DOC.TEXT: About 300 anti-royalists marched in the capital's streets by torchlight on Thursday, the Queen's birthday and eve of a new constitution stripping the king of absolute power. The demonstrators chanted slogans against King Birendra, whom they accused of delaying the reforms prompted by mass pro-democracy demonstrations last year. ``Down with the palace conspiracy!'' the protesters shouted. Queen Aishwarya's birthday is a public holiday, but her 42nd birthday Thursday lacked the pomp and splendor of previous holidays. There were no special functions at the royal palace, and the state-run media did not run programs praising her contributions to the nation, as in the previous years. The king aroused anger among democracy advocates when he revised the constitution submitted by the government in a bid to preserve some power and maintain the monarchy. Further negotiations cleared the way for the proclamation of the new constitution Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Task Force To Study Improvements In Boston-New York Rail Service
DOC.TEXT: A Transportation Department task force will study how to shorten rail passenger travel time between Boston and New York, Secretary Samuel K. Skinner announced Thursday. The federal task force will assign priorities to projects to improve service between the two cities, Skinner said. Scheduled for completion by next summer, the task force will also develop ``logical cost allocations'' for improvements among interested state governments, local transportation authorities and private parties, he said. ``Now that the Washington-New York portion of the northeast corridor has been improved, we need to turn our attention to the New York-Boston segment,'' Skinner told a meeting of the Railway Progress Institute. ``Facilities and services need to be upgraded to improve the travel time on the New York-Boston run and to enhance the commuter services that share the right of way with Amtrak,'' Skinner said. ``Speedy and reliable rail service would encourage more passengers to use the trains and this could help to relieve some of the congestion in the major airports in the Northeast,'' he said. The departmental study, expected to cost $1 million, will be headed by Gil Carmichael, administrator of the Federal Railroad Administration, and Brian W. Clymer, administrator of the Urban Mass Transit Administration.

DOC.HEAD: Former Head of Pacific Stock Exchange Dead at 61
DOC.TEXT: Maurice Mann, former chairman of the Pacific Stock Exchange, died of a heart attack while on an airplane en route to an investors conference. He was 61. Mann was flying from Miami to San Diego when he died Wednesday. James Cirona, president of Federal Home Loan Bank in San Francisco, who had breakfast with Mann last week, said Mann was ``full of new ideas.'' During his three years at the helm of the Pacific Stock Exchange, Mann recognized the interdependence of the Pacific Basin and began forging relationships with other exchanges in the region. His tenure on the stock exchange, from 1987 until January, included the Dow Jones Industrial Average's record crash plunge in October 1987. Mann took control of the situation, holding eight news conferences in a week and delivering the calming message that despite ``one of the most significant events in U.S. financial history ... the system is still working.'' Before joining the exchange, he was vice chairman of Merrill Lynch Capital Markets and president and chief executive officer of the Federal Home Loan Bank in San Francisco. As president of the Federal Home Loan Bank office, he introduced lending products to give member thrifts more flexibility to deal with the coming deregulation. ``He was very innovative in an industry that had not shown much innovation,'' said Robert Parry, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco. ``He told them their world was changing that would make their life more difficult.'' During the early years of the Nixon administration, Mann was assistant director of the office of management and budget. Before that, he was vice president and economist for the Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland. The native of Peabody, Mass., Mann is survived by his wife, Betty, two daughters, a grandchild and a sister.

DOC.HEAD: Insurance Exec Says School Health Clinics Should Expand Services
DOC.TEXT: School health clinics should open their doors to infants, toddlers and pregnant women as a way of helping children begin their education ready to learn, an insurance official said Thursday. ``The pressing challenge to our corporations, our schools and our partnerships in education is to give our poorest children a strong start for a productive life in a highly competitive world,'' said F. Peter Libassi, senior vice president of the Hartford, Conn.-based Travelers Cos. Millions of children, he said, enter kindergarten in poor health because they don't receive medical care during infancy. Poverty and poor health are major barriers to learning, he said. ``Starting to reform education even at the kindergarten level is still not close enough to the heart of the problem,'' Libassi said at a national symposium on education initiatives sponsored by the National Association of Partners in Education. ``Now the question is, `Is it possible ... for our health clinics that are in our schools to be available, not only to the school-age child but to the pre-school-age child in the neighborhood?''' he said. School clinics also could provide prenatal care, he said. Libassi said the city of Hartford may embark on a program to expand primary health care and preventive services in neighborhood health centers and schools. A local hospital board is considering a proposal to create a new children's fund to finance the program using $25 million of the hospital's endowment. The Hartford business community has pledged $10 million, he said. A 1987 study found one-fourth of all Hartford kindergarten children were not ready or able to go on to first grade. In one school, that number was more than 40 percent. The American Academy of Pediatrics said about 16 million children and adolescents through age 21 have no health insurance and that 26 percent of women in their childbearing years, ages 15-44, have no insurance coverage for maternity care. The National Association of Partners in Education is an organization of 7,000 schools, businesses, community groups, educators and volunteers working to help students achieve educational excellence.

DOC.HEAD: WASHN: rectify that.
DOC.TEXT: Q: Mr. President - PRESIDENT BUSH: Yes, sir. No - him. Q: Do you yet have the support you need in order to secure an additional resolution from the U.N. Security Council to explicitly authorize the use of force? Do you now have the sufficient support on the Security Council - PRESIDENT BUSH: I'd - I - I would say that the Baker mission is - what it is about is consultation. That subject will be discussed in some ways. I'm sure that that's not why he's there. We're talking about a wide array of issues. And so, I'd say we have not tried to specifically poll the 15 members - or the other 14 members of the Security Council along those lines, so I can't answer whether we would or not. Q: If I may follow, has any country told you they would block such a resolution? PRESIDENT BUSH: Not - none - some may have said such a thing but I've not - I've not - it's not been brought to my attention at all. And I - again, I think I'd know if that were the case, but I don't think so. Yeah? Q: Mr. President, it would seem that the situation at the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait is crucial to the future of the overall situation in the Gulf. What is the latest there? What is the situation with their food and water supplies? And do you plan - have anything in the works now to resupply them? PRESIDENT BUSH: Well I think it's unconscionable to try to starve people out and to isolate them from food and supplies of all kinds, and that's exactly what's going on. In terms of how long they can survive I'm not sure I could give you a specific answer, but I believe the answer would be a few weeks, something of that nature. Q: Are there plans to resupply them when they run out or - PRESIDENT BUSH: Well, if there were, given the hostile environment in which these people are living, it would be unproductive to discuss it. Yes? Q: Mr. President, what has happened in the last two weeks that has led you to put now an offensive force into Saudi Arabia? PRESIDENT BUSH: Well, we have - we have not only offensive but defensive forces there already. And what leads me to do this is just because I believe - upon the advice of our able secretary of defense and others - that this is in the best security interests of our people that are there and of the coalition. I think it is the best - I think it is just a guarantee of the safety of all and I think it sends a very strong signal, another strong signal, to Saddam Hussein that we are very, very serious about the success of the United - to seeing the United Nations resolutions complied to in their entirety without - without any kind of watering down. Q: Sir, would you say that we're in a critical phase now between a peaceful solution and possible armed conflict? PRESIDENT BUSH: I wouldn't phrase it that way. Q: Mr. President, the longer that you wait, or the longer that no action is taken in Kuwait the less and less there's seems to be of Kuwait. What's the point of waiting if there's not going to be anything left of that country when you finally decide to go in? PRESIDENT BUSH: Well, I've told you that I want to - I would like to feel that Saddam Hussein would come to his senses and comply, under economic pressure, with the sanctions that have been taken in the United Nations and with the objectives. I would like to think the sanctions - economic sanctions would compel him to do that which he has been unwilling to do. Regrettably, he keeps reiterating his view that this is - this is not Kuwait, but Province 19, and that is unacceptable to the United States and to our partners. So it's - I think we're giving these sanctions time to work. We're giving world opinion time to mobilize, and impress on him that - that we're all serious and that - but now we're moving up our forces, for the reasons I've given you.

DOC.HEAD: Panamanian Journalists Protest Press Laws
DOC.TEXT: About 300 journalists marched silently down the city's main street Thursday and picketed the presidential palace to protest press laws carried over from the deposed regime of Manuel Antonio Noriega. President Guillermo Endara, who this week sued a newspaper columnist, met the journalists outside the palace and angrily defended a law under which slander is heavily penalized. ``The president of the republic is a person and is going to demand reponsibility when there is an attempt to damage his honor,'' Endara said. ``That is what I will do in each and every one of the cases, and there is no persecution.'' Then he turned his back and refused to accept a protest letter the journalists had signed. Endara, installed after the Dec. 20 American invasion that overthrew Noriega, has filed a slander and damage complaint against Dagoberto Franco of the daily El Siglo. Franco was detained for two days and released on $5,000 bond. Franco had written a column entitled, ``Endara: The Great Swindle.'' At least 60 formal complaints have been filed against journalists this year, mostly by officials, the protesters said. Journalists are asking that slander be changed from a criminal to a civil violation. The current penalty is two to five years in jail. In their letter, the journalists said, ``We are here because 21 years of castrated journalism has left us a bitter taste of exiles, threats, pressures and fears that we never want to repeat.'' Endara told the journalists: ``I'm not a second-class citizen. I don't have more privileges than anyone else, but I have equal rights with you.'' The constitution provides for freedom of expression but says there are ``legal responsibilities when by any of these media one attacks the reputation or honor of the persons in violation of the social security or public order.''

DOC.HEAD: WASHN: of it.
DOC.TEXT: Q: After you have consulted - if I might follow up - on this deployment and in fact on the military situation overall with the other countries involved in the multi-national forces, there have been complaints, observations, out of Israel that, were there to be offensive action, there needs to be coordination or some sort of chain of command involving the Israelis too, for they may end up being involved. To what extent are you communicating with the Israelis? And to what extent do you envision any role or possible role for the Israelis should this come to war? PRESIDENT BUSH: Well, I think the whole world knows that the United States is - has a very special relationship with Israel - a strong relationship. I think we're in close touch with the key players there in terms of our objectives. And I think they've conducted themselves in a - regarding all of this - very well indeed. But I'm not going to discuss any more details than that. But I - I feel that we're on a good wavelength there. Q: Mr. President - PRESIDENT BUSH: We have some differences obviously. Really I got just - one and one and then I've got to go. Yes? Q: Mr. President, to follow up - PRESIDENT BUSH: I recognize him on the aisle - go ahead. Yes, you and Ellen and then - Q: - to follow up on Wyatt's question, after Foreign Minister Shevardnaze made his comments today, President Gorbachev seemed to say that it was too early to talk about the use of force. Are the Soviets sending us mixed signals? PRESIDENT BUSH: No. Q: Is this an indication that - like President Mubarak made earlier in the week - that some of our allies want more time to try to find a diplomatic solution before use of force? PRESIDENT BUSH: I don't - I don't get the feeling we're getting any mixed signals at all from the Soviets, particularly after I've talked to - to Jim Baker. I know there was some feeling there were mixed signals because of Mr. Primakov's mission, but as that has - upon the completion of that - I think people recognize that we are still very much in accord - in agreement with the Soviet on matters as it relates to the Gulf. So it's good, Ann, and it's strong, and I just can't worry about that point at all after talking to Jim Baker. Q: Does Jim Baker have an explanation for the difference between Mr. Shevardnadze's remarks and Mr. Gorbachev's remarks today? PRESIDENT BUSH: No, he made the point that if we were together with them, and that was not discussed - any differences on the - Q: Mr. President? PRESIDENT BUSH: On the aisle. Q: Mr. President - PRESIDENT BUSH: No, last one - on the aisle, the lovely gentleman with the glasses - Q: Mr. President, some members of your administration have - Q: Mr. President, I have a very important question to ask you. PRESIDENT BUSH: Only if you'll yield. Don't you know, in the Congress they say ``I yield to the distinguished lady from Texas,'' but if you don't want to yield, I'm sorry - I've recognized the gentleman. Q: Mr. President, some members of your - Q: I was expecting to yield but I would expect (inaudible) - (Laughter.) Q: Some members of your administration - PRESIDENT BUSH: Sarah, I've disappointed you so much. Please go ahead. Q: Some of members of your administration are convinced that Saddam Hussein will not move until he is - until the 11th hour or 11:59, when he is totally convinced that you are about to use military force. Why is he not convinced now, do you think? Why - how do you expect that you will be able to get to that 11:59 in a minute?

DOC.HEAD: Sharon Asks Jewish Control over Temple Mount
DOC.TEXT: Housing Minister Ariel Sharon asked Israel on Thursday to establish Jewish control over Jerusalem's sacred Temple Mount, now under Moslem control, and to expand Jewish neighborhoods in annexed east Jerusalem. He told members of his Likud bloc in Tel Aviv these measures were needed to ``stop deterioration in the security situation,'' a Sharon spokesman said in a statement carried by the national Itim news agency. On Oct. 8, police shot and killed 20 Palestinians during a riot on the mount, revered by Arabs as Islam's third holiest site and by Jews as the site of their ancient temple. ``There must be Jewish rule on the Temple Mount. The Temple Mount is the root of the problem,'' Sharon said. He also said leaders of the Palestinian ``terrorism and uprising'' must be deported, naming prominent pro-PLO activists Faisal Husseini and Sari Nusseibeh and Gaza Strip leaders Fayez Abu-Rahme and Issam Saftawi. In statements broadcast on Israel television, Sharon also demanded expulsion of thousands of Palestinians living in the Israeli Arab villages. Sharon is a leading hawk in Likud, the governing right-wing bloc of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir. A hero of the 1973 Middle East war, he later became defense minister and was an architect of Israel's 1982 invasion of Lebanon. The mount in Jerusalem's walled Old City, called Haram al-Sharif by Moslems, is zealously controlled by Islamic religious authorities. The Oct. 8 events were ignited, in part, by rumors that Jews planned to take over the site. Sharon asked that Jewish neighborhoods in Jerusalem be expanded, ``with a special effort in east Jerusalem.'' About 120,000 Arabs live in the annexed part of the city, captured by Israel from Jordan in the 1967 Mideast war. He blamed occasional pro-Palestinian riots and the rising nationalist feelings among Israel's 800,000 Arabs on the presence of Palestinians from the West Bank and Gaza, who he said dwell in Arab villages in northern Israel without a permit. Most Israeli Arabs support Palestinian independence demands and the 35-month-old uprising in the occupied lands. Despite support for the 1.7 million of their brethren in the occupied areas, Israeli Arabs say they remain loyal citizens of Israel. Also on Thursday: -Ethiopian Jewish emigration resumed after a lapse of four months, with 103 Ethiopians arriving in Israel. Israel radio reported from Ben-Gurion Airport near Tel Aviv that the group included many sick and elderly people, and that many kissed the ground after getting off a plane that brought them to the Jewish state via Rome. Israeli officials estimate 22,000 Jews remain in Ethiopia. -Legislator Yair Tzaban of the leftist Mapam party proposed that Parliament adopt a law stipulating a prison sentence of up to five years for anyone attacking a journalist. The proposal came a day after several journalists were attacked or stoned during the funeral of Rabbi Meir Kahane, the leader of the anti-Arab Kach party assassinated in New York by an Arab.

DOC.HEAD: Accused Mail Bomber Refuses to Enter Plea
DOC.TEXT: A man charged in mail bombings that killed a federal judge and a lawyer refused Thursday to enter a plea, pending his attempt to bar any federal judge from hearing the case. In a hearing before a federal magistrate, lawyers for Walter Leroy Moody Jr. said the fact that a federal judge was one of the victims damages the impartiality of all federal judges. Moody's attorneys requested in a court motion that the Senate Judiciary Committee appoint an independent officer to hear the case. U.S. Magistrate William Harper referred the case to U.S. District Judge Richard Freeman for trial. No hearing was scheduled on the motion. An innocent plea was automatically entered for Moody because of his refusal to enter a plea. Special Assistant U.S. Attorney Howard Shapiro would not comment on the motion, which said every federal judge in the country has altered working habits and lifestyles because of the mail bombings last year. A federal indictment issued Wednesday includes a murder charge against Moody in the slaying of Judge Robert Vance in Alabama and explosives charges related to the death of Georgia civil rights lawyer Robert Robinson. Alabama officials said Moody, 56, may also face state murder charges and the death penalty in the slaying of Vance, a member of the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals. Authorities in Georgia said they have not seen enough of the evidence, most of it developed by federal authorities, to decide whether to press state charges against him in the death of Robinson in Savannah. The murder charge in te 70-count indictment carries a maximum penalty of life in prison and a $250,000 fine. No murder charge was included for Robinson's death. Moody was charged with transporting explosive material with intent to kill in that death. The charge also carries a maximum penalty of life and $250,000. Moody also is charged with a variety of other offenses related to the bombings. If convicted on all 70 counts he could face seven life terms plus 385 years in prison and fines of $16.9 million. Jimmy Evans, Alabama's attorney general-elect and currently Montgomery County district attorney, said because Moody is a federal prisoner there would be no petition to extradite him to Alabama. Instead, the state would ``borrow'' Moody from federal authorities long enough to prosecute him, Evans said. He favors pursuing the death penalty if feasible. ``My thought is that the person responsible for the murder of the late Robert Vance should be tried capitally and put in the electric chair. Whoever is guilty for this should receive the maximum penalty and punishment,'' Evans said. Current Alabama Attorney General Don Siegelman said, however, that if Moody is acquitted in the federal trial, there would be little use in trying him in Alabama. In Georgia, Chatham County District Attorney Spencer Lawton Jr. said he has not seen enough evidence in the Robinson death to determine whether to pursue a murder charge against Moody. Lawton said that after the first few days following the Savannah explosion, federal authorities took over the investigation almost exclusively. ``Since then we've taken no substantial role in the investigation,'' Lawton said. ``The net of all this is I am totally unaware of the factual basis for the federal indictment.'' Lawton said Wednesday he was trying to contact federal authorities to gain access to evidence that would help him decide whether to seek local charges against Moody. Roger Brown, assistant district attorney in Jefferson County, Ala., where Vance was killed at his home, said he, too, planned to review the federal evidence to determine if local prosecutors would get involved.

DOC.HEAD: WASHN: a minute.
DOC.TEXT: PRESIDENT BUSH: Well, I'm not sure I accept the 11:59 analogy, but if there has ever been any doubt in his mind about the seriousness of the West and of the other Arab countries and of the coalition - put it that way - I think that those doubts are rapidly being dispelled. You see, I do believe that when he moved into Kuwait, I think he felt he was going to have just an easy time of it and that the world would not rise up in arms against the aggression. I think he miscalculated there. I believe he thought he could just take over Kuwait and then there'd be a lot of talk and discussion, and he would be able to turn Kuwait, a sovereign nation, a member of the Arab League, a member of the United Nations, into Province 19. And the United States, along with other countries, said ``No, we're not going to permit this aggression to stand because an unchecked aggression today could lead to some horrible world conflagration tomorrow.'' And so I think there's where the miscalculation originally was. I find it hard to believe that today, November 8th, he does not understand that he's up against a determined, unprecedented alliance. And so I hope that he is rethinking his position of unyielding - of unyielding opposition to the will of the rest of the world. And I would think that when he surveys the force that's there, this force that's going, what other countries are doing in this regard, he will recognize that he is up against a - just an - a foe that he can't possibly manage militarily. And Margaret Thatcher touched on that yesterday and I thought she did it very well indeed. And so if nothing else happens, I'm convinced that this move will show him how serious we are as a significant partner in this coalition. And I think it's a good thing. It has - will have strong support from others around the world. And let's hope he comes to his senses and does tomorrow that which he should have done weeks ago, because this aggression simply will not stand. Now, Dick, it's all yours. SECRETARY CHENEY: As the president indicated, we've got a briefing scheduled in the Pentagon for General Powell and myself in a few minutes to fill out the details of the decision the president's made today, but I'd be happy to respond to a couple of questions. Q: How many troops are being sent and how many - SECRETARY CHENEY: We have - let me address the question of numbers. We have consistently, since the very beginning of this operation in August, three months ago, indicated that we were not going to put a number on the deployment. As we have achieved a certain level of deployment we've reported that we've had 150,000 or 200,000; today we're at 230,000-plus. We will not put an upper limit on this deployment. We started the flow back in August, and what the president has directed me to do today is to assign additional units to go to the Gulf, and it is a considerable additional increment of U.S. force, involves additional heavy divisions as well as naval and air forces. And we'll announce - Q: Coming from where? SECRETARY CHENEY: Coming from both Europe and the United States. And we will announce those details in a few minutes. Michael? Q: Mr. Secretary, in Europe we waited 40 years for economic pressures to lead the Soviet Union to withdraw its forces from Eastern Europe despite a number of aggressions. Why shouldn't we wait a year or so for economic sanctions to take hold in Iraq and lead the Iraqis to leave Kuwait? And if we're prepared to wait, why should we send such a large force at this time, since it's harder to sustain a large force in the desert than a somewhat smaller force? SECRETARY CHENEY: Well, the directions I've been given by the president are, I think, very clear-cut. That is to say that we're to continue the policy that's currently in force, that the military units that are in the Gulf region are there to deter further aggression, to defend should deterrence fail, to enforce the sanctions. We are also now obviously deploying, as the president mentioned in his statement, sufficient additional force to make certain that should circumstances warrant that we will have the capacity to undertake offensive military action as well. The decision about how long we wait and how much time we're willing to give sanctions to work is something that'll be made above my pay grade. Q: Mr. Secretary, there are reports that Saddam Hussein fired his military chief of staff today. What is going on? Is there dissension in the ranks? And does that have something to do with the timing of these news conferences, to try to keep international pressure on him? SECRETARY CHENEY: I have seen the reports that he's changed out his chief of staff. I don't have any special knowledge as to why that occurred and our announcements are totally unrelated to those developments. In the back? Q: Mr. Secretary, could you give us a range: When does this deployment begin? When do you expect it to end?

DOC.HEAD: Woman Candidate Appears in Strong Position for Presidency
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 10 grafs for 6-15 bgng `On Thursday' to UPDATE returns, minor editing. Pickup graf 16 pvs, `Lenihan quickly...' CORRECTS story slug to AM-Ireland sted AM-Ireland-Elections per news advisory.
DOC.TEXT: A lawyer who favors liberalizing strict laws on birth control and abortion appeared in a strong position Thursday to become Ireland's first woman president, according to partial and unofficial returns. Mary Robinson trailed former deputy prime minister Brian Lenihan in the preliminary count, but pre-election polls indicated the second round on Friday would put her over the top. ``It looks like President Robinson now,'' said Justice Minister Ray Burke, who had supported Lenihan, a member of the dominant Fianna Fail party. ``It's looking good, but it's not by any manner or means decided yet,'' said Mrs. Robinson, whose supporters staged early celebrations. She was nominated by the Labor and Workers party, although she has no party affiliation. As president, she would be expected to refrain from any political controversies. The president's main powers are the right to dissolve Parliament when a government has lost support, and to refer legislation to the Supreme Court. On Thursday night, unofficial returns showed Lenihan with 44.1 percent of the vote, Mrs. Robinson with 38.9 percent and Austin Currie of Fine Gael with 17 percent, according to Press Association, the British news agency. Turnout was estimated at 63 percent of the 2.47 million eligible voters, compared with 68 percent in parliamentary elections last year. Under the Irish system, voters mark a second preference on their ballots. In the second round, Currie stands to be eliminated and his votes distributed among the two top finishers. A poll published Tuesday in The Irish Times indicated Currie's supporters preferred Mrs. Robinson by 3-to-1 over Lenihan. Currie had urged his supporters to make her their second choice. Former Prime Minister Garret FitzGerald of Fine Gael said on Irish Radio that he expected Mrs. Robinson to finish with 52 percent of the vote. Mrs. Robinson, 46, would be the first leftist candidate to be president of Ireland, and the first since 1945 who didn't come from Fianna Fail.
