She is a lecturer in European Community law at Trinity College in Dublin, and has supported more liberal contraception laws, legalized divorce and the right of women to obtain information about abortion, which is outlawed in Ireland but available in Britain. Lenihan, 59, was first elected to Parliament in the 1960s, and has held several Cabinet posts. Prime Minister Charles Haughey was forced to dismiss Lenihan as deputy prime mininster and defense minister last week to save his coalition government from collapse. Lenihan was accused of lying about a his role in a 1982 attempt to keep President Patrick Hillery from calling a national election. Lenihan quickly dropped from frontrunner to second place in opinion polls. Currie, 51, was a leader in the Catholic civil rights campaign in Northern Ireland in the 1960s and a founder of the Social Democratic and Labor Party, the main Catholic party there. He moved to the Irish Republic and was elected last year to the Dail, the lower house of Parliament. All three candidates are Catholics. It is Ireland's first contested presidential election in 17 years.

DOC.HEAD: Winterlike Weather Abates; Rain Splatters Various Regions
DOC.TEXT: Advisories and watches for winter-like weather in various parts of the nation expired Thursday and rain splattered areas from Oregon to New York state. New Mexico got some relief after a storm dumped snow in every corner of the state. Up to 6 inches of snow covered various areas, including the northeast heights of Albuquerque. Winds gusted to 50 and 60 mph across Wyoming's southeast mountains. An advisory for strong winds causing blowing and drifting snow was posted for the region. A high wind warning was posted for Kodiak, Alaska, where 45-mph winds gusted to near 75 mph. Strong winds and low wind chills were expected to linger through Friday around Valdez, Alaska. Winds gusted to near 60 mph and the morning wind chill was 25 to 35 degrees below zero. Rain or occasional thundershowers reached over much of Texas, Oklahoma, northwest Louisiana, southern Arkansas, eastern Kansas, northwest Missouri and southern Iowa. Rain also extended across northwest Oregon and from southwest Idaho into northwest Idaho. Rain changed to snow over southeast Idaho. Snow was scattered in central Colorado, northwest Wisconsin, south-central New York state and northern Maine. The nation's low Thursday morning was 4 degrees below zero at Alamosa, Colo. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EST ranged from 25 degrees at Caribou and Limestone in Maine to 88 degrees at Fort Myers airport in Florida.

DOC.HEAD: WASHN: to end.
DOC.TEXT: SECRETARY CHENEY: I signed the deployment orders this morning. Some of the forces had previously been alerted to be ready to deploy, so in effect, the deployment actually begins today. It will obviously, given the size of the deployment, be something that will run over a significant additional period of time. I wouldn't want to be more precise than that. We've always refrained from indicating when a particular unit would be deployed and combat-ready. Clear in the back? Q: Does this deployment involve a further call-up of reserves, and has there been consultation with congressional leaders today on this deployment? SECRETARY CHENEY: The answer is it will involve an additional call-up of reserves, and there have been notifications to members of Congress. I personally talked with the leadership and the chairmen and ranking members of all of the key Armed Services and Appropriations committees. Q: As you increase your deployments, will you be able to maintain the promise that I think was made by the joint - the chairman of the joint chiefs that you would rotate people in and out every six months? SECRETARY CHENEY: We've never made such a promise. We've said that we were looking at a rotation policy, but the forces that we are ordering into the area today are not going in there to replace those that have already been deployed. They are in addition to those that are already in the area. Frank? Q: Mr. Secretary, is it safe to say that the message that is being sent from this room today is that the United State is now prepared to fight a ground war to force Iraq out of Kuwait if necessary? SECRETARY CHENEY: The message is - as exactly as we've stated it, and as the President stated it, and that is that our policy is to see to it that Saddam Hussein complies with the resolutions voted by the U.N. Security Council. Those are our goals and objectives that - we are hopeful that we can achieve that peacefully; we're hopeful we can achieve that through the application of the economic sanctions now in force. But we also have the military option available to us should the other course of action be unsuccesful. One more question and then I've got to run. Q: If I may follow up, Mr. Secretary - SECRETARY CHENEY: Yes. Q: - you've been reluctant - wait just a - Mr. Secretary - STAFF: On whom did you call? SECRETARY CHENEY: The young man with the hair on the - front - (extensive laughter) - Q: Mr. Secretary, do you agree that the winter months are an optimal time to fight a war in the desert? And is weather compelling a decision to use force before the sanctions have had - SECRETARY CHENEY: I wouldn't want to speculate about future deadlines of when sanctions will be deemed to have failed, or what pressures weather and climate considerations might bring to bear. We are prepared to carry out the president's instructions, and those instructions are as I've already related. One more question. The gentleman I insulted in back, and then I've got to go. Yes, sir. Q: Mr. Secretary, you've been reluctant here to use a number. The number 100,000 additional troops has been widely used and widely reported. Is that ballpark accurate? SECRETARY CHENEY: I have never used the number 100,000. We've never announced a number. Until we actually have those additional forces in theater, we'll continue to pursue that policy. I would expect they'll be all kinds of numbers rumored, leaked, speculated about. But the fact is, none of them has any official standing. We have opened up the pipeline to send forces to the Gulf and to Saudi Arabia in support of Desert Shield, and we are today announcing that there are additional forces going as part of that overall effort. Thank you very much.
DOC.HEAD: END BUSH-FORCES TEXT - 8 Takes
Woman Files $750,000 Lawsuit Against Former Congressman
DOC.TEXT: A woman whose allegations of sexual misconduct led to the conviction of former congressman Donald Lukens has filed a $750,000 lawsuit against him. The lawsuit says Lukens, 59, had sexual relations with Rosie Coffman in 1984 or 1985 when she was 13 and again on Nov. 6, 1988, when she was 16. She turned 19 Wednesday. Ms. Coffman's lawsuit, filed Tuesday in Common Pleas Court, claims the experience continues to cause her ``severe mental anguish, pain and suffering, emotional distress, humiliation and psychological injury.'' ``She has nightmares. She can't forget about it, and that's why we have laws protecting juveniles,'' said her attorney, W. Jeffrey Moore. In May 1989, Lukens was convicted of contributing to the unruliness of a minor, stemming from the 1988 incident. Lukens resigned from Congress on Oct. 24 rather than face new allegations of sexual misconduct stemming from an alleged incident with a teen-age congressional employee. Lukens could not be reached for comment Wednesday night. A man who answered the telephone at his Middletown home said Lukens was planning to move, but would not specify where. There was no answer at the home Thursday. Lukens' Washington home number has been changed to an unlisted number. Ms. Coffman's mother, Anna Coffman, said the attention and harassment her daughter has received because of her involvement with Lukens prompted her to seek a night maintenance job. ``She did it so she could stay away from the public,'' the mother said. ``She can't hold down a daytime job without somebody pointing the finger at her.'' Lukens was sentenced to 30 days in jail and fined $500. He has been free on bond, pending appeals. He ran for re-election but was defeated in the Republican primary in May.

DOC.HEAD: Computer Hacking Pranks Costs $2.4 Million, Company Says
DOC.TEXT: Two youthful computer whizzes are accused of tapping into a company's telephone system to make harassing calls and bomb threats, causing $2.4 million in damages and lost business, authorities said. John Keary, a New York State Police investigator, said the two teen-agers experimented with International Data Group's toll-free number and gained access to the Framingham, Mass., firm's computerized voice mailbox system. The company produces specialty, high-tech magazines like Computer World. Keary said the youths made harassing calls for five months and replaced business calls and advertising orders left on the mailbox system with their own fake - and sometimes lewd - messages. Daniel Rosenbaum, 17, and a 14-year-old friend, both of New York City, were charged Monday with computer tampering, unauthorized use of a computer and aggravated harassment. Keary said the two told police they were annoyed at not receiving a free poster with their subscription to an IDG magazine. Olga Greenwood, telecommunications analyst and voice mail administrator for International Data, said harassing calls also were made to the firm's Peterborough, N.H., office. ``For five months, we've been living a nightmare,'' she said. Keary said the pair placed about 700 calls, mostly after working hours,and changed greetings left on computerized employee answering machines. Greenwood said the name on her message was changed to Marge Simpson, the mother of the television cartoon family, and her greeting was changed to a lewd remark. Keary said Rosenbaum faced a year in jail if convicted on the misdemeanor charges. The 14-year-old was charged as a juvenile.

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Chief to Name Indian as New Refugee Chief
DOC.TEXT: Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar plans to nominate his chief of staff, Virendra Dayal of India, as the next U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees, a U.N. spokesman said Thursday. The nomination may be opposed. Norway has its own candidate, former U.N. Ambassador Tom Vraalsen, to replace the former commissioner, who was Norwegian. Thorvald Stoltenberg resigned last week to become deputy prime minister in Norway's new government. The High Commissioner for Refugees is responsible for about 15 million refugees worldwide, including about 5 million Afghans now in Pakistan and Iran, about 2 million refugees in southern Africa and the Horn of Africa. The Geneva-based agency has been demoralized by the resignation of two commissioners in a year's time. Perez de Cuellar's spokesman, Francois Giuliani said the U.N. chief has been conferring with regional group leaders in the General Assembly on Dayal, the only candidate he is discussing. The secretary-general names the commissioner, but the General Assembly must approve the candidate. Dayal has been chief of staff since 1982. From 1979-82, he was director in the office of the undersecretary-general for special political affairs. He was a senior official in the UNHCR from 1965-79. His intended nomination aroused some opposition among Nordic and other Western nations, which traditionally provide the UNHCR nominee. U.N. sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Perez de Cuellar would probably formally announce Dayal despite such opposition. The Western countries would be reluctant to vote against a candidate from India, a major developing country, they said. Stoltenberg served in the post about 11 months, replacing Jean-Pierre Hocke of Switzerland, who resigned under a cloud in October 1989. Hocke was accused of misusing a special education fund for refugees to upgrade his air travel to first class, and was accused by his staff of financial mismanagement and favoritism. Hocke admitted using the fund to get better airline seats, but denied misusing U.N. funds. The UNHCR's budget has been stuck for years at a ceiling of about $550 million, although the number of refugees has grown from 7 million to 15 million in a decade.

DOC.HEAD: Gunmen Kill Second Catholic in Northern Ireland
DOC.TEXT: Two assailants on Thursday shot and killed a Roman Catholic man in a garage in Stewartstown, police said. He was the second Catholic slain in the province in 24 hours. Friends identified the latest victim as Malachy McIvor, in his early 40s, of Moneymore, in County Londonderry. Police said he had no known links with the security forces or paramilitary groups. On Wednesday night, two men shot and killed Catholic Gary Campbell, 22, in his Belfast home. He too had no known connection with the security forces or paramilitary groups, police said. No one claimed responsibility for the killings, but police said they suspected the killers were extremists from this British province's Protestant majority. ``Everybody is living in terrible fear. I fear the IRA will now retaliate for this murder, and once again an innocent member of the Protestant community will probably suffer,'' said Denis Faul, a local Catholic priest. On Nov. 2, an Irish Republican Army bomb killed Protestant Albert Cooper in Cookstown, six miles from Stewartstown. Cooper was a member of the Ulster Defense Regiment, a part-time security branch of the army dominated by Protestants. A week earlier, also in Cookstown, men shot and killed Tommy Casey, 57, a member of the outlawed IRA's legal political wing, Sinn Fein. The mainly Catholic IRA is fighting to end British rule and unite the province with the overwhelmingly Catholic Republic of Ireland under a leftist administration.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper: Iraq Got Bombs Through Lancaster, Chile
DOC.TEXT: Iraq obtained the technology to make cluster bombs through a Pennsylvania company that did illegal business through a Chilean arms dealer, a newspaper reported Thursday. Federal investigators told the Intelligencer Journal in Lancaster that the technology for the bombs came from the International Signal & Control Corp., which was started by former Lancaster businessman James H. Guerin. Guerin's business partner, Carlos Cardoen of Chile, subsequently sold the technology to Iraq in violation of a 1977 law barring Chile from receiving U.S. military technology, the newspaper said. Cluster bombs release hundreds of smaller bombs on impact, or above a target. The smaller bombs can cover an area equivalent to 10 football fields with shrapnel and incendiary fragments. The smaller bombs can detonate at various times, up to 72 hours after the main bomb has been dropped. The newspaper reported previously that Guerin, who now lives in Naples, Fla., has agreed to plead guilty to fraud for inflating the value of his company prior to its merger with the British defense giant Ferranti International PLC. Court records also indicate Guerin is under investigation for illegal arms sales to South Africa and other countries barred from getting arms from the United States, the newspaper said. The cluster bomb technology reached Iraq with help from the Iraqi-owned, British precision tooling firm Matrix Churchill, the newspaper reported, citing federal sources it did not identify. Nasser Beydoun, Cardoen's former weapons salesman to Iraq and Libya, told the Intelligencer Journal through his attorney that he was aware of the sale of cluster bomb technology to Chile as early as 1983 and its subsequent shipment to Iraq in 1987. The newspaper said Cardoen, 48, used his Santiago headquarters to ship the bombs to Baghdad, via Iraqi Airways or by ship from the port of Iquique, Beydoun said. Much of the planning for the shipments was done from Cardoen's Miami Lakes subsidiary, Swissco Management Group, Beydoun told the newspaper. Cardoen's attorney in Miami, Abbey Kaplan, would not comment on Beydoun's claims. The newspaper, citing other sources it did not identify, said Cardoen began contract negotiations with Iraq in 1983 for the sale of the International Signal-designed cluster bombs. International Signal is based in Lancaster County. A Chilean source told the Intelligencer Journal that Cardoen is believed to have sold Iraq 20,000 of one kind of cluster bomb for $7,100 each and 4,000 of another kind of cluster bomb. A spokesman for Cardoen spokesman in Santiago denied any association with ISC, beyond enlisting the help of two of its engineers to solve a technical problem with a radio-detonated explosive destined for the Chilean Air Force. Sources told the Intelligencer Journal, however, that a three-man team from ISC suppiled charts, drawings and designs that Cardoen used to build an Iraq bomb-making plant in 1986-87. Cardoen displayed the technology at an arms and air show in Chile in late March, the newspaper said.

DOC.HEAD: Experts Say Saudi Women Drivers Didn't Break Law
DOC.TEXT: Legal and religious experts have ruled that a group of Saudi women who defied tradition by driving 15 cars through Riyadh did not violate civil or moral laws, informed sources said Thursday night. But the experts assembled by the governor of Riyadh, Prince Salman Bin Abdel-Aziz, said they shouldn't do it again, the sources said. The protesters won at least a moral victory because the rulings mean there is no ban in Islamic or civil law to women driving. The sources predicted women will eventually be allowed to drive in this conservative Arab country, probably within six months to two years. The veiled women, most of them middle-aged and married, startled this desert kingdom Tuesday by taking the steering wheels in the first open protest by women here. Fifteen of them drove the cars, and 35 rode along in support. Police stopped the convoy and took the women to a police station. Saudi officials said they were released after signing a pledge that they would not repeat their protest elsewhere. Many of the women were concerned that if there is a war in Saudi Arabia, with their husbands away, they will be trapped at home, said the sources, speaking on condition of anonymity. Although there is no written law barring Saudi women from driving, they are prohibited from doing so under strict Islamic tradition. During Tuesday's protest, the Saudi religious police, known as the Committee for Commendation of Virtue and Prevention of Vice, insisted after rounding up the women that they be arrested for committing a moral offense. But King Fahd intervened and told the religious police that the incident was being investigated by the prominent religious scholars and legal experts assembled by the governor of Riyadh, the sources said. They did not disclose the identities of the experts. Organizers of the demonstration said many of the women came from prominent families and had driver's licenses from Europe and the United States. The women insisted there was nothing political about their protest. At least some members of the Saudi royal family reportedly favor ending the ban on women driving but have not pushed for it because of opposition elsewhere in the country. Western women drive inside the huge Saudi ARAMCO compound for oil field workers in Dhahran. In addition, uniformed American women soldiers drive military vehicles as part of their job. The soldiers are in Saudi Arabia as part of the international force opposing Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Charged with Beau's Death: ``I Never Physically Harmed Other People''
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS one graf after penultimate graf, `No, Mrs. ...' to ADD earlier testimony on ant poison. ^By MICHAEL HOBBS
DOC.TEXT: WINSTON-SALEM, N.C. (AP) - A woman defending herself against charges that she killed her boyfriend denied on Thursday that she gave him or her two husbands arsenic and disputed witnesses' descriptions of her as cold. ``I've been in jail for 16 months,'' Blanche Taylor Moore testified. ``I've cried myself to sleep every night, but it's not to the point everybody in there would know it.'' The Alamance County grandmother was calm during most of her time on the stand, but twice broke down. ``I know arsenic was found in these three people, but I know that I didn't do it,'' she said. ``I've never physically harmed other people. To physically harm a person, no, I did not do that.'' Mrs. Moore, 57, is being tried on a murder charge in the 1986 arsenic-poisoning death of Raymond Reid. She also is charged in the death of her first husband, James Taylor, and with two counts of assault in the near lethal arsenic poisoning of her now-estranged husband, the Rev. Dwight Moore. She will be tried on those charges later. Mrs. Moore denied helping Reid draft the will that gave her a share of his estate. ``I had not dictated anything,'' Mrs. Moore testified. ``I had nothing to do with the writing of that will.'' Under cross-examination by prosecutor Janet Branch, Mrs. Moore described the 1973 death of Taylor. The night before Taylor died, Mrs. Moore testified, a friend brought over what he described as holy water in a Dr Pepper bottle with holes in the cap. She said the friend sprinkled some of the liquid on Taylor. Mrs. Moore testified that Taylor said: ``If this is Dr Pepper holy water, I'll just drink the whole thing.'' Mrs. Moore said Taylor drank the liquid and she found him dead the next morning. Defense lawyer Mitchell McEntire asked Mrs. Moore if she ever bought or sought to buy ant poison. ``No,'' Mrs. Moore said. ``I've never had any of it in my home or in my hands.'' Earlier witnesses testified Mrs. Moore had tried to buy an ant poison that contained arsenic. The prosecution rested its case Thursday afternoon. Closing arguments were expected to begin Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Sandinista Chief Offers to Take Action Against Former Rebels
DOC.TEXT: The Sandinista defense chief offered Thursday to clear out Contra rebels who have blocked access to much of eastern Nicaragua in ``practically a coup'' against President Violeta Chamorro's government. Gen. Humberto Ortega said the army and police were awaiting Mrs. Chamorro's go-ahead to free the strategic Rama road, the sole overland connection between a large chunk of eastern Nicaragua and the rest of the country. For the past week rebels have blocked the east-west road between Juigalpa, about 85 miles southeast of Managua, to Rama, another 90 miles east. A reporter who checked three of the 14 roadblocks on Tuesday saw no one armed, but Ortega said he had reports of weapons trafficking on the road. The rebels also control Bluefields, an Atlantic Coast town 35 miles east of Rama, said AP photographer Ruben Farina, who visited the city of about 35,000. He said there was no fighting there. Mrs. Chamorro called for a meeting in Managua with 14 mayors from southeastern Nicaraguan who support the blockade. The mayors are all members of the coalition that elected her last February, ending the 10-year Sandinista government. The mayors and the demobilized rebels claim Mrs. Chamorro has not fulfilled promises of aid and has left the Sandinistas with too much power. They are demanding the firing of Defense Minister Ortega; Antonio Laayo, the presidential chief of staff; Interior Minister Carlos Hurtado; and the chiefs of the Sandinista Police and Sandinista People's Army. The Sandinistas still control security forces under an accord reached with Mrs. Chamorro after the Feb. 25 elections, although Ortega officially resigned from the Sandinista party as part of the agreements. Conservatives dislike Lacayo because they claim he has negotiated away too much power to the Sandinistas. Ortega urged the rebels to abandon their blockade and said he hoped force would not have to be used. ``Those who have been provoking the climate of ... boycotts, chaos ... are not political parties or labor unions, but mayors ... with demands of a change of government, practically a coup d'etat,'' he said at a news conference. Monsignor Pablo Antonio Vega, the conservative bishop of Juigalpa and a supporter of the blockade, said the 14 mayors were considering whether to heed the president's call for talks. Southeastern Nicaragua was an area of support for the Contra rebels during their war against the leftist Sandinista government. The current blockade has isolated a rich agricultural region and is causing heavy losses for ranchers and farmers. Ortega also announced the retirement of 5,000 officers from the armed forces by the first of the year. He said that would shrink Nicaragua's armed forces to 28,000 members, making it the fourth largest in Central America. It once was the largest in the region, with about 100,000 people under arms. Central American governments have agreed to reduce their armies, which eat up scarce resources, are frequently accused of committing rights abuses and tend to be unaccountable to the civilian governments they are supposed to defend.

DOC.HEAD: FDA Issues Warning on Body-Building Drug
DOC.TEXT: The Food and Drug Administration urged consumers Thursday to stop taking an illegally marketed and possibly dangerous drug used for strength training and body building. The FDA said it has received reports of more than 30 people in California, Florida and Georgia who have become ill after taking a drug called GHB, or gamma hydroxybutyric acid. The drug is also called sodium oxybate and gamma hydroxybutyrate sodium. The agency said GHB can cause nausea and vomiting, severe respiratory problems, seizures and coma. California officials acted earlier in the week, urging consumers in that state to stop using the drug. GHB is sold as powder or granules through mail order outlets, health food stores, body-building gyms and fitness centers. It is promoted for strength training, body building, weight loss and as a replacement for L-tryptophan. L-tryptophan, a food supplement used as a sleep aid and for depression and weight control, was ordered off the market last March when it was linked to an outbreak of a rare blood disorder called eosinophilia-myalgia syndrome. GHB is being evaluated in approved clinical trials as a treatment for narcolepsy, a sleep disorder. In Europe GHB has been used as an adjunct to anesthesia, the agency said. It is not approved for any uses in the United States, but the drug agency said GHB has been promoted as a ``legal psychedelic.'' The agency advised anyone taking GHB outside of the clinical trials, which are supervised by physicians, to stop taking it immediately. The agency also said that anyone taking GHB who is having seizures, uncontrolled shaking, headache, unexplained drowsiness or other central nervous system disorders, nausea, vomiting or diarrhea, should see a physician immediately. Physicians treating patients with these symptoms were asked to report the cases to their local poison control center. The FDA said it has been working with health departments in the three states to learn more about the illnesses and so far there is strong evidence linking these to the drug.

DOC.HEAD: Harry Reasoner to Cut Back ``60 Minutes'' Pace
DOC.TEXT: NEW YORK (AP - Harry Reasoner said Thursday he's leaving ``60 Minutes'' as a regular correspondent at the end of the season but will stay with the CBS show. ``It's been a nice ride, but you can't go on forever,'' said the 67-year-old Reasoner. He joined CBS in 1956, went to work on ``60 Minutes'' when it began in 1968, but left the network in 1970 to anchor the ``ABC Evening News,'' at one point co-anchoring that show - unhappily - with Barbara Walters. Reasoner returned to CBS and ``60 Minutes'' in 1978. Next season, he will be an ``editor emeritus'' of the top-rated newsmagazine and do occasional reports for the program. He estimated he would do six a year, compared with 20 he now does annually. ``I could say he'll be missed, but he won't be,'' the show's creator and executive producer, Don Hewitt, said in a playful statement. ``He'll be right here, looking over my shoulder and keeping us on the straight and narrow.'' No correspondent will succeed Reasoner, said a spokeswoman for the show, whose other regulars include Morley Safer, Ed Bradley, humorist Andy Rooney, and two who joined the show this season, Meredith Vieria and Steve Kroft. At 72, Mike Wallace is the show's most senior citizen. Several months ago, he said he won't leave ``60 Minutes'' until he dies, or goes ``toes up,'' as he jokingly put it. The wry, folksy Reasoner, who began his journalism career as a Minneapolis newspaperman, said he was cutting back his workload at his own request. ``It was cumulative,'' he said of the decision. ``I suddenly realized I'd been working 53 years, about half of it on `60 Minutes,' and I thought I'd like to take it a little easier.'' Reasoner, who has won several Emmy awards and a Peabody award for his broadcast work, said that ``CBS has been extremely nice and cooperative, and we'll work something out for next season.'' He also said he never thought that ``60 Minutes,'' begun as a Tuesday night show in September 1968, ``had a chance for success. It's been a continual amazement, a show we're very proud of.''

DOC.HEAD: Pope Tells Germany to Keep Abortion Restrictions
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II, defending strong anti-abortion laws, on Thursday warned Germany against sacrificing ``Western'' values during the reconstruction of their nation. Speaking at a ceremony to accept credentials of Germany's new ambassador to the Holy See, the pope spoke of the challenge of emphasizing moral and social values following the unification of East and West Germany. The status of abortion has emerged as a major issue in reunification. East Germany's Communist regime allowed abortion virtually on demand, while West German legislation was more restrictive. It required that a woman prove the pregnancy would harm her health or cause financial hardship. German politicians have decided to let their next parliament, which will be elected in December, decide the issue. ``The reconstruction in a part of Germany and in central and Eastern Europe currently requires the concurrence of many forces,'' the pope noted. ``Nonetheless, that doesn't impede the continued vigilance of social structures and the resolute commitment to maintain fundamental values of society that belong to all the West. The safeguarding of life, both of the born and unborn, is a great good that must not be sacrificed.'' The comments marked the second time that the pope has expressed concern about abortion in a public speech aimed at Germans. In June, he told Rome's German-speaking community that abortion debases humanity. The new ambassador, 60-year-old Hans-Joachim Hallier, has been serving as ambassador to Japan.

DOC.HEAD: Two Die in Battle Between Israelis, Guerrillas
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 13th graf `Modechai said' to RESTORE full name and title of Gen. Mordechai. Picks up 14th graf, `It was...'
DOC.TEXT: Israeli soldiers battled with five guerrillas who infiltrated from Jordan, and one fighter from each side was killed, the army said. The other four infiltrators were arrested, it said. A high-ranking Israeli officer speculated the infiltrators may have intended a revenge attack for the Oct. 8 riots and shootings by Israeli police that left 20 Palestinians dead at the Temple Mount. The bloodbath set off a chain of reprisals by Arabs and Israelis. The occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip were shut down Thursday by a general strike to mark one month since the killings. Another strike was scheduled Friday, the start of the 36th month of the Palestinian uprising against Israeli occupation. Jerusalem police detained seven followers of slain Rabbi Meir Kahane on suspicion of incitement, after they vowed to avenge his death. ``Police will not sit idly in view of inciting calls that lead to disturbances of order,'' said Jerusalem Police Commissioner Yaacov Terner. One of those detained, Yekutiel Ben Yaakov, said in his eulogy at Kahane's funeral Wednesday that Kahane's men would ``let our friend, the submachine gun, our friend the knife, talk for us.'' The extremist rabbi, who advocated expelling Palestinians from Israeli and the occupied territories, was assassinated in New York on Monday by an Arab-American. The infiltration from Jordan occurred before dawn Thursday along the Jordan River just north of Jericho in the West Bank, the army said. It said soldiers found evidence of an infiltration by the Jordanians and began a search. The guerrillas opened fire with pistols and the army returned fire, the army said. Two of the captured infiltrators were wounded, it said. Reserve Capt. Yehuda Lifshitz, who commanded the army force, was killed in the fighting. Israel Television said the guerrilla squad planned to reach Jerusalem, pray on the sacred Temple Mount, and then slaughter Jews near the adjacent Western or Wailing Wall, Judaism's holiest site. Last month's rioting began there when Arabs threw stones at praying Jews. Maj. Gen. Yitzhak Mordechai, chief of Israel's Central Command, told Israel radio the infiltrators had ``links to the Jordanian security establishment.'' An unidentified Jordanian official later told the state-run Petra News Agency in Amman that four policemen were missing from their posts. It was at least the eighth infiltration or attempted infiltration linked to Jordanian security in the past two years. Also Thursday, an Israeli Druse guard was stabbed to death in Jenin prison in the occupied West Bank, a military source said. The victim was attacked by a Palestinian visiting an inmate. The attacker fled and remained at large, the television said. The death raised to 52 the number of Israelis killed in the Palestinian uprising. A total of 773 Palestinians have been slain by Israeli soldiers or civilians. An additional 295 Palestinians have been killed by fellow Arabs, most on suspicion of collaboration with Israel. In the occupied Gaza Strip, soldiers shot and wounded a Palestinian man who tried to stab a soldier checking identification cards at a roadblock, Israel radio said. The soldier wasn't hurt because he was wearing a flak jacket, it said.

DOC.HEAD: Outgoing Drug Czar Says Nation Is Breaking Drug Habit
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 15th graf: ``Barry issued,'' comment from the mayor
DOC.TEXT: William J. Bennett bade farewell as drug-policy director with characteristic bluster Thursday, boasting Americans have turned against drugs and dismissing a congressional critic as a ``gasbag.'' He allowed that his efforts to rid the nation's capital of drugs didn't work, but said it did not help that Mayor Marion Barry, who has been convicted of cocaine possession, was ``part of the problem.'' Bennett, at a White House send-off with President Bush, denied reports that he had run out of gas or feared for his family's safety as the first director of drug policy. ``I'm not the stampeded-out-of-town type,'' said Bennett, who will actually relinquish his post at the end of the month. Bush said he has not yet settled on a successor. The president showered Bennett with praise, saying he had done ``an outstanding job for his country'' and ``his hard work has paid off.'' ``We're on the road to victory,'' said Bush, who promised to stay ``on the front lines until this scourge is stopped.'' The brash Bennett, 47, predicted that the Bush goal of cutting drug usage in half within 10 years now can be met in five years if states do their part. ``Your taking this issue on, your saying in that inaugural address that `this scourge will stop,' coincided with the great American change of minds about drugs,'' Bennett said to Bush at a news conference. ``This country is beginning to break its interest and habit on drugs,'' he said. The Brooklyn-born Bennett took umbrage with a parting shot fired at him earlier by Rep. Charles Rangel, D-N.Y., chairman of the House Select Committee on Narcotics Abuse and Control. Rangel called Bennett's 19-month tenure ``a colossal failure,'' saying he used the job as ``a bull pulpit (sic), running around the country preaching that families should stay together, that we shouldn't use drugs.'' ``I never thought I would miss Nancy Reagan,'' said Rangel. Rejoined Bennett: ``Mr. Rangel is a gas bag. He has nothing to do with drug policy.'' Bennett said he purposely left Mayor Barry out of the planning when mapping an anti-drug strategy for the district. He had no hard evidence then that Barry was using drugs, said Bennett, ``but I suspected that his interest in the topic was different from mine.'' Barry issued a statement saying Bennett ``has joined the parade of people who are using me as an excuse for our nation's failure to deal adequately'' with the drug problem. Sen. Joseph Biden, D-Del., chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, praised Bennett as ``an outstanding leader'' who proved ``a job which many thought un-doable could be performed with impressive intellect and success.'' Bennett, secretary of education in the Reagan administration, denied that his lack of Cabinet status under Bush impeded his effectiveness. ``I spent more time with this president in 20 months than I spent with Ronald Reagan in three years. ... three times as much,'' he said. Bennett presided over dramatic growth in the federal anti-drug budget, from $6.3 billion in fiscal 1989 to $10.4 billion for fiscal 1991. Bennett plans to become a fellow at a conservative think tank, the American Enterprise Institute, and write books on both education and drugs. He is also certain to resume the lucrative lecture circuit career that earned him $240,000 in just 24 appearances during the four months between quitting Reagan's Cabinet in 1988 and accepting Bush's job offer. He also received a $187,000 advance on a contract for two books then. ``I've had nine years in government. I think that's enough for now,'' said Bennett, who also served as chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities in the early 1980s. But to his critics, he added, ``I may be back.'' Bennett ruled out a return to academia. In the past he has accused Harvard and other universities of failing to impart moral values. ``I am free of that world now,'' he said. ``Does the Soviet dissident wish to return as the head of the gulag?''

DOC.HEAD: NYC City Cutting $288 Million, Eliminating Jobs to Close Budget Gap
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with two grafs and DELETES 9th graf, `An additional ...' to CORRECT cutbacks amount to $288 million, sted $338 million and parking lot sold, sted federal courthouse.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Philly Finances
DOC.TEXT: Mayor David N. Dinkins announced $288 million in cutbacks Thursday, including a reduction of 5,500 city jobs this fiscal year - and perhaps 20,000 next year - through layoffs and attrition. The cuts, combined with the $100 million sale of a parking lot, will make up a $388 million budget shortfall for the fiscal year that ends June 30. ``Today, I have some bad news and some worse news,'' Dinkins told reporters. The bad news, he said, ``requires painful sacrifices from every part of our administration,'' including a 10 percent cut of mayoral staff. The worse news was that on Jan. 15 he'll be back with another proposal for the fiscal year beginning in July to close a budget gap that has grown to $1.6 billion. Already this year, the mayor has closed a gap of $1.8 billion in the fiscal year that began in July through budget cuts, ordered a hiring freeze and cut pay of top management by 5 percent, including lopping $6,500 off his own salary of $130,000. The city faces the cuts because of falling tax revenues. ``The root of all these problems is the economy,'' said budget director Philip Michael. Last month, Standard and Poor's, a major bond rating service, put the city on ``credit watch.'' New York is not alone. A plan to save Philadelphia from bankruptcy is expected to be released Friday. Under the proposal for this fiscal year, New York City's Board of Education would be forced to cut $90 million. Health and human services agencies would be cut $51.9 million. The uniformed services - police and firefighters - would be reduced by $60.6 million and all others $85.5 million. The city also increased its reserve fund for emergencies by $50 million, to $150 million. This was done because of the possibility of possible economic worsening, officials said. The Board of Education faces 550 layoffs and 1,000 people lost by attrition. The board can make the cuts as it sees fit. But the city suggested that teacher layoffs and attrition include 117 teachers who teach teachers; 357 non-instructional personnel; and 1,072 positions that will not be filled as they become vacant. Notices to city workers won't go out until the spring. The mayor said other cuts include wading pools in parks, delaying recycling, postponing hiring additional teachers, and eliminating three fire companies and two fire salvage units. Hundreds of employees also will be lost from the city's housing rehabilitation program. The city also must recoup anticipated losses seen in fiscal year 1992, which begins in July. The 20,000 jobs that may be lost would come roughly half from attrition, half from layoffs, the budget director said. ``These are projections that could have a great deal of range to them,'' Michael said. ``Quite frankly, there's a lot of contingency that has to be played out.'' As the mayor made his announcement, about 800 members of Local 1180 of the Communications Workers of America demonstrated in City Hall Park, then walked to Wall Street. ``We're getting more of the same crap - job freezes, layoffs, wage freezes,'' said Local 1180's president, Arthur Cheliotes, who represents administrative personnel in the city. Leaders of municipal unions have broken off contract talks with the city because city has been unwilling to match a 5.5 percent pay raise teachers received Oct. 1. The city budgeted 1.5 percent increases for all unions and says that is all it is giving the teachers - the rest comes from state aid and a rearrangement of the pension funding system.

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Committee Approves Insectors for Jordan-Iraq Frontier
DOC.TEXT: A Security Council committee on Thursday approved U.N. inspectors for Jordan's border with Iraq to make sure trucks are not taking goods to Iraq and occupied Kuwait in violation of the U.N. economic embargo. Suspicion that Jordan is not enforcing the embargo focuses on highway traffic from Jordan's port of Aqaba to Baghdad, Iraq's capital. Deputy Finnish Ambassador Marjatta Rasi, who presides over the Security Council's committee on sanctions against Iraq, said the committee asked U.N. staff in Jordan to begin spot-checking trucks at the border. Jordanian Ambassador Abdullah Salah requested the observers last week, to prove Jordan is obeying the embargo. Western diplomats, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Jordan became aware it will receive no special economic aid from the world community unless other countries are sure it is observing the embargo. Unless Jordan completely obeys the embargo, approved in Resolution 661 on Aug. 6, it does not qualify for special relief aid, the diplomats said. Jordan applied for help under the U.N. Charter, which provides for countries burdened with ``special economic problems arising from the carrying out'' of sanctions or other Security Council actions. Ms. Rasi said she was sending a letter to Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar informing him of the committee's decision. A. Attiga, resident coordinator of the U.N. Disaster Relief Organization based in Amman, will be in charge of the effort, using his staff, she said. The Sanctions Committee decided not to send in outside observers to keep the cost down, Ms. Rasi said. Americans based in the U.S. Embassy in Amman had been monitoring border traffic, but were pulled back to the capital for their own safety, U.S. officials at the United Nations said last week. Jean Ripert, the U.N. chief's special envoy, said after returning from Amman that Jordan's economy will collapse next year unless Jordan gets help from other countries. He said Jordan will lose about $1 billion between Aug. 2, when Iraq invaded Kuwait, and the end of this year because of the trade embargo on Baghdad, its major trading partner. In terms of the proportion of Jordan's gross national product lost due to the embargo, he said, the picture is far worse. ``For Jordan, in 1990 it is a figure around 30 percent. For next year, it could be something above 50 percent,'' he said. `` ... The question is, will Jordan be able to survive?'' In other U.N. developments Thursday: -Emerging democracies in Eastern Europe said they are ready to renounce a 15-year-old resolution equating Zionism with racism, but Israel and the United States don't want to press the point until they are sure of overwhelming support. U.N. envoys from Czechoslovakia, Hungary, Poland and Bulgaria - among 72 U.N. members who agreed in a Nov. 10, 1975, vote that the founding ideology of Israel was racist - revealed a change of heart at a conference convened by American Jewish leaders. -Perez de Cuellar reported to the Security Council that his latest efforts to end the Cyprus stalement failed and a ``negative atmosphere ... has persisted.'' But he said he would keep trying to bring Greek and Turkish Cypriot sides together and appealed to them to cooperate to avoid aggravating the situation. Turkey invaded and occupied northern Cyprus in 1974 to protect the Turkish minority from what it called persecution and violence.

DOC.HEAD: Italian President Called to Testify About Government Guerrillas
DOC.TEXT: A judge notified President Francesco Cossiga on Thursday that he would be called to testify about a secret, government-organized guerrilla group that was created in the 1950s. It was the first time in Italy's postwar history that a president had been called as a witness in a case, Italian media reported. Italy's No. 2 party, the opposition Communists, called for the resignation of Premier Giulio Andreotti, who has been under siege since admitting last month that the group existed. Politicians have speculated that the group, ostensibly created to fight any Soviet Bloc invasion, had trained its sights on domestic targets - namely, the Communists. There has been speculation the group was behind some right-wing terrorist attacks that plagued Italy in the 1970s and '80s, when the Communists came to the brink of power. Andreotti told the Senate that 622 Italians belonged to the network, codenamed Operation Gladio after the short, double-edged sword used by Roman gladiators. Italians were recruited during the Cold War on the basis of their patriotism and physical fitness, he said. Members of the network were civilians, apparently with military backgrounds. The Christian Democratic premier said that the Defense Ministry knew about the group, which was trained by the Italian secret services. ``No one can doubt that any distorted use of the structure would happen only outside the directives of the ministries,'' he said Thursday. He added that a check by Italian police had shown that none of the ``gladiators'' had had judicial records ``or other indications going against democratic security.'' Andreotti said that in 1959, France requested Italy be allowed to join a special NATO group that coordinated similar guerrilla groups in other member countries. NATO spokesmen have refused to comment on Gladio. The leader of the Communist group in the Senate, Ugo Pecchioli, demanded Andreotti's resignation. ``This government has brought upon itself heavy responsibilities and it doesn't have the credit nor the capacity to deal with such a profound crisis,'' Pecchioli said. His cry was not echoed by any of the five parties of the governing coalition, who hold the majority in the Senate. They are Andreotti's Christian Democrats, the Socialists, Republicans, Liberals and Social Democrats. ``We ask that this all be fully investigated so that there are no dark corners, ambiguities, uncertainties or unresolved mysteries,'' said the Socialist leader in the Senate, Fabio Fabbri. The case has been taken up by Venice Investigating Magistrate Felice Casson, a specialist in terrorism. Casson discovered the existence of the Gladio organization during a probe of a right-wing terrorist attack. On Thursday, Casson sent word to Cossiga that he would be called to testify in the new case. Cossiga, a former premier and interior minister, recently revealed he had known of the Gladio organization for years.

DOC.HEAD: Peru's Fujimori Unable to Attend Akihito Crowning in Japan
DOC.TEXT: President Alberto Fujimori said a pressing workload kept him from traveling to his ancestral home for the enthronement of Emperor Akihito, but he sent Foreign Minister Luis Marchand in his stead. Marchand left Thursday for Monday's ceremony, Fujimori said Wednesday. It is the first time a monarch has ascended the Chrysanthemum Throne under the Japanese constitution enacted in 1946. Fujimori, the son of Japanese parents, visited Japan in June shortly after being elected, to secure fresh loans and emergency donations to help ease Peru's economic crisis. Fujimori, who speaks fluent Japanese, visited his parents' hometown of Kawachi during the weeklong visit. Marchand is to hold talks on Japanese investment in Peru with Japan's Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu. Japan is Peru's second-largest trading partner after the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Pro-Cuban Rebels Bomb Synagogue, U.S. Targets in Peru
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with name of synagogue bombed, fighting in cocaine area kills 11, report on journalists' harassment and deaths. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Left-wing guerrillas have bombed U.S.-linked agencies and Lima's largest synagogue in a wave of attacks protesting American and Israeli policies in the Mideast. No one has been seriously injured in the attacks. A bomb Wednesday night caused minor damage near the U.S. ambassador's residence, police said, and another bomb at the North American Cultural Institute slightly injured a bystander. Bombs last weekend caused minor damage at the U.S. Consulate; a branch office of Xerox Corp.; and the Peruvian Israelite Union Synagogue. A weekly newspaper close to the Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement said Thursday the attacks ``target Jews and Americans engaged in the violation of human and national rights in the Middle East.'' The Jewish community in Peru is quite small, including 3,000 in Lima, the country's capital and largest city. About 70 percent belong to the Israelite Union congregation. Tupac Amaru is the smaller of two guerrilla groups operating in Peru. Like the larger Shining Path, Tupac Amaru is Marxist-Leninist. But the pro-Cuba group mainly has attacked U.S. influence in Peru; Shining Path would like to recreate Peru along the lines of the Chinese Communist revolution. Clashes between the army and the Shining Path left 11 dead Wednesday in a coca-producing jungle area, military sources said. Slain were an army captain, four soldiers and six rebels, the sources said, speaking on condition they not be named. The battles took place about six miles south of Tingo Maria, the main city in the Upper Huallaga Valley, about 200 miles northeast of Lima. Drug traffickers in the area supply rebels with guns and money in return for protection. The region provides over 60 percent of the world's supply of coca leaf. The leaf is ground into paste and flown to Colombia, where it is processed into cocaine. Political violence the past 10 years has claimed the lives of more than 20,000 Peruvians, mostly civilians. An international organization of journalists met Thursday with Defense Ministry officials and congressmen to denounce the murder and harassment of dozens of Peruvian reporters. The Brussels-based International Federation of Journalists delivered a report to Defense Ministry officials Thursday that said 15 journalists have been killed while doing their job the last three years. In the same period, two journalists disappeared, 17 were beaten and many others were threatened, the federation said. Soldiers and police are suspected in at least eight of the killings and guerrillas are suspected in at least six. There are no clear suspects in the other slaying, the federation's report said. Todd Smith, a reporter for the Tampa Tribune, is the only foreign journalist named in the federation's report. Smith was killed in November 1989 in Uchiza, in the Upper Huallaga Valley. Drug traffickers, guerrillas and police have all been mentioned as suspects in his death.

DOC.HEAD: Cast of ``Cheers'' And Boston Celebrate 200th Show
DOC.TEXT: The cast of the television show ``Cheers'' celebrated the show's 200th episode Thursday night, thanking Bostonians for the good humor that made the series famous. The program was broadcast in its usual NBC time slot but ran for an hour rather than a half-hour. ``This is overwhelming,'' said George Wendt, who plays Norm Peterson, the roly-poly beer-swigging barfly on the show. Wendt received a roar from the crowd and chants of ``Norm, Norm'' at his introduction at a City Hall celebration earlier in the day. The cast traveled downtown in a motorcade. ``Sorry we screwed up your lunch hour,'' Wendt told several thousand people who stood in 45 degree temperatures. Mayor Raymond Flynn, who was out of town on vacation, officially named Thursday ``Cheers Appreciation Day.'' The entire staff turned out for the celebration, except for Woody Harrelson, who portrays the slow-witted bartender of the same name. ``Cheers,'' a sitcom about regular patrons at a bar of the same name, is based on Bull & Finch, a Boston basement-level bar. The show is in its 9th season and has included cameo appearances by Flynn and Gov. Michael Dukakis. The sitcom is filmed in Los Angeles and the movie company flew the cast to Boston for the sake of image. The crowd that lined downtown streets to watch the actors' motorcade treated the cast as their own. City and sports officials presented the actors with small gifts reflecting their television characters. Kelsey Grammer, who plays Dr. Frasier Crane, a psychiatrist who graduated from Harvard, was presented with a sweatshirt from the university band for ``perpetuating the stereotypes about Harvard.'' ``I know why Frasier makes so much money in this town. The entire city is suffering from a mass psychosis,'' Grammer said. ``Cheers'' was No. 1 for its time slot last year and has won 22 Emmys since its first airing. The show's success has enabled some cast members to launch movie careers. Ted Danson, the suave womanizer Sam ``MayDay'' Malone on the show, appeared in ``Three Men And A Baby,'' and Kirstie Alley, who portrays self-conscious ``Cheers'' manager Rebecca Howe, is starring in her second motion picture, ``Sibling Rivalry.''

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Support Military Action, Bush Orders in 150,000 Troops
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with deployment of up to 150,000 troops, Cheney, Bush and Colin Powell quotes. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos DHA1,2,3
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. campaign to gain support for U.N. military action against Iraq got a boost Thursday, with the Soviet Union offering its qualified approval. President Bush, as expected, ordered a new round of troop deployments, adding up to 150,000 soldiers to the multinational force facing off against Iraq. In another development, Iraqi strongman Saddam Hussein sacked his army chief, suggesting dissension in the ranks over Kuwait, which his forces overran three months ago. The deployment of as many as 150,000 troops represents a substantial addition to the 230,000 U.S. military personnel in the region. Allies from 26 countries have sent 70,000 soldiers to the multinational force assembled in the area. ``If this movement of force is what convinces him (Saddam), so much the better,'' Bush said in a nationwide broadcast from Washington. ``Let's hope he comes to his senses.'' Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, giving details of the new buildup, said it would include two armored divisions and small armored units from Germany as well as the famed ``Big Red One'' First Infantry Division (Mechanized) from Fort Riley, Kans. Pentagon officials in private conversations said full deployment of the units would total about 150,000 troops. Said Bush, ``We're talking about significant numbers'' of troops. Cheney, who faced reporters after Bush, added, ``We will not put an upper limit on this deployment.'' Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said, ``Whether it will be adequate in the event of going to war with Saddam Hussein's army, I'm not going to speculate.'' ``Iraq's brutality, aggression and violation of international law cannot be permitted to succeed,'' Bush said, referring to the ``dismantling of Kuwait'' by Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion. ``I find it hard to believe that today, November 8, that he (Saddam) does not understand that he's up against a determined, unprecedented alliance ...'' ``When he surveys the force that's there ... he will recognize that he is up against just a foe that he can't possible manage militarily,' Bush said. Former West German Chancellor Willy Brandt, meanwhile, secured the release of 50 more Westerners from Iraq, including Germans, Italians, Dutch and Britons, the Iraqi News Agency reported. It did not say when they would be freed. Iraq on Wednesday promised to free more than 100 Westerners. Hundreds of Americans are among those still trapped, some held at strategic sites to deter attack by the U.S.-led mutinational force in the region. Secretary of State James A. Baker III met in Moscow with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Baker wants Moscow to agree to using force as a last resort to liberate Kuwait. Later, Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze said military might should not be ruled out, but cautioned it should be used only under U.N. auspices. ``A situation may emerge which effectively would require such a move,'' Shevardnadze said. He played down any differences on Iraq between the superpowers. Before Baghdad's invasion of Kuwait, Moscow was Baghdad's principal ally and principal weapons supplier. ``I would advise against looking for some difference in the positions between the Soviet Union and the United States,'' Shevardnadze told reporters. Bush said ``we're on the same wavelength'' with Gorbachev in terms of his policy goals in the Middle East. He said he felt there were no ``mixed signals'' from Moscow. The Bush administration, impatient that months of economic sanctions have failed to dislodge Saddam from Kuwait, intends to ask the U.N. Security Council to authorize force to liberate Kuwait if Iraq doesn't pull out. Baker is on a weeklong tour of Middle Eastern and European nations to gather support for such action. He travels to Paris and London before heading back to Washington on Saturday. If such a measure were adopted, it would be the first time the U.N. authorized a joint military command. During the Korean War, it authorized the United States to command the U.N. forces repelling North Korea's invasion. The United States and its allies are facing about 430,000 Iraqi troops in Kuwait and southern Iraq. There seemed to be indications Thursday that cracks might be opening in Iraq's stated determination to remain in Kuwait. Iraq's army newspaper and U.S. officials said Saddam replaced his military chief of staff, Gen. Nizar Al-Khazraji, with the head of his elite Republican Guards, Gen. Hussein Rashid. It did not say when or why Khazraji was dismissed. Western analysts with knowledge of Iraq's military machine said Khazraji's surprise dismissal indicated growing opposition in some military quarters to Saddam's strategy on Kuwait. ``It's very ominous,'' said Hans-Heino Kopietz, with Control Risks, an international security firm in London. ``It's not wise to change horses in mid-stream at this point in time. Khazraji's dismissal now is indicative of some opposition to Saddam within the military,'' said Kopietz, just back from a Middle East tour. Khazraji had been chief of staff since 1985 and was one of the top officers in Saddam's inner circle of military advisers. He was sacked amid increasingly tough U.S. and British warnings that they might use force to dislodge Iraq from Kuwait if necessary. Saddam regularly purges those he perceives as a threat. It was the second replacement of a high-level Iraqi official in two weeks. Oil Minister Issam Chalabi was fired Oct. 28 and replaced by Brig. Gen. Hussein Kamel, Saddam's cousin and son-in-law. Some analysts said Rashid's appointment was in part designed to keep the Republican Guards on Saddam's side. The guards are considered Saddam's best troops among his million-man forces. In Amman, Jordan, 11 British women arrived Thursday en route to Baghdad to seek the release of their husbands and relatives held hostage after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. They were expected to leave Friday for Iraq. And in Warsaw, Poland, 241 Poles returned from Iraq on Thursday and one told Polish TV at the airport that about 40 Americans being held at a chemical plant were in ``tragic'' condition. Iraq offered to allow relatives of foreigners banned from leaving to spend Christmas with loved ones. The British and U.S. governments discouraged relatives from accepting the invitation. The women hope to negotiate directly with Saddam and ask him to release the men on humanitarian grounds.

DOC.HEAD: Texas Education Officials Escalate Battle Over Evolution
DOC.TEXT: Texas education officials gave preliminary approval Thursday to science textbooks that teach evolution, but a longtime clash with creationists continued. The State Board of Education asked its staff to look into whether a reference in some of the books, which says human embryos have gill slits, was accurate. The board, meeting as a committee, tentatively approved the biology books, striking a blow to religious fundamentalists who say the texts don't treat creationism as an equally valid idea. A final vote was set for Saturday. Texas is one of the nation's largest textbook buying states and influences what publishers put in textbooks. The textbooks under consideration are for grades 1 through 12. ``This is a major victory,'' said Mike Hudson, general counsel for the People for the American Way, a civil rights group that has lobbied for expanded coverage of evolution in science textbooks. ``This is probably the most important thing that has happened in science education in the past five years,'' Hudson said of the board's preliminary vote. Mel Gabler, who with his wife, Norma, has fought against evolution for about 30 years, said the proposed texts were a form of censorship. Gabler argued they treat evolution as a fact without including debate of the theory. ``Why are evolutionists so afraid of giving students weaknesses as well as strengths of evolution,?'' Gabler asked. ``Censorship nullifies critical thinking of students. This is indoctrination, not education,'' he said. The theory of evolution holds that all species of plants and animals developed from earlier forms, through hereditary transmission of slight variations in successive generations. Creationism ascribes the origin of species to acts of God as described in the Bible. Education Board member Will Davis of Austin said the books ``separate religious theory from scientific theory.'' ``In public school textbooks, we are not to engage in religious theory. That's for churches, that's for your own soul-searching. In public schools we deal with science, not religion,'' he said. Davis said the current science textbooks give a cursory review of evolution, while the new books are much more in depth. Each side presented its own scientists to testify. Claud Bramblett, a University of Texas scientist, said the textbooks were well-written and would probably interest more students in science. ``We need to grow future scientists, not import them,'' he said. Walter Bradley, a Texas A&M University scientist, said the books contained errors and were written in a way that students would just accept the teachings as fact. Education Board Chairman Monte Hasie of Lubbock said the books weren't perfect, but better than the current ones. ``I think we're making progress and that's what education is all about,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Personal-Injury Lawyers on Trial in Alleged Scheme of Bribery, Fakery
DOC.TEXT: One of the nation's most successful personal-injury attorneys and two other lawyers reaped millions of dollars by manufacturing evidence, bribing witnesses and creating phony cases, a prosecutor said Thursday. ``These defendants decided that winning personal-injury lawsuits was the most important thing, the only thing, and they were willing to do whatever it took to win,'' Assistant U.S. Attorney Jerome C. Roth told jurors, opening a complicated trial that is expected to last several months. Morris J. Eisen, two of his top lawyers and several aides and investigators at Eisen's Manhattan law firm are accused of a wide-ranging scheme of racketeering, mail fraud, falsification of evidence and bribery of witnesses, law enforcers and court workers dating back nearly a decade. James La Rossa, Eisen's lawyer, argued his client was the object of a vendetta orchestrated by insurance companies and city and state governments who have had to pay millions of dollars in awards to injured people represented by Eisen's firm. ``You're going to hear a lot of things that are going to disappoint you as Americans,'' La Rossa told the jury. He defended Eisen and other personal-injury lawyers, who work on a contingency fee basis and are paid only when they win or settle lawsuits. La Rossa said such lawyers are defenders of poor and disadvantaged people who would not be able to otherwise afford attorneys. Eisen and the other two lawyers, Joseph P. Napoli and Harold M. Fishman, are on trial before U.S. District Judge Charles P. Sifton. Also on trial are several private investigators and the firm's former office manager. The defendants are accused of violating the federal Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act, or RICO, and other crimes. If convicted, they face up to 20 years in prison and fines of as much as double the proceeds of their alleged criminal activity, prosecutors said. An investigation involving 19 personal-injury lawsuits - seven of them against the city - began in 1985. Awards in those lawsuits amounted to as much as $9 million and the firm's contingency fees were about one-third of that amount, prosecutors said. The victims of the alleged frauds, which date to at least 1981, included city and state governments, the Transit Authority, private corporations, individuals and insurance companies, Roth said. He said the defendants manufactured evidence, such as digging potholes where there were none, paid people to falsely say they had witnessed accidents, paid eyewitnesses to lie or not to testify and fabricated accidents when none occurred. The defendants were ``limited only by their own imagination,'' Roth said. La Rossa told jurors the real wrongdoers were the liars and con artists the government had granted immunity and would present as credible witnesses. Those witnesses made a deal to testify for the prosecution, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Man Convicted of Sexual Assault Against Woman with 46 Personalities
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with verdict, reaction from defendant, further background, jury foreman's quote. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto OSH1
DOC.TEXT: A man was convicted Thursday of sexually assaulting a woman who doctors say has 46 personalities after he testified she consented to sex and he learned only later she was mentally ill. ``I still don't think she is mentally ill,'' the defendant, Mark A. Peterson, said after the verdict was announced. ``What's there to be sorry about? Why should I be sorry for her?'' Peterson was convicted of second-degree sexual assault and could be sentenced to 10 years in prison. He remained free on $5,000 bond. Sentencing was scheduled for Dec. 10 and he said he will appeal. Jurors heard psychiatrists disagree over the 27-year-old woman's contention that she was unaware one of her personalities - described as a fun-loving 20-year-old woman - was having sex. She said she learned of it from another personality, a girl the age of 6. Earlier Thursday, Peterson contradicted testimony by the woman and others that he was warned she suffered from multiple personality disorder. He said when he later learned the woman was ill, he telephoned to apologize but she hung up after warning: ``I'm going to prosecute you, you bastard.'' The woman testified Wednesday that Peterson, 29, manipulated the personality that was prevalent at the time to force her to have intercourse. She blinked her eyes and bowed her head as she summoned six different personalities to the witness stand. Four of them were sworn in individually. Darold Treffert, a psychiatrist who testified for the defense, said he feels she comprehended her conduct. Treffert said the woman's various characters were encouraged by her therapists who believe in multiple personality disorder, which he called ``the UFO of psychiatry.'' Peterson testified: ``She excited me. ... She was pretty. ... I asked her if I could love her. She said, `Yes.''' Under Wisconsin law, it is a crime to have sex with people known to suffer from a mental illness that makes them incapable of understanding their conduct. District Attorney Joe Paulus argued that the woman is mentally ill and Peterson knew it when he had sex with her in the front seat of his car June 11 at an Oshkosh park. The defendant wanted to keep one of the woman's personalities, Jennifer, as his mistress, the prosecutor said during closing arguments. Peterson, who's married, treated the victim ``like a piece of meat at his disposal to play games with,'' Paulus said. ``Jennifer is his little secret. She is the person he can call on to have sex. She is the mental illness he can manipulate.'' Defense lawyer Ed Salzsieder argued that the evidence showed Peterson, a former grocery store bagger, was guilty of nothing more than bad judgment and promiscuity but he did not manipulate a mentally ill woman. Peterson is ``no rocket scientist,'' Salzsieder said. The jury was asked to decide three issues: whether the woman was mentally ill, whether the illness made her incapable of appraising her conduct and whether Peterson knew of the illness. Psychiatrists diagnosed the woman, who earned an associate degree from college, as having multiple personality disorder last February, a diagnosis that has only been recognized within the last decade. The disorder is often triggered by childhood abuse that forces the victim to create separate personalities to avoid confronting reality. About 7,000 Americans suffer from the illness. Peterson testified he asked the woman out for coffee, eventually drove her to a park and had sex with her. The woman told him about people she called John, Jamie and Jennifer, but Peterson said he thought she was referring to brothers and sisters at first. He became suspicious that the woman might have a mental illness when they returned to her home after leaving the park, he said. Peterson said he first heard the term multiple personality disorder mentioned when he returned to the woman's home and witnessed the woman switch personalities for the first time. ``I was very surprised, yes. I never seen that before. Never heard of it happening before,'' he told the court. Peterson said a statement he gave police indicating he was aware of the woman's different personalities before he had sex was wrong. He signed the statement because he was tired, he said. Jury foreman David Ward said the statement ``was a key to the conviction.''

DOC.HEAD: Judge: Gainesville Murder Suspect Needs Mental Treatment
DOC.TEXT: A judge said Thursday he would sentence a teen-ager who remains a suspect in the Gainesville student killings to a psychiatric treatment center for beating his elderly grandmother. Circuit Judge Theron Yawn postponed final sentencing of 19-year-old Edward Lewis Humphrey for a week until lawyers find a place that will accept him and provide ``a structured environment to assure that he will not get back on the streets ... until he is mentally able.'' The teen-ager is one of eight suspects in the August killings of five college students near the University of Florida. Investigators have yet to charge him or eliminate him as a suspect. He has been jailed on $1 million bond since Aug. 30 when he was arrested after beating his grandmother. He was convicted Oct. 10 of battery on a person over age 65 and could have been sentenced to as much as 22 months in prison. Noting the intense publicity linking Humphrey to the slayings, Yawn said: ``I want it thoroughly understood there is no connection between the events in Gainesville and this case.''

DOC.HEAD: Thatcher's Party Routed in Two Parliamentary Votes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with two elections, Bradford North results, tightens pvs. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Conservatives finished third in a special parliamentary election Thursday in this northern town in a sound thrashing for her troubled government. In another vote, in the northwest England dockland town of Bootle, the opposition Labor Party got 22,052 votes, compared with 2,587 for the Conservatives and 2,216 for the Liberal Democrats. In Bradford North, Tory candidate Joy Atkin came in third with only 6,048 votes or 16 percent, a 23 percent decline for the Conservatives since the last general election in 1987. Labor candidate Terry Rooney won 18,619 votes or 52 percent; Liberal Democrat David Ward took 9,105 votes for 25 percent. The rest went to fringe parties. Bootle has long been a solid area for Labor, but the Conservatives were viewed as having a chance to win in North Bradford. Their poor showing reflected the crisis in the Conservative Party since Mrs. Thatcher's deputy, Sir Geoffrey Howe, quit last week. ``Clearly a disappointing result,'' Conservative Party chairman Kenneth Baker said of the results in the 67,340-voter district of Bradford North. ``I think out there we're not very popular at the moment.'' The elections were caused by the deaths of the previous legislators in the two districts. The poor Tory showing in Bradford North prompted renewed speculation that an attempt will be made to oust Mrs. Thatcher as Conservative leader and prime minister at the party's annual leadership election this month. ``The pressures and feeling there should be a leadership contest will build up,'' said rank-and-file legislator Tony Marlow. ``I think there will be a new prime minister before Christmas.'' She became prime minister in 1979. Britain's fledgling Islamic Party finished a poor fourth in its first run for office in Bradford North, getting 800 votes. The former textile town has 7,000 Moslem voters, reflecting the large numbers of Pakistani immigrants who came to work in mills in the 1950s and '60s. In both Bradford North and Bootle the voter turnout was low, 53 percent in Bradford North and 39 percent in Bootle. In resigning, Howe complained about Mrs. Thatcher's combative style, but said Thursday he had also resigned over issues of ``substance.'' He was frustrated over Mrs. Thatcher's resistance to a closer union of the European Community. Controversy over a new local government tax imposed last spring dominated the Bradford campaign. But the sight of Mrs. Thatcher in trouble nationally added to the Tories' difficulties. In national opinion polls, the Conservatives are trailing between 12 and 20 points behind Labor. The results scarcely dented dent Mrs. Thatcher's huge majority - down from 100 to 98 - in the 650-member House of Commons. The Conservatives have 373 seats, Labor 227 and the Liberal Democrats 20. Two seats are vacant and the remainder are held by minority regional parties.

DOC.HEAD: Einstein, Freud Letters on War to Be Auctioned
DOC.TEXT: Theories on war and how to prevent it are a dime a dozen, but Albert Einstein's and Sigmund Freud's are expected to bring at least $150,000. Sotheby's announced Thursday that two letters on the subject from two of the greatest minds of the 20th century would be auctioned Dec. 11. The letters were written at the request of the League of Nations for a book of ``letters between leaders of thought.'' Einstein's four-page missive, dated July 28, 1932, focuses on the question, ``Is there a way to liberate man from the doom of war?'' He states his support for a world body to resolve all conflicts between nations and adds that war exists only because ``man has in him the need to hate and destroy.'' Freud's 14-page answer, dated Sept. 12, 1932, attributes that need to man's aggressive instincts. ``In the meantime, we may assure ourselves: everything that serves to promote cultural development works against war,'' he concludes. Both letters are handwritten and signed. They were consigned by the trustees of an educational institution, which Sotheby's would not identify further. Sotheby's is selling them as one lot. The pre-sale estimate was $150,000 to $250,000.

DOC.HEAD: Wives of British Hostages Reach Jordan, Bound for Iraq
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 2 grafs to RECAST to make conditions in which Americans held ``tragic,'' REVISING translation. Picks up 3rd graf, `The group...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto AMM3
DOC.TEXT: Eleven British women arrived Thursday en route to Baghdad to seek the release of their husbands and relatives held hostage after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. They were expected to leave Friday for Iraq. In Warsaw, Poland, 241 Poles returned from Iraq on Thursday and one told Polish TV at the airport that the conditions in which about 40 Americans were being held at a chemical plant were ``tragic.'' The group of women who flew into Amman on Thursday includes wives, girlfriends, one fincee and the mothers of two hostages. The British Foreign Office advised the women against going and called the trip ``risky,'' but they ignored the advice, and paid for the trip themselves. ``Our main objective is to seek the freedom of our husbands,'' said Dorothy Goodwin, 55, whose husband, Peter, was a pilot with Kuwaiti Airways. Sunni Jennings said: ``My husband encouraged me to come now rather than Christmas because the sooner I come, the better.'' She said she hoped to return home before Christmas with her husband, Michael, who worked as an engineer for a Kuwaiti company before the Aug. 2 invasion. Iraq offered to allow relatives of foreigners banned from leaving to spend Christmas with loved ones. The British and U.S. governments discouraged relatives from accepting the invitation. The women hope to negotiate directly with Iraqi President Saddam Hussein and ask him to release the men on humanitarian grounds. Iraqi authorities granted them one-month visas, and promised to assist them. But no meetings with Saddam were promised. Before leaving London, Carol Cox, 31, said: ``This is not a joyous occasion. ... But we are certainly going out there as a solid group with the same aim - to get our husbands and relatives home.'' Her husband, John, was a sales manager for a shipping company in Kuwait and is now believed held at a strategic site in Iraq. At least 600 foreigners, mainly Americans, Britons, Germans and Japanese, are held as human shields at potential military targets in Iraq and Kuwait. Thousands of others are banned from leaving, but have not been relocated. Speaking to reporters at London's Heathrow Airport, the women urged Britain, the United States and the allies to exercise restraint in dealing with Iraq. ``We are not politicians or diplomats, we are just ordinary people,'' Mrs. Goodwin said. ``We are hoping for a peaceful solution to the crisis rather than a military one.''
