DOC.HEAD: AIDS Drug Mired in Corruption and Controversy
DOC.TEXT: A low-cost drug Kenya trumpeted as a breakthrough AIDS treatment has become mired in licensing squabbles and corruption charges, delaying its availability and casting doubt on promising initial findings. Patients and doctors who have used the drug, known as Kemron, say it does seem to alleviate symptoms. And people are coming from Europe, the United States and elsewhere to try it. The optimistic reports await confirmation in clinical trials under way in several countries. Doubtful claims of proprietorship by Kenyan researchers and suggestions they may have overstated their findings have cast doubt on the reports. There also are accusations that one Kenyan doctor has sold test samples of Kemron, including worthless placebos, for exorbitant prices. ``Somebody's been corrupted if they're selling placebos to dying AIDS patients,'' said Joseph Cummins, an American veterinarian who supplied the interferon that comprises the treatment. Interferons, which long have been studied for antiviral properties, occur naturally in the body and help shield the immune system. The U.S. Food and Drug Administration has approved the use of interferons in treating Kaposi's sarcoma, a cancer common among people with AIDS. Cummins devised a method of administering low doses of interferon that is being used by doctors at the Kenya Medical Research Institute, which is known as Kemri. The drug generally has not been tested in pill form because of the belief it would be destroyed by stomach acid. In Cummins' use, a tablet containing the drug is dissolved on the tongue, allowing small doses to be absorbed through the mouth. Kenyan researchers who used Cummins' method announced startling findings in February. They said that after two to four weeks of treatment with Kemron, AIDS symptoms were alleviated in most of 101 patients tested. They claimed the virus that causes AIDS could no longer be detected in the blood of about 10 percent of the patients. The researchers reported no negative side effects. No other scientists have duplicated Kenya's findings, which resulted from uncontrolled trials; no group received placebos for comparison. But the World Health Organization, largely due to the Kenyan results, has recommended worldwide trials while cautioning that patients sometimes respond well to new treatments simply because of the greater attention they receive. In announcing the unverified results, Kemri's director, Dr. Davey Koech, claimed to have been largely responsible for developing the treatment - a contention dismissed by Cummins. Koech said in February that Kemri produced ``a form of interferon not so far described in medical literature.'' As collaborators he cited Cummins, whose Amarillo Cell Culture Institute has four patents on the low-dose use of oral interferon, and Hayashibara Biochemical Laboratories of Akayama, Japan. Hayashibara is one of the few companies in the world that manufactures interferons and produces the drug used in Kenya's program under a licensing agreement with Cummins' company. Soon after the February presentation, Cummins wrote Koech, accusing him of lies and misrepresentations and threatening to sue over Koech's attempts to patent the technique in Kenya. From Texas, Cummins said he developed the treatment after years of experimenting with interferon on animal diseases, including cat leukemia. Cat leukemia, like AIDS, suppresses the immune system. He described one early experiment in a 1987 article in the British medical journal Lancet. Despite their disagreement, Cummins described Koech as ``quite bold and courageous.'' He said Koech's main contribution was to put the treatment ``into people we never could have tested'' due to restrictive U.S. laws. However, Cummins said the legacy of the Kenyan tests was ``an awful lot of drama and not much data.'' Koech declined repeated requests for an interview. Neither Cummins nor Koech claims Kemron is a cure for AIDS. However, critics say false hopes were raised among many in Kenya by Koech's claims that almost 10 percent of those he tested ``seroconverted,'' meaning traces of the disease were erased from their blood, as well as by Kenya's announcement in July that the drug would be widely available by mid-August. ``Saying seroconversion is just another way of saying they have got a cure,'' said Joe Muriuki, 32, who has been on Kemron since December. He said that within two weeks of taking Kemron, he felt better and began gaining weight. His mouth sores, swollen glands, diarrhea, fevers, itchy skin and sweating disappeared. However, Muriuki, who has been an adviser at a clinic for sexually transmitted diseases since learning he had AIDS three years ago, said publicity about Kemron led people to believe it would prevent and cure AIDS. And that has led to a relapse into unsafe sexual behavior, he said. He also cited frustration over the drug's continued inavailability. Although 200,000 tablets were imported for the July announcement, most of them remain with the local marketing agent due to a licensing dispute. The government's chief pharmacist says the agent, Innovative Therapeutics Ltd., cannot sell the drug unless 51 percent gh syrup. She called a friend from Alcoholics Anonymous for help, but she heard nothing of what her friend said. ``All I could think was there were two more bottles of Robitussin in the cupboard,'' she said. Rose told her friend she was all right and hung up. Rose drank the remaining bottles. Another friend took her to the hospital. The doctors said she was depressed. They suggested 30-day outpatient treatment. They gave her pills. The pills didn't work, Rose said. ``A week later I got into a fight with my husband and cut my wrists,'' she said. The doctors gave her more anti-depressants. ``I took all of them and I felt relief for the first time - and went to bed to die,'' Rose said. Her friend from AA found her and called 911. She was unconscious and in convulsions. She was in intensive care for four days. Rose, a pseudonym she chose to protect her identity, is a 34-year-old executive whose third suicide attempt in as many months nearly succeeded. She came from the hospital to Springbrook Institute in Newberg. After 16 days in residential treatment, her outlook changed. ``I truly felt that God intervened for me,'' said Rose, now living as an outpatient in a nearby apartment. ``I have my spark back. I have hope. I have healthy fear, which will keep me motivated. I care about other people and myself. I've made a good start.'' This is her second attempt at recovery. Her failure the first time took her self-esteem to new lows. ``Coming here was real scary,'' she said. ``I felt defeated. I couldn't even die.'' Rose said she started drinking when she was 12, but didn't admit she had a problem until she was in her mid-20s. She had a good job, a house, a nice car. She had a supportive boss and good friends. ``Those last two years, I didn't have a crisis - and I was miserable,'' she said. She had some blackouts and began to recognize a pattern. ``We would go out for `happy hour' and have a few drinks,'' she said. ``I don't know what they would do, but I would get a bottle and go home.'' She knew she needed something. ``I went back to church. I contacted family,'' she said. ``I even joined a softball team.''

DOC.HEAD: Study: Golf May Help Blood Cholesterol
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Sportsmedicine in 3rd graf is cq. A version on sports wires as BC-Lifestyle Sports.
DOC.TEXT: If your best driving performance is in the golf cart, you may be playing the game wrong: Two researchers say you could do your circulatory system more good if you make the trip on foot. Walking a course regularly helps lower cholesterol levels, and therefore may decrease the risk of heart disease, the experts concluded. ``We need to reassess the value of this sport,'' said the report in the journal The Physician and Sportsmedicine. Researchers Edward A. Palank and Ernest H. Hargreaves Jr. of the New Hampshire Heart Institute in Manchester looked at 28 average but enthusiastic male golfers ages 48 to 80. They had not exercised the previous four months. In the study, the golfers walked about 14 miles a week by playing an 18-hole course an average of three times a week from mid-May to mid-September of 1989 - with a pullcart or carrying a light bag. The golfers lowered their total cholesterol by an average of 17 milligrams per deciliter of blood, the study said. The low-density lipoprotein fraction of their cholesterol, the so-called ``bad'' cholesterol associated with higher risk of heart disease, fell by an average of 13.2 milligrams, it said. Both are ``very significant'' decreases, the report said. However, the level of high-density lipoprotein - so-called ``good cholesterol,'' associated with a lower risk of heart disease, did not change significantly, the report said. That's because a golfer's stops to hit the ball get in the way of his workout, said Palank, a cardiologist. It takes a sustained aerobic workout to improve HDL, he said in an interview. Just the same, the study demonstrates the sport has health value. ``If you play golf and you walk, and you take advantage of a sport you like, you can improve your (heart disease) risk ratio,'' he said. ``The thing that's discouraging is that they've taken a very enjoyable sport that was designed to walk, and taken out some of the enjoyment and taken away some of the positive medical benefit.'' Palank blamed economics, saying courses make more money by shuttling more golfers through on carts. Thirty-three percent of members-only courses, 29 percent of daily fee courses and 11 percent of public courses require carts some or all of the time, according to the National Golf Foundation in Florida. The majority of courses require no carts and may not even have them, said Andrew M. Snook, a research associate with the non-profit organization. In a separate survey, done in 1988, golfers said they used a cart about a third of the time they played, Snook said. However, walking may strengthen a golfers' game by reducing the effects of fatigue, said Rob Mottram, a physical therapist with Centinela Hospital, Inglewood, Calif. Mottram staffs a fitness center, including weight machines, treadmlls and ultrasound therapeutic equipment, which travels with professional golf tours.

DOC.HEAD: Researcher Says Sugar Before Lunch Won't Spoil Kids' Appetites
DOC.TEXT: Drinking a sugary drink before lunch may not be as bad for children as parents assume, a researcher says. In a recent study, children ate less food for lunch if they drank a sugared drink, but selected fewer cookies and soft drinks and more cold cuts, bread and other foods than children who did not have sugar beforehand. ``The study shows there's not an unlimited appetite for sugar. The body becomes satisfied,'' said Harvey Anderson, chairman of the nutrition department at the University of Toronto School of Medicine. ``The more calories the children ate before lunch, the less calories they ate at lunch,'' even though they were allowed to eat as much as they wanted, said Anderson, who presented the study at a symposium on nutrition research last month in Toronto. The research has yet to be published. It is more important to consider what a child eats over the course of a whole day than for one meal, said Dr. Ronald Kleinman of Massachusetts General Hospital, who is chairman of the committee on nutrition for the American Academy of Pediatrics. ``There's not very much information about whether having a snack during the day, an hour or two before a meal, really makes a difference in what somebody eats in their meal,'' said Kleinman, who said he was not familiar with Anderson's study. There is a need, however, for research into children's eating patterns, he said. Some studies have shown benefits of afternoon snacks for children who play sports. Several also have been conducted on the effects of breakfast on performance in schools, with contradictory results, Kleinman said. Anderson and his colleagues studied normal-weight children, 10 boys and 10 girls, ages 9 and 10. At 11:30 a.m, the children were given either 8 ounces of unsweetened Kool-Aid, or the drink sweetened with 1.5 ounces or 3 ounces of sugar. Each child was his or her own control in the research, depending on which drink was given on a particular day. ``We then sent the kids to `heaven' at 12 noon by giving them a choice of all the cookies they could eat, all the pop, cake. We also gave them bread, cold cuts, fruit and milk - the range of foods, but all in excess,'' Anderson said. Children who had the sugared drink ate almost no sweets at lunch, he said. Those who had the drink without sugar chose a quarter of their lunch calories from cookies and soft drinks, Anderson said. The children ate about 900 calories, including any calories in the soft drink, Anderson said. The researchers wanted to know whether children respond to calories in sugar, a simple carbohydrate. Anderson said there is no published research on whether the same results would be achieved by a complex carbohydrate, such as a banana. Anderson hopes to look at whether children who have a tendency toward obesity also reach a satiation point with sugar. ``Are they responding in the same way physiologically in terms of sugar load?'' Anderson said he is not recommending that parents give children sugar before meals, ``though it is encouraging for parents that a little sugar will do no harm'' to normal children. In addition to eating and drinking, the children in Anderson's study played during the research. They were not told what was being studied. Anderson said the children did not react against drinking unsweetened Kool-Aid. ``They'd just drink it down quickly - they wanted to get on and play,'' he said.

DOC.TEXT: Oil prices shot up nearly $3 per barrel after British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher warned that war could be near in the Persian Gulf. The surge Wednesday gained momentum when a confidante of Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak said the countdown for confrontation had begun, resurrecting anxiety among oil traders that the flow of petroleum supplies would face disruptions. Traders were also responding to reports that Secretary of State James A. Baker III had given Iraqi President Saddam Hussein an ultimatum for vacating Kuwait, though Baker denied the reports. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - The new heads of Infotechnology Inc., the troubled parent of Financial News Network and United Press International, say they would recommend selling the companies' principal operations. Alan J. Hirschfield and Allan R. Tessler, appointed co-chief executives in a management shakeup on Oct. 24, said Wednesday they have retained the investment banking firm Wertheim Schroder & Co. for the negotiations and hope to conclude sales contracts by the end of the year. United Press International had already said it was seeking a buyer, but said it would have to liquidate if members of the Wire Service Guild reject its proposal to cut wages by 35 percent for 90 days. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - The Food and Drug Administration has banned 223 ingredients in over-the-counter drugs, saying manufacturers had offered no proof they were effective for problems they were supposed to treat. The ingredients ranged from pine tar in dandruff fighters through dehydrated garlic in digestive aids to aspirin in medications for external use, it was announced Wednesday. The FDA did not ban the ingredients entirely, just in certain uses. For example, aspirin may still be used in products for pain relief taken internally, because it has been shown to be effective pain reliever. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - The nation's farm population dipped again last year, but more people than ever were living in small towns, distant suburbs and the rest of rural America, the government reported. Farm people declined by 150,000 to an estimated 4,801,000 in 1989, a decrease described by Wednesday's report as ``not a statistically significant difference'' from 1988. The new estimate put the farm population at 1.9 percent of the U.S. total of more than 248.2 million people, the smallest share on record. --- NEW YORK (AP) - CBS Inc. shares edged higher amid speculation over whether executors of William S. Paley's estate will decide to sell the late CBS Inc. chairman's 8 percent stake in the media company. But CBS executives and media analysts Wednesday said even if the stock were sold, chances were slim it could lead to an unfriendly bid for control of the company, a frequent subject of takeover rumors. The Wall Street Journal reported a sale of the stock seems likely, partly because the Paley estate, valued at about $500 million, must raise $190 million to cover tax obligations. --- PUEBLO, Colo. (AP) - CF&I Steel Corp. and nine subsidiaries filed petitions for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code. Frank Yaklich Jr., president and chief executive officer, Wednesday said the company will continue to operate during reorganization. CF&I, baseed in Pueblo, is a major producer of steel products for energy, transportation and agricultural markets. --- SEATTLE (AP) - A Seattle-based seafood company has sued Exxon Corp. in Washington state courts for loss of business stemming from the 11 million gallon oil spill in Alaska's Prince William Sound. The suit also names Exxon Shipping Co. and seeks an unspecified amount of damages due to the spill caused when the tanker Exxon Valdez hit a reef on March 24, 1989. --- BEIJING (AP) - Premier Li Peng has indicated willingness to give foreign companies a role in developing China's most-promising oilfield, so far closed to foreign involvement. The official Xinhua News Agency said Wednesday Li made the statement during a meeting with the president of Japan's Mitsubishi Corp., Shinroku Morohashi. Morohashi specifically mentioned the Tarim Basin in northwestern China's Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region, saying Mitsubishi ``is ready to participate'' in oil development there, Xinhua said. --- BRUSSELS, Belgium (AP) - The European Commission says it had cleared the proposed alliance between the automobile companies Volvo of Sweden and Renault of France. The Commission said Wednesday the merger between Volvo and Renault in markets for cars, trucks, and buses, would not create or strengthen a dominant position in any of the markets. It said that the linkup in trucks and buses would not impede competition in the European Community or in any substantial part of it. In cars, the alliance did not fall under the Commission's merger powers, it said. ---

The stock market suffered a sharp setback Wednesday in selling attributed to rising oil prices and fears of war in the Middle East. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials tumbled 44.31 to 2,440.84. Bonds fell sharply. The dollar ended moderately lower against most currencies in volatile trading, bouncing off early-day lows with a buying spurt prompted by Middle East saber-rattling. Gold prices were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: United's Bid to Fly into Heathrow Faces Stiff Resistance
Graphic
DOC.TEXT: Another Battle of Britain is raging but it's not about warplane dominance over the skies. This fight concerns jetliner space on the ground. United Airlines' bid to fly into Heathrow, announced last month, is expected to intensify the struggle for landing spots at one of the world's busiest airports. The competition over which airlines can fly to Heathrow is likely to be raised between the U.S. and British governments, which are currently reviewing their air services agreement, the British Department of Transport said. When United announced Oct. 23 it had purchased most of Pan American World Airways' British air routes for $400 million, the buyer asserted Pan Am's slot at Heathrow was part of the deal. But since 1977, the British government has barred any new airline from entering crowded Heathrow, and might force United to fly into Gatwick and other British airports. American Airlines was told to go to Gatwick when it bought Trans World Airlines' Chicago-Heathrow route in a $195 million deal last year. ``We certainly don't think they (United) have the right to operate out of Heathrow,'' said Lizann Peppard, an American Airlines spokeswoman in London. American has indicated an interest in buying the Pan Am routes at a higher price than United is paying, but Pan Am and United say their deal is sealed. Many international and domestic airlines want slots at Heathrow, which is 20 miles west of London and served by the London subway system. Gatwick, 27 miles south of London, links up with the British Rail train network. Heathrow has more shops, restaurants and other amenities, and offers far more connecting flights than Gatwick, primarily a center for charter flights. British Midland Airways, Britain's second largest airline after British Airways, wants more Heathrow slots and is lobbying for a Heathrow expansion. Virgin Atlantic Airways, which operates out of Gatwick, also wants to get into Heathrow. ``We certainly have ambitions ourselves to get into Heathrow and it would obviously be unacceptable for U.S. carrier flying into Heathrow and ourselves not,'' said Ed Hullah, Virgin's director for commercial operations. But Lawrence Nagin, senior vice president for United Airlines, said U.S.-British air services agreement allows successors to the two specified American carriers operating out of Heathrow - Pan Am and TWA - to assume their rights. United has filed with the U.S. Department of Transportation asking for approval of transfer of rights. It has asked for an expedited review, and a decision by Dec. 31. ``We're optimistic that the United States government will be successful to get the U.K. government to approve United Airlines' operations in Heathrow,'' Nagin said in a telephone interview from Chicago. United wants to start operating the Pan Am routes in the spring. They are from New York, Washington, San Francisco, Los Angeles, and Seattle. Pan Am is retaining London routes from Miami and Detroit but is moving those flights to Gatwick. As a result of the United controversy, Britain's Department of Transportation has asked the Civil Aviation Authority to accelerate an existing review of the ``traffic distribution rules'' governing the allocation of landing slots at Heathrow and Gatwick and to report to the department early in the new year rather than in March. The rules, separate from the U.S.-British air treaty, are intended to relieve Heathrow congestion and spur growth at Gatwick. The department must wait to hear from the aviation authority ``before we can decide how to deal with the (United) application,'' said a department official interviewed on condition of anonymity. U.S. and British government officials already had agreed to meet sometime this month for a second round of air services liberalization talks, the official said, and it seemed likely the United issue would be raised. Talks began more than a year ago on a new British-U.S. air services agreement to replace the existing treaty reahed in the mid-1970s. About 42 million passengers, 82 percent of them international, passed through Heathrow last year, making it one of the world's busiest air terminals. Gatwick handled 21.2 million. Heathrow is served by 70 airlines although British Airways dominates.

DOC.HEAD: Increases Miami Presence, Pilots May Have More Cash for Shuttle
With PM-Britain-Heathrow Battle
DOC.TEXT: Pan Am Corp., which has agreed to sell some of its key London routes, will increase service in Miami with more flights to Latin America. Chairman Thomas G. Plaskett said Wednesday an increased number of departures out of Miami and into Latin America by Pan American World Airways and Pan Am Express is part of an overall strategy for the airline and fits in with plans unveiled in October to sell important U.S-London routes to UAL Corp. for $400 million. Pan Am agreed to sell those coveted London routes to UAL, which will join Pan Am in a marketing strategy intended to bolster Pan Am's Latin American routes. The two airlines will coordinate some flights in an effort to feed each other passengers. Pan Am said Wednesday it would be increasing daily flights out of Miami during the winter season by 70 percent, from 63 last year to 107 this year. Included in the expansion will be more nonstops from Miami to Sao Paulo, Brazil, and new flights between Miami and Recife, Brazil. Pan Am also will operate new services from Miami to Managua, Nicaragua; San Salvador, El Salvador; Belize City, Belize; and San Pedro Sula, Honduras. Service to other destinations in Latin America and the United States will become more frequent. ``The broad-based cooperative agreement that we have signed with United Airlines will allow us to focus even more of our attention on our Florida and Latin American services,'' Plaskett said in a statement. Analysts viewed the deal with UAL as a desperate cash-raising attempt by Pan Am, which has lost money for years and like other airlines has been hit hard by rising fuel costs. AMR Corp., parent of American Airlines, called the $400 million price too low and said it would pay in excess of $500 million for the London routes. Plaskett has dismissed that offer, saying the deal with United involves more than just the sale of the trans-Atlantic routes.

DOC.HEAD: As Economy Slumps, City Fears Exodus of Wall Street Firms
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report
DOC.TEXT: Would Wall Street's powerful investment banks have the same clout if the address on their stationery were Jersey City, N.J., or Stamford, Conn.? Municipal, political and business forces are circling their wagons to head off major departures from the city where stocks first were traded nearly 200 years ago. The bureaucrats won a battle Tuesday when four commodity exchanges decided to stay in lower Manhattan rather than cross the Hudson River to New Jersey, swayed by a $145 million incentives package that includes free space. Now officials are turning their sights to Morgan Stanley & Co., a top-line investment bank with more than 4,000 employees, which is considering moving about an hour north to Stamford when the firm's leases expire in 1998. ``Do they want to be all alone in a glass jungle in Stamford?'' said Harold Holzer, a spokesman for Vincent Tese, the state's director of economic development, who helped negotiate the deal to keep the commodity exchanges. ``We're going to tell them it's going to hurt their competitive position,'' Holzer said Wednesday. ``It's ot the world business center.'' Other firms have relocated trading-related support facilities to cheaper space off Manhattan island, but Morgan would be the first investment house to move its headquarters outside the city. In fact, executives couldn't name a major New York law firm, brokerage house or consulting firm that has fled the nation's financial hub. But during a prolonged securities industry recession, in a city facing a $2 billion budget deficit, with layoffs rising, there's a whiff of panic in the air over a possible domino effect of departures. The New York City Partnership, a group of business and civic leaders, sponsored a breakfast for Morgan on Tuesday. Stamford was bashed and pressure was applied by luminaries such as New York Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Cardinal John O'Connor and former Secretary of State Cyrus Vance. ``What great ideas of civilization were ever spawned in the suburbs?'' prominent attorney Arthur Liman asked. Said Moynihan: ``We live in a brutal capitalist system and if you leave New York you die.'' Stamford is undertaking its own campaign. The city of 105,000 paid for a 16-page advertising insert in The Wall Street Journal on Monday touting its virtues - easy access to New York, suburban living, good schools, 3 million square feet of empty office space, no wage taxes, yacht marinas. ``We don't want to see New York fail but, that said, you can't have it all,'' said David E. Anderson, president of The Stamford Partnership. ``We can balance and contrast and have certain strengths that New York can never have.'' To be sure, not all Wall Street firms are considering abandoning New York, but staying can be costly. Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. and Merrill Lynch & Co., for example, moved into extravagant offices during the roaring mid-1980s, but have been forced to lay off thousands as business has declined. Several major firms have moved or plan to move back-office operations outside Manhattan, including Merrill, PaineWebber Inc. and Donaldson Lufkin & Jenrette Inc. - all to New Jersey. First Boston Inc. has hired a major real estate firm to investigate its options when leases expire at the end of 1993. Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. recently hired an executive who engineered PaineWebber's New Jersey move; its back-office leases expire in 1994. Cost is the top consideration. Firms also cite negative quality of life issues in Manhattan such as education, crime, smelly subways and homelessness. ``People will give you a list of a lot of items, but the main thing that's driving them out of the city is economics,'' said John Powers, senior managing director of Edward S. Gordon Co., a major real estate firm. Real estate taxes in a first-class Manhattan building can hit $9 per square foot, compared with about $1.50 in the suburbs. On top of that, commercial tenants pay a 6 percent occupancy tax based on gross rent. Operating costs are $1 to $1.50 per square foot higher in New York than in the outer lands, real estate executives said, while construction costs range from 15 percent to 30 percent higher. ``If it were just money New York City would lose every time,'' said Lee Silberstein, vice president of the New York City Public Development Corp. ``But there is a certain cache to doing business in New York and there is a premium price that firms will pay to stay here.'' Grim times have eaten revenue for the city and state since the 1987 stock market crash, but officials say they won't negotiate out of desperation. Despite the lucrative incentives for the commodity exchanges, the city retains a growing industry of 11,700 workers that generates $1.3 billion a year.

DOC.HEAD: Aetna to Drop Some Policies in Two States
DOC.TEXT: Aetna Life & Casualty Co. is dropping personal auto and homeowners' insurance in New Mexico and Idaho, saying the business is unprofitable with little hope for much improvement. Aetna stopped selling new auto and homeowners' policies in New Mexico and Idaho Nov. 2. Starting in February, the company will not renew policies in New Mexico; in March it will not renew them in Idaho. The decision is the latest move by Aetna to improve dreary financial results in personal insurance lines nationwide. The Hartford-based insurance giant had already dedicated itself to writing less personal auto insurance. Aetna is not a major player in personal lines in either state. The company's decision will affect 10,265 existing policies in New Mexico - 5,603 auto and 4,662 homeowners' - which is about 1.5 percent of the market, said Aetna spokesman Sal Foti. In Idaho, it said 4,140 policies will be affected - 1,802 auto and 2,338 homeowners. Idaho law will require Aetna to keep insuring customers who cannot find coverage elsewhere, Foti said. Withdrawing from the business ``will allow us to devote our resources to other states where the opportunity for profitable results is better,'' Foti said. Aetna has also stopped writing new personal auto policies in Rhode Island, and is challenging laws in Massachusetts that make it very expensive for the company to withdraw from auto insurance there.

DOC.HEAD: CBOT Chairman Nominated for Another Term
DOC.TEXT: William F. O'Connor, the incumbent chairman of the Chicago Board of Trade, has been nominated to seek re-election on Dec. 12. The exchange announced Wednesday that a BOT committee made the nomination. Former Vice Chairman Patrick Arbor has said he also will run for the two-year term. O'Connor, who heads the trading firm O'Connor & Co., was named chairman of the world's largest commodities exchange in August when Karsten Mahlmann resigned because of financial problems at his firm, Stotler Group Inc. One issue dividing the candidates is how to expand the Board of Trade's trading space. Arbor, an exchange director, has suggested exploring a merger with the rival Chicago Mercantile Exchange. O'Connor has taken a more conservative approach, but he says he would consider sharing some of the Merc's trading space.

DOC.HEAD: Cairns Group Says EC Farm Proposal Unacceptable
DOC.TEXT: A 14-nation bloc of farm exporting countries said Thursday that world trade talks may collapse unless the European Community changes its proposal on cutting agriculture subsidies. ``A negotiation which showed no movement away from the current European Community offer would be totally unacceptable,'' said Neal Blewett, chairman of the Cairns Group, which includes such large farm exporters as Australia, Argentina and Canada. Blewett, Australia's foreign trade minister, called the EC proposal for a 30 percent cut in agricultural subsidies over 10 years ``very disappointing.'' He said it has thrown talks to bring down trade barriers worldwide into ``deep trouble.'' But said his group was delaying a possible bid to postpone the final round of the world trade talks, due to be held here next month. The United States has also criticized the EC's proposed 30 percent cut in farm subsidies, calling it ``nadequate.'' ``If they (the EC) come to the table with the attitude that this is our final offer, `take it or leave it,' then that is not acceptable,'' Assistant U.S. Trade Representative Myles Frechette said Wednesday in Washington. Cairns Group officials met Thursday with top EC trade officials to discuss their concerns about the EC farm proposal and the imperiled state of the Uruguay Round of trade talks. They said they welcomed assurances from the top EC trade official, Frans Andriessen, that the Community proposal was an opening position, not a final offer. But they said they worried that did not allow negotiators much room to offer deeper cuts. On Tuesday, the EC became the last major participant in the Uruguay Round of trade talks to submit a proposal on agriculture. The EC proposed a 30 percent cut in subsidies for farmers over 10 years, beginning in 1986. Some cuts have already been made. The EC proposal does not extend to export subsidies. The Cairns Group and the United States, want to cut subsidies to farmers by as much as 75 percent along with a virtual elimination of exporters subsidies. The gap between the EC and its main trade partners threatens to combine with other stumbling blocs in the talks to torpedo the Uruguay Round, a four-year effort of more than 100 nations to bring down global trade barriers. ``Unless there is willingness (by the EC) to move from that position, then there is no prospect of success in the agriculture negotiations,'' Blewett told reporters. Agriculture is one of 15 trade sectors under discussion in the Uruguay Round, which also includes clothing, telecommunications and services such as banking. But Cairns Group and U.S. officials maintain agriculture is the key to a settlement in other areas. Cairns Group officials said they will wait two weeks before deciding whether to advocate delaying a final set of Uruguay Round meetings, scheduled for early next month. Members of the Cairns Group, named for the Australian city where it held its first meeting in 1986, are: Argentina, Australia, Brazil, Canada, Chile, Colombia, Fiji, Hungary, Indonesia, Malaysia, New Zealand, the Philippines, Thailand and Uruguay.

DOC.HEAD: Optical Systems Company To Trim 90 Jobs
DOC.TEXT: Hughes Danbury Optical Systems Inc., citing federal budget cuts, says it will eliminate about 90 jobs early next month, trimming its 920-person work force by about 10 percent. The layoffs of salaried workers likely will account for most of the cutback, but some jobs will be cut through attrition, company spokesman Tom Arconti said Wednesday. Arconti said the company will attempt to transfer some of those dismissed to jobs in other business units of its parent company, the Los Angeles-based Hughes Aircraft division of General Motors Corp. Those units are in California and elsewhere around the nation, he said. Hughes Danbury Optical Systems formerly was part of Perkin Elmer Corp. It is best known as the prime contractor to the National Aeronautics and Space Administration on the problem-plagued Hubble Space Telescope. Arconti said the layoffs planned for early December are unrelated to the telescope's problems, which were traced to measuring instruments used to create its mirrors. Instead, he said the move stemmed from leaner NASA and Department of Defense budgets, which provide much of the funding for the company's programs. ``We're finding a lot of our programs being stretched out and facing reduced funding,'' Arconti said.

DOC.HEAD: EC Commission Drops Phone Monopoly Charges Against Ireland
DOC.TEXT: The European Community's Executive Commission said Thursday it had dropped charges alleging that Ireland violated the community's law by allowing a public telephone monopoly to continue in the country. In a statement, the Commission said that since July the Irish government has abolished Telecom Eirann's monopoly of the market. Private competitors can now compete ``on an equal footing,'' it said. But the Commission said it would continue to monitor the telecommunications markets in other European Community countries. It said a similar infringement proceeding against Denmark had been dropped, but one against Belgium was still being processed. In May 1988, the Commission ordered member states to withdraw the exclusive rights enjoyed by public telephone companies in marketing equipment.

DOC.HEAD: Computer Supplier Files Suit Against Microsoft Over Licensing Fee
DOC.TEXT: Z-Nix Co., a personal computer supplier, filed a $4.5 million lawsuit against software giant Microsoft Corp. alleging restraint of trade and breach of contract. The suit, filed Wednesday in U.S. District Court, says Microsoft agreed to license its popular Windows software to Z-Nix for $27.50 a copy. Microsoft allegedly sought to double the fee when Z-Nix wanted to pair Windows with a device it produces that points out material on computer screens, Z-Nix says. The fee increase effectively priced the Z-Nix product out of the market, Z-Nix contends. ``It's time for us to stand up to Microsoft's unfair trade practices and stop the slow death of innovation in the industry,'' said Thomas T. Chan, attorney for Z-Nix. A spokesman for Microsoft said the Redmond, Wash.-based firm had no comment Wednesday on the suit. Microsoft owns one of the most popular personal computer operating systems, MS-DOS. Windows, released earlier this year, is a popular software program that doubles as an operating system. It has forced other software publishers to quickly devise programs that work with it.

The stock market was little changed today, levelling off after Wednesday's broad decline. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 6.19 to 2,434.65 in the first half hour of trading. Gainers held a slight edge on losers in the early tally of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 451 up, 431 down and 502 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 16.82 million shares as of 10 a.m. on Wall Street. Interest rates held steady in the government bond market pending the completion today of a three-day quarterly auction of Treasury securities. Analysts said investors remained hopeful that the Federal Reserve would take further steps before long to relax its credit policy. One assumed precondition for a more stimulative Fed policy is a reduction in inflationary pressures, especially in oil prices. A bit of encouragement on that score is expected Friday when the Labor Department reports on the producer price index of finished goods for October. Analysts are projecting an increase in the index of between 0.5 percent and 1.0 percent, down from 1.6 percent in September and 1.3 percent in August. Among actively traded blue chips, Exxon rose ] to 48|; Philip Morris was up [ at 48; General Electric dropped \ to 51}, and Boeing was down \ at 44\. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks slipped .17 to 167.30. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down .38 at 289.36. On Wednesday the Dow Jones industrial average tumbled 44.31 to 2,440.84. Declining issues outnumbered advances by about 5 to 2 on the NYSE, with 452 up, 1,117 down and 440 unchanged. Big Board volume totaled 149.13 million shares, against 141.13 million in the previous session.

DOC.HEAD: British Steel to Close Scottish Steelworks; 1,200 Jobs To Go
DOC.TEXT: British Steel announced Thursday it would close a Scottish steelworks early next year, resulting in the loss of 1,200 jobs in an area already hard-hit by the planned closure of another large British Steel plant. British Steel said it had decided reluctantly it could no longer support the losses at Clydesdale, which makes seamless steel tubes for the oil and gas industry. A company spokesman said an oversupply of seamless tubes had caused ``significant losses'' for the past six years at the two tube mills in the Strathclyde area. The mills, built in 1948 and 1956, had become obsolete. Together, they produce about a quarter of a million tons of seamless pipes every year, mainly used in bore holes. Earlier this year, British Steel announced plans to cut 800 jobs next spring at the Ravenscraig plant, also in Strathclyde. Ravenscraig is a hot strip mill. The company said Thursday the closures were unrelated. The company said it recognized the impact the closure decision would have on the community and promised to offer counselling services to retrain workers. British Steel added that the Clydesdale workers had known for some time that processes at the plant were obsolete and faced strong international competition. But Roy Evans, general secretary of the Iron and Steel Trades Confederation, said the decision shocked workers. Evans said he had been told Clydesdale was losing about $34 million a year and the mills were in bad shape. ``There has been a failure to invest in Clydesdale over the years because of the huge over-capacity of the seamless tube product,'' Evans said. ``We knew there were problems but the announcement of a complete closure has come as a shock.'' Strathclyde, in western Scotland, is the traditional commercial and industrial heartland of the country, containing nearly one-quarter of the total population.

DOC.HEAD: Government Proposes Sale Of State-Controlled Corporations
DOC.TEXT: The government has proposed legislation allowing for sale of 49 percent of state-controlled corporations to private interests. The bill, which is being submitted to Parliament for consideration, refers specifically to the Agricultural Bank of Greece, one of the nation's largest banks, and Olympic Airways, the national carrier, and its subsidiaries. The bill provides that shares would become available on the Athens Stock Exchange. Overstaffed public sector corporations have frequently been cited by the government as contributing to Greece's $100 billion public debt. The legislation also entitles the state to sell off the Bank of Crete, a former private bank that was nationalized after its owner and chairman was accused of embezzling about $210 million. It also compels companies to have minimum equity capital of $3.3 million to enter the stock exchange, abolishing a system whereby their shares were underwritten by banks for the first six months.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Turn Mixed Ahead Of Report
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices were mixed in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade in advance of a government report that was expected to project a larger soybean crop and a smaller corn crop than last month's report. The soybean market turned mostly lower after an opening rally that was based in part on rumors the Soviet Union is in the market for U.S. soybean meal. Similar rumors supported the soybean market yesterday. Corn was slightly lower while wheat futures were modestly higher, boosted by new sales of U.S. wheat to the Philippines. The sales confirmed this morning brought the total amount of U.S. wheat purchased this week by the Philippines to more than 500,000 metric tons. Market-watchers expected prices to move within narrow ranges today ahead of this afternoon's monthly Agriculture Department crop report. A survey of private analysts yielded average production projections of 1.84 billion bushels of soybeans compared with last month's USDA estimate of 1.82 billion, and 7.98 billions bushels of corn compared with last month's government projection of 8 billion. ``There's a real choppy attitude right now with rumors of export business, the USDA report and fear of war in the Middle East,'' said William Biedermann, research director with Allendale Inc., a commodities brokerage in Crystal Lake, Ill. In early trading, wheat futures were unchanged to { cent higher with the contract for delivery in December at $2.65} a bushel; corn was unchanged to { cent lower with December at $2.29} a bushel; oats were unchanged to { cent lower with December at $1.21 a bushel; and soybeans were 1 cent lower to 1{ cents higher with November at $5.82} a bushel. Livestock futures were mostly lower and pork bellies were mostly higher in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle were .10 cent lower to .03 cent higher with December at 77.50 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .05 cent to .25 cent lower with November at 87.75 cents a pound; hogs were .55 cent lower to .05 cent higher with December at 53.17 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .17 cent lower to .90 cent higher with February at 69.80 cents a pound. Livestock futures settled narrowly mixed on Thursday. Pork bellies rose sharply.

The stock market was mixed today, attracting some tentative support after Wednesday's broad loss. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, down 44.31 points Wednesday, dropped another 8.41 to 2,432.43 by noontime on Wall Street. But gainers held a slight edge on losers in the overall tally of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 649 up, 623 down and 530 unchanged. Interest rates held steady in the government bond market pending the completion today of a three-day quarterly auction of Treasury securities. Analysts said investors remained hopeful that the Federal Reserve would take further steps before long to relax its credit policy. One assumed precondition for a more stimulative Fed policy is a reduction in inflationary pressures, especially in oil prices. A bit of encouragement on that score is expected Friday when the Labor Department reports on the producer price index of finished goods for October. Analysts are projecting an increase in the index of between 0.5 percent and 1.0 percent, down from 1.6 percent in September and 1.3 percent in August. NCR jumped 8[ to 56[ and American Telephone & Telegraph dropped { to 33[. The Wall Street Journal reported that the two companies were talking about combining their computer operations. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks gained .12 to 167.59. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down .50 at 289.24. Volume on the Big Board came to 67.25 million shares at noontime, up from 63.71 million at the same point Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Christmas Outlook Worsens Amid Disappointing October Sales Reports
DOC.TEXT: The outlook for the Christmas shopping season worsened today as the nation's biggest retailers reported dismal sales results for the month of October. Several companies, including J.C. Penney Co. Inc., May Department Stores Co. and Limited Inc., reported their sales dropped from year-earlier levels. The results, coming on the heels of poor showings in August and September, ``reflected a recessionary psychology'' among consumers, said Jeffrey Feiner, a retail industry analyst with Merrill Lynch & Co. ``We expect the weakness will continue,'' he said. Jeffrey Edelman, an analyst with Barclays de Zoete Wedd Inc., was equally downbeat, predicting, ``We're undoubtedly going to see a continued winding down of the consumer'' into the Christmas season. Consumers have put spending for discretionary items - clothing, furniture and other extras - on hold the past few months because of uncertainty over the economy and the fear of war in the Middle East. They also have less money to spend because they are paying more money for gasoline and heating oil. Analysts said consumers will be buying fewer and cheaper gifts this year, shopping carefully and looking for bargains. With merchandise not moving out of the stores the last few months, the bargains are already there as retailers take markdowns in hopes of reducing inventories. A poor Christmas is bad news for the economy, since two-thirds of the gross national product is generated from consumer spending. A bad season could also be devastating for retailers, who depend on holiday shopping for about half their annual sales and profits. One of the hardest hit last month was Penney, which said its sales at stores open at least a year fell 6.3 percent from October 1989, while overall sales dropped 4.9 percent. Analysts believe sales from stores open at least a year - also known as same-store or comparable store sales - provide a more accurate assessment of a retailer's performance than overall sales do. New stores tend to have extraordinarily strong sales that can skew a retailer's results. Limited, the nation's largest specialty apparel retailer, reported its comparable store sales dropped 1 percent as overall sales rose 13 percent. Apparel stores were also affected by continuing warm weather in some parts of the country. May, the parent of big department store chains including Lord & Taylor, Hecht's, Filene's and Foley's, said comparable store sales dropped 4.4 percent, while overall sales edged up 1.1 percent. Sears, Roebuck and Co., the country's largest retailer, said comparable store sales fell 0.4 percent last month, while overall sales dropped 1.2 percent. But Wal-Mart Stores Inc. continued to outperform the rest of the retail industry, reporting comparable store sales rose 10 percent while overall sales rose 25 percent. Dayton Hudson Corp. said comparable store sales rose 4.1 percent, while overall sales picked up 16.7 percent. The results announced today differ from the monthly retail sales report from the government. The Commerce Department includes sales from supermarkets, restaurants and car dealerships in its figures.

DOC.HEAD: Nissan Recalls Vans
DOC.TEXT: Nissan Motor Corp. on Thursday recalled about 33,000 1987-1990 model Nissan Vans because of a potential power steering problem which could result in an engine fire. The company said it was aware of one slight injury stemming from the problem. The company said a power steering hose may deteriorate because of engine heat. Fluid then could leak onto the exhaust manifold, causing a fire. Nissan said it would notify owners and perform repairs for free.

DOC.HEAD: Jaguar, Rover Workers Accept Double-Digit Pay Offers
DOC.TEXT: Employees of Jaguar and Rover Group have voted to accept new contracts that include double-digit pay increases in the first year, the companies confirmed Thursday. Rover Group's 31,000 hourly workers approved their new contract by nearly 5-to-1. It gives them an 11 percent raise this year and a 7.5 percent raise in November 1991. Information on Rover's current pay rates was not immediately available. At Jaguar, 56 percent of the 9,000-member work force voted in favor of a two-year deal that raises pay 12.5 percent this year and either 7 percent or the rate of inflation next year, whichever is greater. Jaguar, which was acquired by Ford last year, said average wages now are 232 pounds, or $460, for a 39-hour work week.

DOC.HEAD: Moon, Tides Seen By Oil Analysts As Keys To Invasion Date
DOC.TEXT: Some of the investment advisers who earn a living touting their picks on stocks and futures deals are now trying their luck at handicapping the date war might break out in the Persian Gulf. For example, anytime after midnight between Nov. 12 and Nov. 22 is ``the best time for an attack to occur,'' say Peter Beutel and Thomas Blakeslee, oil analysts with Pegasus Econometric Group Inc., in Hoboken, N.J. They say their theories are rooted in military analyses coupled with the lunar cycle. During the ``window'' for war picked by Beutel and Blakeslee, the Kuwaiti tide will be high after midnight, which they say would help commandos get closer to a potential beachhead, and the moon phase will keep the sky dark, making it easier to storm the desert. After weeks in which financial markets were rocked by news and rumors from the Gulf standoff, feelings that war was inevitable perhaps inevitably led some experts to making picks on the startup date. The picks have been gushing through the investing community, with varying amounts of credibility. The Pegasus analysts, who offer advice on oil trading at the New York Mercantile Exchange, have gone so far as to put their predictions in writing. They call Nov. 12-22 ``a time to play any short positions extremely closely. If there is any military action, expect the U.S. to lead with its strong aerial suit.'' They emphasize they're not predicting war, and don't want to convey the impression that there's a sure-fire profiteering opportunity. They are merely saying when and how they think war would be most likely. Other wartime picks are not being made as boldly, and some analysts say all of the guesswork is crazy, but they are cropping up by the hundreds. Many analysts picked the days after the elections on Tuesday, with some taking coming holidays into account. ``Another theory one hears about is the weather factor,'' said Ann-Louise Hittle, a senior oil analyst with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. who emphasizes she is neither making nor touting any picks for a likely day that the war can begin. ``There's a cloudy season that starts up, an overcast season in February, that would make it difficult to stage an air strike,'' Hittle said. One stock market analyst has heard numerous Wall Streeters picking precise days for the attack, say, this coming Sunday. ``If I talk to 47 people, I get 47 opinions,'' said Sara Cerato of Nomura Securities International Inc. ``Each of these opinions seems to be an excuse not to get into the (stock) market right now. In the past, in a bull market, it paid to buy the market dips. Now, it doesn't seem to be working. The war seems to be the latest excuse'' to stay out. Early in the week, some oil traders were picking invasion days between Wednesday, which came and went with no war, and Friday. A Las Vegas oddsmaker said it would be possible to handicap the outset of war, just as people handicap anything else from football games to movies that might win an Oscar. But don't count on any Vegas sports books getting involved in war speculation. It's only legal for them to set odds on sporting events. Other oddsmaking is done only for promotional and entertainment purposes. ``We put out odds on whether George Steinbrenner would be banned from baseball,'' said oddsmaker Art Manteris of the Las Vegas Hilton. ``We put out odds on whether Pete Rose would be admitted to the Baseball Hall of Fame.'' Manteris said handicapping war would be ``a business matter, not an entertainment matter.''

DOC.HEAD: Production Goes Down This Week
DOC.TEXT: Domestic automakers were scheduled to produce 170,708 cars and light trucks this week, down from last week's 230,103, Ward's Automotive Reports said Thursday. This week's production is lower than the same week a year ago, in which 209,208 cars and light trucks were produced, the trade journal said. U.S. automakers were scheduled to make 109,006 cars this week, compared with 140,649 a week ago and 133,936 in the same week in 1989. Light truck production for the week was scheduled at 61,702, compared with last week's 89,454 and last year's 75,272. Canadian automakers were to build 22,620 cars this week, down from 26,177 a week ago and from last year's 26,147. Canadian light truck production was scheduled at 16,379, compared with 14,422 a week ago and 16,168 in the same week last year.

DOC.HEAD: Attorney General Rings Up No Sale on Trump Condo
DOC.TEXT: Developer Donald Trump, already under heavy pressure from his creditors, must prove he can cover the monthly costs of his Trump Palace condominium before any more units are sold, the state attorney general's office said Thursday. Trump must produce evidence he can cover the common charges, real estate taxes and other obligations on the 57-story building at 69th Street and Third Avenue, said Richard Barr, a spokesman for Attorney General Robert Abrams. ``We've requested that information, and we're waiting to receive it,'' Barr said. Abrams took the action after investors complained that Trump has withheld information about his troubled finances since they contracted to buy condominiums. State law requires condo developers to reveal ``material changes'' in their finances which could adversely affect people in the building. If Abrams finds Trump broke the law, the contracts could be invalidated. Sales contracts have been signed on 77 of the building's 283 condominiums. Trump, in an interview with The New York Times, said the depressed Manhattan real estate market has buyers ``looking for any method to break signed contracts.'' ``This is happening at virtually every new development,'' Trump said. ``And if the attorney general allows it, there will never be another dime invested by developers or banks in New York real estate.''

DOC.HEAD: The Hartford, Aetna to Withdraw From Insurance Markets
DOC.TEXT: ITT Hartford Insurance Group and Aetna Life & Casualty Co. said they plan to withdraw from various insurance markets in three states. Aetna is dropping personal auto and homeowners' insurance in New Mexico and Idaho, saying the business is unprofitable with little hope for much improvement. The Hartford, meanwhile, said it plans to withdraw from most of its personal auto insurance business in Michigan, after settling disputes with regulators and insurance agents in that state. The Hartford, which writes only 0.2 percent of Michigan's personal auto insurance, wants to withdraw because of financial losses and regulatory restraints. Eight insurance agencies sued the company, saying The Hartford would be violating their contracts by telling customers they could apply for insurance from another subsidiary that sells directly, not through agents. The agencies dropped the suit after the company agreed to make certain payments to agents, said John C. Colpean, an attorney assisting on the agents' suit. The Hartford plans to withdraw five of its companies - the ones that sell through independent agents - from personal auto insurance and ``umbrella'' liability in Michigan. Individuals buy umbrellas to protect themselves from the costs of lawsuits. However, the company plans to continue selling auto insurance through its Hartford Insurance Company of the Midwest, which insures many members of the American Association of Retired Persons without going through agents. Under an agreement with regulators, The Hartford will notify customers that if they cannot find insurance elsewhere, they can apply to The Hartford of the Midwest. The Hartford will stop renewing auto policies expiring in December. Aetna, which stopped selling new auto and homeowners' policies in New Mexico and Idaho Nov. 2, said it will not renew policies in New Mexico starting next February and in Idaho in March. The decision is the latest by Aetna to improve dreary financial results in personal insurance lines nationwide. The company had already dedicated itself to writing less personal auto insurance. Aetna is not a major player in personal lines in either state. The pullout will affect 10,265 existing policies in New Mexico, only 1.5 percent of the market, said Aetna spokesman Sal Foti. In Idaho, 4,140 policies will be affected. Idaho law will require Aetna to keep insuring customers who cannot find coverage elsewhere, Foti said. Withdrawing from the business ``will allow us to devote our resources to other states where the opportunity for profitable results is better,'' Foti said. Aetna has stopped writing new personal auto policies in Rhode Island, and is challenging laws in Massachusetts that make it expensive for the company to withdraw from auto insurance there.

DOC.HEAD: Low Bond Yields As Treasury Refinancing Concludes
DOC.TEXT: Yields on 30-year Treasury bonds fell in Thursday's auction to the lowest level in nine months as the government concluded its biggest-ever, $34.25 billion quarterly refunding. The average yield was 8.71 percent, down from 8.87 percent at the last auction on Aug. 9. It was the lowest rate since 30-year bonds averaged 8.50 percent on Feb. 8. The bonds will carry a coupon interest rate of 8} percent with each $10,000 in face value selling for $10,037.60. A total of $10.75 billion in bonds were sold out of bids totaling $22.08 billion. The Treasury on Thursday also sold $12 billion in 161-day cash management bills with an average discount rate of 7.08 percent. The discount rate understates the actual return to investors: 7.41 percent with a $10,000 bill selling for $9,683.40. The refunding included the sale of $12.6 billion in three-year notes on Tuesday and $11.1 billion in 10-year notes on Wednesday. This quarter's refunding is $2 billion larger than the previous record set last August. In announcing this week's auctions, Treasury Assistant Secretary Jay Powell said the offering would be used to refund $23.5 billion in privately-held notes maturing Nov. 15 and to raise about $10.73 billion in new cash. The notes and bonds are sold regularly during the large debt auctions held four times a year to replenish the government's coffers. In addition, the Treasury sold $9.8 billion each in three-month and six-month bills at its weekly bill auction on Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Yeutter Says New Farm Bill Will Put Production In Hands Of Farmers
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Grafs 1-7 for release after 3:45 p.m. EST. Grafs 8-17, Yeutter later, for release at 9 p.m. EST. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush soon will sign a farm bill that will help put decisions on what to produce in the hands of farmers, Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter said Thursday. ``We've just gotten a pretty good farm bill that gives farmers more flexibility to choose which crops they're going to plant so they can take advantage of opportunities as they see them, not as someone in Washington, D.C., sees them,'' he said. Yeutter's remarks were prepared for delivery to an annual convention of the Future Farmers of America in Kansas City, Mo. Copies of his talk were released here. The United States also is working in the Uruguay Round of talks under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade ``to open up world markets for America's farmers,'' he said. The ongoing negotiations are in Geneva, Switzerland, and are scheduled to conclude Dec. 31. ``If we're successful in doing so, we're counting on you to beat the pants off the competition, and all America is confident you will,'' Yeutter told the FFA delegates. Yeutter also said young people ``hold the hope and the future of our country'' by deciding what to do with their lives. Decisions about education, drugs, voting and other activities ``will determine not only your future but the course of things to come for America and perhaps for the world,'' he said. Yeutter later told the National Association of Farm Broadcasters that Bush ``believes, as I do, that it's a solid farm bill, one which will support the most efficient, productive farmers in the world: ours. Moreover, it's a far better bill than most American farmers believe.'' The so-called triple base feature of the farm bill gives farmers the option of planting what they choose on 15 percent of their base crop acreage, thus giving growers more leeway in making production and marketing decisions, he said. Yeutter said the GATT talks, which are aimed at liberalizing world trade, including agricultural products, are important to farmers for the same reason that the farm bill is important to them: income. ``In fact, it means a lot more than the farm bill does,'' he said. Yeutter said the farm bill is aimed at keeping U.S. commodities competitive in world markets. The GATT talks are directed at reducing export subsidies and other trade-distorting policies. In the end, he said, American farmers would have greater access to foreign markets. ``If we fail to gain access to these markets, or fail to be competitive in them, our agricultural sector will suffer tremendously,'' Yeutter said. For example, he added, in the 1980s the European Community went from being a net grain importer to a net grain exporter. In 1976, the community imported 30 million metric tons of wheat. In 1989, the bloc exported more than 20 million tons. ``In the process, the United States lost a tremendous European market,'' Yeutter said. ``Worse, this glut of European wheat flooded the world market, driving wheat prices - and American farm income - way, way down.'' Yeutter added: ``Why? Because of market-distorting agriculture supports and subsidies within the European Community. That's why we're pushing so hard to get meaningful agricultural reform from the other major trading nations, such as Japan and the European Community.''

The stock market headed higher today, attracting some modest support after Wednesday's broad loss. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, down 44.31 points Wednesday, rebounded 13.62 to 2,454.46 by 2 p.m. on Wall Street. Gainers outnumbered losers by about 8 to 5 in the overall tally of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 877 up, 555 down and 484 unchanged. Interest rates held steady in the government bond market pending the completion today of a three-day quarterly auction of Treasury securities. Analysts said investors remained hopeful that the Federal Reserve would take further steps before long to relax its credit policy. One assumed precondition for a more stimulative Fed policy is a reduction in inflationary pressures, especially in oil prices. A bit of encouragement on that score is expected Friday when the Labor Department reports on the producer price index of finished goods for October. Analysts are projecting an increase in the index of between 0.5 percent and 1.0 percent, down from 1.6 percent in September and 1.3 percent in August. NCR jumped 7[ to 55[ and American Telephone & Telegraph dropped ] to 33\. The Wall Street Journal reported that the two companies were talking about combining their computer operations. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks gained 1.47 to 168.94. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down .27 at 289.27. Volume on the Big Board came to 108.03 million shares with two hours to go.

DOC.HEAD: Hot Rodders Plan Crush Test
DOC.TEXT: It may not match the sweaty drama of a heavyweight bout, but a hot rod group is wondering if its Bearfoot can knock out a Volvo in a single crunch. Challenged by the Texas attorney general, the Swedish car manufacturer this week pulled an advertisement that showed one of its cars withstanding the attempts of a ``monster truck'' to crush it. The company admitted the Volvo in the ad had been reinforced. Now the U.S. Hot Rod Association says it will ``conduct its own independent, objective test'' Friday using Bearfoot, the truck used in the ads. The association said the test would show ``if a Volvo can truly withstand the grizzly power of Bearfoot's 1,000-pound tires.'' Bob Austin, spokesman for Volvo Cars of North America, said the Hot Rod Association had excellent publicists who are ``spotting an opportunity to ride on the crest of a wave. ... I guess Volvo's response is, we'll see how they stand up.'' On Monday, Volvo agreed to make no unproven claims, run corrective newspaper ads and pay Texas $316,250 in investigative costs. Volvo admitted no wrongdoing, but William Hoover, senior vice president of Volvo Cars of North America, agreed that consumers ``deserve better advertising.'' The ad, filmed in Austin, appears to show a Volvo as the only car left relatively intact after the monster truck runs over a line of autos. Friday's stunt in the parking lot of the Spectrum sports arena is part of the U.S. Hot Rod Camel Mud & Monster Truck Racing Fall Festival of Speed.

DOC.HEAD: British Company Accepts Northern Telecom's Friendly Takeover Offer
DOC.TEXT: STC PLC, a British communications and information systems company, has accepted a friendly takeover offer from Canada's Northern Telecom Ltd., which values STC at $3.6 billion, the companies said Thursday. Northern Telecom, which already owns 27.2 percent of STC, is offering 327 pence, or $6.21, a share for the rest of the company, or a total of about $2.6 billion. STC's shares closed Thursday at 312 pence, or $5.92, up 19 pence, or about 36 cents, from Wednesday. Northern Telecom's offer, which was expected, is conditional on STC completing the sale of 80 percent of its computer subsidiary, ICL, to the Japanese computer maker Fujitsu Ltd., expected to occur Nov. 30. Paul Stern, Northern Telecom's president and chief executive officer, said the combined operations and the close working relations that have already been established between the two companies ``represent an excellent platform for growth in our international business in the future.'' STC Chairman and Chief Executive Arthur Walsh said the merger would make it easier for his company to establish a European-based communications group. STC has been in talks with various companies since July about establishing a European operation. When news of talks between STC and possible partners became known, analysts said a merger would fit a pattern seen among STC's European counterparts, which have been trying to streamline and combine operations to cut costs and capital expenditure associated with new product launches. At the time, some analysts said STC had a dim future if it didn't merge. In the six months ended July 1, STC reported a 32 percent decline in pretax profit to 77.7 million pounds, or $147 million, from a year before. Following completion of the 700 million-pound, or $1.3 billion, cash sale of ICL to Fujitsu, STC's principal activities will be the development and suply of communications systems, software and services. Northern Telecom acquired its 27.2 percent stake in STC in October 1987 as part of its long-term strategy to increase its presence in worldwide telecommunications equipment markets. Standard & Poor's Corp., a leading credit-rating agency, said it was concerned about the additional debt Northern Telecom would take on through the STC takever. S&P put the company's senior debt on its ``creditwatch'' list for further evaluation. STC was owned by ITT Corp. until 1979.

DOC.HEAD: London Shares Close Lower
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with closing prices.
DOC.TEXT: Share prices closed lower Thursday, as the market found little inspiration from Chancellor of the Exchequer John Major's autumn statement on public spending. Major dashed the London market's hopes for interest rate cuts when he said that interest rates would fall only when it was ``safe to do so.'' One trader said the initial reaction to the House of Commons statement was neutral, and the market needed more time to digest the remarks. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index closed down 23 points, or 1.1 percent, at 2,036.2. The Financial Times 30-share index closed down 15.9 points at 1,574.9. The Financial Times 500-share index fell 11.82 points to 1,084.72. Volume was 423.1 million shares, compared with 373.7 million shares traded Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: LA Daily News to Lay Off 4 Percent of Work Force
DOC.TEXT: The Los Angeles Daily News will lay off 4 percent of its workers in a cost-cutting restructuring, Publisher David J. Auger said. The San Fernando Valley-based daily newspaper employs about 1,200. Four percent of the work force is 48 employees. As part of the restructuring, the Daily News has offered a voluntary early retirement plan to some employees, Auger said Wednesday. He blamed the layoffs on an economic downturn that has affected newspapers across the country.

The stock market turned in a mixed showing today, struggling to rally after Wednesday's broad loss. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, down 44.31 points Wednesday, dropped another 8.91 to 2,431.93 by 3 p.m. on Wall Street. Gainers outnumbered losers by about 4 to 3 in the overall tally of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 825 up, 608 down and 517 unchanged. Interest rates held steady in the government bond market pending the completion today of a three-day quarterly auction of Treasury securities. One assumed precondition for a more stimulative Fed policy is a reduction in inflationary pressures, especially in oil prices. A bit of encouragement on that score is expected Friday when the Labor Department reports on the producer price index of finished goods for October. Analysts are projecting an increase in the index of between 0.5 percent and 1.0 percent, down from 1.6 percent in September and 1.3 percent in August. NCR jumped 7[ to 55[ and American Telephone & Telegraph dropped | to 33. The Wall Street Journal reported that the two companies were talking about combining their computer operations.
