DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Rise Ahead Of Report
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices closed mostly higher Thursday on the Chicago Board of Trade ahead of an eagerly awaited government crop report amid signs that foreign demand for U.S. grains is picking up. The corn and wheat markets posted the strongest gains on indications that Spain bought 780,000 metric tons of U.S. corn and on reports that the Agriculture Department targeted Brazil for sales of 300,000 metric tons of wheat at subsidized prices. The soybean market was supported by unconfirmed rumors that the Soviet Union bought 200,000 metric tons of U.S. soybean meal, analysts said. Export demand for U.S. crops, especially soybeans, has been weak lately but foreign sales typically rise at this time of year after the corn and soybean harvest ends. Analysts said the rally also reflected book-squaring by traders ahead of the USDA's monthly crop report. In the report, which was released after the close, the USDA raised it soybean harvest projection to 1.9 billion bushels from 1.82 billion and lowered its corn production estimate to 7.94 billion bushels from 8.02 billion. Analysts had expected the USDA to raise the soybean number to about 1.84 billion bushels and to lower the corn estimate to about 7.98 billion bushels. At the close, wheat futures were 2{ cents to 3\ cents higher with the contract for delivery in December at $2.69 a bushel; corn was 1 cent to 2} cents higher with December at $2.33 a bushel; oats were \ cent to { cent higher with December at $1.21{ a bushel; soybeans were { cent lower to 1 cent higher with November at $5.83 a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Workers Complete Structure for Britain's Tallest Building
LaserPhoto LON2
DOC.TEXT: Construction workers topped the Canary Wharf Tower on Thursday, but the developers face a tall order in filling the loftiest structure in Britain. The Reichmanns, an extremely wealthy family of landowners based in Canada, still are seeking tenants for nearly half the space in the flagship project of the vast and troubled Docklands development in east London, hampered by a slow economy and inconvenient transportation. It is Europe's largest office complex and the biggest project ever undertaken by the Reichmanns, who own a vast array of commercial properties in North America, including swathes of prime Manhattan real estate. ``I hope this marks the beginning of public acceptance for Canary Wharf,'' said Charles Young, executive director of the Reichmanns' Olympia and York company. Construction workers hoisted a steel pyramid cap, signed by officials and festooned with flags, to the top of the skyscraper. Greenwich residents across the Thames River have complained about the glass-tipped steel obelisk designed by architect Cesar Pelli. Prince Charles, a frequent critic of postwar British architecture, has said about Canary Wharf, ``I would go mad if I had to work there.'' At Thursday's ceremony, Sir Nigel Broackes, chairman of Trafalgar House PLC, which fabricated the tower's 27,500 metric tons of steel, said: ``I think if Christopher Wren and Inigo Jones were here today, they would rejoice at this achievement.'' Wren was the architect of St. Paul's Cathedral, the dome that once dominated the east London skyline. Jones, designer of the Queen's House in Greenwich, introduced the Palladian style to Britain. The 800-foot, 50-story Canary Wharf Tower surpassed the 600-foot National Westminster Bank building, located near the Bank of England in the City of London, or financial district. ``The topping off shows what you can do with a little organization, a little will and a lot of effort,'' said Michael Dennis, managing director of Olympia and York Canary Wharf Ltd. Dennis said the achievement should dispel skepticism which has plagued the project in the past three years. Canary Wharf's final price is expected to cost 4 billion pounds or $7.8 billion. Peter Marano, senior vice president for leasing at Olympia and York Canary Wharf, said it will be about 10 months before tenants start moving in, ``and we expect to be 75 to 80 percent leased by next May or June.'' But real estate experts say the 71-acre project is risky because of its huge size and its hard-to-reach location. ``In the 10-year view it will be a profitable investment,'' said Nan Rogers, a real estate analyst with the London investment firm James Capel & Co. ``In the meantime they're having a lot of trouble getting tenants in because of the transportation.'' It will be years before the area's Docklands Light Railway, which can carry 4,000 people an hour, will be upgraded enough to handle the flow of people who will work at Canary Wharf, she said. A collapse of London real estate market because of high interest rates, now running at 14 percent, and a slowing economy, have hampered the Docklands development. Questions were raised about Canary Wharf when the Reichmanns announced in September that they planned to sell 20 percent of their extensive U.S. properties. But Olympia and York officials said the sale had nothing to do with the project and expressed satisfaction with the progress on tenants and on long-term financing.

DOC.HEAD: Report: AT&T, NCR Discuss Combining Computer Businesses
DOC.TEXT: American Telephone & Telegraph Co. and NCR Corp. are discussing combining their computer businesses, according to a report published Thursday. Both companies said they had no comment. The Wall Street Journal quoted individuals familiar with the talks as saying they are uncertain what form the combination could take and cautioned that nothing may come of the discussions. The Journal did not identify its sources. The report said the companies have been holding discussions for more than a month and have explored several scenarios. One would have AT&T acquire NCR outright, the story said, while another could involve a spinoff of AT&T's computer business to NCR with AT&T taking an equity stake in the combined operation. The Journal said the first scenario seems more likely because AT&T has long coveted NCR, while a spinoff may be seen as a defeat for the telecommunications powerhouse. AT&T spokeman Walter Murphy said the company never comments on such speculation. Spokeswoman Connie Olasz at NCR's heradquarters in Dayton, Ohio, said her company also had no comment. Charles Nichols, an independent industry analyst who follows AT&T, said there have been reports for several years that the phone company was interested in acquiring a computer company. NCR and Unisys Corp. have been among the names mentioned, he said. An NCR-AT&T computer venture would make sense because it would combine AT&T's strengths in networked computers and telecommunications with NCR's strong customer base in the retail industry, where such skills are needed, Nichols said. He said he believed the least likely scenario would be for AT&T to buy NCR outright. A more likely arrangement would be for the two companies to enter into a joint computer venture, or for AT&T to buy a stake in NCR. AT&T has cooperative ventures with several computer companies, including Sun Microsystems Inc. AT&T owns about 20 percent of Sun's stock. AT&T's computer business is small compared with industry leaders. But it has achieved success in the past few years in selling computers to the federal government. It also recently landed several major commercial contracts, including one with American Airlines, Nichols said. NCR, the nation's fifth largest computer company, launched a major revamping of its computer line this fall under which it will base all its machines on industry standards and Intel Corp. microprocessors, getting rid of its proprietary computer lines. NCR also is a major maker of automated teller machines and cash registers. AT&T generates $36 billion in revenue annually overall, while NCR had revenue of about $6 billion last year.

DOC.HEAD: French Computer Maker Plans 5,000 Job Reductions, Half in U.S.
Graphic
DOC.TEXT: Groupe Bull, France's state-owned computer maker with extensive U.S. operations, said Thursday it would eliminate more than 10 percent of its work force due to a ``crisis'' facing the world computer industry. Bull said it would slash 5,000 jobs, including up to 1,000 in Massachusetts where it has extensive operations and its U.S. headquarters, and 250 in Phoenix. Bull also projected it would lose 2.88 billion francs, or about $511 million, this year. The steps are part of a long-awaited reorganization that also will include unspecified plant closings. Bull said the plan is aimed at helping the company turn a profit by 1992. Bull said in a statement it was trying to refocus its resources to ``confront the worldwide crisis facing the information systems industry.'' Growth in the industry has slowed in recent years from its previous clip of 30 percent or more a year. Bull, which employs about 47,000 people worldwide, already laid off 2,000 workers during 1989 and 3,000 more so far this year. Bull's U.S. operations include the former Honeywell computer units as well as Zenith Data Systems Corp., a maker of personal computers. Under a new corporate structure, Bull HN, the company's U.S.-based subsidiary, will take control of all Groupe Bull operations in the Far East. The company also plans to consolidate its European operations outside of France. Analysts said Bull has been hurt by shifts in the marketplace. Customers increasingly are demanding ``open'' computer systems that allow machines from different companies to work together. Bull has moved into this market with computers based on the popular Unix operating system, but profit margins for these machines are smaller than on traditional proprietary models. As a result, Bull spokesman Edward Russell said, administrative and sales costs have had to be cut. The company said it would implement an early retirement plan for its U.S. workers. But it said the job reductions would include layoffs. Bull plans to eliminate at least 20 percent of the 2,050 jobs at its U.S. headquarters in Billerica, north of Boston. The company also said it will cut its payroll at three other Massachusetts facilities. Aside from the cuts in Massachusetts and Phoenix, the company plans to eliminate 350 other jobs at field locations in the United States. In addition, Bull plans to cut about 170 jobs at Zenith Data Systems, which is based outside Chicago, and up to 100 jobs in Canada. The company stressed that it also was investing in long-term research to develop new products. This year, other computer companies, including Digital Equipment Corp., Unisys Corp., Data General Corp. and Wang Laboratories Inc., have reduced their payrolls, either through layoffs or voluntary measures. In France, labor leaders said they would protest the cutbacks. Jean-Francois Bolzinger, an administrator of the leftist General Confederation of Labor, said 1,100 of the jobs targeted for elimination were in France. Bolzinger contended that Bull overestimated its losses to create ``psychological shock'' among the work force. On Oct. 25, Europe's largest electronics and computer company, NV Philips of the Netherlands, announced plans to cut 45,000 jobs from its worldwide payroll of 285,000.

DOC.HEAD: Chrysler UAW Members Voting on Contract
DOC.TEXT: Ratification voting is under way for 63,000 Chrysler Corp. workers on a three-year contract with the United Auto Workers union. The voting period opened Wednesday and results must be reported to the UAW's headquarters in Detroit by Nov. 18. The union said it would not issue partial results. Balloting at one of Chrysler's most profitable factories, a minivan assembly plant in St. Louis, won't be held until Nov. 17, however, a union official said Thursday. A special part of the UAW-Chrysler contract deals just with the minivan plant, and officials said more time was needed to give details to the workers. Under the special provision, workers would change from two production shifts to three. Officials expect Chrysler workers nationwide to ratify the pact and close the final chapter of this year's UAW-Big Three negotiations. UAW contracts with General Motors Corp. and Ford Motor Co. were ratified by ratios of better than 4-to-1. Terms of the Chrysler-UAW contract are essentially the same as the contracts the union signed last month with GM and Ford. In all, more than 450,000 active auto workers are covered by UAW-negotiated agreements with the Big Three. The St. Louis factory is one of two Chrysler plants making one of its most profitable vehicles. The other is in Windsor, Ontario. Chrysler, which as recently as the mid-1980s sold more minivans than all other automakers combined, needs the extra supply to fight off competitors eating away at its share of the popular segment of the U.S. vehicle market. An increase in minivan sales also would prop up Chrysler's slumping profits. Last week, the No. 3 automaker reported it lost $214 million in the third quarter, and there has been speculation among Wall Street analysts that the company may end 1990 in the red. There are about 3,500 union members at the St. Louis II minivan factory. ``We just got the (contract) highlights out to the people today,'' Ray Ramsey, financial secretary of UAW Local 110 at the St. Louis II plant, said Thursday. ``This weekend is just too short a notice.'' The contract would change scheduling at the plant from a two-shift operation to three shifts in July 1991 with the company having an option of adding two nine-hour shifts on Saturdays. Elsewhere, the voting process appeared to go smoothly. ``Most of the stewards say it's flying good down here,'' Richard McDonaugh, president of UAW Local 1183 at Chrysler's Newark, Del., assembly plant, said Thursday. His local plans to vote next week.

DOC.HEAD: Two States Seek To Bar `Junk Bond' Mutual Funds
DOC.TEXT: Officials in New York and Massachusetts took legal action Thursday to bar the sale of two junk-bond mutual funds that allegedly duped 270,000 investors, many of ``very modest means,'' with tricky sales pitches. First Investors, a large mutual fund company targeted in the suit, denied the charges, which included scripted and misleading sales pitches by aggressive representatives seeking to sign up investors in their own living rooms. The company said in a statement it ``will vigorously defend itself and is confident it will prevail.'' The action capped a 15-month undercover investigation by the two states into what New York Attorney General Robert Abrams called fraudulent selling techniques employed by two of the largest junk funds in the mutual-fund industry. Abrams filed suit in State Supreme Court; Massachusetts Secretary of State Michael Connolly filed an administrative complaint and will conduct a hearing into the alleged fraud, which dates back to 1985. Several other states are considering legal action. The two Manhattan-based funds are First Investors Fund for Income Inc., with assets of $971 million as of June 30, and First Investors High Yield Fund Inc., which had assets of $640 million at that time. An estimated 90 percent of those assets were in junk bonds, the risky IOUs peddled by hundreds of companies for takeovers or expansion during the 1980s. But over the past year the junk-bond market has collapsed, making these investments worth much less. Named in the suit are First Investors Consolidated Corp. and its subsidiaries First Investors Corp., and First Investors Management Co., along with a number of executives. Abrams said in a press release that First Investors offered false assurances that the funds were safe and that the bonds were guaranteed at a high rate of return. Investors were unaware, he contended, that ``they were going into the riskiest sector of the bond market.'' Abrams said the funds were sold ``primarily in people's homes by aggressive salespeople using a prepared script which greatly misrepresented the risks involved. ``They preyed upon investors who were unsophisticated ... Many victims were of very modest means and could ill afford their losses,'' he said. The funds offered an installment plan for as little as $50 a month in an effort to ``entice investors with little or no savings.'' The undercover operation included investigators posing as potential investors. Abrams said audiotape evidence of the sales pitch and ``evidence of such salesperson-client interactions'' would be introduced in court. First Investors said in its statement that it has conducted business ``according to the rules and guidelines set forth by regulatory bodies.'' The company noted that the lawsuits are limited to the sales of two of its 25 mutual funds. First Investors performed in the bottom 10 percent of junk-bond funds in rate of total return, Abrams said. In the last 16 months, the funds' net asset value has plummeted 35 percent. ``This lawsuit seeks to end the deceptive practices we uncovered and to gain restitution for those defrauded,'' Abrams said. The suit also named David Grayson and Glenn O. Head, president and chairman of the corporations, as well as Howard Froman and Alvin Blumenfeld, senior vice president of First Investors Corp. New York and Massachusetts residents comprise more than 30 percent of the investors in both funds.

DOC.HEAD: Former Memories Magazine Editor Named to Same Post at American Health
DOC.TEXT: Reader's Digest Association Inc. said Thursday that the former editor of Memories magazine, Carey Winfrey, has been named editor in chief at its American Health magazine. Reader's Digest also named a new acting publisher for the magazine. The new appointees replace a pair of magazine executives who were holdovers from the period when American Health was controlled by a group led by Owen Lipstein, its founder who sold American Health for $29 million in February. ``We are making these changes as part of our ongoing development of American Health,'' said Thomas M. Kenney, president of Reader's Digest Magazine Publishing Group. ``We feel that American Health has great potential.'' The decade-old magazine had undergone some rocky moments in the months before it was sold. Advertisers complained issues were often sent late. Readers' Digest slashed the magazine's guaranteed circulation rate base to 800,000 from 1 million shortly. American Health is published 10 timesa a year. In a weak ad market, American Health has seen its advertising pages plunge 41.3 percent to 328 pages through the first nine months of this year, according to Publishers Information Bureau. That compared with an average 3.3 percent decline through September at the 172 magazines the bureau tracks. Kenney said the company's immediate plan was to stabilize the magazine by building up its infrastructure and circulation base, and then hoped to make it the premiere health magazine of the 1990s. The company also feels the magazine will complement its book publishing efforts in the health field. Winfrey replaces Joel Gurin as editor in chief of American Health. Reader's Digest named Greg Coleman to replace Sheila Wyle temporarily as publisher of American Health while a secarch goes on for a permanent replacement. Coleman is already group publisher of the Reader's Digest Special Interest Magazine Group. The anouncement said only that Gurin and Ms. Wyle were leaving their posts and calls to each of them were not returned. Gurin had been with American Health since 1981 while Ms. Wyle joined the magazine in 1983. Asked whether they were fired, Bruce Trachtenberg, a spokesman for Reader's Digest, said, ``There was a meeting this morning. They both met with Kenney and those were the results.'' Winfrey, 49, has worked for 23 years in magazines, newspapers and television. He had been a vice president at Hachette SA's Diamandis Communications Inc., where he was founding editor in chief in 1988 of Memories magazine which took another look every other month at important events of past decades. Hachette suspended regular publication of Memories two months ago after efforts to sell it failed and the market for advertising grew too weak to support it. Hachette plans to publish the magazine twice a year. Before Memories, Winfrey was editor in chief of Cuisine magazine, an associate editor at Time magazine, a reporter for the New York Times and a producer for a cable television venture by CBS Inc.

DOC.HEAD: Dow Jones, German Company in Deal to Publish in Europe
DOC.TEXT: Dow Jones & Co., publisher of the Wall Street Journal, said Thursday it has formed a company with the German business publisher Von Holtzbrinck Group to pursue English-language publishing ventures in Europe. Von Holtzbrinck publishes Germany's leading business daily, Handelsblatt. The new company, Handelsblatt-Dow Jones Gmbh, will have an initial capitalization of $1 million and will be based in Frankfurt. Its mission will be to develop joint advertising, circulation and distribution arrangements between the Wall Street Journal Europe and Handelsblatt in Europe, and explore English-language publishing opportunities. Dow Jones and Von Holtzbrinck are equity partners in several European enterprises, including France's Groupe Expansion and Eurexpansion, a network of national-language business publications in a dozen European countries.

The stock market made little progress today in a bid to rally after Wednesday's broad loss. Interest rates held steady in the government bond market through the completion today of a three-day quarterly auction of Treasury securities. Analysts said investors remained hopeful that the Federal Reserve would take further steps before long to relax its credit policy. One assumed precondition for a more stimulative Fed policy is a reduction in inflationary pressures, especially in oil prices. A bit of encouragement on that score is expected Friday when the Labor Department reports on the producer price index of finished goods for October. Analysts are projecting an increase in the index of between 0.5 percent and 1.0 percent, down from 1.6 percent in September and 1.3 percent in August.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: M&M-Mars Introduces Peanut Butter M&M
DOC.TEXT: M&M-Mars has introduced a peanut butter M&M to cash in on what analysts say is a booming demand for the palate-clinging product. The newest version of the familiar M&M consists of a creamy peanut butter center covered by a layer of milk chocolate and wrapped in the famous candy-coated outer shell. It can be bought only on the West Coast because of limited production capacity, said Bill Deeter, a spokesman for M&M-Mars, a division of Mars Inc. He declined to predict when it would be widely available. ``We're rolling it out as we have the capacity to supply,'' Deeter said in a telephone interview from his office in Hackettstown, 35 miles west of Newark. Deeter denied that the popularity of Reese's Pieces - Hershey Foods' peanut butter candy - had fueled M&M-Mars' marketing strategy. ``Mars makes up its mind based on where it sees its opportunities and consumer appetites,'' Deeter said. ``This was the logical next step for the product.'' Industry analysts said the new product, which was rolled out in September, underscores an insatiable appetite in the United States for peanut butter. Earlier this year, M&M-Mars added peanut butter to its popular Snickers candy bar and also rolled out PB MAX, another peanut butter confection that the industry sees as a competitor to Reese's Peanut Butter Cups. ``Peanut butter sales are increasing in America,'' said marketing consultant Phil Lempert of Montclair. He noted the addition of chocolate chip and cinnamon raisin peanut butters on the supermarket shelf next to creamy and crunchy styles. ``This is just one of a number of products that Mars has introduced with peanut butter aimed at slowing down Reese's and gaining a foothold in this growing category,'' said John McMillin, a food industry analyst with Prudential Bache in New York. Hershey Foods' Reese's Cups are the second most popular candy in the United States after M&M-Mars' Snickers bars, analysts said. McMillin noted that the Reese's product line was boosted after Reese's Pieces were used to lure a shy alien in the movie, ``E.T.: the Extraterrestrial.'' The sales gap between the top two candies, however, has been narrowed considerably in the past few years, with Snickers bringing in revenues of $129 million in 1989 compared with $105 million for Reese's Cups, McMillin said. ``Snickers used to be way out in front,'' he said, ``and Mars wants to maintain its lead.'' Hershey, based in Hershey, Pa., controls about 44 percent of the $5 billion chocolate candy market compared with Mars' 38 percent, McMillin said. The peanut butter-enhanced M&M - which marks the first new M&M flavor since the peanut variety was introduced in 1954 - will boost an already successful product line. Peanut M&Ms are the third best-selling candy in the United States with $102 million in sales, followed by M&Ms Plain, with $83 million in revenue, analysts said. Ironically, McMillin noted, M&M-Mars chose to launch its new peanut butter-heavy product line in the midst of a severe peanut drought in Georgia that has driven up the price of peanuts. Deeter said the peanut drought would have little effect because commodity buying is done ``years in advance.''

DOC.HEAD: Bad October Sales Makes Gloomy Christmas For Retailers More Likely
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Kmart in 24th graf is cq, reflecting new style on company name.
DOC.TEXT: The outlook for the Christmas shopping season went from bad to worse Thursday as the nation's biggest retailers reported dismal sales results for the month of October. Several companies including Sears, Roebuck & Co. and J.C. Penney Co. Inc. said sales dropped from levels of a year earlier as consumers, with one eye on the economy and the other on the Middle East, avoided buying anything they didn't need. With Christmas less than seven weeks away, neither the retailers nor the industry analysts who track their performance expect consumers to suddenly shift gears and go on mammoth gift-buying sprees. The 1990 holiday season will be ``a much more frugal Christmas,'' predicted Thomas Tashjian, an analyst with Seidler Amdec Securities Inc. in Los Angeles. ``They'll probaby be going in and buying the same number of items, but they're not going to pay as much ...'' Tashjian said. ``They're not going to buy $100 electronic toys for their kids, not this year.'' The poor October sales, coming in the aftermath of disappointing showings in August and September, ``reflected a recessionary psychology'' among consumers, said Jeffrey Feiner, an analyst with Merrill Lynch & Co. Consumers cut spending as the economy weakened and after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait raised the specter of war, inflating prices of gasoline andhome heating oil. The first items crossed off shopping lists were so-called discretionary items - clothing, furniture and other extras that are the bread and butter of many big stores. If retailers have a difficult Christmas, it could contribute to a further deterioration of the economy, since two-thirds of the nation's economic growth is generated consumer spending. Unsold goods on store shelves could also affect manufacturing - if stores don't place new orders, factories don't need to provide as many products and could lay off workers. A poor Christmas season could be devastating for the retailers themselves, as they depend on holiday shopping for about half their annual sales and profits. Christmas 1989 was a disappointment for many storeowners after they were forced to slash prices to attract customers. Sears, the country's largest retailer, said results from stores open at least one year fell 0.4 percent last month from October 1989, while overall sales dropped 1.2 percent. Analysts believe sales from stores open at least a year - also known as same-store or comparable store sales - provide a more accurate assessment of a retailer's performance than overall sales do. New stores tend to have extraordinarily strong sales that can skew a retailer's results. One of the hardest hit last month was Penney, which said comparable store sales fell 6.3 percent from October 1989, while overall sales dropped 4.9 percent. Limited Inc., the nation's largest specialty apparel retailer, reported comparable store sales dropped 1 percent as overall sales rose 13 percent. Apparel stores were also affected by continuing warm weather in some parts of the country. May Department Stores Co., parent of big department store chains including Lord & Taylor, Hecht's, Filene's and Foley's, said comparable store sales dropped 4.4 percent, while overall sales edged up 1.1 percent. But Wal-Mart Stores Inc., one of the biggest discount retailers, continued to outperform the rest of the retail industry, reporting comparable store sales rose 10 percent while overall sales rose 25 percent. Analysts are already predicting trouble for some stores, especially those going into the Christmas season with high inventory levels and unexpectedly poor sales. These retailers are expected to be the first ones to mark down merchandise - and see their profits evaporate. Markdowns set off a spiral of sorts as consumers, having seen one round of price reductions, wait for more merchandise to be marked down and end up forcing retailers to take further cuts. When one retailer lowers prices, it pressures others to follow. Feiner, the Merrill Lynch analyst, noting that Christmas 1989 sales were hurt by markdowns, issued this warning about another disappointing season: ``The end result ... could be further bankruptcies and-or consolidations in the industry.'' Several retailers, notably Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp., filed for bankruptcy court protection during this past year. Among other reports from retailers Thursday: -Dayton Hudson Corp. said comparable store sales rose 4.1 percent, while overall sales picked up 16.7 percent. -Kmart Corp. reported a 1.3 percent sales gain at comparable stores, and an 11.2 percent rise overall. -Woolworth Corp. said comparable store sales increased 1 percent, while overall sales rose 4.2 percent. The results announced Thursday differ from the monthly retail sales report from the government. The Commerce Department's figures includes sales from supermarkets, restaurants and car dealers.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Moves Sharply Higher
DOC.TEXT: The dollar staged a sharp advance on world currency markets Thursday amid indications there is some international support for a stronger U.S. currency. Gold prices rose, reversing a downward trend in Europe. On New York's Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $387.30 a troy ounce, up $1 from Wednesday. At Republic National Bank, the late bid for gold was $387.15, up 45 cents an ounce. The dollar got a boost from French Economics Minister Pierre Beregovoy's disclosure that he had written to Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady recently asking for support in seeking coordinated action to prop up the dollar. Beregovoy, who spoke at a news conference in Paris, said he wants the so-called Group of Seven leading industrialized nations to meet and address the issue. ``I don't think that the United States has an interest in the sustained and accentuated decline of the dollar,'' he said. But U.S. and German officials denied that a G-7 meeting is necessary, and that pushed the dollar temporarily lower in seesaw domestic trading. ``The market is very nervous and is looking for any kind of intervention by the central banks,'' said Bob Morrissey, a senior trader at the Bank of Boston's office here. While it is widely accepted that the United States is satisfied with the dollar's current trading range, a stronger dollar is attractive to Europeans because it would make U.S. imports more expensive for consumers overseas. Concern that tensions are heightening in the Persian Gulf region also helped the dollar recover to its session highs, said John McCarthy, chief dealer at Amsterdam Rotterdam Bank in New York. The dollar is considered a safe haven in times of global turmoil. The dollar's biggest advance came against the Japanese yen, which has been pushed lower because of overall disappointment with the decline in the Japanese stock market and an uncertain political climate. In Tokyo, the dollar rose to a closing 129.50 Japanese yen, from 127.55 yen at Wednesday's close. Later in London, it rose to 129.90 yen. In New York, the dollar jumped to close at 130.35 yen, from 128.73 yen on Wednesday. In London, the British pound fell to $1.9670 from $1.9760 late Wednesday. In New York, it cost $1.9625 to buy one pound, less expensive than Wednesday's $1.9690. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday's rates included: 1.4930 German marks, up from 1.4874; 1.2535 Swiss francs, up from 1.2485; 5.0100 French francs, up from 4.9870; 1,122.75 Italian lire, up from 1,117.00, and 1.1694 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1671. Other late dollar rates in Europe compared with late Wednesday's rates included: 1.4885 German marks, up from 1.4820; 1.2580 Swiss francs, up from 1.2435; 4.9935 French francs, up from 4.9715; 1.6780 Dutch guilders, up from 1.6712; 1,129.00 Italian lire, up from 1,113.75, and 1.1685 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1627. Gold fell in London to a late bid of $385.75 a troy ounce, down from $387.25 late Wednesday. In Zurich, the metal fell to $384.75 an ounce from $386.75. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose $2.67 an ounce to close at $386.31. Silver prices were mixed. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $4.277 a troy ounce, up from $4.267 on Wednesday. But in London, the metal slipped to a late bid of $4.25 a troy ounce from $4.28.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: The stock market posted a small gain Thursday after several fitful attempts to rally from Wednesday's broad decline. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, down 44.31 points Wednesday, edged up 2.97 to 2,443.81. Advancing issues outnumbered declines by about 5 to 4 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 834 up, 654 down and 510 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 155.57 million shares, up from 149.13 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 191.64 million shares. Interest rates held steady in the government bond market through the completion of a three-day quarterly auction of Treasury securities. Analysts said investors remained hopeful that the Federal Reserve would take further steps before long to relax its credit policy. One assumed precondition for a more stimulative Fed policy is a reduction in inflationary pressures, especially in oil prices. A bit of encouragement on that score is expected Friday when the Labor Department reports on the producer price index of finished goods for October. Analysts are projecting an increase in the index of between 0.5 percent and 1.0 percent, down from 1.6 percent in September and 1.3 percent in August. Stock prices changed direction several times during the session, buffeted by rumors and speculation about the two-month-old showdown in the Persian Gulf. Much of the furor died down at the close, however, when President Bush announced only that he was sending additional forces to the area. NCR jumped 5~ to 53~ and American Telephone & Telegraph dropped { to 33[. The Wall Street Journal reported that the two companies were talking about combining their computer operations. Browning-Ferris Industries rose | to 22] and Waste Management gained } to 32\. The two stocks sold off sharply earlier in the week as Browning-Ferris reported sharply lower quarterly earnings. UST added \ to 33\, trading at record highs. The shares of the producer of smokeless tobacco and other products were featured this week as the ``stock highlight'' in the Value Line Investment Survey. USF&G lost } to 10~. On Wednesday the company announced a cost-cutting plan and reduced its quarterly dividend from 73 cents a share to 25 cents a share. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market increased $8.83 billion, or 0.31 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks gained .67 to 168.14. Standard & Poor's industrial index rose 1.57 to 359.72, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was up 1.60 at 307.61. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market slipped .43 to 336.37. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 289.07, down .67.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Merrill Lynch VP Pleads Guilty in Kickback Scheme
DOC.TEXT: A former Merrill Lynch & Co. vice president pleaded guilty Thursday to soliciting and demanding payoffs from vendors hired to construct the brokerage firm's headquarters at the World Financial Center. Albert Young, 61, of Manhattan, pleaded guilty to conspiracy, mail fraud and two counts of tax fraud. He faces up to 18 years in prison and a $1 million fine when sentenced Jan. 18 by U.S. District Judge Lawrence M. McKenna of Manhattan. Authorities alleged that vendors supplied Young with a stretch limousine and chauffeur and helped pay for his country home in Hawley, Pa. Court papers said he also received a $2,900 silver fox coat, use of a corporate credit card, furniture and cash payments. The complaint claimed Young received at least $350,000 in cash and other benefits from contractors between 1984 and 1987 in return for promises that they would get business with his employer. Young, a company vice president, resigned from the firm in September 1988. One of the vendors, Marvin Weiner of Newark, N.J., also pleaded guilty Thursday to a related charge of violating currency regulations. Weiner, who owns Newark Food Service Equipment in New Jersey, was accused of helping launder cash payoffs to Young in order to avoid Internal Revenue Service reporting requirements. He faces up to five years in prison and a $250,000 fine when sentenced Jan. 7 by U.S. District Judge Pierre Leval.

DOC.HEAD: Merrill, First Boston Confirm More Layoffs
DOC.TEXT: Merrill Lynch & Co. and CS First Boston Inc. on Thursday confirmed they were laying off about 100 more professionals, extending the latest round of cutbacks on Wall Street. Merrill Lynch said it laid off 50 investment bankers, bringing the number of bankers the nation's biggest securities firm has cut this year to 125. Merrill's investment banking force totals 575, down 18 percent this year. First Boston, which reportedly may lay off up to 500 people by the end of 1990, confirmed it dismissed 45 traders, salesmen and support staff from its stock department. The firm earlier this week fired 50 operations personnel. Bear, Stearns & Co. confirmed it laid off 10 investment bankers of a staff of about 200. But the firm, considered one of the best managed on Wall Street, also said it had hired five executives for a new foreign stock trading department. Other firms also are expected to trim investment bankers. ``We're near a low in banking,'' said Lawrence Eckenfelder, an analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. ``I would think by early next year most firms will have contracted to where they need to be in banking.'' Wall Street is stuck in a prolonged downturn dating to the October 1987 stock market crash. The latest cuts of more than 45,000 since the crash involve highly paid professionals, especially investment bankers who handled the large mergers and takeovers of the 1980s. The value of U.S. mergers and acquisitions in the first 10 months of 1990 was down 50 percent compared with the same period last year, according to IDD Information Services, a Wall Street research and publishing concern. IDD said 3,575 deals valued at $185.9 billion were completed from January through October, vs. 4,273 valued at $373.4 billion in the same 1989 period. The drop was most severe in deals worth more than $50 million. Also Thursday, the chairman of First Boston's merchant banking department announced his resignation at the end of the year. The departure of William E. Mayer comes after the firm's owners agreed to purchase the bulk of a portfolio of bad loans that couldn't be sold to investors. First Boston has been struggling this year to cope with declining business across Wall Street and the collapse of the junk bond market that left it holding more than $1 billion in loans to clients that could not be resold and had severly hurt its balance sheet. Mayer's departure was expected. In January, he was pushed aside as chief executive of First Boston Corp., CS First Boston's U.S. investment banking subsidiary and asked to take over a new merchant banking unit. Mayer said in an interview that once the loan problems had been resolved he decided to leave the firm. Mayer had been at First Boston for 23 years. Mayer said his departure was not tied to the latest round of layoffs. A First Boston spokesman said reports circulating at the firm of 300 to 500 layoffs in the next two months were unfounded.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Prices Jump As Traders Bet Bush Would Rattle Saber
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices rallied in a wild session in the petroleum market Thursday, dropping early then surging on a correct hunch by traders that President Bush would increase military pressure on Iraq's Saddam Hussein. After the market closed, however, traders said they may have overestimated the gravity of Bush's move. Crude oil dropped about $1 per barrel in early trading, but finished the day with a 22 cent gain, closing at $35.53 per barrel for December delivery contracts on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Bush told Washington reporters he was building up the U.S. military force in the Persian Gulf to provide for ``an adequate offensive option'' that could drive Iraq from Kuwait. Administration officials had previously indicated they would send more troops. Some traders said Thursday evening they had perhaps overreacted to their nervousness over what Bush would say. ``I didn't hear anything new,'' said Brian Tagler, a broker with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. ``I think that the market definitely pushed itself higher than (it would have on) what we know now.'' Analysts said the market got scared in the afternoon when traders learned a White House news conference on foreign policy, originally scheduled to take place during the trading session, had been delayed until after the exchange would be closed. Tension built as traders learned the news conference was again delayed until after the stock market's closing bell. Oil prices probably would have stayed lower for the day if Bush had made his statements while trading was still going on, analysts said. The sharp rally had been driven in part by a rumor, said to have floated in from the bond market, that Bush had been prepared to announce plans to airlift supplies into the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait, where diplomats have been surviving for weeks on scanty provisions. Traders believed such a scenario could provide the confrontation that would trigger war in the Persian Gulf. Others put no faith in the rumor, saying it had cropped up before. ``This is the second time I've heard it in a week,'' said trader Ed Kevelson of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. ``It's like the `Saddam has been shot' rumors.'' Some tense traders also believed Bush would give Iraq a deadline for getting out of Kuwait, which Bush did not do. Oil prices also strengthened partly on news that the Soviet Union was refusing to rule out the use of force against Iraq, which has for years had close ties to Moscow. Other energy futures moved higher as traders waited on Bush, but for the day they finished mixed. Home heating oil prices moved higher, with December delivery contracts rising 1.59 cents to 94.30 cents a gallon and all later contract months closing higher. Unleaded gasoline fell .68 cent to 90.51 on December delivery contracts, but later contract months were all higher. Natural gas prices were either down or unchanged for the day. December delivery contracts dropped 1.5 cents to $2.435 per 1,000 cubic feet.

DOC.HEAD: Hearst Buys RJR Nabisco's 20 Percent Stake in ESPN
DOC.TEXT: Publishing and broadcasting powerhouse Hearst Corp. has purchased the 20 percent stake that RJR Nabisco Inc. held for seven years in the sports cable television service ESPN Inc., it was announced Thursday. Terms were not disclosed, but people familiar with the deal said the price was less than $180 million. The deal forges another link between Hearst and Capital Cities-ABC Inc., which owns 80 percent of ESPN and is Hearst's partner in two other cable channels. ``It's a happy situation for both of them,'' said media analyst John Reidy of Smith Barney Harris Upham Inc. RJR Nabisco, the food and tobacco giant taken private last year in the biggest debt-financed takeover on record, hired an investment banker 15 months ago to help it decide whether to sell the ESPN stake. Capital Cities-ABC had the right to match any offer for RJR's interest in ESPN, but had little to gain from buying the minority interest itself. Speculation quickly centered on Hearst as a potential buyer of the ESPN stake. Hearst and Capital Cities-ABC have a long association. They each have equity stakes in the Lifetime and Arts & Entertainmnet cable channels. Five of Hearst's six TV stations are ABC network affiliates. In addition, Capital Cities-ABC was responsible for running the operation under a shareholder agreement that left little to do for the minority shareholder. ``It it were any other company than Capital Cities-ABC, Hearst would not be nearly as interested,'' said Raymond E. Joslin, head of the Hearst Entertainment and Syndication Group. He said Hearst hopes to benefit, however, from the maturation of the cable television business and the prospect that cable TV networks will soon be able to charge nearly as much for advertising as broadcast networks. ESPN is is the largest cable TV programming service in the United States with more than 57 million cable TV subscribers, or about 60 percent of U.S. homes with television. It offers coverage of professional and amateur sports events as well as sports news and lifestyle programs. Industry insiders said ESPN had operating income of about $135 million on revenues of $390 million in 1989. It is expected that operating income will fall this year because of losses estimated at about $30 million on the cable network's first year under a four-year contract to cover major league baseball. While declining to comment on the financial figures, Joslin said Hearst expects that ESPN will make a small profit over the life of the baseball contract. The contract permits ESPN to carry 175 regular season games a year. RJR Nabisco, swallowed up in a $24.5 billion buyout by the investment firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co. in early 1989, sold assets to trim its debt. Jason Wright, a spokesman for RJR, said the sale of the ESPN stake was not required under any of the company's debt covenants, but he said the company felt it should sell the stake because it was outside its core business areas. He said no decision has been made yet on what will be done with the proceeds of the sale. He said RJR's debt is expected to fall to $20 billion by the end of the year, down from $28 billion at the time of the buyout. He said there were ``numerous expressions of interest'' in the ESPN stake, but declined to say how many companies made bids. The deal expands the cable television interests at Hearst, a privately held company with major operations in magazines, newsapapers and book publishing. Earlier this month, Hearst announced formation of New England Cable Newschannel, an all-news cable network for the New England region. Its partner in that deal is Continental Cablevision Inc. Hearst is also a partner with the French pay-TV network Canal Plus in Ellipse Programme, a French production company specializing in game shows, made-for-TV movies, animated programs and documentaries.

DOC.HEAD: Money Supply Lower
DOC.TEXT: The two broadest measures of the nation's money supply fell in the week ended Oct. 29, the Federal Reserve Board reported Thursday. The Fed said the measure known as M2 fell to a seasonally adjusted $3,316.5 billion from $3,317.7 billion the previous week. An even broader measure, M3, fell to a seasonally adjusted $4,087.3 billion from $4,090.3 billion. The narrowest measure of the money supply, M1, rose to a seasonally adjusted $820.0 billion from $818.4 billion. M1 includes cash in circulation, deposits in checking accounts and non-bank travelers checks. M2 is M1 plus accounts like savings deposits and money-market mutual funds. M3 is M2 plus less-liquid accounts, such as certificates of deposit in minimum denominations of $100,000. In judging its monetary policy, the Fed has indicated it is monitoring the value of the dollar, commodity prices and the difference between short- and long-term interest rates. It also has shifted its attention from M1 to the two broader money supply measures. The growth rate in M2 in the last 52 weeks was 3.8 percent, which is within the Fed's target range of 3 percent to 7 percent. The growth rate in M3 over the past year was 1.5 percent, which is within the Fed's target range of 1 percent to 5 percent. The Fed has not set a target for M1 growth since early 1987. For the latest 13 weeks, M2 averaged $3,312.4 billion, a 4.2 percent seasonally adjusted annual rate of gain from the previous 13 weeks. M3 averaged $4,089.1 billion, up 2.0 percent, while M1 rose 5.6 percent to an average of $819.1 billion. In other reports: -The Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported commercial and industrial loans at major New York City banks rose $921 million. -The Federal Reserve said bank borrowings from the Federal Reserve System at the discount window, excluding extended credit, averaged $252 million a day in the week ended Wednesday, down from $399 million the previous week. -The Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis reported that the monetary base, the seasonally adjusted total of member bank reserves held at Federal Reserve banks and cash in bank vaults and in circulation, was $317.8 billion in the two-week period ended Oct. 31, down from $318.8 billion two weeks earlier.

DOC.HEAD: States Seek Guidelines for Environmental Marketing Claims
DOC.TEXT: Consumers can be misled by some ``green'' marketing, according to 10 state attorneys general who called Thursday for national guidelines for environmental marketing claims. ``Consumers who want to purchase products that are good for the environment should not become innocent victims of `green-collar' fraud,'' New York Attorney General Robert Abrams said. ``Manufacturers should not be allowed to cash in on the public's concern for the environment by making false and unsubstantiated claims.'' Uniform definitions for such words as ``recycled,'' ``compostable'' and ``degradable'' would give businesses parameters and make sure consumers get what they pay for, according to the attorneys general task force set up last November to review environmental advertising. In a report released Thursday, the group urged the Federal Trade Commission and the Environmental Protection Agency to work with states, businesses and consumer groups to set the standards. The report also recommended ``testing procedures and standards for determining whether a product meets a particular definition.'' The task force said environmental claims should be as specific as possible and avoid overly broad or vague terms like ``environmentally friendly'' or ``safe for the environment.'' ``Generalized environmental claims may create an unwrranted impression that a product is good for the environment in all respects,'' the report said. And because the word ``recycled'' does not provide consumers with enough information to compare products meaningfully, the attorneys general suggested the percentage of recycled material used in the product be listed. The 40-page report also said claims that a product is degradable or recyclable should not be made unless that particular disposal option is available in the area where the product is sold. Some businesses were particularly upset with that suggestion, saying it would not be feasible for national marketers. Pressure from consumer groups and state agencies has recently resulted in advertising changes for several products. First Brands and Mobil Chemical Corp. agreed in June to drop a claim that its Glad and Hefty trash bags were degradable after the Texas attorney general filed a lawsuit. Last month, American Enviro Products Inc., of Placentia, Calif., agreed to stop promoting its Bunnies disposal diapers as biodegradable after attorney generals in 10 states threatened to sue. The attorneys general urged other companies ``to modify their environmental marketing claims in light of the above recommendations.'' Those involved in the task force include the attorney generals from California, Florida, Massachusetts, Minnesota, Missouri, New York, Texas, Utah, Washington and Wisconsin. State and federal officials will hold public hearings on the recommendations in San Diego Dec. 10 and 11.

DOC.HEAD: FCC OKs Pacific Digital Fiber-Optic Cables
DOC.TEXT: Three fiber-optic, undersea telephone cables linking the U.S. mainland, Hawaii, New Zealand and Guam got the go-ahead Thursday from the Federal Communications Commission. The cables will carry as many as 80,000 digital conversations simultaneously on laser pulses through hair-thin glass wire. They are needed because of the expected large increase in phone, fax and computer traffic between Pacific Ocean rim countries, the commission said. American Telephone & Telegraph Co., one of the seven applicants for the systems, says its Pacific rim business is growing at an annual rate of about 12 percent to 14 percent - faster than its transAtlantic traffic. The FCC said 65 percent of the traffic between the United States and Australia now is being carried by satellites, and that more capacity was needed. The FCC gave 5-0 approval for the projects to a consortium of AT&T, GTE Hawaiian Telephone Co., MCI International Inc., Overseas Telecommunications Inc., TRT-FTC Communications Corp., US Sprint Communications Co. and World Communications Inc. The cables will be jointly owned by the seven telecommunications companies and telecommunications administrations from 14 foreign locations, the FCC said. The HAW-5 cable will connect San Luis Obispo, Calif., with Keawaula, Hawaii, at a cost of $199 million. The seven applicants will contribute an estimated $156.5 million to the project, which should be ready for service by early 1993, the FCC said. It will have twice the capacity of the existing undersea cable. The PacRimEast cable will connect Takapuna, New Zealand, and Keawaula, Hawaii. It will cost $279.6 million, with the seven applicants' cost estimated to be $67.9 million. The PacRimWest cable will connect Sydney, Australia, and Dededo, Guam. It will cost about $282 million, with the applicants picking up $51.7 million of the tab. It is scheduled to begin service in the fourth quarter of 1994. The first fiber-optic undersea cable went into operation in the Atlantic in 1988. A Pacific fiber-optic cable followed in 1989. AT&T announced plans on Oct. 17 to build a super-high capacity fiber-optic line between the United States and Japan by 1996. It will team with Japan's Kokusai Denshin Denwa in the project, which will be able to handle 600,000 simultaneous conversations. FCC approval of that project is pending.

DOC.HEAD: Wal-Mart Earnings Up 22 Percent in Third Quarter
DOC.TEXT: Wal-Mart Stores Inc. said Thursday its third-quarter earnings rose 22 percent as the retailer continued to thrive despite a slowdown in consumer spending. Wal-Mart said it earned $282.8 million, or 25 cents per share, in the quarter ended Oct. 31, up from $232.7 million, or 20 cents per share, in the same period a year earlier. Sales at the Bentonville, Ark.-based company rose 26 percent to $7.93 billion from $6.28 billion. Other retailers saw their sales slump during the quarter as consumer confidence was shaken by the weakening economy and the Persian Gulf crisis. Wal-Mart, which has outperformed the retail industry for years, continued to do so in spite of the poor environment. David Glass, Wal-Mart's president, said the company met its goals for the quarter and for the first nine months of its fiscal year. Wal-Mart earned $809.2 million, or 71 cents per share, for the nine months ended Oct. 31, up from $650 million, or 57 cents per share, a year earlier. Nine-month sales totaled $22.24 billion, up from $17.7 billion. The company has 1,503 Wal-Mart discount stores, 141 Sam's wholesale clubs and four Hypermart USA stores in 34 states.

DOC.HEAD: Navistar Elects President
DOC.TEXT: Navistar International Corp. on Thursday said John R. Horne will become president and chief operating officer of the truck manufacturer. The company also named Robert C. Lannert, 50, executive vice president and chief financial officer. Horne, 52, had been group vice president and general manager of engine and foundry operations. He will replace Neil A. Springer, who retired on Oct. 31. Lannert had been vice president and treasurer. Together with James C. Cotting, chairman and chief executive officer, Horne and Lannert will become members of a newly formed office of the chief executive. Navistar makes medium and heavy trucks and mid-range diesel engines.

DOC.HEAD: ENTel Finally Sold; Next Up: Aerolineas
DOC.TEXT: The government on Thursday returned to private ownership the telephone company it nationalized 42 years ago. European and U.S. investors agreed to pay about $1.34 billion for 60 percent of the Empresa Nacional de Telecomunicaciones, or ENTel. The privatization is one of the largest in Latin American history. The contracts were signed Thursday night by President Carlos Menem, who wants to privatize public companies to reduce the role of the state in Argentina's economy. Another privatization, the sale of Aerolineas Argentinas, may be completed within a month. The Spanish carrier Iberia has offered to buy it. A group of investors led by Spain's phone company Telefonica and U.S.-based Citibank won the bid for ENTel's southern operations. The consortium agreed to pay $114 million in cash and $202 million in notes, and to retire $2.7 billion in Argentina's foreign debt, in return for a seven-year lease. Italian and French phone companies, along with U.S.-based J.P. Morgan bank, were awarded ENTel's northern operations. That group agreed to pay $100 million in cash and $178 million in notes, and to retire $2.3 billion in Argentina's foreign debt. With the sale, the government rids itself of a company that lost about $250 million last year. The government has no money to upgrade ENTel's infrastructure and services that are ``in collapse,'' said director Maria Julia Alsogaray. Investors hope that by increasing the number of lines by one-third within six years, and lowering costs by trimming staff and modernizing equipment, the two regional companies will be profitable. Consumers view the sale with hope and dread. Service seems bound to improve, but rates may be unaffordably high. The current rate of about 5 U.S. cents per pulse is one of the highest in the world, analysts say. A pulse is a unit of time that varies according to the distance of the call and the time of day it is made. However, for many Argentines, the sale of ENTel may be the only way to get phone service at any price. As many as one of every seven lines may be out of service at any moment, and repairs can take months. Some Argentines wait years for a line, or pay several thousand dollars for one.

DOC.HEAD: Anti-Acne Medication, Antacids Pace SmithKline Beecham Profits
DOC.TEXT: The British pharmaceutical maker SmithKline Beecham on Thursday reported its pre-tax earnings rose 30 percent in the third quarter, paced largely by U.S. sales of its anti-acne and antacid products. SmithKline reported pre-tax earnings of 218 million pounds, compared with earnings of 168 million pounds in the same period a year earlier. The earnings were worth $408 million when the quarter ended on Sept. 30, but the percentage increase in dollars would likely have varied because of fluctuating exchange rates. Sales from continuing operations were 1.08 billion pounds, a 3 percent decrease from 1.11 billion pounds in the 1989 period. The company attributed the decrease to exchange rate fluctuations, especially the weakening U.S. dollar. The main rise in profits came in the consumer brands sector, which reported a 53 percent increase from the same period of 1989. Sales of over-the-counter drugs were led in the United States by its Oxy anti-acne products, which increased 15 percent, and Tums antacid, which increased 30 percent. For the first nine months, the company had pre-tax profits of 634 million pounds, 8 percent higher than the 588 million pounds earned a for the period a year earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Hit New Record
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS interest rate figures on Super NOW accounts in 8th graf
DOC.TEXT: Assets of the nation's 525 money market mutual funds rose $2.94 billion in the latest week to a new record of $418.33 billion, the Investment Company Institute said Thursday. The rise in the seven-day period ended Wednesday followed a $140.4 million decline in fund assets the previous week, and broke the record high of $415.53 billion set the week ended Oct. 24. The Washington-based mutual fund trade group said that in the latest week, assets of 259 general purpose funds rose by $1.06 billion to $148.79 billion; assets of 104 broker-dealer funds rose $608.5 million to $165.33 billion; and assets of 162 institutional funds rose $1.27 billion to $104.22 billion. The seven-day average yield on money market mutual funds fell in the week ended Tuesday to 7.38 percent from 7.42 percent the previous week, said Donoghue's Money Fund Report, a trade journal based in Holliston, Mass. The 30-day average yield fell to 7.42 percent from 7.45 percent, Donoghue's said. The average maturity of the portfolios held by money funds was 49 days, up from 47 days, Donoghue's said. The newsletter Bank Rate Monitor said its survey of 100 leading commercial banks, savings and loan associations and savings banks in the nation's 10 largest markets showed the effective annual yield available on money market accounts remained at 6.02 percent as of Wednesday, unchanged from a week earlier. The North Palm Beach, Fla.-based newsletter said the effective annual yield available on special savings accounts, called Super NOW accounts, rose to 5.08 percent from 5.06 percent. Bank Rate Monitor said the effective annual yield was 7.60 percent on six-month certificates of deposit, down from 7.63 percent the previous week. Yields were 7.73 percent on 1-year CDs, down from 7.76 percent; 7.84 percent on 2{-year CDs, down from 7.88 percent; and 8.05 percent on 5-year CDs, up from 8.03 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Standard & Poor's Sues Chicago Options Exchange
DOC.TEXT: Standard & Poor's Corp. filed a lawsuit charging the Chicago Board Options Exchange with violating a 1983 licensing agreement for use of two widely known measures of stock market activity. The lawsuit, filed Wednesday in Manhattan federal court, claims the CBOE wrongly asserted an exclusive right to use the S&P 100 Index and S&P 500 Index on financial products other than options contracts traded on the exchange. The CBOE on Thursday denied it had breached the agreement. In a statement, CBOE general counsel Nancy R. Crossman said the exchange believes the licensing agreement gives it the exclusive right to use the indexes ``in connection with the trading of securities options.'' ``The CBOE has always met all of its obligations under the license agreement and has never breached the agreement since its inception,'' the statement said. The S&P 100 Index and S&P 500 Index measure stock performance and are traded in units on the nation's major options exchanges. Options give an investor the right to buy or sell a security at a specified time for a specific price. S&P said its license limits the CBOE to options contracts on the two indexes that are traded on a securities exchange and settled through an established clearing house by payment of cash or the underlying security. S&P said the CBOE's rights do not apply to other financial instruments that offer a return based in whole or part on the two indexes. Those include notes, certificates of deposit and other debt instruments, products that trade over the counter and financial instruments issued by institutions other than an exchange. The lawsuit asked the court to terminate the license with the CBOE on Dec. 7, or to rule that the agreement does not extend to financial instruments other than exchange-traded stock options as defined in the agreement. S&P, a subsidiary of McGraw-Hill Inc., said the withdrawal of a note offering for Denmark because of the dispute has caused the firm ``severe harm to its reputation and impairment of its licensing business.'' S&P, a financial information and credit rating agency, for several years has licensed the rights to use its indexes in connection with financial products sold off of exchanges.

DOC.HEAD: Lower Earnings Blamed on Economic Slowdown
DOC.TEXT: Hoechst Celanese Corp. on Thursday blamed a 26 percent drop in third-quarter earnings on a continued slowdown in the economy. The company reported $49 million in earnings on $1.4 billion net sales for the quarter ended Sept. 30. That compares to earnings of $66 million on revenues of $1.5 billion for the same period last year. ``We experienced lower earnings this quarter because of the continued slowdown in the economy, which has affected many of the markets we serve,'' said Ernest H. Drew, president and chief executive officer of the company based in Somerville. Hoechst Celanese is a wholly owned subsidiary of Hoechst AG of Germany. It deals in chemicals, fibers, advanced materials and technologies, and life sciences. Sales declined in three of the company's four major divisions this quarter: chemicals, life sciences and fibers and film. A strong demand for super-absorbent materials used in diapers boosted sales of specialty chemicals by $24 million to $351 million, for a 7.3 percent gain over the same quarter last year. But in the life sciences group, net sales fell $17 million to $126 million, or 12 percent, after strong sales in 1989 of Trental, a drug used to treat geriatric disease. Sales of the blood medication were especially strong in the third quarter of 1989 because the company announced a fourth-quarter price increase last year. Sales in fibers declined from $643 million to $605 million, while sales in chemicals fell from $433 million to $395 million. In the first nine months, the company earned $159 million on revenues of $4.2 billion, compared to earnings of $214 million on $4.5 billion in sales for the same period last year.

DOC.HEAD: Weaker U.S. Economy Slows Disney Earnings Growth
DOC.TEXT: The weakening economy slowed profit growth at Walt Disney Co. to 9 percent in the quarter that ended Sept. 30, the entertainment giant said Thursday. In a joint statement, Chief Executive Michael Eisner and President Frank Wells said theme park attendance had dropped off during the crucial summer months. Despite higher per capita spending, operating income from the parks rose just 1 percent for the fourth fiscal quarter, Disney said. Company earnings increased 17 percent in the full year. Eisner and Wells have set a goal of 20 percent growth in profits over any five-year period. The company posted earnings increases of 17.6, 20 and 23 percent in the first three quarters of the fiscal year. Recession fears and other concerns have caused investors to knock Disney's stock price down from a high of $136.50 per share in the past year to the $90 range in recent weeks. During the fourth fiscal quarter, Disney earned $232.7 million, or $1.72 per share, compared to $212.7 million, or $1.54 per share, during the same period in 1989. Revenue rose 27 percent, to $1.71 billion from $1.35 billion. The per-share figure was toward the lower end of analysts' estimates. For the fiscal year, Disney earnings rose to $824 million, or $6 per share, on revenue of $5.8 billion. Last year, earnings were $703 million, or $5.10 per share, on revenue of $4.6 billion a year earlier. During the fourth quarter, operating income in Disney's filmed entertainment segment rose 22 percent, led by home video sales of ``Peter Pan'' and the syndication of the ``Golden Girls'' television series. Operating income from the consumer products segment increased 8 percent for the quarter. Disney doesn't break out attendance figures for its theme parks. But the company characterized them as strong for the full year despite the disappointing fourth quarter. Higher per capita spending at all theme parks and benefit from Disney's 49 percent stake in Euro Disneyland SCA helped operating profits for the quarter and year, the company said.

DOC.HEAD: Media Baron Decries New York Violence and Newspaper Unions
DOC.TEXT: Rupert Murdoch said Thursday he was horrified by the rising violence in New York, which the media baron blamed partly on what he called the shortcomings of the city's union-controlled newspapers. Murdoch, chief executive of the worldwide media empire News Corp., also called the city's newspaper unions, currently on strike against the Daily News, the world's worst since the demise of the British newspaper unions which his company broke in a bitter labor struggle in the mid 1980s. ``The truth is, ladies and gentlemen, that the crime problem in New York is quite simply horrible. In fact, it seems to be unprecedented in American history,'' Murdoch said in a speech at New York University. ``It's certainly worse than the Wild West.'' In that lawless era, he said, gunfighters generally shot each other, crimes like murder ``almost never affected innocent people, and crimes like robbery and rape were far more infrequent than today.'' He said the city's press was to some extent responsible because ``the media's inibitions about reporting the crime wave resulted in a sort of false consciousness among the public.'' Murdoch, one of the world's wealthiest men, maintains several homes, including a penthouse overlooking Manhattan's Central Park. His company owns several newspapers, magazines and television operations around the world, mainly in the United States, Britain and Australia. In addition, News Corp. is parent of the Fox Broadcasting Co., a national programming service for independent TV stations, and has extensive interests in book publishing activities. Murdoch owned the New York Post from 1976 to 1988. His company still owns WNYW, a local New York Fox TV channel. When Murdoch ran the Post he was regularly denounced for what critics called overly sensational coverage of brutal crimes that appealed to the public's ``base passion.'' ``I don't agree that I took it too far downmarket,'' Murdoch told his audience Thursday. ``I think I didn't take it downmarket far enough.'' Regarding the city's powerful newspaper unions, which have been striking the Post's rival tabloid the News since last month, Murdoch called them one of the obstacles to better newspaper operations and journalism in the city. ``As you will know, in 1986 I took on the printing unions in Britain, the world's worst, and broke them,'' he said. ``The result has been a silver age for British journalism: newly prosperous papers and wholly new papers.'' With the demise of those unions, he said, ``the New York City unions have succeeded to the distinction of being the world's worst.'' Murdoch was the guest speaker at the ninth Chet Huntley Memorial Lecture, named after the late television journalist.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Higher, Stock Fall
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with morning Nikkei, comments
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rose against the yen Friday morning following President Bush's announcement that he is sending more troops to the Middle East. Stock prices fell, continuing a slide that began Tuesday. The dollar was changing hands at 130.38 yen at late morning. It opened at 130.45 yen, up 0.95 yen from Thursday's close, and ranged between 130.30 yen and 131 yen during early trading. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average lost 346.23 points, or 1.51 percent, ending the morning session at 22,623.58. The index lost 530.44 points Thursday. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bond fell to 83.94 points from Thursday's 84.26-point finish. Its yield was higher at 7.950 percent from 7.875 percent. Stock traders said the Nikkei fell quickly with the majority of investors avoiding buying shares because of increasing tensions in the Middle East. The declining yen and the government bond prices, resulting from investors' fears about the Gulf, also accelerated the Nikkei's plunge, a trader with Nomura Securities Co. said on condition of anonymity. ``Nobody was interested in buying. ... Japanese institutional investors, as well as foreign investors are all sitting on the sidelines,'' he said. The Nomura trader said political uncertainties resulting from the government's lack of leadership in deciding Japan's role in the Gulf made investors reluctant to trade. Amid worries over the increasing tensions in the Middle East, Japanese currency investors bought the dollar up to the 131-yen level on short covering before the start of a three-day weekend in Tokyo, dealers said. Japanese financial markets will be closed on Monday for a national holiday commemorating the Emperor Akihito's enthronement. War in the Middle East would likely drive the price of oil sharply higher. The dollar normally rises with oil prices because crude is bought and sold in dollars. Also, the currency traditionally has been viewed as a safe haven in times of international turmoil. ``As long as the Middle East crisis continues, the dollar's plunge will be prevented,'' said Katsumi Oshima, a researcher at Sanyo Securities Co. But Oshima said the dollar's recent upswing is the result of adjustments by investors who had overbought the yen. Overall market conditions still favor a stronger yen because ``the U.S. economy is definitely headed toward a recession,'' he said.
